Charter reference- Elections, § 5-1 et seq. 

Sec. 6-1. - Registration of electors-Eligibility; challenge. 
(a)  Eligibility. Any person who is a resident of the city for a period of thirty (30) days prior to any municipal election, and who is registered as an elector with the board of registrars of the county in which such person resides shall be eligible to vote in any election of the city. 
(b)  Challenge of registration. Any elector of the municipality shall be allowed to challenge the right of registration of any person whose name appears upon the electors list or who is applying for registration with the registrar. The elector making the challenge shall appear before the registrar on or before election day, and state the grounds for the challenge in writing. The initial decision shall be made forthwith by the registrar with a right of appeal to the governing body of the city. If possible, the registrar will notify the challenged elector and provide him with an opportunity to answer the challenge. If the registrar does not find probable cause for sustaining the challenge, the challenged elector will be given the right to vote or the right to be registered to vote. If in doubt as to the merit of a challenge, the registrar shall notify the chief manager in the challenged elector's election district and the challenged elector shall be allowed to cast a challenged ballot. 
(Code 1963, § 5A-4) 
Charter reference- Authority to regulate, § 5-12. 
State Law reference- Elector qualifications, O.C.G.A. § 21-2-216. 
Sec. 6-2. - Same-Registration board. 
(a)  Appointment; powers, duties; compensation. The governing body of the city shall appoint three (3) members of a board to be known as a registration board. The members shall receive such compensation as provided by the governing body and shall exercise those powers and duties and shall be subject to such regulations as set forth in the Georgia Municipal Election Code and any regulations established by the governing authority. 
(b)  Terms; resignations and removal. The members shall serve for a term of one year and until their successors are appointed and qualified, except in the event of resignation or removal as hereinafter provided. The governing body shall have the right to remove one or more of such members, at any time for cause after notice and hearing. Any member shall have the right to resign at any time by submitting a resignation to the governing body. In the event of any such removal or resignation of a member, such member's duties and authority as such shall terminate instantly. In case of the removal, death or resignation of a member, the governing body shall appoint a successor who shall serve the unexpired term if such term is specified. Each such appointment or change in designation shall be entered on the minutes of the governing body. 
(Code 1963, § 5A-5) 
Sec. 6-3. - Election districts; polling places. 
(a)  The ward lines of the City of College Park are hereby reconstituted, reset, and redrawn so that, as redrawn, they are and shall be as shown on Exhibit "A" attached and made a part hereof. The original Exhibit "A" shall be maintained in the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  The following shall be the official polling places for city election purposes within each ward: 
(1)  Ward 1: All registered voters shall vote at College Park Auditorium, located at 3631 Main Street, College Park, Georgia 30337-2614. 
(2)  Ward 2: 
a.  All registered voters in that part of Ward 2 which is South of Riverdale Road, shall vote at Camp Truitt Senior Center, located at 4320 Herschel Road, College Park, Georgia 30337-4902. 
b.  All registered voters in that part of Ward 2 which is North of Camp Creek Parkway, shall vote at College Park Auditorium, located at 3631 Main Street, College Park, Georgia 30337-2614. 
c.  All registered voters in that part of Ward 2 which is South of Camp Creek Parkway and North of Riverdale Road, shall vote at Camp Truitt Senior Center, located at 4320 Herschel Road, College Park, Georgia 30337-4902. 
(3)  Ward 3: 
a.  All registered voters in that part of Ward 3 which is South of Interstate-285, shall vote at Godby Road Community Building, located at 2300 Godby Road, College Park, Georgia 30349-5041. 
b.  All registered voters in that part of Ward 3 which lies in Clayton County, shall vote at Godby Road Community Building, located at 2300 Godby Road, College Park, Georgia 30349-5041. 
c.  All registered voters in that part of Ward 3 which is North of Interstate-285, shall vote at College Park Auditorium, located at 3631 Main Street, College Park, Georgia 30337-2614. 
(4)  Ward 4: 
a.  All registered voters in that part of Ward 4 which is South of Interstate-285 and West of Old National Highway, shall vote at Godby Road Community Building, located at 2300 Godby Road, College Park, Georgia 30349-5041. 
b.  All registered voters in that part of Ward 4 which is North of Interstate-285, shall vote at Camp Truitt Senior Center, located at 4320 Herschel Road, College Park, Georgia 30337-4902. 
(c)  For city elections, the city shall use direct recording electronic or "DRE" voting equipment for recording and computing votes, beginning with the 2005 elections and all future elections until otherwise authorized by the city. 
(d)  During the period of advance voting provided for by state law, any registered voter may cast a ballot in a city election at the College Park Historical Society Building, 3675 Auditorium Way, College Park, GA 30337. The time and manner of such advanced voting shall be consistent with the provisions of state law regulating the casting of advanced votes in municipal elections. 
(Code 1963, § 5A-3; Ord. No. 84-12, 5-7-84; Ord. No. 85-6, 5-6-85; Ord. No. 86-26A, 8-27-86; Ord. No. 2001-15, § 1, 4-16-01; Ord. No. 03-30, § 1, 7-7-03; Ord. No. 05-13, § 1, 6-6-05; Ord. No. 05-29, § 1, 8-1-05; Ord. No. 2011-08, §§ 1, 2, 7-18-11; Ord. No. 2011-09, § 1, 8-17-11; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 1, 1-5-15; Ord. No. 2015-21, § 1(Exh. A), 11-16-15) 
Charter reference- Original ward descriptions, § 5-4. 
State Law reference- Election districts and polling places, O.C.G.A. § 21-2-265. 
Sec. 6-4. - Nonpartisan elections. 
    All elections held for the purpose of filling municipal offices in the city shall be nonpartisan, and no political party shall conduct primaries for the purpose of nominating candidates for such municipal elections. 
(Code 1963, § 5A-7) 
Sec. 6-5. - Candidate qualification fees. 
(a)  The city clerk for the City of College Park, not later than February 1 of each year in which a general municipal election is held in the City, and at least twenty (20) days prior to a special election, in the case of a special election, shall cause to be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, the amount of each qualifying fee for each municipal office to be filled in the upcoming general or special election, as the case may be. 
(b)  Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, the fee for each such office shall be three (3) per cent of the annual salary of such office if such office is a salaried office. 
(c)  Any candidate who subscribes and swears to an oath that he or she has no assets nor income to pay the qualifying fee may file a pauper's affidavit in lieu of payment of such qualifying fee. Such pauper's affidavit shall, under oath, affirm the candidate's poverty and his or her resulting inability to pay the qualifying fee otherwise required. The form of the affidavit shall be such as is prescribed by the Secretary of State for the State of Georgia and shall include a financial statement which lists the total income, assets, liabilities, and other relevant financial information of the candidate, as required, and shall indicate on its face that the candidate has neither the assets nor the income to pay the qualifying fee otherwise required. The following warnings shall be printed on the affidavit form prepared by the Secretary of State: "WARNING: Any person knowingly making any false statement on this Affidavit commits the offense of false swearing and shall be guilty of a felony." 
(Code 1963, § 5A-6; Ord. No. 99-03, § 1, 2-1-99) 
Charter reference- Qualification of candidates, § 5-5. 
State Law reference- Qualification fee, O.C.G.A. § 21-2-131. 
Sec. 6-6. - Election officials. 
    The following offices are created in connection with the conduct of elections for the city: 
(a)  Superintendent. The governing body shall appoint a municipal election superintendent who shall receive such compensation as provided by the governing body of the city. The superintendent shall exercise those powers and duties as set forth in the Georgia Municipal Election Code. 
(b)  Poll officers. 
(1)  Chief manager. A chief manager for each election district shall be appointed by the governing body for each election. The chief manager shall receive such compensation as provided by the governing body and shall exercise those powers and duties as set forth in the Georgia Municipal Election Code. 
(2)  Assistant managers. Two (2) assistant managers for each election district shall be appointed by the governing body of the city for each election. The assistant managers shall receive such compensation as provided by the governing body and shall exercise those powers and duties as set forth in the Georgia Municipal Election Code. 
(3)  Clerks. Prior to the opening of the polls in each district of each election the governing body shall appoint a sufficient number of clerks to serve at such election. The clerks shall receive such compensation as provided by the governing body and shall exercise those powers and duties as set forth in the Georgia Municipal Election Code. 
(Code 1963, § 5A-1) 
Charter reference- Managers, § 5-10. 
State Law reference- Election officials, O.C.G.A. § 21-2-70 et seq. 
Sec. 6-7. - Expenses. 
    The election superintendent is authorized to incur expenses in the preparation and conduct of an election, including the cost of purchasing identification badges for poll officers, the printing of ballots and voters certificates, and the purchasing of all other supplies necessary for the conduct of an election. The superintendent is further authorized to incur all necessary expenses to provide voting booths for the proper conduct of all elections. 
(Code 1963, § 5A-2) 
Sec. 6-8. - Lighting, heating of polling places. 
    The superintendent shall cause all polling places to be provided with sufficient light and heat. 
(Code 1963, § 5A-3.1) 
Sec. 6-9. - Vote required for election. 
    A candidate for municipal office may be elected in a general or special election by receiving a majority of the votes cast to fill such nomination or public office. Run-off elections shall be governed by the Georgia Municipal Election Code. 
(Code 1963, § 5A-9) 
Sec. 6-10. - Contested elections. 
(a)  Where determined. A contest case governed by the provisions of this section shall be determined in the county in which the city hall is located. 
(b)  Grounds for contest. Any person who was a candidate in an election or any aggrieved elector shall be permitted to contest the election of any candidate upon any of the following grounds: 
(1)  Malconduct, fraud or irregularity by any election official sufficient to change or place in doubt the result. 
(2)  Ineligibility of the candidate for the office in dispute. 
(3)  Illegal votes received, or legal votes rejected, sufficient to change or place in doubt the result. 
(4)  An error in counting the votes or in declaring the result of an election, if such error would change the result. 
(5)  Any other cause which shows that another was the person legally elected. 
(c)  Petition to contest; notice; hearing. A petition to contest the results of a general or special election shall be filed with the city clerk within five (5) days after the results of an election are certified to the governing body. A hearing shall then be set before the governing body. Written notice shall be given to all affected candidates by the governing body. The notice shall state the time and place of the hearing and shall contain a copy of the petition of contest. The hearing will take place not less than seven (7) days, nor more than fourteen (14) days, after service of the notice upon the affected candidates. 
(d)  Determination of validity. The governing body shall have the authority to examine the qualifications of electors concerning their right to vote, order a recount of ballots, examine the registration lists and perform such acts and conduct such examinations as may be deemed necessary to determine the validity of a contest of an election. 
(e)  Appeal from determination. The final determination of the governing body may be appealed to the superior court in the manner of appeal from a court of probate, except that such appeal shall be made within ten (10) days after determination of the contest by the governing body by issuance of an order so signifying. 
(Code 1963, § 5A-10) 
State Law reference- Contested election, O.C.G.A. § 21-2-522 et seq. 
Sec. 6-11. - Effect of qualifying of elective office on employment or appointment to city boards. 
(a)  The employment status of any city employee shall be declared voluntarily resigned upon such employee qualifying in any election for municipal elective office within the city. Any such person who is contracted with the city for employment shall be deemed to have submitted the applicable notice of termination to the city. 
(b)  The office of any appointed official, board member, commission member or authority member shall be declared vacant upon such individual qualifying, in any election for municipal elective office within the city. 
(Ord. No. 2012-11, § 1, 5-15-12) 
Sec. 6-12. - Ward residency for councilmembers. 
(a)  No person shall be eligible to serve as a councilmember representing a ward of the city unless that person has been a resident of such ward for a continuous period of at least twelve (12) months immediately prior to the date of his or her qualification as a candidate for councilmember, and if elected, he or she shall continue to reside therein throughout his or her period of service. 
(b)  For any regular elections occurring in 2017, no person shall be eligible to serve as a councilmember representing a ward of the city unless that person has been a resident of such ward for a continuous period of at least five (5) months immediately prior to the date of his or her qualification as a candidate for councilmember, and if elected, he or she shall continue to reside therein throughout his or her period of service. 
(Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 3-20-17) 
Chapter 7 - FIRE PROTECTION AND PREVENTION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Fire limits, § 5-2; furnace insulation required, § 5-23; removal of underground inflammable liquids tanks, § 5-24; false alarms, § 12-24; smoking in city auditorium, § 13-10. 

Sec. 7-1. - Fire inspectors. 
    The chief of the fire department is permitted to detail such members of the fire department as inspectors as shall from time to time be necessary. The chief of the fire department shall recommend to the city manager and governing body the employment of technical inspectors, who, when such authorization is made, shall be selected through an examination to determine their fitness for the position. The examination shall be open to members and nonmembers of the fire department, and appointments made after examination shall be for an indefinite term, with removal only for cause. 
(Code 1963, § 7-2(c)) 
Sec. 7-2. - Reports of fire department activities; recommendations. 
    A report of the activities of the fire department shall be made annually and transmitted to the city manager; it shall contain all proceedings under the fire prevention code, with such statistics as the chief of the fire department decides to include therein or as requested by the city manager; the chief of the fire department shall also recommend any amendments to the fire prevention code which, in the chief's judgment, shall be desirable. 
(Code 1963, § 7-2(d)) 
Sec. 7-3. - Cooperation by other city officials. 
    The chief of the fire department may request and shall receive so far as may be necessary, in the discharge of such chief's duties, the assistance and cooperation of other officials of the municipality. 
(Code 1963, § 7-2(e)) 
Sec. 7-4. - Plan review and certificate of occupancy fees. 
    In addition to other fees and licenses as may be required, a plan review fee for each review by the fire department of proposed construction plans shall be assessed in the amount of ten cents ($0.10) for each one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or fraction thereof, of construction cost with a minimum fee of twenty dollars ($20.00). A fire safety certificate of occupancy, issued by the fire department upon satisfactory completion of construction, shall require a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Code 1963, § 7-1(c)) 
Sec. 7-5. - Permits and licenses. 
(a)  Permits covered by Chapter 4 of the fire prevention code, and required in various sections of this chapter or in other city fire prevention ordinances are for the purpose of giving the fire department more effective control over hazardous conditions regulated by the code and related ordinances. Where fees are charged for such permits, the money for fees shall be handled by the city clerk or the clerk's designated agents. 
(b)  Where licenses are required by the city, in addition to the permits required by the fire prevention code, and the licenses are renewable each year, permits shall remain in effect during the time that the business license is valid. In cases where business licenses may not be required, the permit shall remain in effect for one year after issuance. The chief of the fire department shall have authority to revoke any permit where the applicant fails to meet code requirements. 
(Code 1963, § 7-1(d), (e)) 
Sec. 7-6. - Appeals. 
    Whenever the fire chief shall disapprove an application or refuse to grant a permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the provisions of the fire prevention code or other provisions of this chapter do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of the code has been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant is permitted to appeal from the decision of the chief to the governing body within thirty (30) days from the date of the decision appealed. 
(Code 1963, § 7-14) 
Sec. 7-7. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the fire prevention code hereby adopted, or other provisions of this chapter, or fail to comply therewith, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any order made thereunder, or who shall build in violation of any detailed statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any certificate or permit issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been taken, or who shall fail to comply with such an order as affirmed or modified by the governing body, or by a court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed herein, shall severally for each such violation and noncompliance respectively, be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable as provided in section 1-8. The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue; and all such persons shall be required to correct or remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable time; and, when not otherwise specified, each day that prohibited conditions are maintained shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  The application of the above penalty shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. 
(Code 1963, § 7-16) 
Sec. 7-8. - International Fire Code adopted. 
    There is hereby adopted by the city for the purpose of establishing rules and regulations for the alteration and repair of existing buildings and other similar work in the city, the Standard Fire Prevention Code (International Fire Code) referenced in O.C.G.A. Section 8-2-20(9)(B), as adopted and amended from time to time by the Department of Community Affairs, and the same is incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein. A current copy of said code shall be maintained on file in the office of the city fire marshall, where it shall be available for public inspection. 
(Code 1963, § 7-1(a); Ord. No. 05-06, § 1, 5-2-05) 
Sec. 7-9. - Same-Revisions. 
(a)  The following revisions are hereby made to the Standard Fire Prevention Code (International Fire Code): 
    Section 101.1: Replace the phrase "[NAME OF JURISDICTION]" with the phrase "the City of College Park, Georgia." 
    Section 109.3: Replace the phrase "[SPECIFY OFFENSE]" with the phrase "violation of the City Code." Replace the phrase "[AMOUNT]" with the phrase "five hundred dollars ($500)." Replace the phrase "[NUMBER OF DAYS]" with the phrase "ninety (90) days." 
    Section 111.4: Replace the first instance of the phrase "[AMOUNT]" with the phrase "one hundred dollars ($100)." Replace the second instance of the phrase "[AMOUNT]" with the phrase "five hundred dollars ($500)." 
(b)  The geographic limits referred to in the below sections of the Standard Fire Prevention Code (International Fire Code) shall be as follows: 
    Section 3204.3.1.1 (geographic limits in which the storage of flammable cryogenic fluids in stationary containers is prohibited): All zoning districts other than M-1, M-2 and W-1, except as may be approved by the City Fire Code Official as otherwise conforming to the requirements of this Code. 
    Section 3404.2.9.5.1 (geographic limits in which the storage of Class I and Class II liquids in above-ground tanks outside of buildings is prohibited): All zoning districts other than M-1, M-2 and W-1, except as may be approved by the City Fire Code Official as otherwise conforming to the requirements of this Code. 
    Section 3406.2.4.4 (geographic limits in which the storage of Class I and Class II liquids in above-ground tanks is prohibited): All zoning districts other than M-1, M-2 and W-1, except as may be approved by the City Fire Code Official as otherwise conforming to the requirements of this Code. 
    Section 3406.2.4.4 (geographic limits in which the storage of liquefied petroleum gas is restricted for the protection of heavily populated or congested areas): All zoning districts other than M-1, M-2 and W-1, except as may be approved by the City Fire Code Official as otherwise conforming to the requirements of this Code. 
(Code 1963, § 7-12; Ord. No. 05-06, § 2, 5-2-05) 
Sec. 7-10. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 05-06, § 3, adopted May 2, 2005, repealed former § 7-10 in its entirety which pertained to the power of the chief of the fire department to allow modifications of fire prevention code in certain situations. 
Sec. 7-11. - Same-New materials, processes or occupancies which require permits. 
(a)  The city manager and the chief of the fire department shall act as a committee to determine and specify, after giving affected persons an opportunity to be heard, any new materials, processes or occupancies, which shall require permits, in addition to those enumerated in said code. 
(b)  The chief shall post such list in a conspicuous place in such chief's office, and distribute copies thereof to interested persons. 
(Code 1963, § 7-15) 
Sec. 7-12. - State standards adopted. 
    In addition to the Standard Fire Prevention Code, the city also hereby adopts the state minimum fire safety standards as issued by the safety fire commissioner. In addition to those buildings and structures regulated by the state minimum fire safety standards, such standards shall also apply to all existing and proposed buildings, including warehouses, manufacturing plants and all retail and department stores regardless of size; however, specifically excluding single-family unattached dwellings, duplexes, outbuildings ancillary to such dwellings, and garages. 
(Code 1963, § 7-1(b)) 
State Law reference- As to safety fire commissioner regulations, see O.C.G.A. § 25-2-4. 
Sec. 7-13. - Conflict of regulations. 
    In the event provisions of the state minimum fire safety standards, Standard Fire Prevention Code, or the building code, of the city conflict or differ in application, those provisions which are deemed, by the chief of the fire department, as the strictest shall take precedence and be enforced. 
(Code 1963, § 7-1(b)) 
Sec. 7-14. - Establishment of districts in which storage of explosives and blasting agents is prohibited. 
(a)  The limits referred to in the fire prevention code in which storage of explosives and blasting agents is prohibited, are hereby established as follows: May be allowed in M-1, M-2 and X-1 zoning districts only. The storage of explosives and blasting agents shall only be allowed by special permission with permit of fire department. 
(b)  The prohibited area shall include closely built commercial areas and heavily populated areas. 
(Code 1963, § 7-4) 
Sec. 7-15. - Establishment of districts in which manufacture and storage of fireworks is prohibited. 
    The limits referred to in the fire prevention code, in which manufacture and storage of fireworks is prohibited, are hereby established as follows: The manufacture and storage of fireworks shall not be allowed in the city. 
(Code 1963, § 7-5) 
Cross reference- Fireworks, § 7-22. 
Sec. 7-16. - Establishment of districts in which storage of flammable liquids in outside aboveground tanks and bulk plants are prohibited. 
(a)  The limits referred to in the fire prevention code in which storage of flammable liquids in outside aboveground tanks is prohibited, are hereby established as follows: All C-1 and C-2 zoning districts; these limits shall also include all congested areas, residential, mercantile, and other areas where the fire marshal determines that it would present an undue hazard. 
(b)  The limits referred to in the fire prevention code, in which new bulk plants for flammable or combustible liquids are prohibited, are hereby established as follows: All residential areas, apartment, commercial, congested, or other areas where the fire marshal determines the same would cause an undue hazard. 
(c)  These limits shall include such areas as those zoned solely for residential occupancies, and for mercantile establishments primarily retail in character. 
(Code 1963, § 7-6) 
Sec. 7-17. - Establishment of districts in which bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gases is restricted. 
(a)  The limits referred to in the fire prevention code, in which bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gas is restricted, are hereby established as follows: All zoning districts except M-1, M-2, W-1 and X-1. Such storage shall be allowed only after an inspection by the fire marshal determines that there will be a minimum threat to life and property. 
(b)  These limits shall include the heavily populated and the congested commercial areas where the fire marshal determines that the same would cause an undue hazard. 
(Code 1963, § 7-7) 
Sec. 7-18. - Establishment of motor vehicle routes for vehicles transporting explosives and blasting agents. 
    The routes to be used for vehicles transporting explosives and blasting agents are hereby established as follows: Camp Creek Parkway, Highway 29, Highway 139, U.S. Interstate 1-85, U.S. Interstate 1-285, Old National Highway, Washington Road, Virginia Avenue, Sullivan Road. Special permission shall be obtained from the fire department before transporting on other streets. 
(Code 1963, § 7-8) 
Sec. 7-19. - Establishment of motor vehicle routes for vehicles transporting hazardous chemicals or other dangerous articles. 
    The route to be used for vehicles transporting hazardous chemicals and other dangerous articles are hereby established as follows-Camp Creek Parkway, Highway 29, Highway 139, U.S. Interstate 1-85, U.S. Interstate 1-285, Old National Highway, Washington Road, Virginia Avenue, Sullivan Road. Special permission shall be obtained from the fire department before transporting on other streets. 
(Code 1963, § 7-9) 
Sec. 7-20. - Establishment of fire lanes on private property, devoted to public use. 
(a)  Fire lane access to buildings by fire apparatus referred to in the fire prevention code are hereby established as follows: All premises which the fire department may be called upon to protect in case of fire, and which are not readily accessible from public roads, shall be provided with suitable gates, access roads, and fire lanes so that all buildings on the premises are readily accessible to fire apparatus. All exposures within the city (except single-and two-family dwellings) shall have fire apparatus access to a public thoroughfare a minimum width of twenty (20) feet, as approved by the fire marshal on at least one side of the exposure. Access to alternate sides of the exposure shall be provided for fire apparatus in cases where more than two hundred (200) feet of hose lay, as measured from the access side of the exposure, would be required to reach the far side of the exposure. Hose lay may be increased to four hundred (400) feet, provided the exposure has a total sprinkler system. All access requirements shall be approved by the fire marshal. 
(b)  These lanes shall be established on private property, devoted to public use, where the parking of motor vehicles or other obstructions can interfere with the ingress and egress of fire department vehicles for the protection of persons and property, such as at shopping centers, bowling lanes, theaters, hospitals, churches, and similar locations. The width and route of such lanes shall be specifically determined by the city. 
(c)  The marking of fire lanes on private property devoted to public use, shall be approved by the chief of the fire department and the chief of the police department. When it is determined that fire lanes are needed, the designation of the area as a fire lane shall be prepared with a description of the area. Copies of the description and the designation shall be signed by the fire chief and the police chief and shall be filed in the city clerk's office. Marking of the fire lanes shall be done by installing a "no parking, fire lane" sign, and the owner of the location shall provide yellow markings on the street and curb to identify the fire lane area. Markings shall be as determined by the fire chief. The fire chief may waive the requirement for yellow markings on the curb, but not on the street, upon a showing to his or her professional satisfaction that yellow markings on the street alone will be so designed as to provide an equal level of protection of the safety of the public as yellow markings on both the curb and the street. 
(d)  Parking of motor vehicles obstructing fire lanes shall be prohibited. 
(e)  Any person who shall park in a designated fire lane, in violation of the markings at said location, shall, upon the entering of a plea of guilty, nolo contendere, or a finding of guilty, be fined one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Code 1963, § 7-10; Ord. No. 92-6, § 2, 3-16-92; Ord. No. 2002-18, § 1, 5-20-02) 
Sec. 7-21. - Fire hydrant and water main installation, spacing and maintenance. 
(a)  Water mains installed in shopping centers, malls and industrial areas, and in other areas not specified in this section, shall be a minimum of eight (8) inches in diameter, provided an adequate gridiron is completed. The fire marshal shall determine the adequacy of the gridiron and may require larger pipe sizes depending upon the size, construction, layout and occupancy of the buildings serviced. 
(b)  Water mains installed in multiple housing developments shall be a minimum of six (6) inches in diameter, but only where an adequate gridiron is completed, and no longer than six hundred (600) feet in length shall be permitted between interconnecting mains. Should six hundred (600) feet between interconnecting mains be exceeded, then all mains shall be eight (8) inches in diameter at a minimum. The fire marshal shall determine the adequacy of the gridiron and may require larger pipe sizes, depending upon the size, construction, layout and occupancy of the buildings serviced. 
(c)  Fire hydrants installed in shopping centers, malls and industrial areas, and in areas not otherwise specified in this section, shall be spaced a maximum of three hundred (300) feet apart, and so located that all buildings in the complex can be reached by comparatively short hose lays as determined by the fire marshal. 
(d)  Fire hydrants installed in multiple housing developments shall be spaced a maximum of five hundred (500) feet apart and located in such a way as to permit hose lays of no more than four hundred (400) feet. Should it become necessary for the city to place hydrants on private property to meet the above requirements, the owners of said properties so serviced shall be required to maintain said hydrants according to the specifications of the city. 
(e)  Fire hydrants installed by private companies and individuals must comply with installation specifications of the city. 
(f)  All owners of private property, including owners of multi-family structures, within the city, with existing exposures which do not meet the current code requirements for fire hydrants and water main installations, shall be required to meet the following minimum standards: 
(1)  Where the existing fire hydrant spacing exceeds the requirements of this section by more than fifty (50) per cent, additional fire hydrants shall be installed to reduce the spacing to no more than fifty (50) per cent of the requirements of this section. 
(2)  Where existing fire hydrant spacing requires hose lays of more than six hundred (600) feet, additional fire hydrants shall be installed to reduce such hose lays to no more than six hundred (600) feet. 
(3)  Sizing and installation of piping and water mains servicing fire hydrants shall conform with the requirements of this section. 
(4)  No fire hydrant connected to a sprinkler system, standpipe system, or other private fire protection system shall be considered in determining the minimum code requirements for fire hydrants. 
(Code 1963, § 7-11) 
Sec. 7-22. - Fireworks. 
(a)  Defined. The term "fireworks" shall include and mean any combustible or explosive composition, or any substance or combination of substances, or article prepared for the purpose and producing a visible and/or an audible effect by combustion, explosion, deflagration or detonation, and shall include blank cartridges, toy pistols, toy cannon, toy canes or toy guns in which explosives are used, the type of balloons which require fire underneath to propel the same, firecrackers, torpedoes, skyrockets, Roman candles, cherry bombs, sparklers or other fireworks of like construction, and any fireworks containing any explosive or flammable compound, or any tablets or other device containing any explosive substance; however, the term "fireworks" shall not include toy pistol paper caps in which the explosive content does not average more than one-fourth (0.25) grain per cap, and toy pistols, toy cannon, toy cones, toy guns or other devices using paper caps. 
(b)  Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to offer for sale, expose for sale, sell, use, ignite, explode or posses any fireworks within the city. 
(Code 1963, § 16-15; Ord. No. 2001-03, § 1, 1-16-01) 
Cross reference- Manufacture and storage prohibited, § 7-15. 
State Law reference- Fireworks, O.C.G.A. § 25-10-1 et seq. 
Sec. 7-23. - Smoke detectors. 
(a)  Smoke detectors are required for all the following: 
(1)  For every multi-family dwelling containing three (3) or more dwelling units, a smoke detector shall be installed in each dwelling unit. If, in the opinion of the chief of the fire prevention bureau, a single smoke detector in a dwelling unit will not provide adequate warning signals, the chief shall require the installation of additional smoke detectors. Additionally, for every such multi-family dwelling containing three (3) or more dwelling units, smoke detectors shall be installed in each hallway or corridor, exitway, and lobby as provided in subsection (2) below. 
(2)  For every hotel, motel, dormitory, rooming house, and such other similar structures, smoke detectors shall be installed in each bedroom and residential room, and in each hallway or corridor, exitway and/or lobby. The installation of the required detectors in hallways, corridors, exitways and lobbies shall be on thirty-foot centers on smooth ceilings. For areas of beamed or joisted ceilings, the chief of the fire prevention bureau shall approve placement based on practical knowledge and in conjunction with NFPA 72, 72E, and 74. 
(3)  For every business occupancy, assembly occupancy, church, school, auditorium and such other similar structures, a smoke detector shall be placed in each assembly room and in each hallway or corridor, exitway and/or lobby. The installation of the required detectors in hallways or corridors, exitways and lobbies shall be on thirty-foot centers on smooth ceilings. For areas of beamed or joisted ceilings, the chief of the fire prevention bureau shall approve smoke detector placement based on practical knowledge and in conjunction with NFPA 72, 72E, and 74. 
(4)  Battery powered smoke detectors shall not be installed in any new construction or existing construction involving renovation where such cost of renovation exceeds forty (40) per cent of the value of the structure for which renovation is being performed. Additionally, where fire, water or other damage has resulted in damage to an existing structure where replacement of wiring and/or ceilings is required as a portion of repairs, battery power smoke detectors shall be prohibited. 
(b)  For every multi-family dwelling containing four (4) dwelling units no charcoal or gas burners shall be kindled or used on combustible balconies or within ten (10) feet of combustible patios on ground floors. 
(Code 1963, § 5-6; Ord. No. 96-07, § 1, 3-4-96) 
Sec. 7-24. - Open burning. 
(a)  No person, without having obtained a permit therefor, shall cause, suffer, allow or permit open burning in any area of the city except as follows: 
(1)  Open burning in a reasonable fashion for the purpose of cooking food for immediate human consumption. 
(2)  Fires set for the purpose of training fire fighting personnel of the College Park Fire Department, or for the purpose of teaching fire safety techniques to industrial fire brigades or civilians who reside or work within the city, provided that such training is being conducted by city personnel. 
(3)  Operation of devices using open flames such as tar kettles, blow torches, welding torches, portable heaters, and other flame-making equipment where approved safety measures are used. 
(4)  Warming fires in a barrel of fifty-five gallon capacity or less, provided that the outside temperature is fifty (50) degrees Fahrenheit or less, that the fire does not procedure dense smoke or obnoxious odors, and that the fire is attended by an individual over the age of seventeen (17) years of age. Untreated wood or lumber shall be the only material or substance allowed in the warming fire. No permit or fee is required for warming fires. 
(5)  Reduction of leaves on the premises on which they fall by the person in contact with the premises; however, only during the times when the leaves are dry and there is no wind. The chief of the fire department shall have the authority to order that any fire be put out if he determines there is a danger to public safety, a nuisance or significant environmental harm. 
(b)  If there are adequate disposal facilities reasonably available for the particular combustible materials involved, the following open burning may be permitted if conducted in strict compliance with the provisions of this section: 
(1)  Disposal of tree limbs from storm damage; 
(2)  For weed abatement, disease, and pest prevention; and 
(3)  Open burning in other than predominantly residential areas for the purpose of land clearing or construction or right-of-way maintenance. 
(c)  Standards; inspection. 
(1)  Materials such as heavy oils, gasoline, asphaltic materials, plastic, items containing natural or synthetic rubber, or any other material producing dense smoke and/or obnoxious odors shall not be used for starting or maintaining an open fire. 
(2)  All burning shall be located on private property so as not to interfere with any traffic on public streets or sidewalks. 
(3)  No burning shall occur prior to the city's inspection of the site and air curtain destructor pit and the issuance of a burning permit. 
(4)  All pit fires shall be operated in strict compliance with the Air Curtain Destructor Operating Guide and Procedure, as published by the North Georgia Region and Environmental Protection Division. 
(5)  The location of the air curtain destructor shall be at least one thousand (1,000) feet from any occupied or habitable structure. This distance may be increased by the College Park Fire Department on a site-specific basis at the discretion of the fire chief. 
(6)  During pit fire operations, fire shall be attended at all times by a person qualified to operate the heavy equipment used in the pit fire operation. Heavy equipment capable of securing and covering the pit is required to be at the pit site at all times during burning operations. 
(7)  A fence or barrier surrounding the combustion pit as depicted in the Air Curtain Destructor Operating Guide and Procedures shall be required at all times. 
(8)  Pit burning is not permitted at night. After dark, the pit may continue to be uncovered to allow the burning coals and ember to die down during the night, provided the pit is attended. 
(9)  Pit fires may be fueled only between one (1) hour after sunrise and two hours prior to sundown (but in no event later than four o'clock p.m.). Fueling of pit fires is prohibited at all other times. 
(10)  Except for a reasonable period to get a fire started, no smoke of a shade darker than a #2 of the Ringlemann, chart, or equivalent opacity, shall be emitted by a source of open burning. 
(11)  Only wood wastes consisting of trees, logs, large brush, stumps relatively free of soil, and untreated lumber may be burned. Sawdust, other densely packed wood wastes, paper (any type), chemically treated, coated or impregnated wood, or nonwood construction materials shall not be burned. Any material or substance not specifically allowed herein shall not be burned. 
(d)  No burning shall be allowed in violation of restrictions imposed by the Environmental Protection Agency or the State Environmental Protection Division. 
(e)  Permit application; contents; terms 
(1)  For all burning permitted under this section, the property owner shall obtain all necessary permits from the Environmental Protection Division of the Department of Natural Resources of the State of Georgia. 
(2)  In addition to state approval, the property owner shall submit a burning permit application to the College Park Fire Department. Such application shall include: 
a.  A plat or survey indicating that the air pit destructor in which the burning is to occur is located more than one thousand (1,000) feet away from any occupied or habitable structure. 
b.  The names and qualifications of the individuals who will be attending to the fire during pit fire operations. 
c.  A permit application fee in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
d.  An applicant shall submit a performance bond in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00). Said bond may be in the form of cash, an irrevocable letter of credit, or in a form suitable to the city and executed by a surety or sureties, reasonably acceptable to the city. If the applicant does not comply with the provisions of this section or with the conditions of the burning permit after issuance, the entire performance bond fee shall be forfeited to the city and the city may use said sum to stabilize the site and bring it into compliance. If the applicant does comply with the provisions of this section and with conditions of the burning permit, the performance bond shall be released by the city following extinguishment of the fire under the permit. 
(3)  Duration of permit. A permit issued by the College Park Fire Department shall be valid for thirty (30) days after issuance and shall be issued on a site-specific basis. 
(4)  Revocation. A burning permit may be suspended, revoked, or modified by the fire chief upon finding that the holder or his successor in title is not in compliance with the approved plan or that the holder or his successor is in violation of this section. 
(5)  Stop-work orders. The fire chief may issue a stop-work order when atmospheric conditions or local circumstances make open burning hazardous. In addition, the fire chief may issue a stop-work order on any burning permit which has already been issued in the event that the holder of such permit is found to be in violation of the requirements of this section. 
(f)  Denial of a burning permit, modification or grant with conditions of such a permit, and/or issuance of a stop-work order by the fire chief shall entitle the person applying for a burning permit or the holder of such a permit to a hearing before the city manager within thirty (30) days after receipt by the manager of written notice of appeal. Such written notice of appeal shall only be effective if submitted in writing within ten (10) days of the date of the action or notice from which appeal is requested. 
(g)  Neither the issuance of a burning permit, nor compliance with the provisions of this section, shall relieve any person of the responsibility for damages to any person or property otherwise imposed by law nor impose any liability upon the city for damage to any person or property. 
(h)  Any person who violates the provisions of this section, or who violates any order or determination of the fire chief promulgated pursuant to this section shall be cited for such violation and, upon conviction, shall be punished by fine or imprisonment, or both, as established by section 1-8 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 97-21, § 1, 8-18-97) 
Chapter 7.5 - FRANCHISES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2000-16, § 1, adopted June 5, 2000, and subsequently amended by Ord. No. 2000-20, § 1, adopted Aug. 7, 2000, added new provisions to the Code as Ch. 21, §§ 21-1-21-19. In order to preserve the alphabetical sequencing of chapters within the Code, the provisions of Ord. No. 2000-16 and 2000-20 have been redesignated as Ch. 7.5, §§ 7.5-1-7.5-19, at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Cable television standards and procedures, Ch. 5.5. 

Sec. 7.5-1. - Purpose. 
    In accordance with Section 2-5(a) through (c) of the Charter of the City of College Park, Georgia, the city establishes requirements necessary to preserve and advance universal service, protect the public safety and welfare, ensure the continued quality of services, and safeguard the rights of consumers in the franchise, license or right to use or occupy any street, road, alley, sidewalk or other city owned or controlled public right-of-way or property. 
(Ord. No. 2000-16, § 1, 6-5-00; Ord. No. 2000-24, § 1, 8-7-00) 
Sec. 7.5-2. - Franchise required. 
    Prior to any person, firm, corporation, or other entity using the city right-of-way by constructing, installing, altering, or repairing lines, devices, or other physical objects within the city right-of-way as part of any commercial enterprise then a franchise must be gained by the mayor and council of the City of College Park. For the purposes of this chapter only, the term "using the city right-of-way" shall be defined as any activity that affects: the preservation of the physical and aesthetic integrity of city streets and highways, the orderly flow of vehicles and pedestrians, the management and safety of gas, water, cable, electric and telecommunication oriented (except for television) and telephone facilities that are located in or occupying any street, road, alley, sidewalk or other public place in said city, for public utility purposes, such as electric light plant, electric or steam or other streetcar line or road, gas line, railroad line, telephone line, telegraph line, telecommunications facilities, express line, waterworks, or other public utility service, whether the same be surface, underground, overhead or otherwise, except as hereinafter provided, in city right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 2000-16, § 1, 6-5-00; Ord. No. 2000-24, § 1, 8-7-00) 
Sec. 7.5-3. - Procedure for grant of franchise. 
(a)  Application in writing, signed by the applicant, shall be made to and filed with the mayor and council for such franchise, license or right, setting forth what streets or areas are to be occupied and for what purpose. Two (2) weeks notice of application shall be given by the clerk of council by posting said notice at the door of the council chamber, before the same is acted on by council; and before such franchise, license or right shall be granted. If granted, such franchise shall be passed upon favorably by a two-thirds ( 2/3 ) vote of the entire council at two (2) regular monthly meetings of same. The application shall be considered by the mayor and council no later than ninety (90) days after submittal by the applicant as noted by the clerk receiving the application. 
(b)  Council may grant the franchise upon such terms and conditions as it may deem advisable and revoke same for a violation of such terms and conditions. 
(c)  Council may preliminarily approve an application pending a final agreement entered into under section 7.5-7. If no final agreement is reached such application approval shall be deemed void. 
(Ord. No. 2000-16, § 1, 6-5-00; Ord. No. 2000-24, § 1, 8-7-00) 
Sec. 7.5-4. - Standards for approval or refusal of franchise application. 
    The city shall manage the public rights-of-way by approving or denying franchise application and fees on a competitively neutral and non-discriminatory basis while publicly disclosing the compensation (franchise fee and administrative fee) required. 
(Ord. No. 2000-16, § 1, 6-5-00; Ord. No. 2000-24, § 1, 8-7-00) 
Sec. 7.5-5. - Franchise fee and administrative fee. 
(a)  All franchise fees shall be calculated based upon five (5) per cent of the applicant's annual gross revenue generated within the city. All such payment of franchise fees shall be made on a quarterly basis and shall be remitted simultaneously with the submission of a quarterly franchise fee report to be forwarded to the city by mail not later than thirty (30) days after the last day of each March, June, September, and December throughout the term of the franchise setting forth the gross revenue for the quarter ending on said last day. 
(b)  An administrative fee shall be paid by the applicant at the time a final contract is executed. The fee shall reflect the actual costs of administering the franchise application and any resulting agreement. These costs shall be paid at the lowest hourly rate of the lowest paid employee or worker competent in the city's opinion to perform the work required to process, draft, and negotiate the application and agreement. Such fees will include but are not necessarily limited to document preparation, document processing, document review, field review, legal review, legal work regarding contract negotiation and drafting, contract execution, and any other city cost the city incurs as a result of the franchise application and award. 
(Ord. No. 2000-16, § 1, 6-5-00; Ord. No. 2000-24, § 1, 8-7-00) 
Sec. 7.5-6. - Audit and provision of audit information. 
(a)  Franchise fee payments subject to audit; remedy for underpayment. No acceptance of any [franchise fee payment] by the city shall be construed as an accord and satisfaction that the amount paid is in fact the correct amount or a release of any claim that the city may have for further or additional sums payable under a franchise and all amounts paid shall be subject to audit and recomputation by the city. Except as provided in subsection (b), the cost of the audit shall be borne by the city. 
(b)  Cost of audit. If, as a result of such audit or any other review, the city determines that grantee has underpaid its fees in any twelve-month period by ten (10) per cent or more, then, in addition to making full payment of the relevant obligation, the grantee shall reimburse the city for all of the reasonable costs associated with the audit or review, including all reasonable out-of-pocket costs for attorneys, accountants, and other consultants. 
(c)  Payments not to be set off against taxes or vice versa. Payments made pursuant to this section and any other provision of this chapter are not a tax and are not in the nature of a tax and are in addition to any and all taxes of general applicability or other fees or charges (including any fees or charges which may be imposed on the grantee for the use of poles, conduits or similar facilities that may be owned or controlled by the city) which the grantee or any affiliated person shall be required to pay to the city. 
(d)  Interest on late payments. If any payment required by this chapter is not actually received by the city on or before the applicable date fixed in this chapter, the grantee shall pay interest thereon, from the due date to the date paid at a rate of one (1) per cent per month, for the period of delinquency. 
(Ord. No. 2000-16, § 1, 6-5-00; Ord. No. 2000-24, § 1, 8-7-00) 
Sec. 7.5-7. - Franchise agreement. 
    Each grantee shall enter into an agreement with the city, which is consistent with the terms of this chapter. Each franchise agreement granted under this chapter shall be personal to the grantee and the terms of each franchise agreement may vary. 
(Ord. No. 2000-16, § 1, 6-5-00; Ord. No. 2000-24, § 1, 8-7-00) 
Sec. 7.5-8. - Duration of franchise. 
    Franchise agreements that extend beyond a calendar year shall comply with O.C.G.A. § 36-60-13. 
(Ord. No. 2000-16, § 1, 6-5-00; Ord. No. 2000-24, § 1, 8-7-00) 
Sec. 7.5-9. - Renewal of franchise. 
    Sixty (60) days prior to the expiration of the agreement term, the grantee may apply for the renewal of this authorization. The city reserves the right to grant or deny such renewal. 
(Ord. No. 2000-16, § 1, 6-5-00; Ord. No. 2000-24, § 1, 8-7-00) 
Sec. 7.5-10. - Rights personal. 
(a)  The rights granted by this chapter to the grantee are personal to the grantee (as owned and controlled on the effective date of this chapter) and shall not be assigned, sold, pledged, leased, sublet, mortgaged or transferred, directly or indirectly, without the prior written consent of the city. 
(b)  It is not the intention of this chapter nor any subsequent agreement to grant any property right whatsoever to grantee. Further, grantee is required to contractually relinquish any claimed easement right within the city's municipal right-of-way. If any facility is placed by grantee outside of the city's right-of-way and such right-of-way is later expanded to include the grantee's facility, upon the city's request, such facility shall be removed or relocated at grantee's full and sole expense. The grantee, under contract and for the express consideration of the use of the city's right-of-way shall waive any and all claim for reimbursement for any costs for any removed or relocated facility and for any claim of any easement or other property right in the pubic right-of-way or expanded public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 2000-16, § 1, 6-5-00; Ord. No. 2000-24, § 1, 8-7-00) 
Sec. 7.5-11. - Inspections provisions of construction information. 
    The city shall inspect the activities of the grantee within the right-of-way including inspection of construction procedures and relocation of facilities and may require information necessary to perform an inspection including, but not limited to the information required under section 7.5-12 (e) and (f). Such information shall include descriptions of how the grantee's facilities fit into the affected rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 2000-16, § 1, 6-5-00; Ord. No. 2000-24, § 1, 8-7-00) 
Sec. 7.5-12. - Construction practices. 
(a)  No grantee shall commence any construction, operation, maintenance, repair or upgrading of a franchise, or any part thereof, without having first secured the necessary permits from the city or other required public agencies having jurisdiction over the work to be performed. 
(b)  In those areas of the city where transmission or distribution facilities of all the public utilities providing telephone and electric power service are underground, the grantee likewise shall construct, operate and maintain its transmission and distribution facilities therein underground. 
(c)  In those areas of the city where a grantee's cables or facilities are located on the above-ground transmission or distribution facilities of the public utility providing telephone, electric power, or other service, and in the event that the facilities of such public utilities subsequently are placed underground, then the grantee likewise shall construct, operate and maintain its transmission and distribution facilities underground, at grantee's cost, provided that grantee may request a waiver, in writing, of the requirement for underground placement where such underground placement would be technologically unfeasible. Certain of grantee's equipment, such as pedestals, amplifiers and power supplies, which normally are placed above ground, may continue to remain in above-ground closures. 
(d)  If the grades, lines or right-of-way of any street within the service area are changed at any time during the term of a franchise, then the grantee shall, at its own cost and expense and upon the request of the city, protect or promptly alter or relocate the facilities or any part thereof, so as to conform with such new grades, lines, or right-of-way. In the event that the grantee refuses or neglects to so protect, alter, or relocate all or part of the facilities, the city shall have the right to break through, remove, alter, or relocate all or any part of the facilities without any liability to the city and the grantee shall pay to the city all costs incurred in connection with such breaking through, removal, alternation, or relocation. 
(e)  Prior to construction a final location plan shall be submitted for approval by the inspection department, and the inspection department shall be authorized to permit or to require an alternate location for the proposed facilities within the public right-of-way to avoid conflict with other permitted uses or to establish an appropriate width from curb for placement of conduit for the use proposed. The city also reserves the right to inspect the installation and maintenance of grantee's facilities in or on the city's property. 
(f)  The grantee shall provide as-built drawings, acceptable to the city detailing the number and location of facilities installed pursuant to this chapter. The number and location of facilities may be reasonably regulated as set forth in this chapter. 
(g)  The grantee shall give the city thirty (30) days advance written notice requesting any additional use of right-of-way and shall abide by any permitting requirements as specified by city ordinances. 
(h)  In connection with the construction, operation, maintenance, repair, upgrade, or removal of the facilities the grantee shall, at its own cost and expense, protect any and all existing structures belonging to the city and all designated landmarks. The grantee agrees that it shall be liable, at its own cost and expense, to replace or repair and restore to its previous serviceable condition, in a manner as may be specified by the city, any street or any municipal structure involved in the construction, operation, maintenance, repair, upgrade or removal of the facilities that may become disturbed or damaged as a result of any work thereon by or on behalf of the grantee. 
(i)  In connection with the construction, operation, maintenance, repair, upgrade, or removal of the facility, the grantee shall not obstruct the streets, railways, passenger travel, river navigation, or other traffic to, from, or within the public rights-of-way without prior consent of the city and any other appropriate authorities. All such work shall be performed so as to cause minimal interference with users of the streets and adjoining property owners. 
(j)  The grantee shall, upon prior written notice by the city or any person holding a permit to move any structure, temporarily move its wires to permit the moving of said structure. The grantee may impose a reasonable charge on any person other than the city for any such movement of its wires. However, imposition of such a charge shall not be deemed to constitute an easement benefiting grantee. 
(k)  In case of a grantee's disturbance of pavement, sidewalks, driveways or other surfaces, the grantee shall, at its sole expense, replace and restore such surfaces, in as good a condition as before such work was commenced and in accordance with city standards. 
(l)  Erection, removal and common uses of poles. 
(1)  No poles or other wire-holding structures shall be erected by the grantee without first having entered into a pole attachment agreement with the city. However, no location of any pole or wire-holding structure of the grantee shall be vested interest and such poles or structures shall be removed or modified by the grantee at its own expense whenever the council determines that the public convenience would be enhanced thereby. 
(2)  Where poles or other wire-holding structures already existing for use in serving the city are available for use by the grantee on reasonable terms the council may require the grantee to use such poles and structures. If a grantee believes the terms with a private supplier to be unreasonable, it may apply, in writing, to the city for a waiver of this requirement. 
(3)  Poles in public right-of-way shall be removed or relocated at the sole expense of grantee of the request of the city when, in the city's sole discretion, removal or relocation is deemed necessary. 
(Ord. No. 2000-16, § 1, 6-5-00; Ord. No. 2000-24, § 1, 8-7-00) 
Sec. 7.5-13. - Insurance. 
(a)  Liability insurance. Throughout the term of any franchise, the grantee shall, at its own cost and expense, maintain a liability insurance policy or policies in a form acceptable to the city, and approved by the city attorney. The grantee shall furnish at least annually to the city certificates of insurance for all policies required by this chapter and the franchise. Each such liability insurance policy shall contain the following, or equivalent, endorsement: "It is hereby understood and agreed that this policy may not be canceled nor the intention not to renew be stated until sixty (60) days after receipt by the City, by registered mail, of a written notice of such intent to cancel or not to renew." No later than thirty (30) days prior to cancellation of required insurance, the grantee shall obtain and furnish to the city replacement insurance policies in a form reasonably acceptable to the city. 
(b)  Increase insurance coverage. In the event of any changed circumstances following the effective date, city may, after consulting with the grantee, alter the minimum limitation of the liability insurance policy or policies required in this section. 
(c)  Liability not limited. The legal liability of the company and any affiliated person to the city and any person for any of the matters which are the subject of the liability insurance policies required by this section, including, without limitation, the grantee indemnification obligations set forth in this section shall not be limited by such insurance policies nor by the recovery of any amounts thereunder, except to the extent necessary to avoid duplicative recovery from or payment by the grantee. 
(d)  In lieu of purchasing one (1) or more commercial insurance policies, grantee may provide for the above-referenced types and amounts of insurance through self-insurance, subject to approval of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2000-16, § 1, 6-5-00; Ord. No. 2000-24, § 1, 8-7-00) 
Sec. 7.5-14. - Letter of credit. 
(a)  Within ten (10) days after formal award of a franchise, the grantee shall deposit with the city a letter of credit from a financial institution in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). The form and content of such letter of credit shall be approved by the city attorney. The letter of credit shall be used to insure the faithful performance by the grantee of all provisions of a franchise; and compliance with all orders, permits and directives of any agency, commission, board, department, division or office of the city having jurisdiction over its acts or defaults under the franchise, and the payment by the grantee of any claims, liens and taxes due the city which arise by reason of the construction, operation or maintenance of the system. 
(b)  The letter of credit shall be maintained at ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) during the entire term of the franchise, even if amounts have to be withdrawn pursuant to subsections (a) or (c) of this section. 
(c)  If the grantee fails to pay to the city any compensation within the time fixed herein; or fails to repay the city within ten (10) days, for underpayments any damages, costs or expenses which the city is compelled to pay by reason of any act or default of the grantee in connection with this franchise; or, fails, after three (3) days' notice of such failure by the grantee to comply with any provision of the franchise which the city reasonably determines can be remedied by demand on the letter of credit, the council may immediately request payment of the amount thereof, with interest, calculated at the rate of one (1) per cent per month, from the date of delinquency, and any penalties, from the letter of credit. Upon such request for payment, the city shall notify the grantee of the amount and date thereof. 
(d)  Enforcement of this chapter with respect to the letter of credit is in addition to all other rights of the city, authorized by law, and no action, proceeding or exercise of a right with respect to such letter of credit shall affect any other right the city may have. 
(e)  The letter of credit shall contain the following, or equivalent, endorsement: 
"It is hereby understood and agreed that this letter of credit shall not be canceled by the surety nor the intention not to renew be stated by the surety until sixty (60) days after receipt by the City of College Park, Georgia Mayor and Council, by registered mail, of a written notice of such intention to cancel or not to renew." 
(Ord. No. 2000-16, § 1, 6-5-00; Ord. No. 2000-24, § 1, 8-7-00) 
Sec. 7.5-15. - Performance bond. 
(a)  Within thirty (30) days after the award of a franchise, the grantee shall file with the city a performance bond in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) in favor of the city. This bond shall be approved by the city attorney and shall be maintained throughout the construction or upgrade of the entire facility or until such time as the city may require. 
(b)  In the event the grantee fails to comply with any law, ordinance or regulation governing the franchise, or fails to well and truly observe, fulfill and perform each term and condition of the franchise, there shall be recoverable, jointly and severally, from the principal and surety of the bond, any damages or loss suffered by the city as a result, including the full amount of any compensation, indemnification, or cost of removal or abandonment of any property of the grantee, plus a reasonable allowance for attorney's fees, up to the full amount of the bond. This section shall be an additional remedy for any and all violations outlined in this chapter. 
(c)  The city may, upon completion of construction or upgrade of the grantee, waive or reduce the requirement of the grantee to maintain said bond. However, the city may require that a performance bond be posted by the grantee for any construction subsequent to the completion of the work in the right-of-way, in a reasonable amount and upon such terms as determined by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2000-16, § 1, 6-5-00; Ord. No. 2000-24, § 1, 8-7-00) 
Sec. 7.5-16. - Abandonment or removal of franchise property. 
(a)  In the event that the use of any property of grantee within the right-of-way or a portion thereof is discontinued for a continuous period of six (6) months, grantee shall be deemed to have abandoned that franchise property. 
(b)  The city, upon such terms as it may impose, may give grantee permission to abandon, without removing, any grantee property or equipment under the franchise. Unless such permission is granted or unless otherwise provided in this chapter, the grantee shall remove all abandoned above-ground facilities and equipment upon receipt of written notice from the city and shall restore any affected city property to its former state at the time such facilities and equipment were installed, so as not to impair its usefulness. In removing its plant, structures and equipment, grantee shall refill, at its own expense, any excavation that shall be made by it and shall leave all public ways and places in as good condition as that prevailing prior to such removal without materially interfering with any electrical or telephone cable or other utility wires, poles or attachments. The city shall have the right to inspect and approve the condition of the public ways, public places, cables, wires, attachments and poles prior to and after removal. The liability, indemnity and insurance provisions of this chapter and any security fund provided in the franchise shall continue in full force and effect during the period of removal and until full compliance by grantee with the terms and conditions of this section. 
(c)  At the expiration of the term for which the franchise is granted, or upon abandonment as defined above or upon its revocation or earlier expiration, as provided for herein, in any such case without renewal, extension or transfer, the city shall have the right to require grantee to remove, at its own expense, all above-ground portions of its facilities from all streets and public ways within the city within a reasonable period of time, which shall not be less than one hundred eighty (180) days. 
(d)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary set forth in this chapter, the grantee may abandon any underground franchise property in place so long as it does not, in the city's sole discretion, materially interfere with the use of the street or public right-of-ways in which such property is located or with the use thereof by any public utility or other cable grantee. 
(Ord. No. 2000-16, § 1, 6-5-00; Ord. No. 2000-24, § 1, 8-7-00) 
Sec. 7.5-17. - Enforcement and penalties. 
    In addition to the penalties set forth hereinabove violations of this chapter shall be punishable as provided under Georgia law in municipal court for city ordinance violations. Each day a violation occurs shall be considered a separate offense and punishable thereas. 
(Ord. No. 2000-16, § 1, 6-5-00; Ord. No. 2000-24, § 1, 8-7-00) 
Sec. 7.5-18. - Relationship to other ordinances and franchises. 
    This chapter shall not supersede nor repeal Chapter 5.5, Cable Television Standards and Procedures, of the Code of Ordinances of the City of College Park, Georgia. If it is determined that this chapter and Chapter 5.5 conflict, the more restrictive provision shall apply except in the area of cable television which shall be governed by Chapter 5.5. 
    Furthermore, this Ordinance shall not be deemed to repeal any franchise agreement duly approved and executed before the effective date of this chapter. Furthermore, this provision shall not be deemed to in any way to allow any attempt by the mayor and council to contractually or otherwise limit their police powers. 
(Ord. No. 2000-16, § 1, 6-5-00; Ord. No. 2000-24, § 1, 8-7-00) 
Sec. 7.5-19. - Revocation. 
    If the grantee fails to comply with any of the terms and conditions of this chapter, then the city may in addition to the other penalties herein revoke the authorization granted herein. The city shall notify the grantee of its failure to comply and give grantee thirty (30) days to correct such default before revocation. The notice required hereunder shall not be required for issuance of a citation for a violation of this chapter as set out in section 7.5-17 without invoking the revocation provisions hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 2000-16, § 1, 6-5-00; Ord. No. 2000-24, § 1, 8-7-00) 
Chapter 8 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Health studio licenses, § 11-160 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Health regulations adopted, incorporated by reference. 
    There are hereby adopted for the purpose of securing the public health and welfare, the regulations of the Fulton County Board of Health, as amended from time to time, of which at least one (1) copy has been and is filed in the office of the city clerk, and the same, together with the amendments thereto are adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, and the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the city; provided however, that should the provisions thereof conflict with any provisions of this Code, then the more restrictive provisions shall take precedence. 
(Code 1963, § 10-1) 
Sec. 8-2. - Nuisances generally; defined, abatement. 
(a)  Definition. A "nuisance" in general terms shall be construed to mean anything that causes hurt, inconvenience or damage to another, and the fact that the act done may otherwise be legal does not keep it from being a nuisance. The consequences complained of must not be fanciful or such as would only affect a person of fastidious tastes, but it must be such as would affect an ordinary, reasonable person. The definition of "nuisance" herein shall be in addition to all other definitions of nuisance contained in the Code and ordinances of the city. 
(b)  Authority to abate. The city court shall have full power to order the abatement of any nuisance, whether public or private, within the city, and the appropriate city officials or the sheriffs of the counties or their deputies shall have full power and authority to execute the court's order. 
(c)  Complaint, notice of hearing. When any nuisance exists in the city, any person affected thereby may apply or complain to the city court or the appropriate city official for abatement thereof, and it shall be the duty of the court or of the appropriate city official to cause to be issued reasonable notice of not less than four (4) days, to the parties interested, of the time and place of hearing. The complaint shall be in writing, shall specify the acts or thing complained of, and shall be signed by the person seeking the abatement. Notice of the hearing shall be in writing, shall be served upon the parties interested, and shall reasonably specify the nuisance sought to be abated. Such service may be personal or may be accomplished by leaving said notice at the residence of the parties interested. 
(d)  Order to abate; execution for costs. When any person shall be convicted of creating or maintaining a nuisance, such person shall be ordered to abate such nuisance within a reasonable time to be fixed by the court, and should such person fail or refuse to abide the court's order, it shall be the duty of the appropriate city official of the city to abate the same at the cost of the defendant. In any instance of failure or refusal to abate a nuisance after ordered to do so by the city court, and the abatement thereof by the appropriate city official, the cost thereof shall be collected by levy and sale as in cases of fines and forfeitures as provided elsewhere in this Code. 
(e)  Issuance of execution. The execution provided for in subsection (d) shall be issued by the city clerk when the appropriate city official shall make affidavit stating the reasonable cost of abating the nuisance, and the execution shall issue for the reasonable cost or expense as shown by such affidavit. 
(Code 1963, § 16-24) 
Cross reference- Keeping animals, § 4-5 et seq.; sewage disposal, § 8-4 et seq. 
State Law reference- Abatement of nuisances in city, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-5. 
Sec. 8-3. - Abandoned iceboxes, refrigerators and similar receptacles. 
(a)  Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any owner or tenant of any premises within the city to allow or permit any abandoned or discarded icebox, refrigerator, trunk, chest or other receptacle or container in which a person might become imprisoned to be or remain on such premises if such icebox, refrigerator, trunk, chest, receptacle, container or device has a virtually airtight lid, door, snap lock, latch, or other locking device, without first removing such door, lid, snap lock, latch or other locking device. 
(b)  Definition. Any such container shall be considered and deemed abandoned or discarded, when it is no longer used for the purpose for which it was intended, and is unattended outside of any building or structure, or is within an abandoned or unoccupied house, shed, barn or other structure within the city. 
(Code 1963, § 16-1) 
Cross reference- Disposal of old appliances, § 10-113. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-100. 
Sec. 8-4. - Deposit of sewage, etc., in unsanitary manner generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit, or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any human or animal excrement, garbage, or other objectionable waste. 
(Code 1963, § 18B-2) 
Cross reference- Sewers and sewage disposal, § 10-50 et seq. 
Sec. 8-5. - Dumping of refuse on private or public property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any persons to dump, or scatter, garbage, trash, refuse or other waste matter upon private or public property within the city, or to in any way litter any premises in the city. 
(Code 1963, § 8-8) 
Sec. 8-6. - Grass and weeds on private property; height limited. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner of any property in the city, or for any person having control or management of property for the owner, to permit and allow the growth of grass or weeds on said property to a height greater than six (6) inches. 
(Code 1963, § 8-5; Ord. No. 2006-28, § 2, 9-18-06) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2006, § 2, adopted Sept. 18, 2006, repealed former § 8-6 in its entirety which pertained to littering streets and derived from the Code of 1963. Said ordinance also renumbered the remaining sections fo this article. 
Sec. 8-7. - Spitting. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to spit upon the sidewalks, or upon floors of churches, public halls, theaters or other public places. 
(Code 1963, § 16-31; Ord. No. 2006-28, § 2, 9-18-06) 
Editor's note- Formerly numbered as § 8-9. 
Sec. 8-8. - Open wells and pits. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, either as owner or occupant, of premises within the city whereon any open well or open pit is located, to maintain or permit to remain open and uncovered any well or pit. 
(Code 1963, § 16-27; Ord. No. 2006-28, § 2, 9-18-06)
