On all other individual consumer accounts, the foregoing utility deposits shall become effective at the time new accounts are established. 
(Ord. No. 2018-11, § 1(Exh. A), 11-19-18) 
Sec. 10-4. - Same-Filing to avoid charges; false statements. 
    Whoever makes application for any utility service in such person's own behalf, or on behalf of another, for the purpose of avoiding past due amounts and charges for previous service to the same or separate account; or whoever uses a false name in applying for such service or in any other manner attempts to obtain any such service through fraud or false pretense shall be guilty of an offense punishable in the City Court of College Park and said application shall be void. Any deposit remitted with the application shall be forfeited and applied to any such existing past due account. 
(Ord. No. 2018-11, § 1(Exh. A), 11-19-18) 
Sec. 10-5. - Due dates for utility service charges-Delinquency; discontinuance of service. 
(a)  All electric, sanitation, water and sewer charges incurred by a person or entity for the provision of such utility services to one (1) property during a calendar month shall be listed on a single, monthly bill issued by the city. 
(b)  Any bill issued by the city for the provision of any utility service shall be due and payable immediately upon issuance and shall be considered delinquent if not fully paid before 11:59 p.m. on the twenty-first (21 st ) day following the date of such bill; provided, however, that if such date falls on a Saturday, a Sunday, or a legal holiday observed by the city, then such bill shall be due and payable by 11:59 p.m. on the following business day. 
(c)  In the event the person or entity fully liable for all monetary obligations arising from the city's provision of a utility service to a property fails to fully pay any bill for the provision of such service before 11:59 p.m. on the twenty-first (21 st ) day following the date of such bill, a penalty in an amount determined by resolution of the mayor and council shall be automatically added to any outstanding, unpaid amount due under such bill. 
(d)  In the event the person or entity fully liable for all monetary obligations arising from the city's provision of a utility service to a property fails to remit to the city monies for all amounts shown on the bill required by subsection (a) before 11:59 p.m. on the seventh (7 th ) calendar day after the past due date indicated on such bill, the city shall have the right, pursuant to section 10-13(b), to discontinue the utility service. In addition to the right to discontinue such service, the failure to remit to the city all amounts shown on such bill by 11:59 p.m. on the seventh (7 th ) calendar day after the past due date indicated on the utility service bill shall result in the imposition by the city of an administrative charge as determined by resolution of the mayor and council. The purpose of such administrative charge is to defray the cost to the city of identifying, and monitoring delinquent accounts. 
(e)  (1)  For a period of four (4) years after the date of each bill issued on an account established for the provision of utility service, the city shall maintain a record of each such bill. Said record shall indicate the date of the bill; the date the bill was issued; the name and mailing address of the person or entity to whom the bill was sent; the amount owed under the bill, any prior, unpaid balance owed upon the account prior to the issuance of the bill; and any payments or credits reflected upon the bill. Said record shall also include any information as to whether any bill was returned to the city due to the inability of the mail carrier to deliver such item to the listed mailing address or any information indicating any other delivery issue. 
(2)  Where the city's records show a bill was issued to the person or entity fully liable for all monetary obligations arising from the provision of the utility service at the current mailing address provided to the city by such person or entity and said records do not indicate the bill was returned by the mail carrier as undelivered or any other delivery issue, a rebuttable presumption arises that such bill was actually received by the person or entity fully liable for said monetary obligations within five (5) calendar days after the date the bill was issued. 
(Ord. No. 2018-11, § 1(Exh. A), 11-19-18) 
Sec. 10-6. - Same-Special account established for penalty payments. 
    A separate account of the city, to be denominated "Penalties-Late Utilities Payments," shall be maintained, through which the funds received for the penalties and administrative charges described in section 10-5 shall be collected and disbursed. 
(Ord. No. 2018-11, § 1(Exh. A), 11-19-18) 
Sec. 10-7. - Service charge for returned checks. 
    There shall be a service charge to cover administrative costs in an amount determined by resolution of the mayor and council against any utility service account where the remitting person or entity paid any amount due under a utility service bill by check and such check has been returned to the city by the bank for the lack of sufficient funds in the checking account to honor the check, the closure of the checking account, the stoppage of payment on the check, or other similar reason. Such service charge shall be in the amount as set by the mayor and council, from time to time, by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 2018-11, § 1(Exh. A), 11-19-18) 
Sec. 10-8. - Unlawful restoration of service. 
(a)  Whenever any utility service shall have been discontinued by the city, it shall be unlawful for any person or entity except an authorized agent or employee of the city to restore the service. 
(b)  Upon the conviction of any person or entity for a violation of this section, the City Court of College Park may impose a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each violation. 
(Ord. No. 2018-11, § 1(Exh. A), 11-19-18) 
Sec. 10-9. - Reconnection charges. 
    A service charge shall apply for the reconnection and restoration of any disconnected water, electric or sewer service. Such service charge shall be in an amount as set by the mayor and council, from time to time, by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 2018-11, § 1(Exh. A), 11-19-18) 
Sec. 10-10. - Liability for utility charges. 
(a)  Any utility service furnished by the city may be instituted by the owner or occupant of premises where such service are available. Such owner or occupant shall be liable for payment of all rates and charges therefor. 
(b)  All unpaid charges for sanitation services shall constitute a lien on the property to which such services were provided in accordance with section 6-10 of the City Charter, and such lien may be enforced and foreclosed in the same manner as liens for city property taxes. 
(c)  Provided that the owner of the property is the person who incurred charges for electric, water, and/or sewer services, all unpaid charges for such services shall constitute a lien on the property to which such services were provided in accordance with section 6-10 of the City Charter, and such lien may be enforced and foreclosed in the same manner as liens for city property taxes. Unpaid charges incurred by a party other than the owner of the property may constitute a lien on the property provided that the owner of the property indicates in writing that he will be responsible therefor. 
(Ord. No. 2018-11, § 1(Exh. A), 11-19-18) 
Sec. 10-11. - Meter tests; replacement or repair of meter. 
(a)  General meter test. The city may, at its own expense, make routine tests of any utility service meter when it considers such test desirable. 
(b)  Meter test at the request of the customer. The city shall also make tests or inspections of a utility service meter at the request of a customer who believes his meter to be faulty or registering inaccurately. Upon receipt of such a request by the administrator, accompanied by a service charge in an amount determined by resolution of the mayor and council to cover the costs of removing the meter, testing and reinstallation, this work shall be accomplished and a check of the registering device made. Should the results of the check show the meter to be functioning accurately and in accordance with the city's standards, the deposit will be forfeited by the customer. Should the results of the check show the registration of the meter to be in error in excess of the city's standards or show the meter is registering more utility than actually is passing through that device, the city will refund the deposit to the customer. 
(c)  Repair or replacement of meter. If the results of the meter test performed by the city under this section show the registration of the meter to be in error in excess of the city's standards or show the meter is registering more utility than actually is passing through the device, the city shall repair or replace the meter at no charge to the customer. The results of the meter test show the meter to be functioning accurately and the customer requests the replacement of that meter, the city shall replace the meter and shall charge the customer an administrative fee in an amount as determined by resolution of the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 2018-11, § 1(Exh. A), 11-19-18) 
Sec. 10-12. - Administrative adjustment of charges. 
(a)  Any person or entity who is fully liable to the city for all monetary or other obligations arising from the provision of any utility service may obtain an administrative adjustment to any charge imposed for such provision under the following conditions: 
(1)  The request for the administrative adjustment must be in writing and must be delivered to the administrator before 11:59 p.m. on the twenty-eighth (28 th ) day after the date of the bill initially showing the charge for which an adjustment is sought. 
(2)  An administrative adjustment may be granted for any of the following reasons: 
a.  The charge or a portion of the charge is in error due to a misreading or malfunction of the meter. 
b.  The charge or a portion of the charge is in error due to an incorrect clerical or computer billing entry for the account. 
c.  The property to which the utility service is provided did not in fact received the service for which the charge was imposed. 
d.  As to water service, the charge or a portion of the charge is due to excessive water loss cause by a faulty water heater, a faulty meter, or by a water pipe leak. 
e.  Any other ground for which the administrator, in his/her discretion, determines that an adjustment is appropriate and that the grant of such adjustment would not violate any provision of this article or any other ordinance of the city. 
(3)  The following conditions and restrictions shall apply to any administrative adjustment sought under subsection (a)(2)d.: 
a.  No administrative adjustment may be granted for excessive water loss due solely to a faulty or malfunctioning faucet, spigot or toilet. 
b.  To be eligible for such adjustment, the requestor must submit to the administrator documentation or other evidence establishing that the faulty water heater, the faulty meter or the water pipe leak that caused the excessive water loss has been repaired. 
c.  In determining the monetary amount of any administrative adjustment, the administrator may not consider account information or charges on any account statement that was issued by the city more than six (6) months before the date of the bill in issue. 
(4)  Individual financial hardship. In the case of individual financial hardship, the requestor may obtain an administrative adjustment that extends (for a maximum of six (6) months) the period in which the requestor may have to remit to the city the full amount due under a utility service account. The administrator may grant an administrative adjustment due to a requestor's individual financial hardship under the following terms: 
a.  The requestor can obtain only an extension of the time in which to pay and cannot obtain a reduction of any charge (other than penalties assessed under section 10-5(c)). 
b.  The requestor must submit to the administrator documentation or other evidence establishing (i) the financial hardship; and (ii) the ability to pay future utility service charges as they become due. 
c.  A requestor may obtain only one (1) administrative adjustment due to an individual financial hardship in any twelve-month period. 
(5)  Medical condition. Where any resident of the property has a medical condition that requires the provision of the utility service and additional time is needed to fully pay all amounts due on the account for such service, the requestor may obtain an administrative adjustment that extends (for a maximum of six (6) months) the period in which the requestor may remit to the city the full amount due under a utility service account. The administrator may grant an administrative adjustment due to such medical condition under the following terms: 
a.  The requestor can obtain only an extension of the time in which to pay and cannot obtain a reduction of any charge (other than penalties assessed under section 10-5(c)). 
b.  The requestor must submit to the administrator written documentation from a medical provider explaining the need for the provision of such utility service due to the resident's medical condition. 
c.  The requestor must submit to the administrator written documentation or other evidence establishing the ability to pay future utility service charges as they become due. 
This subsection applies only where the utility service is provided to a single family residential property or a multiple unit residential property for which the utility service is furnished through the use of a separate meter for each unit. 
(b)  The administrator may not grant an administrative adjustment where the written request for such adjustment is not delivered within the period specified in subsection (a)(1). 
(1)  The time limitation in subsection (a)(1) shall not apply where the requestor rebuts the presumption in section 10-5(e)(2) and the administrator determines the requestor did not actually receive the bill showing the charge for which an adjustment is sought. 
(2)  Notwithstanding subsection (b)(1), the administrator shall have no authority to consider an administrative adjustment to any charge where the written request for such adjustment is delivered more than three (3) months after the date of the bill initially showing the charge for which the adjustment is sought. 
(c)  Extension of due date based on a request for an administrative adjustment. 
(1)  Except as provided in subsection (c)(2) of this section, the submission of a written request for an administrative adjustment does not automatically extend the due date for the full payment of all charges and assessments shown on a bill or relieve the requestor from the monetary obligation for any such charge or assessment. Notwithstanding a pending written adjustment request, the failure to timely remit full payment for all charges and assessments shown on a bill shall be grounds for the involuntary discontinuance of utility service under section 10-13(b). The administrator has the discretion to waive the requirements of this subsection and to set a new due date for the full payment. 
(2)  Where the written request for an administrative adjustment is sought under subsection (a)(4) or (a)(5) of this section, the due date for the full payment of all charges and assessments for the adjustment is sought shall be automatically extended until seven (7) days after the date the administrator's decision on the request. The administrator has the discretion to grant a further extension, to set a schedule for the payment of the full amount due, or to set a new due date for the full payment. 
(d)  Upon the submission of a written request for an administrative adjustment that is timely under subsection (a) or (b), the administrator shall review such request and shall have the power to make such further investigation into the circumstances of the request as he deems appropriate. The administrator shall render a decision on the request no later than thirty (30) days after the date he receives the written request. In the event the administrator determines that an adjustment is warranted, he may: 
(1)  Make an adjustment of any charge or assessment on the bill for any of the reasons identified in subsection (a)(2) to ensure the amount of the bill is based on actual usage; 
(2)  If applicable, determine the amount of any necessary credits toward a future charge or assessment for an excess monies received pursuant to subsection (c); 
(3)  If applicable, establish a schedule for the payment of all outstanding balances; and 
(4)  If applicable, waive accumulated interest and penalties. 
The decision of the administrator under this subsection shall be dated, in writing, and delivered to the requestor at the mailing address shown in the city's records. 
(Ord. No. 2018-11, § 1(Exh. A), 11-19-18) 
Sec. 10-13. - Discontinuance of utility service. 
(a)  Voluntary discontinuance of utility service. A person or entity who is fully liable to the city for all obligations arising from the provision of any utility service, may discontinue the provision of such service by giving written notice to the city that contains the requesting party's name, mailing address and telephone number; the address at which the service is provided and for which discontinuance is sought; and the desired date upon which such service is to be discontinued. Discontinuance shall not relieve the requesting party of the obligation to fully pay any amounts due under the account or distinguish any claim held by the city or any lien imposed for any past due, unpaid amounts owed for the service, monthly service charges, connection fees, meter installation fees or any other charge under the account. Subsequent to such discontinuance, the provision of the utility service may be re-established only in compliance with section 10-3. 
(b)  Involuntary discontinuance of utility service-Failure to timely pay. 
(1)  In general. Whenever the owner or the user of any property provided any utility service by the city is notified of the amount of any charge or assessment due for the provision of such service by the inclusion of such amount on the bill required by section 10-5(a) and fails to remit to the city monies to fully satisfy said amount by 11:59 p.m. on the seventh (7 th ) calendar day after the past due date shown on such bill, the city shall have the immediate right to discontinue such utility service to the property. After the inclusion of such amount on a bill sent to the address on record of the owner or user of the property, the city shall have no obligation to provide such owner or user additional notice of its intent to discontinue the provision of the utility service. This subsection shall not apply to the provision of water or sewer service to any multiple unit residential property to which water is furnished through a single water meter for the entire property. 
(2)  Multiple unit residential property. Whenever the owner of any multiple unit residential property to which water or sewer service is provided to the entire property through a single water meter is notified of any charge or assessment due for the provision of such service by the inclusion of such amount on the bill required by section 10-5(a) and fails to remit to the city monies to fully satisfy said amount by 11:59 p.m. on the seventh (7 th ) calendar day after the past due date shown on such bill, the city shall have the right to discontinue the provision of water and sewer service to the property subject to the requirements stated in this subsection. 
a.  After the inclusion of such amount on a bill sent to the address on record of the owner of such property, the city shall have no obligation to provide such owner additional notice of its intent to discontinue the provision of water and sewer service to the property. 
b.  Ten (10) calendar days prior to the discontinuance of such water and sewer services, the city shall provide notice to the occupants of said multiple unit residential property of its intent to discontinue such service by (i) the placement of a sign on the property in a readily visible location stating the date the service will be discontinued and the reason for such action; or (ii) written notice delivered to each unit stating the date the service will be discontinued and the reason for such action. 
(3)  The city shall impose the fee or fees provided in section 10-9 on any account for which utility service has been disconnected under subsection (b)(1) or (b)(2) herein. 
(4)  After the discontinuance of any utility service under this subsection, the city may refuse to reestablish the provision of such service to the property (including any building or premises located thereon) until all outstanding, past due amounts and any fees imposed under subsection (b)(3) have been remitted to the city. This subsection shall not apply to the provision of water to any single or multi-family residential property for which water is furnished through the use of a separate water meter for each residential unit thereon where the indebtedness to the city was incurred by a prior owner, occupant, or lessee for water services previously furnished to the property. 
(5)  After the discontinuance of any utility service to any property under this subsection, the city shall immediately re-establish the provision of such service to the property and impose no fees, penalties or interest under this article if the following conditions are met: 
a.  The person or entity who is fully liable for all monetary or other obligations incurred on the account for such service rebuts the presumption in section 10-5(e)(2); 
b.  The administrator determines said person or entity did not actually receive the bill for the account showing the unpaid charges that caused the discontinuance; and 
c.  No more than thirty (30) consecutive days have transpired since the date of discontinuance of such utility service. 
(c)  Involuntary discontinuance-Other grounds. 
(1)  In addition to the grounds stated in subsection (b), the city shall have the right to discontinue the provision of a utility service to any property for any of the following grounds: 
a.  A violation of any provision of this chapter or any other provision in the Code of Ordinances; 
b.  A violation of any rule or regulation pertaining to such utility service; 
c.  The unauthorized tampering, molesting or altering of any meter, seal or other equipment used by the city to control or regulate the supply of such utility service; 
d.  Failure of the owner or user of the property to protect the connection, service lines and fixtures located on such property for the provision of such utility service; 
e.  In the event of vacancy of the premises; 
f.  As to water services, insufficiency of water supply due to circumstances beyond the city's control; 
g.  Upon the direction of county, state or federal authorities that such utility service be discontinued to the property; or 
h.  Non-usage of such utility service by the property for more than sixty (60) consecutive days; or 
(2)  No less than seven (7) calendar days prior to the discontinuance of the provision of a utility service to any property for a ground stated in subsection (c)(1)a., b., c., d., e., f. and j., the city shall provide notice to the owner and the user of such property of its intent to disconnect such service by: (i) written correspondence delivered to said owner; or (ii) the placement of a sign in a readily visible location on the property. The notice shall identify the date the service will be discontinued, state the reason for such action, and inform the owner and the user of the right to request a hearing before the administrator upon the matter. 
(3)  The owner or the user of the property for which the city intends to discontinue utility service for a ground stated in subsection (c)(1) may seek a hearing before the administrator on the matter by delivering a written request for such hearing to the administrator no later than seven (7) calendar days after the date of the notice provided in subsection (c)(2). In the event that a timely written request for a hearing is delivered, the city shall take no further action to discontinue the utility service until after the administrator issues a written decision on the matter. 
(4)  Upon the timely filing of a written request for a hearing under subsection (c)(3), the administrator shall hold such hearing as soon as possible. The administrator shall hear the disputes or issues, consider any relevant testimony or evidence, and issue a written decision as to whether or not the subject utility service should be discontinued. A copy of the written decision shall be delivered to the owner or the user who requested the hearing. 
(5)  After the discontinuance of any utility service under this subsection, the city may refuse to reestablish the provision of such service to the property (including any building or premises located thereon) until the person requesting such reestablishment provides to the city documentation proving that the circumstances which resulted in the discontinuance no longer exist. The city shall provide written notice to the requesting party of its decision on granting or refusing to reestablish such utility service. The requesting party may seek a hearing before the administrator on that decision by delivering a written request for such hearing no later than seven (7) calendar days after the notice. The procedures set forth in subsection (c)(4) shall apply to a timely written request for such hearing. 
(d)  Temporary discontinuance of water or sewer services by the city. The city shall have the right to temporarily discontinue water or sewer service to any property in any of the following situations: 
(1)  Under exigent circumstances (including, but not limited to, an emergency); 
(2)  Whenever such discontinuance is necessary for repairs; or 
(3)  Whenever such discontinuance is necessary to protect life, health or property from an immediate threat; 
In the event water or sewer service is temporarily discontinued under this subsection, the city shall not be liable on any claim arising therefrom for: (i) any damage to real or personal property; (ii) any inconvenience; (iii) any interruption in service; (iv) lessening of the water supply; (v) inadequate water pressure; (vi) quality of water; or (vii) the flow (or the lack of flow) of wastewater. 
(e)  Temporary discontinuance of utility service at the request of the customer. In the event the provision of any utility service is temporarily discontinued by the city at the request of the occupant of the property for which such service is provided or at the request of the person or entity who is fully liable for all monetary or other obligations arising from the provision of such service, a charge shall be imposed upon the account for such service in an amount set by the mayor and council, from time to time, by resolution. Any request to discontinue a utility service for more than three (3) calendar days shall be treated as a request for voluntarily discontinuance under subsection (a). 
(Ord. No. 2018-11, § 1(Exh. A), 11-19-18) 
Sec. 10-14. - Discontinuance, suspension or transfer of utility service within thirty days after initiation of service. 
    In the event that the provision of any utility service is initiated to any rental unit in a multiple unit residential building and, within thirty (30) days after such initiation, the provision of the utility service is discontinued, suspended or transferred to another rental unit, a fee shall be imposed upon the person or entity who submitted the application for such service. The fee shall be in an amount as determined by resolution of the mayor and council. This subsection shall not apply to the provision of a utility service to any multiple unit residential property for which said service is provided to the entire property through a single meter. 
(Ord. No. 2018-11, § 1(Exh. A), 11-19-18) 
Sec. 10-15. - Appeal of administrator's decision. 
(a)  Any person or entity who is aggrieved by a decision of the administrator rendered under section 10-3, section 10-12, section 10-13(c)(4) or section 10-13(c)(5) may appeal such decision to the city manager or his/her designee by delivering a written notice of appeal to the city clerk within five (5) calendar days after the date of the administrator's decision. In the event that no appeal is made within said five-day period, the decision of the administrator shall be final. 
(b)  In the event a timely notice of appeal is delivered, the city manager shall review the documentation and other evidence considered by the administrator, any additional relevant documentation and other evidence provided by the appellant or contained in the city's records, and shall issue a written decision affirming or reversing the appealed ruling. The city manager's decision on the matter shall be final. 
(c)  The city shall take no further action to discontinue or suspend the provision of the utility service that the appeal concerns until ten (10) calendar days after the date the city manager issues the written decision. 
(Ord. No. 2018-11, § 1(Exh. A), 11-19-18) 
Secs. 10-16-10-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ELECTRICITY 

Sec. 10-20. - Connection charges. 
(a)  For each new customer of the electrical system or where the service is rebuilt or relocated for the convenience of or at the request of the customer, the following connection charges shall be levied: 
(1)  Where both the meter and receptacle are furnished by the city, the charge shall be as determined by resolution of the mayor and council. 
(2)  Where the receptacle is furnished by the customer and the meter is furnished by the city, the connection charge shall be as determined by resolution of the mayor and council. 
(3)  Where neither an additional meter nor receptacle is furnished by the city, the cost for rebuilding or changing of a customer's individual service facilities for the customer's convenience or at customer's request shall be as determined by resolution of the mayor and council. 
(4)  The city shall furnish the meter and the customer shall furnish the receptacle, unless otherwise approved by the mayor and council. 
(5)  Charges made for normal maintenance or repair associated with the individual customer's service due to normal wear and aging shall be as determined by resolution of the mayor and council, provided that such repairs are acknowledged by the city as part of the city's normal maintenance responsibility. 
(6)  For three (3) phase services, additional increases in the above charges shall be as determined by resolution of the mayor and council. 
(7)  Charges with respect to any business located in the city for any subsequent relocation requiring the same size meter and receptacle shall be as determined by resolution of the mayor and council. 
(b)  The preceding charge shall provide partial reimbursement to the city for material, labor, equipment and overhead costs associated with provision of new or revised customer service installations on the customer's property or immediately adjacent thereto. Except as provided in paragraph (a)(3) where additional service line must be provided, this charge is not intended to cover any portion of service line, distribution, transmission, transformer, or substation construction or maintenance costs. 
(c)  All electrical meters shall be the sole property of the city and complete ownership and control of the meter shall be vested in the city. The city reserves the right in the event of actual or threatened power failure or safety hazard to make repairs of a permanent or temporary nature on meter receptacles and no receptacle shall be tampered with or altered in a manner as to affect the safety, convenience, adequacy of service or the accuracy of metering service in any manner, direct or indirect. 
(d)  Where any material or work associated with the customer's service installation is provided by the customer, such material or work shall conform to specifications and requirements set by the city, so that the public health, safety, convenience and welfare may be protected. 
(e)  The charges specified herein shall be in addition to any other charges presently levied for or provision of underground electrical service. 
(f)  Temporary electrical service. 
(1)  Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, all customers or contractors requesting temporary electrical service shall pay to the city one hundred (100) per cent of the cost prior to installation by the city. 
(2)  In the event of the construction of a single-family residential home, construction of which is being performed on behalf of the owner who intends to occupy such home, all customers or contractors requesting temporary electrical service shall pay to the city only the connection fee for such service, provided that the temporary service can be extended and utilized fully as the connection for permanent service. If the temporary service cannot be extended and utilized fully for the connection of permanent service, all customers or contractors requesting temporary electrical service shall pay to the city one hundred (100) per cent of the cost of the temporary electrical service and the connection fee for such service prior to installation of the city. 
(Code 1963, § 22-22; Ord. No. 85-5, 3-18-85; Ord. No. 96-01, § 1, 1-16-96; Ord. No. 2010-24, § 7, 6-21-10) 
Sec. 10-21. - Meter placement. 
    All electric meters shall be installed on the exterior of the building at a height and in a location so as to make the meter accessible for reading. No meter shall be enclosed within an area so as to prohibit reading without the presence of the owner or occupant. No meter shall be placed or maintained within any area where vicious dogs or other animals may prohibit the reading of the meter. In the event any meter is installed or maintained in violation of the above, and the meter cannot be read on two (2) consecutive regular reading dates, the city may, after thirty (30) days' notice to the owner and occupant, install a meter at the expense of the consumer. 
(Code 1963, § 22-23) 
Sec. 10-22. - Monthly rates-Residential. 
    The schedule of monthly electric rates and service charges, including adjustments for fuel costs and wholesale costs and adjustments for multiple units served by a single meter, in respect to electricity supplied by the electrical system of the city for residential use and for use incidental thereto shall be as fixed from time-to-time by resolution of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1963, § 22-18; Ord. No. 84-10, § a, 6-25-84; Ord. No. 86-22, §§ A, B, 7-7-86; Ord. No. 88-11, § 19, 5-2-88; Ord. No. 2010-24, § 8, 6-21-10) 
Sec. 10-23. - Same-General service. 
    The schedule of electric rates and service charges, including adjustments for fuel costs and wholesale costs and adjustments, in respect to electricity supplied by the electrical system of the city for all electric service of one standard secondary voltage required on customer's premises, delivered at one point and metered at or compensated to the voltage shall be as fixed from time to time by resolution of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1963, § 22-19; Ord. No. 84-10, §§ b, c, 6-25-84; Ord. No. 86-22, §§ C-F, 7-7-86; Ord. No. 88-11, § 20, 5-2-88; Ord. No. 90-23, § 1, 12-10-90; Ord. No. 2010-24, § 9, 6-21-10) 
Sec. 10-24. - Inspection of rates by public. 
    All current rates, charges and fees shall be maintained on file in the office of the city clerk where they shall be available for public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 2010-24, § 10, 6-21-10) 
Editor's note- Prior to the reenactment of section 10-24 by Ord. No. 2010-24, Ord. No. 88-11, § 21, adopted May 2, 1988, repealed section 10-24, pertaining to monthly industrial electricity rates, which derived from Code 1963, § 22-20. 
Sec. 10-25. - Monthly rates; sales tax not included. 
    The state sales tax in the amount prescribed by law is not included in the rate and charges established in this article. 
(Code 1963, § 22-21) 
State Law reference- Sales tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-8-1 et seq. 
Sec. 10-26. - Tampering with electrical metering devices. 
(a)  For purposes of this section, "Electrical Metering Device" includes but is not limited to electric meters, meter bases, meter base covers, meter locks, meter seals, and switch gears. 
(b)  "Tampering" with electrical metering devices provided by the city includes but is not limited to the following situations and is therefore prohibited: 
(1)  Obtaining or the restoration of electrical service by any means after such service has been terminated for nonpayment. 
(2)  Obtaining electrical service without making the proper deposit with the city, or without receiving proper authorization from the city to receive such services. 
(3)  Obtaining electrical service by any means which bypasses the electrical metering device, either partially or completely. 
(4)  Obtaining electrical service by use of an electrical metering device which is not authorized and installed by the city. 
(5)  Obtaining, or attempting to obtain, electrical service by using a false name or identification. 
(6)  Obtaining, or attempting to obtain, electrical service by placing the account in another person's name, after the service has been disconnected for nonpayment or theft of service, while the person in default or violation continues to reside at the location of the service. 
(7)  Cutting, removing, or in any manner making ineffective, any seal, locking band or lock on an electrical metering device. 
(8)  Damaging or tampering in any manner with any part of an electrical metering device belonging to the city. 
(9)  Changing or altering the normal installed position of an electrical metering device in any fashion which causes the normal accurate recording of electrical service received to be altered and/or inaccurate. 
(10)  Interfering with the automatic registration, recording and transmission of electrical consumption when readings are recorded and/or transmitted electronically. 
(c)  Any evidence of the violation of any provision of this section shall result in immediate disconnection of electrical service and a tampering fee of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per incident. 
(d)  A violation of any provision of this section shall be a separate and distinct offense, in addition to any other violation that may be established. 
(e)  Any person found in violation of any provision in this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine or imprisonment, as prescribed in section 1-8 of this Code. Any person found in violation of any provision in this section shall be required to make full restitution to the city for the cost of the electrical services illegally obtained, for damage to equipment of the city, if applicable, and for all costs associated with the investigation of the violation. In calculating the amount of restitution to be paid, the court will be asked to consider the following evidence: 
(1)  The cost of the electrical service received at the prevailing rate. 
(2)  The current cost to repair or replace the damaged equipment, if applicable. 
(3)  The hourly rate of the code enforcement officer and time spent investigating the violation, together with any other costs associated with the investigation. 
(f)  Disconnected electrical service shall not be restored until all applicable fees, restitution, and/or fines are paid in full. If electrical service is disconnected due to tampering with meter bases or wires connecting meter bases to the premises, electrical service shall not be restored until such meter base and/or such wiring is repaired by the owner of the premises. 
(g)  This section shall be cumulative to the O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25, and is enacted pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25(c). 
(Ord. No. 2016-10, § 1, 4-4-16) 
Sec. 10-27. - Electric rates; outside the city. 
    The schedule of electric rates and service charges, including adjustments for fuel costs and wholesale costs and adjustments in respect to electricity supplied by the electric system of the city to customers outside of the corporate limits of the City of College Park shall be determined by resolution of the mayor and council. Should any customers of the city electric service subject to the rates outlined in this section be subsequently annexed into the city limits of the City of College Park, the rates levied against said customers shall change to the rate schedule as outlined in section 10-22(a) of this Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 87-25, § 1, 8-17-87; Ord. No. 88-3, § 1, 2-1-88; Ord. No. 2010-24, § 11, 6-21-10) 
Sec. 10-28. - All other rates, fees and charges. 
    All other rates, service charges, and fees of the power department shall be determined by resolution of the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 2010-24, § 12, 6-21-10) 
Sec. 10-29. - Liability for tampering. 
(a)  Any person in possession of any premises as owner is strictly liable for any violations of section 10-26 on the premises. 
(b)  Any person in possession of any premises as owner, occupant, or tenant where a violation of section 10-26 has occurred shall be presumed to have knowledge of such violation and is individually liable for such violation. Further, the owner, occupant and tenant of the premises are jointly liable for such violation. 
(c)  The receipt of electrical services in violation of any provision of section 10-26 shall be deemed prima facie evidence of intent to defraud or deprive the city from recovering proper payment for such service. 
(Ord. No. 2016-10, § 2, 4-4-16) 
ARTICLE III. - WATER[2]

Sec. 10-30. - Installation of water mains-Charge in subdivisions. 
    When any land shall be subdivided within the city and application is made for the installation of water mains to serve the same, such applicant shall be charged and the city shall be paid the actual cost for pipe, labor and materials installed in such subdivision by the city pursuant to such application. No water main shall be installed in such subdivision until the applicant has deposited with the city clerk a deposit at the rate of three dollars ($3.00) per lineal foot estimated to be used in the installation. On completion of the installation, the deposit shall be applied to the payment of the actual cost of installation with the applicant receiving a refund if the actual cost be less than three dollars ($3.00) per lineal foot and the applicant shall pay to the city the excess if the actual cost exceeds three dollars ($3.00) per lineal foot. 
(Code 1963, § 22-50) 
Sec. 10-31. - Same-Authorized installers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person other than city employees, or agents or contractors of the city, to lay any water main in any street within the city. 
(Code 1963, § 22-51) 
Sec. 10-32. - Connection charges-Inside the city. 
(a)  Schedule. The schedule of charges for water connections to the water system of the city shall be determined by resolution of the mayor and council. 
(b)  Time for payment. Prior to the laying of a proposed water main into a subdivision or along a street or proposed street subsequently to be paved or resurfaced, the owner of each property lot along the proposed water main extension shall pay in advance the cost of a water stub to such person's lot. The charge for the meter shall be paid upon application for a building permit to build upon any lot for which the water stub has been paid. 
(c)  Multiple dwellings. A single meter may be installed for use of a multiple dwelling having three (3) or more units, the size of said meter to be determined by the city engineer, and charges therefor to be made in accordance with subsection (a).

(a)  Schedule. The schedule of charges of water connections to the water system of the city outside the city limits shall be determined by resolution of the mayor and council. 
(b)  Multiple dwellings. In multiple dwelling units, in excess of three (3) dwelling units, a single water meter may be installed, the size to be determined by the city engineer, and charges to be made in accordance with subsection (a). 
(Code 1963, § 22-48; Ord. No. 86-28, § 2, 9-2-86; Ord. No. 2010-24, § 14, 6-21-10) 
Sec. 10-34. - Same-Charges for cutting into streets and sidewalks. 
(a)  Where the street right-of-way is twenty-five (25) feet or more, additional water connection charges shall be determined by a resolution of the mayor and council. 
(b)  In new subdivisions or developments where no existing street or sidewalk is directly involved, as determined by the city engineer, only the minimum charges shall be made. 
(Code 1963, § 22-49; Ord. No. 2010-24, § 15, 6-21-10) 
Sec. 10-35. - Fire protection system-Connection; approval. 
    No automatic fire sprinkler system or private fire hydrant for fire protection shall be connected to the city water system until application therefor has been made to and approved by the city engineer, building official and fire chief. 
(Code 1963, § 22-67) 
Cross reference- Rates and charges, § 10-40. 
Sec. 10-36. - Same-Misuse of water. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use or cause to be used any water through an automatic sprinkler system or any fixtures, pipes, or other parts thereof or through the pipe connecting such system to the city water system, or to private fire hydrants for any purpose except extinguishing a fire on the premises where such system is located and the necessary testing of such equipment to maintain same in good working order. 
(b)  Any fire protection water service line connected to the city water system must be installed with an approved detection check device. The installation of said device shall be subject to the approval of the building official, public works director and fire chief. 
(c)  The metering device on the detection check installation required by paragraph (b) of this section shall be read to determine water consumption on a regular basis. Any indication of water consumption on detection check equipment shall be presumed by the city to be for non-fire protection related purposes and the customer shall be billed for any such consumption at four (4) times the currently established water rate. 
(Code 1963, § 22-68; Ord. No. 87-33, §§ 1, 2, 11-16-87) 
Sec. 10-37. - Water rates. 
    The council shall by resolution fix rates for which water shall be furnished for all purposes within the area served by the city water system. Water rates shall be sufficient to pay for the operation, maintenance, reserves, debt service, additions, extensions and betterments of the water system, including those reasonably required for the anticipated growth of the area served, and should also be sufficient to provide for the accumulation of reserves for improvements that cannot be acquired from a single year's receipts. 
(Code 1963, § 22-52; Ord. No. 86-20, 6-30-86; Ord. No. 87-21, § 1, 6-15-87; Ord. No. 88-16, § 1, 7-5-88; Ord. No. 90-17, § 1, 7-16-90; Ord. No. 92-8, § 1, 5-20-92; Ord. No. 2000-19, § 1, 6-29-00; Ord. No. 2000-39, § 1, 9-18-00; Ord. No. 2002-01, § 1, 1-7-02; Ord. No. 2003-27, § 1, 1-6-03; Ord. No. 04-20, § 1, 7-6-04; Ord. No. 2005-17, § 1, 7-18-05; Ord. No. 2005-17B, § 1, 8-15-05; Ord. No. 2006-23, § 1, 7-17-06; Ord. No. 2009-14, § 1, 8-3-09) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2009-14, § 1, adopted August 3, 2009, changed the title of section 10-37 from "Water rates-Within the city" to "Water rates." 
Sec. 10-38. - Same-Outside the city. 
    For water furnished to users beyond the corporate limits of the city there is hereby fixed and established net water rates and charges in an amount of one and one-half (11/2) times the rates and charges designated for users within the city limits. 
(Code 1963, § 22-53) 
Sec. 10-39. - Same-Minimum for multiple dwellings. 
(a)  Reserved. 
(b)  Special rates. In instances where exceptional circumstances such as the quantity used, the location to be served, the number of meters and the like, exist, special rates suitable to the particular circumstances shall be fixed. In situations where more than one (1) meter serves one (1) building, the several meters may be treated as one (1), for reading, billing, accounting and service. 
(c)  Special rates. In instances where exceptional circumstances such as the quantity used, the location to be served, the number of meters and the like, exist, special rates suitable to the particular circumstances shall be fixed. In situations where more than one meter serves one building, the several meters may be treated as one, for reading, billing, accounting and service. 
(Code 1963, § 22-54; Ord. No. 86-20, 6-3-86; Ord. No. 87-21, §§ 2, 3, 6-15-87; Ord. No. 88-15, §§ 2, 3, 7-5-88; Ord. No. 90-17, §§ 2, 3, 7-16-90; Ord. No. 92-8, §§ 2, 3, 5-20-92; Ord. No. 2000-39, § 2, 9-18-00; Ord. No. 2006-23, § 2, 7-17-06; Ord. No. 2009-14, § 2, 8-3-09) 
Sec. 10-40. - Same-Fire protection systems. 
    The rates and charges for automatic sprinkler systems or private fire hydrants for fire protection, where such systems are connected to the water system of the city, shall be established by resolution of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1963, § 22-66; Ord. No. 2010-24, § 16, 6-21-10) 
Sec. 10-41. - Use of water when supply is low; authority of mayor. 
(a)  Authority of mayor. Whenever the mayor finds as a matter of fact that an emergency exists in the city on account of the lack of sufficient water for the safety of the city and its inhabitants, such official may issue a proclamation, in which proclamation reasonable restrictions on the use of water shall be imposed. 
    Such restrictions may include but not be limited to the prohibition of the use of water by hose or automatic sprinkling device for the purpose of sprinkling or watering outside plant material, such as lawns, vegetable and flower gardens, plants and trees during certain days of the week and/or during certain hours of the day. Such restrictions shall apply evenly to all premises served by the City of College Park water system, including residences, businesses, private and governmental institutions; provided that the proclamation may except from the general restrictions those businesses such as car washes, nurseries, and similar facilities, which depend upon greater amounts of water supply for their livelihood. 
(b)  Effect of proclamation. When such proclamation by the mayor shall have been issued and said restrictions imposed, it shall be unlawful for any one in the city to water lawns or wash automobiles with water from the city's water system, or to use water for any purpose other than essential purposes until such emergency has passed and a proclamation to this effect shall have been issued by the mayor. 
    The City of College Park is hereby authorized and directed to monitor compliance with any restrictions imposed pursuant to subsection (a) of this section and to issue citations for violation thereof. Conviction of a violation of any restriction imposed under this section shall be treated as follows: 
(1)  The first time a customer or consumer violates the above restrictions shall result in an issuance of a violation or citation. A first violation or first citation issued under this paragraph shall result in a one hundred dollar ($100.00) fine. 
(2)  The second time that a customer or consumer violates the above restriction shall result in a second issuance of a violation or citation. A second violation or second citation issued under this paragraph shall result in a five hundred dollar ($500.00) fine. 
(3)  Upon issuance of a third citation or violation, water service shall be terminated to the premises where noncompliance occurred. Said water service shall be restored at the request of the customer or consumer upon payment of an additional one thousand dollar ($1,000.00) fine which fine includes a charge to cover the operations and administrative costs of restoring service. 
(4)  In the case of multi-unit residential dwellings known to be served by a single meter, water service shall not be terminated unless and until written notification is given to the person in whose name the water bill is issued, that the procedures stated in subparagraphs (1), (2) and (3) above apply. 
(c)  [Appeal.] Any person aggrieved or affected by any decision hereunder may appeal to the mayor and council of the City of College Park for relief or reconsideration of such decision. 
(d)  [Modification or cancellation of restrictions.] The mayor may modify or cancel the above restrictions the above restrictions or add additional restrictions from time to time as the emergency conditions affecting the water system may worsen or abate. 
(Code 1963, § 22-32; Ord. No. 88-21, §§ 1-3, 8-15-88; Ord. No. 2007-29, § 1, 11-5-07) 
Sec. 10-42. - Tampering with water metering devices. 
(a)  For purposes of this section, "Water Metering Device" includes but is not limited to water meters, valves, pipes and conduits belonging to the city and part of its waterworks system. 
(b)  "Tampering" with water metering devices provided by the city includes but is not limited to the following situations and is therefore prohibited: 
(1)  Obtaining or the restoration of water service by any means after such service has been terminated for nonpayment. 
(2)  Obtaining water service without making the proper deposit with the city, or without receiving proper authorization from the city to receive such services. 
(3)  Obtaining water service by any means which bypasses the water metering device, either partially or completely. 
(4)  Obtaining water service by use of a water metering device which is not authorized and installed by the city. 
(5)  Obtaining, or attempting to obtain, water service by using a false name or identification. 
(6)  Obtaining, or attempting to obtain, water service by placing the account in another person's name, after the service has been disconnected for nonpayment or theft of service, while the person in default or violation continues to reside at the location of the service. 
(7)  Cutting, removing, or in any manner, making ineffective any seal, locking band or lock on a water metering device. 
(8)  Damaging or tampering in any manner with any part of a water metering device belonging to the city. 
(9)  Changing or altering the normal installed position of a water metering device in any fashion which causes the normal accurate recording of water service received to be altered and inaccurate. 
(10)  Interfering with the automatic registration, recording and transmission of water consumption when readings are recorded and/or transmitted electronically. 
(c)  Any person in possession of any premises as owner, occupant, or tenant where such violation has occurred shall be presumed to have knowledge of such violation. The receipt of water services in violation of any provision of this section shall be deemed prima facie evidence of intent to defraud or deprive the city from recovering proper payment for such service. 
(d)  Any evidence of the violation of any provision of this section shall result in a tampering fee of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per incident. 
(e)  A violation of any provision of this section shall be a separate and distinct offense, in addition to any other violation that may be established. 
(f)  Any person found in violation of any provision in this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine or imprisonment, as prescribed in section 1-8 of this Code. Any person found in violation of any provision in this section shall be required to make full restitution to the city for the cost of the water services illegally obtained, for damage to equipment of the city, and for all costs associated with the investigation. In calculating the amount of restitution to be paid, the court will be asked to consider the following evidence: 
(1)  The cost of the water service received at the prevailing rate. 
(2)  The current cost to repair or replace the damaged equipment, if applicable. 
(3)  The hourly rate of the code enforcement officer and time spent investigating, together with any other costs associated with the investigation. 
(g)  Disconnected water service shall not be restored until all applicable fees, restitution, and/or fines are paid in full. 
(h)  This section shall be cumulative to the O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25, and is enacted pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25(c). 
(Code 1963, § 22-1(b); Ord. No. 2016-11, § 1, 4-4-16) 
Sec. 10-43. - Cross-connections, auxiliary intakes, by-passes and interconnections. 
(a)  Definitions. 
(1)  Public water supply. The waterworks system furnishing water to the City of College Park for general use and which supply is recognized as the public water supply by the Georgia Department of Natural Resources/Environmental Protection Division. 
(2)  Cross-connection. Any physical connection whereby the public water supply is connected with any other water supply system, whether public or private, either inside or outside of any building or buildings, in such manner that a flow of water into the public water supply is possible either through the manipulation of valves, or because of ineffective check or back-pressure valves or because of any other arrangement. 
(3)  Auxiliary intake. Any piping connection or other device whereby water may be secured from a source other than that normally used. 
(4)  By-pass. Any system of piping or other arrangement whereby the water may be diverted around any part or portion of a water purification plant. 
(5)  Inter-connection. Any system of piping or other arrangement whereby the public water supply is connected directly with a sewer, drain, conduit, pool, storage reservoir, or other device which does or may contain sewage or other waste or liquid which would be capable of imparting contamination to the public water supply. 
(b)  The City of College Park public water supply shall comply with Chapter 391-3-5-.13 of Georgia Rules for Safe Drinking Water and (PL 93-523) of the Federal Safe Drinking Water Act, which pertain to control of undesirable cross-connections and other unauthorized installations. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cause a cross-connection, auxiliary intake, by-pass or inter-connection to be made with the public water supply system; or to allow such a condition to exist for any purpose. 
(d)  Any person whose premises are supplied with water from the public water supply, and who has on the same premises a separate source of water supply or stores water in an uncovered or unsanitary storage reservoir from which the water stored therein is circulated through a piping system, shall file with the public works director a statement of the non-existence of unapproved or unauthorized cross-connections, auxiliary intakes, by-pass, or inter-connections. Such statement shall also contain an agreement that no cross-connection, auxiliary intake, by-pass, or inter-connection will be permitted upon the premises. 
(e)  The public works department shall cause inspections to be made of all properties served by the public water supply where cross-connections with the public water supply are deemed possible. The frequency of inspections and re-inspections based on potential health hazards involved shall be as established by the public works director. 
(f)  The public works director or authorized representative shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time, any property served by a connection to the public water supply of the city for the purpose of inspecting the piping system or systems thereof for cross-connections, auxiliary intakes, by-passes, or inter-connections. On request, the owner, lessee, or occupant of any property so served shall furnish to the inspector any pertinent information regarding the piping system or systems on such property. The refusal of such information or refusal of access, when requested, shall be deemed a violation of this section. 
(g)  Any person who now has cross-connections, auxiliary intakes, by-passes, or inter-connections in violation of the provisions of this section shall be allowed thirty (30) days within which to comply with the provisions of this section. Violations of this section discovered after a thorough investigation of existing conditions and an appraisal of the time required to complete the work, shall be corrected within such time as shall be designated by the public works director. 
(h)  Where the nature of use of the water supplied a premises by the city is such that it is deemed: 
(1)  Impractical to provide an effective air-gap separation; 
(2)  That the owner and/or occupant of the premises cannot or is not willing to demonstrate to the official in charge of the system, or his designated representative, that the water use and protective features of the plumbing are such as to pose no threat to the safety or potability of the water supply; 
(3)  That the nature and mode of operation within a premises are such that frequent alterations are made to the plumbing; or 
(4)  There is a likelihood that protective measures may be subverted, altered, or disconnected; then the public works director, or his designated representative, shall require the use of an approved protective device on the service line serving the premises to assure that any contamination that may originate in the customer's premises is contained therein. The protective device shall be a reduced pressure zone type backflow preventer approved by the public works director as to manufacturer, model, and size. The method of installation of backflow protective devices shall be approved by the public works director prior to installation and shall comply with the criteria set forth by the public works director. 
(i)  The installation of all backflow prevention devices and other protective measures shall be at the expense of the owner or occupant of the premises on existing service lines. 
(j)  The department of public works shall have the right to inspect and test on an annual basis or whenever deemed necessary by the public works director or his designated representative. Water service shall not be disrupted to test the device without the knowledge of the occupant of the premises. 
(k)  Where the use of water is critical to the continuance of normal operations or protection of life, property, or equipment, duplicate units shall be provided to avoid the necessity of discontinuing water service to test or repair the protective device or devices. Where only one (1) unit is installed and the continuance of service is critical, the public works director shall notify, in writing, the occupant of the premises of plans to discontinue water service and arrange for a mutually acceptable time to test and/or repair the device. The public works director or authorized representative shall require the occupant of the premises to make all repairs indicated promptly, and the expense of such repairs shall be the responsibility of the owner or occupant of the premises. These repairs shall be made by qualified personnel, acceptable to the director of public works. 
(l)  The potable water supply made available on properties served by the public water supply shall be protected from possible contamination as provided in this section. Any water outlet which could be used for potable or domestic purposes and which is not supplied by the potable system must be labeled in a conspicuous manner as: 
  
  
WATER UNSAFE 
  
FOR DRINKING 
  
   
Minimum acceptable signs shall have black letters one (1) inch high, located on a red background. 
(m)  Any person who neglects or refuses to comply with any of the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of an offense and, upon conviction therefor, shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), and each day's continued violation after conviction shall constitute a separate offense. In addition to the foregoing fines and penalties, the public works director shall discontinue the public water supply service at any premises upon which there is found to be a cross-connection, auxiliary intake, by-pass, or inter-connection, and service shall not be restored until such cross-connection, auxiliary intake, by-pass, or inter-connection has been discontinued. 
(2001-13, § 1, 3-19-01) 
Sec. 10-44. - Permissible hours for outdoor landscape watering. 
(a)  Persons may irrigate outdoors daily for purposes of planting, growing, managing, or maintaining ground cover, trees, shrubs, or other plants only between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m. 
(b)  Paragraph (a) of this section shall not create any limitation upon the following outdoor water uses: 
(1)  Commercial agricultural operations as defined in O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3; 
(2)  Capture and reuse of cooling system condensate or storm water in compliance with applicable local ordinances and state guidelines; 
(3)  Reuse of gray water in compliance with O.C.G.A. § 31-3-5.2 and applicable local board of health regulations adopted pursuant thereto; 
(4)  Use of reclaimed waste water by a designated user from a system permitted by the environmental protection division of the department to provide reclaimed waste water; 
(5)  Irrigation of personal food gardens; 
(6)  Irrigation of new and replanted plant, seed, or turf in landscapes, golf courses, or sports turf fields during installation and for a period of thirty (30) days immediately following the date of installation; 
(7)  Drip irrigation or irrigation using soaker hoses; 
(8)  Handwatering with a hose with automatic cutoff or handheld container; 
(9)  Use of water withdrawn from private water wells or surface water by an owner or operator of property if such well or surface water is on said property; 
(10)  Irrigation of horticultural crops held for sale, resale, or installation; 
(11)  Irrigation of athletic fields, golf courses, or public turf grass recreational areas; 
(12)  Installation, maintenance, or calibration of irrigation systems; or 
(13)  Hydroseeding. 
(c)  (1)  No person shall use or allow the use of water in violation of the restrictions on outdoor water use contained in this section. 
(2)  The code enforcement officer(s) shall be the enforcement authority for this section, and the city manager may, as he deems necessary, authorize other departments or employees to enforce this section. 
(3)  Any person who violates any provision of this section shall, upon conviction by the municipal court be punished as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2010-23, § 1, 12-6-10) 
Secs. 10-45-10-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SEWERS; WASTEWATER DISPOSAL[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Sewage disposal, § 8-4. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-50. - Definitions. 
    Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meanings of terms used in this article shall be as follows: 
    ASTM: The American Society for Testing and Materials. 
    BOD (denoting biochemical oxygen demand): The quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five (5) days at twenty (20) degrees centigrade, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
    Building drain: That part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five (5) feet (1.5 meters) outside the inner face of the building wall. 
    Building sewer: The extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
    Chemical oxygen demand (COD): A measure of the oxygen-consuming capacity of inorganic and organic matter present in water and wastewater. It is expressed as the amount of oxygen in milligrams per liter by weight consumed from a chemical oxidant in a specific test. 
    Combined sewer: A sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage. 
    Director: The director of public works of the city, or authorized deputy, agent, or representative. 
    Easement: An acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others. 
    Garbage: Solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage, and sale of produce. 
    Industrial wastes: The liquid wastes from industrial manufacturing processes, trade, or business as distinct from sanitary sewage. 
    Natural outlet: Any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake, or other body of surface or groundwater. 
    OSHA: The Federal Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 (PL 91-596), as amended. 
    pH: The standard industry measurement of the acidity or alkalinity of a substance expressed on a scale of 0-14 standard units, with 0 being highly acidic and 14 being highly alkaline. 
    Properly shredded garbage: The wastes from the preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half (1/2) inch (1.27 centimeters) in any dimension. 
    Public sewer: A sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal rights, and which is controlled by public authority. 
    Sanitary sewer: A sewer which carries sewage and to which storm, surface, and groundwater are not intentionally admitted. 
    Sewage: A combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions, and industrial establishments, together with such ground, surface, and stormwaters as may be present. 
    Sewage treatment plant: Any arrangement of devices and structures used for treating sewage. 
    Sewage work: All facilities for collecting, pumping, treating, and disposing of sewage. 
    Sewer: A pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. 
    Slug: Any discharge of water, sewage, or industrial waste which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes more than five (5) times the average twenty-four (24) hour concentration or flows during normal operation. 
    Storm drain, sometimes termed storm sewer: A sewer which carries storm and surface waters and drainage, but excludes sewage and industrial wastes, other than unpolluted cooling water. 
    Suspended solids: Solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in water, sewage, or other liquids, and which are removable by laboratory filtering. 
    Total suspended solids (TSS): Solids that either float on the surface of or are in suspension in, water, sewage, or other liquids, and which are removable by laboratory filtering. 
    Total Kjeldahl nitrogen (TKN): the quantity of organic nitrogen and ammonia expressed in mg/l. 
    Total phosphorus (P-total): shall mean the quantity of total phosphorus, mg/l, as determined in accordance with 40 CFR Part 136. 
    Unpolluted water: Water of quality equal to or better than the effluent criteria in effect or water that would not cause violation of receiving water quality standards and would not be benefited by discharge to the sanitary sewers and wastewater treatment facilities provided. 
    Wastewater: The spent water of a community; used interchangeably with the term "sewage." 
    Watercourse: A channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
    WPCF: The Water Pollution Control Federation. 
(Code 1963, § 18B-1.1; Ord. No. 2007-34, § 1, 7-23-07) 
Sec. 10-51. - Morning Creek Sewerage District defined. 
    The Morning Creek Sewerage District shall consist of all that part of the city that lies in the 13th District of Fulton County, parts of Land Lots 61, 62, 67, 68, 69, 92, and 93; being more particularly described as being all that land within the city limits south of the present center line of Interstate Highway 285 (I-285) in Land Lots 61 and 62, all lands within the city limits in Land Lot 67, and all lands south of Godby Road and east of Old National Highway within the city limits in Land Lots 68, 69, 92, 93; and all future systems which may be discharged by pumping into the sewers located within this designated area. 
(Code 1963, § 22-37; Ord. No. 88-28, § 1, 10-3-88) 
Sec. 10-52. - Clayton/Camp Creek Sewerage District defined. 
    All that part of the City of College Park that lies in the 13th District of Clayton County; bounded on the east by State Route 314; bounded on the north by Godby Road; bounded on the west by the Fulton/Clayton County line, and bounded on the south by the city limits of College Park, and all future systems which may be discharged by pumping into the sewers located within this described area. Said property being a portion of land within the City of College Park lying in the southwest corner of State Route 314 and Godby Road, and being located in a portion of Land Lots 70 and 91 of the 13th District of Clayton County, Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 86-15, 4-21-86) 
Secs. 10-53-10-59. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONNECTION[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Minimum sanitary equipment required for housing, § 5-80; minimum plumbing requirements, § 5-150 et seq. 

Sec. 10-60. - Sanitary facilities-Required installation; connection required when sewer available non-approved systems to be abandoned; prohibition of connections and sewage discharge for premises that use water not supplied by the city. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any residence and building within the city in which human beings reside, are employed or congregate not to have a sanitary method of human excreta disposal, namely either a sanitary water closet connected with the city sewer system, where sewer connection is available; or in case such sewer connection is not available, a septic tank of a type approved by the department of natural resources. No building permit shall be issued or no connection shall be made to a septic tank, an independent sewage disposal system or to a sewage disposal system other than the system operated and maintained by the city, without prior approval of the governing body. 
(b)  All private sewage disposal systems not approved by the county board of health shall be abandoned and all houses, buildings, or property shall be connected to public sewers within ninety (90) days after official notice by the director of public works, provided that a serviceable public sewer is within one hundred (100) feet of the property line. All such private sewage disposal systems thus abandoned shall be cleaned of sludge and filled with bankrum gravel or suitable earth when connection is made. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person owning, leasing or otherwise occupying any land, site, building parcel or premises in the city to connect such property to the city's sanitary sewage system and to discharge any water not delivered to such premises by the City of College Park, unless: 
(1)  The water is drawn from a well existing on such property; or 
(2)  The governing authority of the City of College Park has a written agreement with such public or private water supplier or distribution enterprise regarding the distribution and disposal of such water within the city. 
(d)  The public works director shall be charged with monitoring all construction projects within the city and, upon discovery of any proposed construction project which would violate this section, shall notify the owner thereof that it shall not have access to the sewer system of College Park unless and until an agreement is put in place between the water supplier and the City of College Park. Failure to deliver such notice shall confer no rights upon any person to otherwise violate this Code section. 
(e)  In the event it is discovered after the effective date of this section that any property owner or occupant is violating the provisions hereof, the director of public works, or his designee, shall notify the owner or occupant of the premises with any unlawful connection that sewer service will be disconnected within seventy-two (72) hours of the notification and that the water provider should cease to supply water to the premises within that time period. 
(f)  The chief of police or his designee, with the assistance of the city engineer, or his designee, shall be authorized to disconnect and cap any connection of such premises to the sanitary sewage collection system at such sites as may lie within the city's right-of-way. The owner or occupant of the premises shall be assessed the full costs incurred for the capping and disconnection by the city. 
(Code 1963, § 10-3; Ord. No. 2008-16, § 1, 12-1-08) 
Cross reference- Sewer use charge applies when sewer available, § 10-100. 
Sec. 10-61. - Same-Use required; regulated. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to dispose of any human excreta within the city except in a sanitary water closet connected with the city sewer system, where sewer connection is available, or in case such sewer connection is not available, in a septic tank of the type approved by the department of natural resources, or in a sanitary privy. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person owning or leasing any premises in the city to permit the disposal of any human excreta on any property owned, leased or rented by such person, or by such person's agent, except in a sanitary water closet connected with the city sewer system where sewer connection is available, or in case such sewer connection is not available, in a septic tank of the type approved by the department of natural resources, or a sanitary privy; and it shall be unlawful to permit the disposal of any material in a sanitary privy other than human excreta and paper. 
(Code 1963, § 10-4) 
Cross reference- Deposit of sewage in unsanitary manner, § 8-4. 
Sec. 10-62. - Same-Septic tanks; minimum requirements. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any septic tank other than of the type approved by the department of natural resources, to be constructed or maintained within the city. 
(b)  No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any natural outlet. 
(Code 1963, § 10-5) 
Sec. 10-63. - Connection permit-Required. 
(a)  No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the director. 
(b)  Applicants for a building sewer connection permit shall notify the director when the building sewer plumbing is ready for connection onto the public sewer. This connection shall be made under the supervision of the director or the director's representative. 
(Code 1963, § 18B-4) 
Sec. 10-64. - Same-Classes; application. 
(a)  There shall be two (2) classes of building sewer permits: 
(1)  For residential and commercial service, and 
(2)  For service to establishments producing industrial wastes. 
(b)  In either case, the owner or the owner's agent shall make application on a special form furnished by the city. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications, or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the director.
