A permit and inspection fee for residential or commercial building sewer permit and a permit and inspection fee for an industrial building sewer permit shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed. 
(Code 1963, § 18B-5) 
Sec. 10-65. - Same-Application by persons outside city. 
(a)  Anyone outside the city limits desiring to connect to the city sewer system shall file an application with the city clerk. Said application shall show the location of the property to be served and the location of the city sewer tap connection. The same shall be examined and approved by the city engineer. The city engineer shall determine the cost of extending the line from the applicant's location to the city's system. The applicant shall then post an amount of money sufficient to cover the cost as determined by the city engineer. 
(b)  After the foregoing application has been approved by the city engineer and the cost deposited with the city clerk the governing body shall examine the same and may approve the application if found to be in the best interest of the city. 
(Code 1963, § 22-45(e), (f)) 
Sec. 10-66. - Buildings to have independent drainage systems; exceptions. 
(a)  Where there is a sewer in the street, the drainage and plumbing system of each building shall be separate from and independent of that of any other building except as provided in subsection (b), and every building shall have an independent connection with a sewer. 
(b)  Where one building stands at the rear of another building on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, courtyard, driveway or easement, the house drain from the front building and the rear building will be considered as one house drain. 
(c)  In each case included in the above exception, the owner must make application to and receive permission from the plumbing inspector, such permission when granted, to state the conditions under which such connections may be made and the size of pipes to be used. 
(Code 1963, §§ 18B-7, 22-33) 
Sec. 10-67. - Performance of connection of building sewer to public sewer-Conformance to rules; responsibility for expense; indemnification. 
(a)  The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. 
    All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the building official before installation. 
(b)  All costs and expense incident to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. 
(c)  The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
(Code 1963, §§ 18B-6, 18B-11) 
Sec. 10-68. - Same-Excavations. 
(a)  All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. 
(b)  Streets, sidewalks, parkways, and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city. 
(Code 1963, § 18B-12) 
Sec. 10-69. - Same-Use of old sewers. 
    Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found on examination and test by the director to meet all requirements of this chapter. 
(Code 1963, § 18B-8) 
Sec. 10-70. - Same-Materials of construction and method of connection. 
    The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing, and backfilling the trench, shall all conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing codes and other applicable rules and regulations of the city. In the absence of code provisions, or in amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the ASTM and WPCF Manual of Practice No. 9 shall apply. 
(Code 1963, § 18B-9) 
Sec. 10-71. - Same-Elevation of sewer. 
    Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by an approved means and discharged to the building sewer. 
(Code 1963, § 18B-10) 
Sec. 10-72. - Connection charges-Inside city. 
    The schedule of charges for sewer connections for stubs inside the city limits shall be determined by a resolution of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1963, § 22-44; Ord. No. 86-7, §§ B, C, 3-3-86; Ord. No. 86-12, §§ B, C, 4-7-86; Ord. No. 86-28, § 3, 9-2-86; Ord. No. 2010-24, § 17, 6-21-10) 
Cross reference- Payment at time application for connection is filed, § 10-64. 
Sec. 10-73. - Same-Outside the city. 
    The schedule of charges for sewer connections for stubs outside the city limits shall be determined by a resolution of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1963, § 22-45(a), (b), (c); Ord. No. 2010-24, § 18, 6-21-10) 
Sec. 10-74. - Same-Charges for cutting into streets, sidewalks. 
(a)  In addition to the minimum charges for single residences and multiple dwelling units, where the street right-of-way is twenty-five (25) feet or more, the charge for additional sewer connections shall be determined by a resolution of mayor and council. 
(b)  In new subdivisions where private enterprise installs connection laterals, trunk lines and stub services to lot property lines for sewerage connections and where taps are made at no expense to the city, an engineer inspection fee shall be determined by a resolution of mayor and council. 
(Code 1963, § 22-46; Ord. No. 2010-24, § 18, 6-21-10) 
Secs. 10-75-10-79. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - USE OF SEWERS 

Sec. 10-80. - Discharge of unpolluted water restricted. 
(a)  Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as combined sewers or storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the director. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged, on approval of the director, to a storm sewer, combined sewer, or natural outlet. 
(b)  Connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, areaway drains or drains which in turn are connected directly or indirectly to public sanitary sewers, are specifically prohibited. 
(c)  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any unpolluted waters such as storm water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage or cooling water to any sewer, except storm water runoff from limited areas, which storm water may be polluted at times and may be discharged to the sanitary sewer by permission of the director. 
(Code 1963, § 18B-13) 
Sec. 10-81. - Discharge of polluted waters prohibited. 
    Unless they apply for and receive a permit therefore from the city, no person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the following described substances, materials, waters, or wastes if it appears likely in the opinion of the director that such wastes can harm either the sewers, sewage treatment process, or equipment, have an adverse effect on the receiving stream, or can otherwise endanger life, limb, public property, or constitute a nuisance. In forming such opinion as to the acceptability of these wastes for the purposed of determining if a Permit should issue, the director will give consideration to such factors as the quantities of subject wastes in relation to flows and velocities in the sewers, materials of construction of the sewers, nature of the sewage treatment process, capacity of the sewage treatment plant, degree of treatability of wastes in the sewage treatment plant, and other pertinent factors. The director, in issuing a permit, shall establish the necessary preconditions that must be followed by the permit holder, including periodic testing and reporting of the levels of such discharges. 
(1)  Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas. 
(2)  Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids, or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, to damage or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance, or create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant, including but not limited to cyanides in excess of one mg/l as CN in the wastes as discharged to the public sewer. 
(3)  Reserved. 
(4)  Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of such size capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or other interference with the proper operation of the sewage works, such as, but not limited to, ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and fleshings, entrails and paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc., either whole or ground by garbage grinders. 
(Code 1963, § 18B-14; Ord. No. 2007-34, §§ 2, 3, 7-23-07) 
Sec. 10-82. - Discharge of dangerous materials-Approval of director. 
    No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the following described substances, materials, waters, or wastes if it appears likely in the opinion of the director that such wastes can harm either the sewers, sewage treatment process, or equipment, have an adverse effect on the receiving stream, or can otherwise endanger life, limb, public property, or constitute a nuisance. In forming such opinion as to the acceptability of these wastes, the director will give consideration to such factors as the quantities of subject wastes in relation to flows and velocities in the sewers, materials of construction of the sewers, nature of the sewage treatment process, capacity of the sewage treatment plant, degree of treatability of wastes in the sewage treatment plant, and other pertinent factors. The substances prohibited are: 
(1)  Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit (65 degrees centigrade). 
(2)  Any water or wastes, containing fats, wax, grease, or oils, whether emulsified or not, in excess of one hundred (100) mg/l or containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures between thirty-two (32) and one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit (0 and 65 degrees centigrade). 
(3)  Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. The installation and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of three-fourths (3/4) horsepower (0.76 hp metric) or greater shall be subject to the review and approval of the director. 
(4)  Any waters or wastes containing strong acid iron pickling wastes, or concentrated plating solutions whether neutralized or not. 
(5)  Any water or wastes containing iron, chromium, copper, zinc, or similar objectionable or toxic substances; or wastes exerting an excessive chlorine requirement, to such degree that any such material received in the composite sewage at the sewage treatment works exceeds the limits established by the director for such materials. 
(6)  Any waters or wastes containing phenols or other waste or odor-producing substances, in such concentrations exceeding limits which may be established by the director as necessary, after treatment of the composite sewage, to meet the requirements of the state, federal, or other public agencies of jurisdiction for such discharge to the receiving waters. 
(7)  Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration as may exceed limits established by the director in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations. 
(8)  Any waste having a pH of less than six (6) or greater than nine and one-half (9.5). 
(9)  Materials which exert or cause: 
(a)  Unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids (such as, but not limited to, Fuller's earth, lime slurries, and the lime residues) or of dissolved solids (such as, but not limited to, sodium chloride and sodium sulfate). 
(b)  Excessive discoloration (such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions). 
(c)  Chemical oxygen demand (COD), or chlorine requirements in such quantities as to constitute a significant load on the sewerage treatment works. 
(d)  Unusual volume of flow or concentration of wastes constituting "slugs" as defined herein. 
(10)  Waters or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to treatment or reduction by the sewage treatment processes employed, or are amenable to treatment only to such degree that the sewage treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of other agencies having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters. 
(11)  Hydrogen sulfide, sulphur dioxide and nitrous oxide shall be limited to one mg/l in any wastes introduced to the public sanitary sewer. 
(12)  Any wastes having a five-day COD in excess of five hundred (500) mg/l by weight on a 24-hour composite basis shall be prohibited from introduction to the public sanitary sewer. 
(13)  Any waters or wastes having any corrosive properties capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment, or personnel of the sewerage works. 
(Code 1963, § 18B-15; Ord. No. 2007-34, §§ 4-7, 7-23-07) 
Sec. 10-83. - Same-Remedy for discharge. 
(a)  If any waters or wastes are discharged, or are proposed to be discharged to the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess the characteristics enumerated in section 10-82, and which in the judgment of the director, may have a deleterious effect upon the sewage works, processes, equipment, or receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the director may: 
(1)  Reject the wastes, 
(2)  Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers, 
(3)  Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge, and/or 
(4)  Require payment to cover the added cost of handling and treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges under the provisions of section 10-88. 
(b)  If the director permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows, the design and installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject to the review and approval of the director, and subject to the requirements of all applicable codes, ordinances, and laws. Dilution of incompatible wastes with uncontaminated water is not an acceptable method of waste equalization. 
(Code 1963, § 18B-16) 
Sec. 10-84. - Grease, oil, and sand interceptors required. 
    Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the director, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing floatable grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand or other harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be required for detached single-family residential units. All interceptors shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. In the maintaining of these interceptors, the owner shall be responsible for the proper removal and disposal by appropriate means of the captured material and shall maintain records of the dates and means of disposal which are subject to review by the director. Any removal and hauling of the collected materials not performed by the owner or owner's personnel must be performed by currently licensed waste disposal firms or approved recycling firms. 
(Code 1963, § 18B-17) 
Sec. 10-85. - Flow-equalizing facilities. 
    Where preliminary treatment or flow-equalizing facilities are provided for any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at the owner's expense. 
(Code 1963, § 18B-18) 
Sec. 10-86. - Manholes for industrial wastes. 
    When required by the director, the owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling, and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located, and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the director. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at the owner's expense, and shall be maintained by the owner so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(Code 1963, § 18B-19) 
Sec. 10-87. - Measurement, tests, and analyses of wastes. 
    All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this article shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater," published by the American Public Health Association, and shall be determined at the control manhole provided, or upon suitable samples taken at said control manhole. In the event that no special manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected. Sampling shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and to determine the existence of hazards to life, limb and property. (The particular analyses involved will determine whether a twenty-four (24) hour composite of all outfalls of a premises is appropriate or whether a grab sample or samples should be taken. Normally, but not always, BOD and suspended solids analyses are obtained from twenty-four (24)-hour composites of all outfalls whereas pH's are determined from periodic grab samples.) 
(Code 1963, § 18B-20) 
Sec. 10-88. - Exception to provisions by special agreement. 
    No statement contained in this article shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the city and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the city for treatment, subject to payment therefor, by the industrial concern. 
(Code 1963, § 18B-21) 
Sec. 10-89. - Damaging sewerage works. 
    No unauthorized person shall maliciously, wilfully, or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface, or tamper with any structure, appurtenance, or equipment which is a part of the sewerage works. Any person violating this provision shall be subject to immediate arrest and charged with a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1963, § 18B-22) 
Sec. 10-90. - Director's power to enter and inspect properties-Generally; limitation. 
    The director and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, and testing in accordance with the provisions of this article. The director or the director's representatives shall have no authority to inquire into any processes including metallurgical, chemical, oil, refining, ceramic, paper, or other industries beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the sewers or waterways or facilities for waste treatment. 
(Code 1963, § 18B-23) 
Sec. 10-91. - Same-Duty of director to observe safety rules; liability of company. 
    While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to in section 10-90, the director or duly authorized employees of the city shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the company and the company shall be held harmless for injury or death to the city employees and the city shall indemnify the company against loss or damage to its property by city employees and against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage asserted against the company and growing out of the gauging and sampling operation, except as such may be caused by negligence or failure of the company to maintain safe conditions as required in section 10-86. 
(Code 1963, § 18B-24) 
Sec. 10-92. - Same-Easements. 
    The director and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all private properties through which the city holds a duly negotiated easement for the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair, and maintenance of any portion of the sewerage works lying within said easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on said easement, shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement pertaining to the private property involved. 
(Code 1963, § 18B-25) 
Sec. 10-93. - Analysis-Periodic. 
(a)  The industrial waste of each person discharging same into the city sanitary sewers shall be subject to periodic inspection. A determination of character and concentration of said wastes shall be made as provided in the permit issued by the director. 
(b)  Determination of character and concentration of wastes, as determined by sampling, may be used to adjust these factors in the formula for the billing period following determination. 
(c)  Samples shall be collected in such a manner as to be representative of the actual quality of the wastes. The laboratory methods used in the examination of said wastes shall be those set forth in "Standard Methods." 
(Code 1963, § 18B-30; Ord. No. 2007-34, § 8, 7-23-07) 
Sec. 10-94. - Same-Disputed; regauging and sampling of wastes. 
    In the event that an analysis of wastes, determined by the samplings and gauging of wastes from a person or industry by the city is disputed, a program of resampling and gauging, with subsequent chemical determinations may be instituted as follows: 
(1)  The person or industrial user interested must submit a request for resampling and gauging of their wastes to the director of public works by letter and bind themselves to bear the expenses incurred by the city in the resampling and gauging and subsequent chemical determination of the wastes. 
(2)  The chemist or engineer employed by the company responsible for the request submitted to the city must confer with the city's engineer in charge of gauging and sampling. They will establish the length of the rerun and the methods to be employed to determine the flow and to sample the flow. 
(3)  The chemist or engineer engaged by the person or industry may be present during the gauging and sampling operation and also in the city laboratory during the chemical determination of the analysis. 
(4)  The results of the analysis, determined from the quantity and quality of the flow, shall be considered the analysis of record and shall be used to establish current billing procedures. 
(Code 1963, § 18B-31) 
Sec. 10-95. - Compliance with federal pretreatment requirements; maintenance. 
(a)  All industrial users of the sanitary sewers discharging incompatible or toxic pollutants shall meet the requirements of the federal pretreatment standards (40 CFR, Part 129) as provided by section 307(b) of Public Law 92-500. In some cases, these pretreatment standards may not be sufficient to protect the operation of treatment works, or to ensure compliance with state and federal regulations. In such cases, the right is reserved to impose more stringent pretreatment standards than those specified in federal regulations. 
(b)  Where treatment or flow equalizing facilities are provided or required for any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at the owner's expense. 
(Code 1963, § 18B-34; Ord. No. 2007-34, § 9, 7-23-07) 
Sec. 10-96. - Treatment of wastewater discharged to natural outlet. 
    It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any sewage or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with provisions of this article. 
(Code 1963, § 18B-3) 
Sec. 10-97. - Penalties; correction. 
(a)  Any person found to be violating any provision of this division, except sections 10-89 and 10-96 shall be served by the city with written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations. 
(b)  Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the time limits provided for in subsection (a) of this section, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and on conviction thereof shall be punished as provided in section 18 for each violation. Each day in which any such violation shall continue shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(c)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this division shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss, or damage occasioned the city by reason of such violation. 
(Code 1963, § 18B-26) 
Secs. 10-98, 10-99. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - USER CHARGES 

Sec. 10-100. - Sewer use charge applies when sewer available. 
    Where a sanitary sewer has been installed in any street of the city and is available for use to the abutting property, all property which is connected to the city water system and which abuts upon such street shall be subject to the sewer use and maintenance charge in the amount prescribed by the applicable city ordinances. Said maintenance charge shall begin six (6) months following the date the sanitary sewer becomes active and available for use or the month the abutting property is connected to the sewer, whichever shall first occur. 
(Code 1963, § 22-34) 
Sec. 10-101. - Charge generally for use, maintenance of sewer system; imposed amount. 
(a)  Charges. There is hereby assessed and levied upon each parcel of real property in the city on which is located a water pipe used for the purpose of channeling water purchased from the city or on which is located a water pipe line or sewer line connected to the sewer system of the city, and against the owners of same, a monthly charge, based upon water usage, for use and maintenance of the sewer system. The council shall by resolution fix rates for which sanitary sewer services shall be furnished for all purposes within the area served by the city. 
(b)  Abutting property. Property abutting the sanitary sewer system shall pay a charge which shall be set by the council by resolution. 
(c)  Negotiated charges. All industrial customers, purchasing water that is consumed in their product, shall pay a monthly assessment based on the formula of subsection (a). When any industrial customer is of the opinion that said formula is not fair and equitable, said customer may apply and request the city to negotiate and establish a monthly assessment in the customer's product and the discharge into the system. The customer shall provide to the city certified engineering data establishing the amount of water consumed in the product and the customer's daily average discharge into the system. The city may, if it so elects, conduct its own survey of such information. 
(d)  Due date. Each monthly charge shall mature and be due and payable according to the cycle billing dates for electricity and water charges as set out in section 10-5. 
(e)  Charge constitutes lien. The amount of each of said monthly charges shall be payable in cash and shall constitute a lien upon the real estate, and be subject to be enforced as provided in the charter of the city. 
(f)  Charges outside corporate limits. For the monthly sewer maintenance charge for users beyond the corporate limits of the city, there is affixed and established a rate and charge in an amount of one and one-half (11/2) times the rates and charges designated for the users within the city limits. 
(g)  Charges for users within Morning Creek Sewerage District. For the monthly sewer maintenance charge for users within the Morning Creek Sewerage District, there is hereby affixed and established a rate and charge as established by the formula of an assessment and levy equal to four dollars and ninety-five cents ($4.95) for the first three thousand (3,000) gallons of water consumption, plus one dollar and sixty-five cents ($1.65) per one thousand (1,000) gallons over three thousand (3,000) gallons, as determined by appropriate water meter readings for the current billing period. 
(h)  Charges for users within the Clayton/Camp Creek Sewerage District. For the monthly sewer maintenance charge for users within the Clayton/Camp Creek Sewerage District, there is hereby affixed and established a rate and charge per one thousand (1,000) gallons of water as shown by water meter readings for the current billing period based on a pro-ration of Clayton Co. Water Authority billing charge (established in accordance with paragraph four (4) of the agreement titled "Sanitary Sewer Service Agreement Camp Creek Drainage Basin" dated April 21, 1986) divided by the total quantity of all water meter readings in thousands of gallons within the Clayton/Camp Creek Sewerage District. 
    Charges to users within the district shall commence on the first of the month that any users discharge of sewage is tied into the collection system of the district which discharges to the Clayton County Water Authority sewage metering station (established in accordance with paragraph two (2) of the agreement titled "Sanitary Sewer Service Agreement Camp Creek Drainage Basin" dated April 21, 1986). 
(i)  Charges for users with water not supplied by the city. For the monthly sewer maintenance charge for users not supplied domestic water by the city who have been issued a permit by the governing authority pursuant to section 10-60(c) there shall be fixed and established a rate and charge as determined by a formula that includes a surcharge for sewer main capacity reserved and opportunity cost associated with providing sewer service for users who are not using domestic water supplied by the city as well as any third party, internal and administrative costs related to conveyance and treatment of sewage discharged into the sanitary sewers of the City of College Park as determined by appropriate meter readings for the current billing period set at the users connection to the sanitary sewers of the city. 
(Code 1963, § 22-35; Ord. No. 86-7, § A, 3-3-86; Ord. No. 86-12, § A, 4-7-86; Ord. No. 86-15, 4-21-86; Ord. No. 88-17, §§ 1, 2, 7-5-88; Ord. No. 90-16, §§ 1, 2, 7-16-90; Ord. No. 91-12, §§ 1, 2, 7-1-91; Ord. No. 2000-20, § 1, 9-18-00; Ord. No. 2002-02, § 1, 1-7-02; Ord. No. 2003-28, § 1, 7-7-03; Ord. No. 2003-28, § 1, 8-1-03; Ord. No. 04-21, § 1, 7-6-04; Ord. No. 2006-22, § 1, 7-17-06; Ord. No. 2007-22, § 1, 9-4-07; Ord. No. 2007-34, § 10, 7-23-07; Ord. No. 2008-16, § 2, 12-1-08; Ord. No. 2009-14, § 3, 8-3-09) 
Sec. 10-102. - Industrial wastes surcharges-When required. 
    Established. All persons discharging industrial wastes into the public sewers shall be charged and assessed a surcharge per billing period unless otherwise indicated, in addition to any sewer service charges, if these wastes have a concentration greater than the following: 
(1)  A COD (chemical oxygen demand) content of five hundred (500) mg/l as determined by laboratory analysis in accordance with procedures prescribed in section 10-103. The surcharge shall be ten cents ($0.10) per pound. 
(2)  A suspended solids content of two hundred fifty (250) parts per million as determined by laboratory analysis in accordance with "Standard Methods". 
(Code 1963, § 18B-27; Ord. No. 2007-34, § 11, 7-23-07) 
Sec. 10-103. - Same-Formula for determining. 
(a)  When the COD, P-total, TKN and/or TSS of wastewater accepted for admission to the city sewerage works exceeds the values of these constituents for "normal" sewage, the excess concentration shall be evaluated in terms of 'normal' sewerage and be subject to a surcharge on the amount derived in accordance with the following formula: 
Amount of surcharge = (S or N or C or P)(F)(S)(8.34) 
Where: 
S = The total suspended solids in the wastewater above the established maximum of 250 mg/l. N = Total Kjeldahl nitrogen above the established limit of 25 mg/l. C = Chemical oxygen demand above the established limit of 500 mg/l. P = Total Phosphorous above 10 mg/l. F = The quantity of wastewater discharged into the sewerage works per billing period, expressed in million gallons. S = The cost per pound for the handling and treatment of the surcharge testing parameter, expressed in amounts per pound. 8.34 = Conversion factor from gallons of wastewater to pounds of wastewater.  
(b)  The rate of surcharge ($) shall be reviewed annually by the director of public works in order that the above factors may correctly represent current treatment costs. If changes are deemed advisable, they may be made when approved by the city council. The rate of surcharge ($) referred to above shall be as designated in section 10-102, and the industrial wastes surcharge shall be initiated effective immediately. 
(Code 1963, §§ 18B-28, 18B-29(b), 18B-32; Ord. No. 2007-34, § 12, 7-23-07) 
Sec. 10-104. - Prohibited discharges. 
    It shall be unlawful for any wastewaters or wastes to have a pH lower than six (6.0) or higher than nine and one-half (9.5) at any time, or to have any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment, or personnel of the water pollution control facilities, as determined by laboratory analysis in accordance with procedures prescribed in section 10-103. The first violation of this article shall result in a written letter warning of the violation. The penalty for subsequent violations of this provision shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each day that a laboratory analysis indicates the pH lower or upper limit has been violated or that any corrosive property exists. 
(Ord. No. 2007-34, § 13, 7-23-07) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2007-34, § 13, adopted July 23, 2007, amended section 10-104 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, section 10-104 pertained to industrial wastes surcharge-to effectuate cost recovery, and derived from the Code of 1963, § 18B-29(a). 
Secs. 10-105-10-109. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SOLID WASTE DISPOSAL[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Keeping property clean, § 8-4 et seq.; littering, § 8-6. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-110. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings respectfully ascribed to them in this section: 
(1)  Building rubbish. Waste building materials resulting from construction, remodeling, repair or demolition operations. 
(2)  Bulky waste. Automobile parts, furniture, and other waste materials other than building rubbish, dead animals or hazardous waste, with weights or volumes greater than seventy-five (75) pounds per loading. 
(3)  Combustible materials. All flammable waste including, but not limited to, oily rags or oily waste, empty boxes, barrels, flammable liquids, or other like combustible materials. 
(4)  Dead animals. Animals or portions thereof equal to or greater than twenty (20) pounds in weight that have died from any cause, except those slaughtered or killed for human consumption. 
(5)  Dry-cleaning waste. Inflammable waste generated by dry-cleaning operations. 
(6)  Garbage. Waste paper and plastics, normal household disposable items, any or all dead animals of less than twenty (20) pounds in weight except for those slaughtered for human consumption; every accumulation of waste (animal, vegetable and/or other matter) that results from the preparation, processing, consumption, dealing in, handling, packing, canning, storage, transportation, decay or decomposition of meats, fish, fowl, birds, fruits, grains or other animal or vegetable matter including, but not limited to, used tin cans and other food containers; and all putrescible or easily decomposable waste, animal, or vegetable matter. 
(7)  Hazardous waste. Any chemical, compound, mixture, substance or article which is designated by the United States Environmental Protection Agency or an appropriate agency of the state to be "hazardous," as that term is defined by federal or state law or regulations. 
(8)  Industrial waste. Waste generated by manufacturing or industrial processes or operations including, but not limited to, waste resulting from the following manufacturing processes: electric power generation; fertilizer and agricultural chemicals; food-related products and by-products; inorganic chemicals; iron and steel products; leather and leather products; nonferrous metal and foundry products; organic chemicals; plastics and resin; pulp and paper; rubber and miscellaneous plastic products; stone, glass, clay, and concrete products; textiles; transportation equipment; and water treatment. 
(8.1)  Oversized container. Any container for the collection of garbage, recycling materials, trash, yard trimmings and other refuse which has a capacity of not less than ten (10) and not more than fifty (50) cubic yards. 
(9)  Recycling materials. Any and all materials which could otherwise become solid waste which, if collected, separated, or processed are capable or being reused or returned to use in the form of raw materials or products. Recycling materials shall include, but are not limited to HDPE and PET plastic; clear, green and brown glass; old newsprint; aluminum and bi-metal cans; and office paper and related paper products. 
(10)  Refuse. All ashes, garbage, recycling materials, trash, yard trimmings, or other waste accumulated within the city which is subject to collection by the city through the city collection and disposal system. 
(11)  Solid waste. All building rubbish, concrete, rocks, earth, bulky waste, combustible materials, dead animals, dry-cleaning waste, garbage, recycling materials, hazardous waste, industrial waste, trash, yard trimmings, or other waste accumulated within the city which is not subject to collection by the city through the city collection and disposal system. 
(12)  Trash. Lumber (excluding building rubbish), sticks, limbs, cans or one-gallon size or larger, discarded toys, and small household items (not including appliances over seventy-five (75) pounds in weight or other large or heavy items over seventy-five (75) pounds in weight), clothing, boxes, bundled paper and similar items. Putrescible food containers which contained such food should not be considered as trash. Dirt or heavy car parts shall not be considered as trash or hauled by the city. Rock and concrete will be hauled by the city from residential property when the work is done by the homeowner. Material from work done by a contractor shall be hauled away by the contractor. 
(13)  Yard trimmings. Leaves, brush, grass clippings, shrub and tree limbs (but not including log sections over forty (40) pounds each), and prunings, discarded Christmas trees, nursery and greenhouse vegetation residuals, and vegetative matter resulting from landscape development and maintenance other than mining, agricultural, and silvicultural operations. Provided, however, that yard trimmings shall not include limbs or other materials generated by commercial gardeners, tree services, and the like. 
(Code 1963, § 8-1(a), (b); Ord. No. 96-27, § 1, 10-7-96; Ord. No. 98-18, § 1, 9-8-98) 
Sec. 10-110.1. - Collection by city required; permit required where service is not offered by city. 
(a)  (1)  All garbage, recycling materials, and yard trimmings accumulated in the city shall be collected, conveyed and disposed of by the city or by the city's contractor except as otherwise expressly authorized in this chapter. Owners or, if applicable, non-owners, as that term is defined in section 10-132 of this chapter, of all unites to which the city provides collection and disposal services shall us the city collection and disposal system and shall pay such fees for said services as the city may establish from time to time. 
(2)  No person shall collect, convey over any of the streets or alleys of the city or dispose of any refuse accumulated in the city, except as expressly authorized in this chapter or as allowed by pertinent and appropriate actions of the governing body. 
(3)  For the purposes of this section, the term "Unit" shall mean a building, structure, or property within the city occupied by a person or group of persons or a business. A unit shall be deemed occupied when water services, either public or private, are being supplied thereto. Each unit of an apartment or condominium dwelling, whether of single-level or multi-level construction, shall be treated as a residential unit; provided, that any multi-family complex provided with dumpster service in lieu of approved containers for each housing unit shall be excluded from this definition. 
(b)  To the extent that the city does not collect or provide for the collection of certain types of solid waste accumulated in the city through the city collection and disposal system, a person may obtain a non-exclusive permit from the city to provide such service and shall conduct such activities in full compliance with state laws and regulations and city ordinances regulating the collection, transportation or disposal of such waste, and, upon failure to do so, shall be subject to prosecution for such violations. No person shall collect, convey over any of the streets or alleys of the city, or dispose of any solid waste accumulated in the city, except as expressly authorized in this chapter or as allowed by pertinent actions of the governing body. The annual fee for a non-exclusive permit to collect, transport, or dispose of such solid waste in the city shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00) per year. In the event the city institutes service in any area in which permit holders operate, such permits shall not be renewed for a new period, and the rights of such collectors to continue collecting such items shall cease with expiration of the permit. 
(c)  Owners and occupants of commercial, industrial, or residential property serviced by a private collector of solid waste shall maintain the areas immediately surrounding any exterior containers for such waste free of unsightly trash, garbage, or refuse at all times. In addition, any exterior container provided by a private collector of solid waste shall not reduce the number of available parking spaces at the property, nor shall any such container obstruct containers used in the collection of garbage, trash, recycling materials, or other refuse by the city. The owner or manager of the property shall be responsible for instructing all employees and occupants on the proper method for the use of the containers and shall ensure that all materials are placed completely within the container, with all doors and lids to be closed at all times the container is not being loaded or emptied. 
(Ord. No. 96-27, § 2, 10-7-96; Ord. No. 98-18, § 2, 9-8-98; Ord. No. 2002-10, § 1, 3-4-02) 
Sec. 10-110.2. - Containers required for residents, businesses and public buildings; placement at fence property; separating ashes. 
(a)  All owners and occupants of commercial, residential, and industrial property within the city shall provide sufficient containers with tight-fitting covers of a capacity not greater than thirty-five (35) gallons, and shall place garbage and other refuse in same, not to exceed seventy-five (75) pounds loading per container. On all fenced property used to restrain animals, the containers shall be made readily accessible to the collection personnel without their entry into the fenced area. Containers shall be shielded from the sight of the street and shall be within the property building line. This regulation shall not apply to commercial and industrial property served by bulk receptacle boxes. 
(b)  Ashes shall be placed in separate containers subject to the same size and weight limitations specified in subsection (a) and placed at the curb. 
(c)  Paint cans may be collected by the city so long as the lid is removed, any remaining liquid has been absorbed through use of an absorbent material such as sawdust or fuller's earth, and the can is placed separately at curbside for collection. 
(Ord. No. 96-27, § 3, 10-7-96) 
Sec. 10-111. - Receptacles for cups, plates, etc.; keeping such business premises clean. 
(a)  All business firms dispensing their product in cups, plates, wrappers, sacks, and other similar forms of containers shall provide adequate metal or plastic containers upon the premises for collection of refuse. 
(b)  It shall be the express responsibility of all such business firms to collect all cups, plates, wrappers, sacks and other similar forms of containers dispensed by said business that may be discarded upon the premises or neighboring street and sidewalks. It further shall be the responsibility of said business to collect the aforementioned items from the premises of the neighboring property when the owners of the property specifically request and authorize the business personnel to enter upon their property for that purpose. 
(c)  Failure to comply with the terms of this section shall be deemed a misdemeanor. 
(d)  Any wilful and wanton violation of this section resulting in the unlawful littering of the streets, sidewalks and neighboring property shall be deemed a nuisance and on conviction of the defendant, the governing body may revoke the business license of the defendant. 
(Code 1963, § 8-1(j)) 
Sec. 10-112. - Disposal of trash. 
(a)  Trash shall be placed at the street edge behind the curb or where the curb would normally be, but shall not be placed in the street so as to obstruct the sidewalk or an area of public vehicular or pedestrian travel; nor shall it be placed in the gutter, in any ditch or other path of storm water runoff. Where exceptional problems or difficulties are encountered, trash shall be placed as directed by the public works director or the director's designated agent. Where this section is violated, the director of public works of the director's agent may give notice requiring that such trash be moved by the person placing such trash or the occupant or owner within twenty-four (24) hours, or immediately if deemed a sufficient hazard. 
(b)  Small items of trans, such as clothes, paper, small household items, and items generally below one foot in length on their maximum dimension, or which can reasonably be bent or compressed to such length, but excluding all yard trimmings, shall be put in receptacle containers, not exceeding seventy-five (75) pounds in weight when full. Such container shall be of sufficient strength, wet or dry, not to burst or rupture when handled or emptied by city collection personnel. Cardboard boxes, when wet, shall not be deemed as acceptable containers. No plastic bags or sacks are to be used as containers for any trash. 
(c)  Leaves, grass and pine straw may be placed at the edge of the curb, unbagged, provided that leaves and grass shall not be placed on the paved street surface, but shall be kept behind the curb line. The leaves and grass must be close enough to the curb to enable the city's leaf removal machine to reach them from the paves surface. Yard trimmings shall not be mixed with garbage, building rubbish, waste materials or other disposed materials. Should yard trimmings be mixed with other disposed materials, then the city may charge the resident or business operator for all separation and disposal costs or may refuse to haul the mixed waste until all yard trimmings have been separated and removed into individual piles for disposal. 
(d)  Trash shall not be placed at the curb more than forty-eight (48) hours prior to the beginning of the day for which pick-up is assigned in an area. This time limit shall not apply for the placement of leaves at the curb during the months of October through April. 
(e)  No item shall be placed in such a manner that it can blow off or wash into the street or away from the area of placement. 
(f)  Trash shall be placed only on the owner's property or on the street right-of-way immediately adjacent to the property fro which the trash originated. Trash shall not be placed on vacant lots, parks, across the street from the property on which the trash originated or on another person's property. 
(g)  Trash shall not be mixed, stacked, or placed so as to make pick-up or collection difficult or slow. For example, leaves or grass shall not be mixed with limbs, cans, sticks, or other items. Limbs shall not be crossed but shall be placed with the butt or cut end facing the street edge. In general, dissimilar items shall not be mixed so as to slow pick-up or collection. 
(Code 1963, § 8-1(c); Ord. No. 92-11A, 5-18-92; Ord. No. 96-27, § 4, 10-76) 
Sec. 10-113. - Disposal of old appliances and tires. 
    Any non-commercial resident who desires to have an old appliance or automobile tires removed from their property may contact the tax office at city hall to arrange for the city to remove the old appliance or automobile tires. Truck tires will not be picked up by the city. All items must be placed by the curb no more than one (1) day prior to the scheduled pick-up. Old or unused appliances or tires may not be placed or stored outside in the open on public or private property. The public works director or the director's agent or other appropriate official designated by the city manager may direct the removal of such appliance or tires at the property owner's expense within forty-eight (48) hours of notification or in a lesser time, if deemed a hazard. 
(Code 1963, § 8-1(c); Ord. No. 2000-48, § 1, 12-18-00) 
Cross reference- Abandoned iceboxes, etc., § 8-3. 
Sec. 10-113.1. - Yard trimmings. 
    All yard trimmings shall be placed in neat piles in the area on the back side of the curb no more than forty-eight (48) hours prior to the city's scheduled collection. Limbs shall not be in excess of four (4) feet in length and three (3) inches in diameter. All limbs shall be secured in bundles not exceeding forty (40) pounds in total weight and may be placed at any time on the back side of the curb for disposal when the material has been cut, hauled and stacked by the residential property owner. 
(Ord. No. 96-27, § 5, 10-7-96) 
Sec. 10-113.2. - Items not collectible. 
    The following items are not collectible by the city: 
(1)  Dirt or rocks; 
(2)  Tires; 
(3)  Batteries (mercury, lead-acid, rechargeable, etc.); 
(4)  Hazardous waste (including, but not limited to, HTH, paint, oil, and car batteries); 
(5)  Metal drums, thirty-five (35) gallon size or larger; 
(6)  Dead animals, or portions thereof greater than twenty (20) pounds in weight; 
(7)  All items weighing in excess of seventy-five (75) pounds; 
(8)  Bulky waste; 
(9)  Automobile parts; and 
(10)  Pressurized containers and vessels. 
(Ord. No. 96-27, § 6, 10-7-96) 
Sec. 10-113.3. - Fee for removal of appliances and tires. 
    The fee for removal of appliances by the city under section 10-113 shall be seven dollars and fifty cents ($7.50) per appliance. The fee for removal of old tires under section 10-113 shall be one dollar and fifty cents ($1.50) for each tire. This fee must be paid in advance of the scheduled pick-up. 
(Ord. No. 2000-48, § 2, 12-18-00) 
Sec. 10-114. - Disposal of building rubbish. 
    No building materials or refuse from building, remodeling or repair operations or landscape work will be handled by city forces. All waste material of this nature shall be removed by the contractor, or in the event of the contractor's failure, by the owner of the property; provided, that the owner may make application to the sanitation superintendent and the superintendent may, if practical, remove the rubbish at the expense of the owner. The charge made for such service shall be determined in each case by the superintendent with relation to the service performed. 
(Code 1963, § 8-1(d)) 
Sec. 10-115. - Disposal of industrial wastes. 
    Industrial wastes from factories, processing plants, and other manufacturing operations shall be collected, removed and disposed of by the operator of the enterprise. 
(Code 1963, § 8-1(e)) 
Sec. 10-116. - Disposal of dead animals. 
    Dead animals, excluding horses and cows, will be picked up during working hours upon notice. It shall be the responsibility of the occupant to remove an animal from under any building. 
(Code 1963, § 8-1(f)) 
Sec. 10-117. - Disposal of combustible materials-Generally. 
(a)  Placement for garbage collectors. It shall be the duty of the occupant of any building within the city to collect and remove daily to a place convenient for city garbage collectors, empty boxes, barrels, rubbish, trash, waste paper, excelsior or other like combustible materials. 
(b)  Ashes, wooden containers prohibited. No person shall place ashes within any building in any box, barrel, or other wooden vessel or upon any wooden vessel or floor. 
(c)  Oily waste; metal containers required. No person shall keep or permit to be kept on the premises any oily rags or oily waste, unless at all times when not actually in use such oily rags and oily waste be kept in a metal can with self-closing cover and riveted joints, standing on metal legs which raise the bottom of the container at least four (4) inches above the floor. 
(Code 1963, § 8-2) 
Cross reference- Separate container required for ashes, § 10-110(b). 
Sec. 10-118. - Same-Dry cleaning wastes. 
    Inflammable wastes from dry cleaning operations shall be deposited in metal containers of a capacity not larger than five (5) gallons, without covers, and placed on the outside of the establishment for collection. 
(Code 1963, § 8-1(h)) 
Sec. 10-119. - Disposal of liquid wastes. 
    Liquid wastes other than normal garbage juices, shall not be combined with garbage and refuse, and the disposal of same shall be the responsibility of the occupant. 
(Code 1963, § 8-1(g)) 
Sec. 10-120. - Disposal of other waste by city discretionary. 
    The sanitation superintendent may remove any waste materials for which no provision is made in this division, provided the cost that is determined by the superintendent as being reasonable for the service performed, is paid by the person making application for the removal of such waste material. 
(Code 1963, § 8-1(i)) 
Sec. 10-121. - Frequency of collection. 
(a)  Residential garbage and other refuse shall be collected twice per week. 
(b)  Commercial garbage and other refuse shall be collected as required, as will yard trimmings and leaves. 
(Code 1963, § 8-3) 
Sec. 10-122. - Collection outside city limits. 
    No waste collections shall be made by the city forces outside the city limits. 
(Code 1963, § 8-4) 
Sec. 10-123. - Containerized garbage pick-up. 
(a)  Containerized garbage pick-up may be required where any dwelling house, apartment building or other building or place of dwelling or any commercial establishment discards three (3) or more cubic yards of garbage in a consecutive seven (7)-day period. The city shall have the authority to require the use of containerized garbage pick-up where it deems necessary except where an existing situation is physically impossible to operate city equipment safely. The superintendent of sanitation or public works director shall negotiate the size of the container and the frequency of dumping same in each case, with a mutual understanding in writing with the owner of the property involved. All properties that are required to use containerized garbage pickup shall provide upon the premises an accessible hard-surfaced space of sufficient size to accommodate the required city garbage container. There shall be sufficient driving area to permit reasonable ingress and egress by city trucks. No building permit shall be issued by the building official for new construction unless appropriate plans and specifications are submitted setting forth and meeting the requirements of this section. 
(b)  All existing properties shall have complied with this section on or before May 1, 1982. 
(Code 1963, § 8-10) 
Sec. 10-124. - Dumping in refuse containers regulated. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person other than a resident of the city or a representative of a business located within the city to dump garbage, trash, refuse or waste matter in containers placed about the city for the collection of garbage, trash, refuse or other waste matter of said residents and businesses. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dump refuse, garbage, trash or any type of waste material in a container placed or located for the collection of refuse, garbage, trash or any other waste material when said container belongs to another person, unless the person dumping such refuse, garbage or waste shall have the written permission of the person or authorized representative of the person owning the container, paying for it or on whose property it is located. 
(Code 1963, §§ 8-7, 8-9) 
Secs. 10-125-10-129. - Reserved.

    The charges with respect to the collection of garbage within the city shall be determined by a resolution of the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 96-28, § 3, 11-4-96; Ord. No. 98-11, § 7-6-98; Ord. No. 2000-18, § 1, 6-19-00; 2001-27, § 1, 10-1-01; Ord. No. 2003-29, § 1, 7-7-03; Ord. No. 2005-16, § 1, 7-18-05; Ord. No. 2005-16B, § 1, 8-15-05; Ord. No. 2006-21, § 1, 7-17-06; Ord. No. 2010-24, § 19, 6-21-10)

Sec. 10-132. - Solid waste disposal deposit. 
(a)  For the purposes of this section, the following terms shall have the meanings assigned to them: 
(1)  Actual monthly fee shall mean the monthly fee actually invoiced by the city to a non-owner for city solid waste disposal services. 
(2)  Anticipated monthly fee shall mean the monthly fee anticipated by the city at the time of application for services by a non-owner for city solid waste disposal services. 
(3)  Non-owner shall mean a person or entity applying under Article V of this chapter for city solid waste disposal services, which person or entity does not won the property to which the solid waste disposal services are to be provided. 
(b)  Every owner and non-owner shall, at the time of application for services provide to the city a deposit in the amount of twice the anticipated monthly fee. 
(c)  Every person or entity who receives city solid waste disposal services of the effective date of Ord. No. 2002-10 shall, within one hundred eighty (180) days of the effective date of this ordinance, provide to the city a deposit in the amount of twice the most recent monthly fee paid to the city by that person or entity for said city solid waste disposal services. 
(d)  In the event that the initial actual monthly fee should exceed the anticipated monthly fee, or in the event of any increase in the actual monthly fee, the owner or non-owner shall remit to the city within thirty (30) days of receipt of an invoice reflecting such actual monthly fee or such increase in the actual monthly fee, sufficient funds to raise that owner's or non-owner's deposit amount to twice that owner's or non-owner's then current actual monthly fee. 
(e)  In the event that an owner or non-owner fails to make any payment to the city required by this chapter, including but not limited to any payment required by subsection (c) of this section, the city shall deduct the amount of the non-payment and any other applicable penalties, fees and other charges from the deposit. The city, in such event, additionally may terminate the provision of services to the applicable property until such time as the owner or non-owner remits to the city all payment due, including sufficient funds to return the deposit to the appropriate amount. 
(Ord. No. 2002-10, § 2, 3-4-02) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2002-10, §§ 2, 3, adopted March 4, 2002, amended the Code by adding provisions designated as sections 10-131.1 and 10-131.2. In order to simplify the numbering of provisions the editor has redesignated the provisions as 10-132, 10-133, which were formerly reserved. 
Sec. 10-133. - Penalties. 
    Failure to perform any act required by this article, or the performing of any act prohibited by this article, shall constitute an offense and shall subject the offender to prosecution in the municipal court of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2002-10, § 3, 3-4-02) 
Note- See the editor's note to section 10-132. 
Secs. 10-134-10-139. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - STORMWATER MANAGEMENT[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2006-30, §§ 1-27, adopted Sept. 18, 2006, amended, reorganized and relocated the former stormwater management regulations, formerly Art. XIV of Ch. 5, §§ 5-310-5-326, as a new Art. VI of this chapter. The former stormwater regulations of the city derived from Ord. No. 93-14, § 1, adopted Nov. 15, 1993. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-140. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known as the Stormwater Management Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 2006-30, § 1-3, 9-18-06) 
Sec. 10-141. - Authority. 
    This article is enacted pursuant to Official Code of Georgia Section 12-5-582(e)(1) and the grant of police powers to the City by Ga. L. 1895, p. 251, Sec. 14 and section 2-1 of the City Charter. 
(Ord. No. 2006-30, § 1, 2, 4, 9-18-06) 
Sec. 10-142. - Findings of fact. 
    The mayor and council make the following findings of fact: 
(1)  Uncontrolled stormwater drainage/discharge may have a significant, adverse impact on the health, safety, and welfare of the city, and the quality of life of its citizens. More specifically, surface water runoff can carry pollutants and nutrients into receiving waters; 
(2)  Uncontrolled stormwater drainage can increase the incidence of flooding and the level of floods which occur, endangering roads, other public and private property and human life; 
(3)  Altered land surfaces can change the rate and volume of runoff; 
(4)  Adverse water quality and quantity consequences described above could result in substantial economic losses. Potential losses include, but are not limited to, increased water treatment costs, as well as state and federal fines associated with water quality violations; 
(5)  Many future problems can be avoided through proper stormwater management; 
(6)  Every parcel of real property, both public and private, either uses or benefits from the maintenance of the municipal separate stormwater system; and 
(7)  Current and anticipated growth will contribute to and increase the need for improvement and maintenance of the municipal separate stormwater system. 
(Ord. No. 2006-30, § 1, 2, 5, 9-18-06) 
Sec. 10-143. - Purpose and intent. 
    The purpose of this article is to protect the public health, safety, environment and general welfare through the regulation of non-stormwater discharges to the municipal separate stormwater system to the maximum extent practicable as required by federal law. This article establishes methods for controlling the introduction of pollutants into the municipal separate stormwater system in order to comply with requirements of the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System ("NPDES") permit process. 
(Ord. No. 2006-30, §§ 1, 2, 6, 9-18-06) 
Sec. 10-144. - Objectives. 
    The objectives of this article include the following: 
(1)  To protect, maintain, and enhance the short-term and long term public health, safety, and general welfare. This objective will be achieved by providing for regulation and management of the municipal separate stormwater system, including public and private facilities in the city's service area; 
(2)  To comply with the state (EPD) and federal (EPA) stormwater regulations developed pursuant to the Clean Water Act. These requirements include: 
(a)  Control of the contribution of pollutants to the municipal separate stormwater system by stormwater discharges associated with commercial and industrial activity and the quality of stormwater discharged from sites of commercial and industrial activity; 
(b)  Prohibition of illicit connections to municipal separate stormwater system; 
(c)  Control of discharge to municipal separate stormwater of spills, dumping or disposal of materials other than stormwater; and 
(d)  Control, through intergovernmental agreements, the contribution of pollutants from one (1) municipal or county system to another; 
(3)  Regulate the contribution of pollutants to the municipal separate stormwater system by any person; 
(4)  Prohibit illicit discharges and illegal connections to the municipal separate stormwater system; 
(5)  Prevent non-stormwater discharges, generated as a result of spills, inappropriate dumping or disposal, to the municipal separate stormwater system; and, 
(6)  To establish legal authority to carry out all inspection, surveillance, monitoring and enforcement procedures necessary to ensure compliance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 2006-30, §§ 1, 2, 7, 9-18-06) 
Sec. 10-145. - Definitions. 
(1)  Accidental discharge. A discharge prohibited by this article into the municipal separate stormwater system, which occurs by chance and without planning or consideration prior to occurrence. 
(2)  Best management practices (BMP's). A wide range of management procedures, activities, and prohibitions on practices which control the quality and/or quantity of stormwater runoff and which are compatible with the planned land use. 
(3)  Clean Water Act. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act, as amended (33 U.S.C. 1251 et seq.). 
(4)  Construction activity. Activities subject to the Georgia Erosion and Sedimentation Control Act or NPDES General Construction Permits. These include construction projects resulting in land disturbance. Such activities include, but are not limited to, clearing and grubbing, grading, excavating, and demolition. 
(5)  Conveyance. Stormwater features designed for the movement of stormwater through the drainage system, such as concrete or metal pipes, ditches, depressions, swales, etc. 
(6)  Cooling water. Water used exclusively as a cooling medium in an appliance, device or apparatus. 
(7)  Development activity. 
(a)  All activities associated with the conversion of land or the expansion or replacement of an existing use to any new use intended for human operation, occupancy or habitation, other than for agricultural purposes devoted strictly to the cultivation of the land, dairying or animal husbandry; 
(b)  The construction installation, or alteration of a structure, impervious surface, or drainage facility; 
(c)  Clearing, scraping, grubbing, or otherwise significantly disturbing the soil, vegetation, mud, sand or rock of a site; or 
(d)  Adding, removing, exposing, excavating, leveling, grading, digging, burrowing, dumping, piling, dredging, or otherwise disturbing the soil, vegetation, mud, sand or rock of a site. 
(8)  Discharge. The release of treated or untreated water to the municipal separate stormwater system. 
(9)  Easement. An acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others. 
(10)  Illegal connection. Either of the following: 
(a)  Any pipe, open channel, drain or conveyance, whether on the surface or subsurface, which allows an illicit discharge to enter the storm drain system including, but not limited to, any conveyances which allow any non-stormwater discharge, including sewage, process wastewater, and wash water, to enter the storm drain system, regardless of whether such pipe, open channel, drain or conveyance has been previously allowed, permitted, or approved by an authorized enforcement agency; or 
(b)  Any pipe, open channel, drain or conveyance connected to the municipal separate stormwater system which has not been documented in plans, maps, or equivalent records and approved by an authorized enforcement agency. 
(11)  Illicit connection. A connection to a municipal separate stormwater system which results in discharge that is not composed entirely of stormwater runoff except discharges pursuant to a NPDES permit (other than the NPDES permit for discharges from the municipal separate stormwater). 
(12)  Illicit discharge. Any direct or indirect non-stormwater discharge to the municipal separate stormwater system, except as exempted in Division 2 of this article. 
(13)  Industrial activity. Activities subject to NPDES Industrial Permits as defined in 40 CFR, Section 122.26 (b)(14). 
(14)  Maintenance. Any action necessary to preserve stormwater management facilities in proper working condition, in order to serve their intended purposes and to prevent structural failure of such facilities. 
(15)  Municipal separate stormwater system. A conveyance or system of conveyances (including roads with drainage systems, highways, rights-of-way, municipal streets, catch basins, curbs, gutters, ditches, man-made channels, storm drains, detention ponds, otherstomwater facilities) which are: 
(a)  Owned or maintained by the city; 
(b)  Designed or used for collecting or conveying stormwater; 
(c)  Not a combined sewer; and 
(d)  Not part of a Wastewater Treatment Plant ("WTP"). 
(16)  National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System ("NPDES") Storm Water Discharge Permit. A permit issued by the Georgia EPD under authority delegated pursuant to 33 USC § 1342(b) that authorizes the discharge of pollutants to waters of the United States Army Corps of Engineers, whether the permit is applicable on an individual, group, or general area-wide basis. 
(17)  Non-stormwater discharge. Any discharge to the storm drain system that is not composed entirely of stormwater. 
(18)  Person. Except to the extent exempted from this article, any individual, partnership, firm, association, joint venture, public or private corporation, trust, estate, commission, board, public or private institution, utility, cooperative, city, county or other political subdivision of the state, any interstate body or any other legal entity. 
(19)  Pollutant. Anything which causes or contributes to pollution. Pollutants may include, but are not limited to: paints, varnishes, and solvents; petroleum hydrocarbons; automotive fluids; cooking grease; detergents (biodegradable or otherwise); degreasers; cleaning chemicals; non-hazardous liquid and solid wastes and yard wastes; refuse, rubbish, garbage, litter, or other discarded or abandoned objects and accumulations, so that same may cause or contribute to pollution; floatables; pesticides, herbicides, and fertilizers; liquid and solid wastes; sewage, fecal coliform and pathogens; dissolved and particulate metals; animal wastes; wastes and residues that result from constructing a building or structure; concrete and cement; and noxious or offensive matter of any kind. 
(20)  Pollution. The contamination or other alteration of any water's physical, chemical or biological properties, including change in temperature, taste, color, turbidity, or odor of such waters or the discharge of any liquid, gaseous, solid, radioactive, or other substance into any such waters as will or is likely to create a nuisance or render such waters harmful, detrimental or injurious to the public health, safety or welfare or to domestic, commercial, industrial, agricultural, recreational, or other legitimate beneficial uses, or to livestock, wild animals, birds, fish or other aquatic life. 
(21)  Premises. Any building, lot, parcel of land, or portion of land whether improved or unimproved including adjacent sidewalks and parking strips. 
(22)  Private. Property or facilities owned by individuals, corporations and other organizations, and not by the city, county, state or federal government. 
(23)  Procedure. A procedure adopted by the director of public works or city engineer and approved by the city manager, to implement a regulation or regulations adopted under this article, or to carry out other responsibilities as may be required by this article or other articles, codes, ordinances, or resolutions of the City or other agencies. 
(24)  Regulation. Any regulation, rule or requirement prepared by the director of public works or city engineer and approved by the city manager, pursuant to the requirements of this article. 
(25)  Restaurant. Any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out as a place where food is prepared and served to customers either over the counter, at a table or counter, or through an exterior sales window. 
(26)  Sanitary sewer system. The complete sanitary sewer system of the city or county which discharges sewage directly or indirectly into any waste water treatment plant, including sanitary sewer pipelines, manholes and flushing inlets and appurtenances to the foregoing, but shall exclude any portion or facilities of the sewage treatment plant. 
(27)  Site. Any lot, plot, parcel or tract of land. 
(28)  State waters. Any and all rivers, streams, creeks, branches, lakes, reservoirs, ponds, drainage systems, springs, wells, and other bodies of surface and subsurface water, natural or artificial, lying within, or forming a part, of the boundaries of the State of Georgia which are not entirely confined and retained completely upon the property of a single person. 
(29)  Stormwater. Stormwater runoff, snow melt runoff, and surface runoff and drainage. 
(30)  Stormwater management facilities. Constructed or natural components of a stormwater drainage system designed to perform a particular function, or multiple functions including, but not limited to, pipes, swales, ditches, culverts, street gutters, detention basins, retention basins, constructed wetlands, infiltration devices, catch basins, oil/water separators, sediment basins, natural systems and modular pavement. 
(31)  Stormwater runoff. The direct response of a land surface to precipitation, and includes the surface and subsurface runoff that enters a ditch, stream, storm drain or other concentrated flow during and following precipitation. 
(32)  Structural stormwater control. A structural stormwater management facility or device that controls stormwater runoff and changes the characteristics of that runoff including, but not limited to, the quantity and quality, the period of release or the velocity of flow. 
(33)  Variance. The modification of the minimum stormwater management requirements for specific circumstances where strict adherence of the requirements would result in unnecessary hardship and not fulfill the intent of this article. 
(34)  Water quality. Those characteristics of stormwater runoff that relate to the physical, chemical, biological, or radiological integrity of water. 
(35)  Water quantity. Those characteristics of stormwater runoff that relate to the rate and volume of the stormwater runoff. 
(Ord. No. 2006-30, §§ 1, 2, 8, 9-18-06) 
Sec. 10-146. - Applicability. 
(a)  The provisions of this article shall apply throughout the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  The application of this article and the provisions expressed herein shall be the minimum stormwater management requirements and shall not be deemed a limitation or repeal of any other powers granted by state statute or local ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2006-30, §§ 1, 2, 9-18-06) 
Sec. 10-147. - Compatibility with other regulations. 
    This article is not intended to modify or repeal any other article, ordinance, rule, regulation, or other provision of law. The requirements of this article are in addition to the requirements of any other article, ordinance, rule, regulation, or other provision of law, and where any provision of this article imposes restrictions different from those imposed by any other article, ordinance, rule, regulation, or other provision of law, whichever provision is more restrictive or imposes higher protective standards for human health or the environment shall control. 
(Ord. No. 2006-30, §§ 1, 2, 9, 9-18-06) 
Sec. 10-149. - Duties of the city engineer. 
    The city engineer or designee shall: 
(1)  Administer, coordinate and oversee acquisition, design and construction of the municipal stormwater management facilities and conveyances; 
(2)  Establish or oversee establishment of development standards and guidelines for controlling stormwater runoff; 
(3)  Determine the manner in which stormwater management facilities should be operated; 
(4)  Advise the mayor and council on issues related to stormwater; and 
(5)  Develop programs or procedures to control the discharge of pollutants into the municipal separate stormwater system. 
(Ord. No. 2006-30, §§ 1, 2, 10, 9-18-06) 
Sec. 10-150. - Duties of the public works director. 
    The public works director or designee shall: 
(1)  Administer, coordinate and oversee operations and maintenance of the municipal stormwater facilities and conveyances; 
(2)  Inspect private systems which discharge to the municipal separate stormwater system; 
(3)  Conduct follow up inspections of private systems as required by the city's NPDES permit; 
(4)  Protect facilities and properties controlled by the city and prescribe how they are used by others; 
(5)  Require new, increased, or significantly changed stormwater contributions to comply with the terms of this article; 
(6)  Coordinate and monitor educational programs required under the city's NPDES permit; and 
(7)  Implement the stormwater management program for the city. 
(Ord. No. 2006-30, §§ 1, 2, 11, 9-18-06) 
Sec. 10-151. - Stormwater runoff quantity controls. 
(1)  Water quantity controls will be provided as part of all development pursuant to the provisions of the city's soil erosion and sedimentation control ordinance and the flood damage prevention ordinance; 
(2)  The city may allow stormwater runoff that otherwise is of unacceptable quantity or which would be discharged in volumes or at rates in excess of those otherwise allowed by the soil erosion and sedimentation control ordinance or the flood damage prevention ordinance, to be discharged into drainage facilities off-site of the development, provided the following conditions are met: 
(a)  It is not practicable to completely manage runoff on site in a manner that meets the design and performance standards found in the soil erosion and sedimentation control and the flood damage prevention ordinances and any accompanying design manuals; 
(b)  Off-site drainage facilities and channels leading to them are designed, constructed and maintained in accordance with requirements of those ordinances; 
(c)  Adequate provision is made for sharing of construction, maintenance and operating costs of facilities; and 
(3)  The Standards and Guidelines for Roadway Enhancement and Vegetation Control Policies as promulgated by the Georgia Department of Transportation are hereby adopted as standards of the city and incorporated into this article as fully as though set out at length herein. Copies of such standards shall be maintained on file in the office of the city engineer where they shall be available for public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 2006-30, §§ 1, 2, 12, 9-18-06) 
DIVISION 2. - PROHIBITIONS 

Sec. 10-152. - Prohibitions. 
(a)  No person shall throw, drain, run, or otherwise discharge, cause, or allow others under its control to throw, drain, run, or otherwise discharge, into the municipal separate stormwater system, any pollutants, matter of any nature, or waters other than stormwater or surface water whether they contain any pollutants or not. 
(b)  The following discharges are exempt from the prohibition provision above:
