Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether this purpose is manifested are: that the person, while a pedestrian or in a motor vehicle, repeatedly beckons to, attempts to stop, engages or attempts to engage in conversation with any person by hailing, waving arms or bodily gestures for the purpose of inducing, enticing, or hiring another to commit an unlawful sex act. 
(Ord. No. 97-11, § 1, 4-21-97) 
Sec. 12-18. - Picketing. 
(a)  Persons engaged in peaceful picketing shall observe the following: 
(1)  No picketing shall be permitted upon any street or other way designed primarily for vehicular traffic. 
(2)  Persons engaged in peaceful picketing shall remain on the outer limits of any sidewalk being used for that purpose, i.e., upon the side nearest the street, and shall keep moving at all times. 
(3)  No person, while picketing, shall impede or hinder pedestrian or vehicular traffic upon any sidewalk, street or public way. 
(4)  Persons engaged in picketing shall maintain a distance of ten (10) feet from each other, and shall at no time prevent free and unimpeded movement of invitees and owners onto and away from any private property, or any person onto and away from any public property. 
(5)  It shall be unlawful to picket between 8:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. Eastern Standard Time or Eastern Daylight Time, whichever is in effect within the city. 
(b)  Any person violating any provision of this section shall be guilty of an offense. 
(Ord. No. 97-11, § 1, 4-21-97) 
Sec. 12-18.1. - Damage to property by animals. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or any person having custody of any dog or other animal to permit, either willfully or by failure to exercise due care or control, any dog or other animal to enter upon or damage the property of the City of College Park or to damage the property of another, whether said animal is leashed or unleashed. For purposes of this section, the leaving or dropping of fecal matter by any dog or other animal upon the property of another, or upon the property of the city, shall be deemed to cause damage thereupon. If such dog or other animal damages property as provided herein, the owner or other person having custody or control of such dog or other animal shall be required to immediately remove and dispose of such fecal matter or other droppings, or upon his failure to do so, shall be fined as provided in paragraph (d) hereof. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, the property of the city shall include but shall not be limited to any and all public streets, sidewalks, parks, and buildings, as well as lawns and driveways adjacent thereto; the term "property of another" shall include the driveways, lawns and swales of single-family residential homeowners as well as common halls in any apartment house, tenement house, hotel or other multiple dwelling; any entranceway, stairway or wall immediately abutting on a public sidewalk; any theater, shop, store, office building, and any other building used in common by the public. 
(c)  In the event that any dog or other animal shall cause damage upon any property of another or upon the property of the city, proof of the occurrence and proof of the identity of the owner or other person having custody or control of the dog or other animal shall be sufficient to convict the person owning or having charge or control of the animal, of violating the terms and conditions of this section. 
(d)  The penalty for any violation of this section shall be a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500,00). 
(Ord. No. 98-19, § 1, 9-21-98) 
Sec. 12-19. - Failure to disperse. 
    At any lawful assembly as defined by section 19-70 of this Code of Ordinances, or at any place where rioting occurs, it shall be unlawful to fail to disperse or to fail to move on after having been commanded by a police officer to do so. 
(Ord. No. 97-11, § 1, 4-21-97) 
Sec. 12-20. - Vandalism, trespass, property damage-Public and private property generally. 
(a)  Writing, carving, mutilating. It shall be unlawful for any person to write, paint, carve or cut any letter, character, or device, or in any way mutilate or deface any public or private property, including but not limited to any church, public building, private house, wall or fence belonging to the City of College Park or to another person within the city. 
(b)  Damaging property generally. It shall be unlawful for any person intentionally, willfully, maliciously, wantonly, negligently, recklessly, or otherwise to damage, injure, deface, destroy, tamper with, or interfere with, any property, real or personal, or any improvements to any real or personal property or other property, public or private, located within the corporate limits of the City of College Park or to trespass upon said property. "Public property" shall include real or personal property owned by the City of College Park, any property in which the city has a substantial legal interest, property under the supervision or control of the city, or other publicly-owned property within the City. Property shall include but not be limited to approaches to buildings, the trees, shrubbery and grounds belonging to the same, or any other furniture, fixtures or structures thereof. 
(c)  Aiding or abetting the unlawful damaging, defacing, or possessing of private property. It shall be unlawful for any person in any manner to aid, assist, or abet another person intentionally, willfully, maliciously, wantonly, negligently or otherwise to damage any property, public or private, real or personal, as prohibited in subsection (b) of this section. It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his or her possession or control the property of another, knowing that the owner has not consented thereto. 
(d)  Restitution to property owner or city. Any person convicted of violating subsection 12-20(a), (b) or (c) of this section may, as a condition of receiving a suspended jail sentence, be required to pay restitution to the property owner or to the city in an amount sufficient to compensate the owner or the city for the cost of restoring the property to its original condition. 
(e)  Property owner responsibility It shall be unlawful for any person who is the owner or who has primary responsibility for control of property or for repair or maintenance of in the city to permit property that is defaced with graffiti to remain defaced for a period in excess of ten (10) days. The city may provide notice of defacement to such owner or responsible by first class mail or personal service; provided, that failure to receive notice shall not alleviate the person's responsibility for removal of the graffiti. Notice shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The street address and/or description of the property sufficient for identification of the property; 
(2)  A description of the graffiti with notice to remove same, and notice that the property owner shall, if the graffiti is not removed within ten (10) days after receipt of the notice, be cited for violation of this section. 
(f)  Exceptions to property owner responsibility. The removal requirements of subsection (e) above shall not apply if the property owner or responsible party can demonstrate that: 
(1)  The property owner or responsible party lacks the financial ability to remove the defacing graffiti; or 
(2)  The property owner or responsible party has an active program for the removal, of graffiti and has scheduled the removal of the graffiti as part of that program, in which case it shall be unlawful to permit such property to remain defaced with graffiti for a period of thirty (30) days after defacement. 
(g)  Citation of owner, right of city to remove graffiti. Whenever the owner or person responsible for control or maintenance of private property fails or refuses to remove the graffiti after notice by the city to do so, such owner or responsible person shall be cited for violation of this section. The city may, upon the owner's or responsible person's failure to act, take any necessary action to remove, repaint, or repair the graffiti-damaged property and may use public funds for such action, the cost of which shall be a lien on the property served. Nothing in this section shall be construed to require the city to undertake such repair, repainting or removal. 
(h)  (1)  For the purposes of this section, the term "graffiti" shall have that meaning ascribed to it in O.C.G.A. Section 17-15A-2. 
(2)  For the purposes of this section, the term "graffiti implement or paraphernalia" shall mean any substance or material such as, but not limited to, aerosol paint containers, permanent ink markers, paint sticks, and etchers; also including, but not limited to, tips or nozzles which can be applied to aerosol paint containers. 
(i)  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess any graffiti implement or paraphernalia while in, on, at or about any private property without the owner or occupant's permission or any public property; including, but not limited to, public parks, playgrounds, swimming pools, recreation facilities, schools, school district facilities, libraries, court houses, utility stations, storm drains or any other publicly owned, operated and/or maintained facility. This subsection shall not apply to persons located on public sidewalks or streets during each daily period from sunrise to sunset. This subsection shall not apply to any officer, employee or agent of the public entity that owns the public property acting within the scope of their employment. 
(j)  Violations of this section shall be punishable pursuant to section 1-8 of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 97-11, § 1, 4-21-97; Ord. No. 98-08, § 1, 4-6-98; Ord. No. 2005-10, § 1, 5-16-05) 
Cross reference- Damaging property in parks, § 13-7; damaging streets with vehicles, § 19-33. 
State Law reference- Damaging property, vandalism, trespass, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-21 et seq. 
Sec. 12-21. - Same-Cemeteries. 
(a)  Disturbing graves. It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb any grave, or deface, pull up or remove anything placed to mark a grave, or any paling or wall placed around a grave, or remove any planks, posts or timbers in a cemetery. 
(b)  Damaging, destroying other structures, ornaments. It shall be unlawful for any person to destroy, mutilate, deface, damage or remove any tomb, monument, gravestone, or other structure placed in a cemetery, or any fence, railing or other work used for the protection or ornamentation of a cemetery, or to willfully destroy, cut, break, remove, or injure any tree, shrub or plant that may have been planted or may be growing in a cemetery, or to commit any other trespass within a cemetery. 
(Ord. No. 97-11, § 1, 4-21-97) 
Sec. 12-22. - Shopping carts; removal, abandonment, recovery by owner, disposition of unclaimed carts. 
(a)  As used in this section, "shopping cart" means those push carts of the type which are commonly provided by grocery stores, drug stores, or other merchant stores or markets for the use of the public in transporting commodities in stores and markets, and incidentally from the stores to a place outside the store. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to remove a shopping cart from the premises of the owner of such shopping cart without consent of the owner or the owner's agent, servant or employee. For the purpose of this section, the premises shall include all of the parking areas set aside by the owner or on behalf of the owner for the parking of vehicles for the convenience of the patrons of the owner. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon a shopping cart upon any public street, sidewalk, way, or parking lot, other than the parking lot of the premises of the owner, or to abandon same upon private property not authorized by the owner of the shopping cart for the storage of shopping carts. Any shopping cart found off of the premises of a shopping area shall be deemed an abandoned shopping cart unless ownership is claimed by an adult who shall give such adult's name and address and the name and address from whom said shopping cart was purchased or acquired. 
(d)  Upon the discovery of any abandoned shopping cart which can be identified as belonging to a particular owner, the city police or the city building inspector shall give written notice to the owner of said abandoned shopping cart, who shall within three (3) days of the written notice, take possession of and return the shopping cart to such owner's premises. 
(e)  If the owner fails to remove the abandoned shopping cart after three (3) days from the written notice, the city may remove the abandoned shopping cart and dispose of the same at the expense of the owner. 
(f)  If the owner of an abandoned shopping cart cannot be identified, the city may remove said abandoned shopping cart and dispose of the same in any manner, including the sale by private or public sale. Any owner proving ownership at a private or public sale shall be liable for the expenses incurred by the city. Notwithstanding the above, the city shall be authorized to charge a fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) to any owner proving ownership of an abandoned shopping cart. 
(Ord. No. 97-11, § 1, 4-21-97) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 16-8-21. 
Sec. 12-23. - Fortune telling. 
    It shall be unlawful to engage in fortune telling, palmistry, astrology, phrenology, or any other similar occupation within the city. 
(Ord. No. 97-11, § 1, 4-21-97) 
State Law reference- Authority of the county to prohibit or tax, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-15. 
Sec. 12-24. - Weapons-Discharging. 
(a)  Firearms. It shall be unlawful to discharge, fire or shoot any firearm within the city except in defense of person, provided that this section shall not prevent the discharge of firearms in honor guards at funerals, the discharge of firearms by authorized city employees in the discharge of their duties, the discharge of firearms in a regularly-licensed shooting gallery, or at ceremonial functions for which a permit for the discharge of firearms has been obtained. 
(b)  Other weapons. It shall be unlawful for any person to shoot an air rifle or B.B. gun, or to use a slingshot or bow and arrow in the city. 
(Ord. No. 97-11, § 1, 4-21-97) 
State Law reference- Weapons, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-10 et seq. 
Sec. 12-25. - Same-Carrying knives, razors and similar devices. 
    It shall be unlawful to have, possess or carry upon the streets, alleys or sidewalks of the city, any of the following implements unless the same are securely wrapped so as not to be readily available for harmful use. 
(1)  Any knife which has a blade which opens automatically by hand pressure applied to a button, spring, or other device in the handle, the blade of which projects from the handle more than two (2) inches. 
(2)  Any knife which has any obstruction or other device of any kind which holds the blade open, the blade of which when open projects from the handle more than two (2) inches. 
(3)  Any knife of any kind, the blade of which when open projects from the handle more than three (3) inches. This shall include all knives, such as butcher knives or knives which do not close. 
(4)  Any razor. 
(5)  Any ice pick or similar device having a sharp point, except that this shall not apply to any person delivering ice. 
(Ord. No. 97-11, § 1, 4-21-97) 
Sec. 12-26. - Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority (MARTA) offenses. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to commit or attempt to commit any of the following acts in a public transit bus, a rapid rail car, a rapid rail station, or intermodal bus station: 
(1)  Spitting, defecating, or urinating; 
(2)  Discarding litter, except into receptacles designated for that purpose. Litter under this subsection specifically includes, but is not limited to, chewing gum and tobacco products; 
(3)  Using tobacco in any form, including but not limited to, smoking or using smokeless tobacco; 
(4)  Smoking any other substance, whether legal or illegal; 
(5)  Consuming food or beverage or possessing any open food or beverage container, provided that this paragraph shall not apply to an operator of a public transit bus at an authorized lay over point or to a person providing food or beverage to any child under age five (5); 
(6)  Consuming alcoholic beverages or being under the influence of alcoholic beverages while on or being transported by MARTA buses, trains or rail cars within the corporate limits of the City of College Park. Charter bus services shall be excluded from these restrictions; 
(7)  Playing any radio, cassette, cartridge, or tape player, compact disc player, or other similar device, unless such device is connected to an earphone that limits the sound to the hearing of the individual user; 
(8)  Carrying or possessing any explosives, acids, other dangerous articles, or live animals, except for the following: 
a.  A guide dog or service dog as described in O.C.G.A. § 30-4-1, provided that such guide dog or service dog is accompanied by a physically disabled person, blind person, person with visual disabilities, deaf person, or a person who is responsible for training a guide dog or service dog; and 
b.  Small pets confined to rigid pet carriers with locks or latches; 
(9)  Threatening, intimidating, obstructing, injuring, interfering with, or otherwise disrupting or disturbing the operation, operator, or passengers of a public transit bus or rapid rail car; 
(10)  Boarding any public transit bus through the rear exit door, unless so directed by an employee or agent of the carrier; 
(11)  Remaining aboard any public transit bus or rapid rail car after such vehicle has completed its scheduled route and passengers have been advised to exit the vehicle or, remaining aboard any public transit bus or rapid rail car after having been warned that such vehicle has entered a garage or other restricted area not open to the public; 
(12)  Entering, exiting, or passing through any emergency door of any rapid rail car or public transit bus in the absence of a bona fide emergency; or 
(13)  Entering the operator's cab or driver's seat of any rapid rail car or public transit bus in the absence of a bona fide emergency. 
(b)  Employees of a public transportation authority or carrier while at work performing the duties of their employment shall be exempted from the restrictions of paragraphs (10), (11), (12), and (13) of subsection (a). 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to evade or attempt to evade payment of fare for transportation service upon MARTA buses, trains, or rail cars within the corporate limits of the City of College Park. As used in this section, evasion of payment of the fare shall include, but not be limited to the following acts, activities, or conduct: 
(1)  Selling, making, or possessing any coin, note, token, transfer, Transcard, or similar article which has been altered from its original condition, contrary to its intended use to enter or gain entry into or on any bus, rail, vehicle, or station; 
(2)  Selling or exchanging any token, transfer, Transcard, ticket, fare medium, or similar article used or to be used as payment for entry into or on any bus, rail, car, vehicle, station or terminal without the express consent of the public transit agency owning or operating such vehicles or stations; 
(3)  Misusing a transfer, Transcard, pass, ticket, token, or other evidence of payment or prepayment of a fare issued by MARTA with the intent to avoid or to assist another in avoiding payment of the fare for transportation services; 
(4)  Offering entry or providing entry into or on any bus, rapid rail car, or station to any person without the payment of the proper fare to the public transit agency owning or operating such vehicles or stations; 
(5)  Gaining entry into or on any bus, rapid rail car, or station without the payment of the proper fare to the public transit agency owning or operating such vehicles or stations; or 
(6)  Gaining entry into or on any bus, rapid rail car, or station through the use of a Transcard or other similar fare medium which is the property of another person other than the person whose signature appears on the Transcard. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to write, paint, carve or cut any letter, character or device or in any way to mar, mutilate, or deface any rail station or approaches thereto or any retaining wall, tree, shrubbery or other any other furniture or fixtures belonging to or located on such property within the City of College Park owned and/or operated by the Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority, or owned or maintained by the City of College Park, if such property is adjacent to a MARTA station, including but not limited to, streets and sidewalks. 
(Ord. No. 97-11, § 1, 4-21-97; Ord. No. 97-23, § 1, 10-6-97; Ord. No. 98-15, § 1, 8-17-98) 
Sec. 12-27. - Brown bagging. 
(a)  For the purpose of this section: 
(1)  "Brown bagging" means the bringing, taking or carrying of any alcoholic beverage into a business licensed to operate within the city, but not licensed for the consumption of alcoholic beverages on the premises, provided that bringing an alcoholic beverage into a house, apartment, room or other unit designed for private residential occupancy shall not fail within this definition. 
(2)  Brown bagging shall include the following prohibited acts: 
a.  Any person who brown bags; 
b.  Any person participating in consumption of an alcoholic beverage being brown bagged; 
c.  Any person who consumes an alcoholic beverage on any premises holding a business license, except for those premises licensed for on-premises consumption of alcoholic beverages or otherwise exempted from the definition of brown bagging by virtue of the private residential character of the occupancy. 
d.  Any employee of the business establishment in whose presence brown bagging knowingly or with reckless indifference occurs. 
(b)  Brown bagging is prohibited within the city. 
(Ord. No. 97-11, § 1, 4-21-97) 
Sec. 12-28. - Vehicles to be parked in driveways. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to place an automotive vehicle, boat or trailer-type vehicle on the front yard of any premises unless placed on established driveway. For the purpose of this section, "established driveway" means any area cleared and prepared for vehicular parking and covered by an impenetrable surface such as asphalt or concrete. No established driveway shall have a width in excess of twenty (20) feet. 
(b)  Any automotive vehicle, boat or trailer type vehicle may be parked or stored within a side or rear yard of a residentially zoned lot, subject to the conditions and limitations set forth in this section. 
(1)  Automotive vehicles, boats and trailer type vehicles parked on side or rear yards shall be placed only on a permanently installed unpenetrable surface such as concrete or asphalt. 
(2)  No automotive vehicle, boat or trailer type vehicle shall be parked or stored within ten (10) feet of any door, window, or other opening of the dwelling which provides light, air, entrance or exit from the dwelling necessary to or which serves the health, safety and general welfare of the occupants of the dwelling or lot. 
(3)  The ground area of any such parking and storage area (or if there is more than one (1) such area, the total ground area of all such parking areas) shall not occupy more than twenty (20) per cent of the required side or rear yard area prescribed by the district and other regulations of the zoning ordinance [Appendix A] applicable to the lot; provided, that no part of the required rear yard of a through lot shall be occupied if the rear lot line abuts the street. 
(4)  No automotive vehicle, boat or trader type vehicle shall be parked or stored in any part of the required street side yard of a corner lot. 
(5)  No automotive vehicle, boat or trailer type vehicle shall be parked or stored outdoors within ten (10) feet of the rear lot line or within ten (10) feet of the side lot line of the lot; provided, that such distance or space clearance requirements shall not apply where a wall of one-hour fire resistive material is constructed on the lot line adjacent to the parking area or between the parking area and the lot line, the height of which shall equal the height limits for walls applicable at the location of such wall. 
(6)  Should an owner or occupant maintain multiple vehicles on his property, all such vehicles in excess of four (4) shall be stored in a structure which is roofed and completely enclosed on all sides. No more than four (4) automotive vehicles, boats or trader type vehicles shall be routinely parked or stored on the property unless so screened from view of public rights-of-way and adjacent lots by placement in such enclosed structure. 
(Ord. No. 97-11, § 1, 4-21-97; Ord. No. 98-05, § 1, 3-2-98) 
Sec. 12-29. - Operation of unmuffled engines on recreational vehicles prohibited. 
(a)  Prohibited acts. It shall be a violation of this section for any person to operate or allow to be operated a recreational or leisure-type vehicle which makes or creates noise of such a character, intensity, or duration as to be detrimental to the life, health or welfare of any individual or which steadily or intermittently annoys, disturbs, injures, or endangers, the comfort, repose, peace of safety of any individual. 
(b)  Definitions. For the purpose of this section the following definitions shall apply: 
(1)  "Engines" shall include any reciprocating or rotary engine which is fueled by gasoline, diesel or other similar-type of fuel or mixture. 
(2)  "Unmuffled engine" is an engine which is not equipped with a functioning muffler or other similar silencing or noise-reducing device which reduces the level of noise to an acceptable level as set out in this section. 
(3)  "Recreational vehicles" shall include all vehicles which are designed and used primarily for recreational purposes or other leisure-type uses, whether driven or otherwise controlled, and shall be deemed to include off-road motorcycles and three wheelers, trail-bikes, go-carts, dune buggies, all-terrain vehicles, mopeds and other such recreational vehicles. 
(c)  Exemptions. The provisions of this section shall not include and shall specifically exclude the operation of engines under the circumstances as follows: 
(1)  Operation of such engines in connection with a commercial business for the sale or repair of such recreational vehicles, provided that the business is operated in an area properly zoned or that type of commercial activity. 
(2)  The operation of such engines which are connected to or used as mowers, blowers, cutters, trimmers, pumps, generators, saws, shredders or similar equipment or tools, provided that the silencing device on the engine is reasonably maintained in a condition as originally designed. 
(Ord. No. 97-11, § 1, 4-21-97) 
ARTICLE II. - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE 

Sec. 12-30. - Purpose. 
    To require the maintenance of premises to retain property values and to protect the general environment and appearance of neighborhoods, residential complexes, and commercial and industrial areas, and to insure safe and sanitary conditions in buildings, structures, and premises in the city to protect the public health, safety, and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 86-27, § 1, 9-2-86) 
Sec. 12-31. - Definitions. 
(a)  Object shall be any items of personal property, other than a vehicle, boat or trailer-type vehicle, which is not related to the use and purpose for which the real property is occupied or owned or permitted by the applicable zoning classification. "Objects" under this article shall also include junk materials (any item that has no significant value in its present form); machinery and equipment; appliances or other household items; lumber and building materials; dirt, sand, fill, rock, stone, or other materials not forming part of a structure or landscaping. This definition shall also apply to abandoned tires, dilapidated buildings, and other unsightly accumulations of debris that may be placed on residential, commercial, or industrial property. 
(b)  To place shall mean to establish the presence on property of an object which (1) is capable of being moved or removed which is not affixed to the real property, and (2) is present for a period of ten (10) consecutive days whether or not the location of the item on the property is changed. 
(c)  Person shall mean any natural person, corporation, partnership, authority created by statute, association or other entity or combination thereof. 
(d)  Vehicle automotive shall be an automobile, truck, van, or other motor vehicle designed and intended for use in transporting people and goods. 
(e)  Front yard for the purposes of this article is that portion of the property running the width of the principal building on the lot as extended to the right-of-way line of an abutting street. If there is no building on the property, the entire property shall be deemed the "front yard." 
(f)  Established driveway means an area that is paved, graveled, bare of vegetation, or otherwise clearly indicative of the area that is normally used for vehicles to enter onto or exit from real property from or to a public or private street. 
(g)  Derelict automotive vehicle is a vehicle that for a period of at least ten (10) consecutive days: 
(1)  Is physically incapable of traveling under it s own power; 
(2)  Is physically capable of traveling under its own power, but during such traveling on a public road would be in violation of any provision of Title 40, Chapter 8, Article I of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated; or 
(3)  Possesses at least one (1) of the following characteristics: 
a.  At least one (1) broken window. 
b.  At least one (1) door that cannot be opened. 
c.  At least one (1) door that cannot be closed. 
d.  Parts of the vehicle are attached to the vehicle with tape or wire. 
e.  Excessive rusting covering at least thirty (30) per cent of the body of the vehicle. 
f.  Missing a door, the hood, the trunk cover, or a tire. 
(h)  Derelict boat or trailer-type vehicle is a boat or trailer-type vehicle which (1) is dismantled, partially dismantled, deteriorated or not safe for use due to disrepair or damage, and (2) which constitutes a nuisance or health or safety hazard in that it provides a place for insects, rodents, and other animals to exist, attracts children, vagrants, or other individuals and may cause injury to them. 
(i)  Accessory building means a carport, attached or detached garage, storage building or any other not-for-habitation buildings on the premises. 
[As] generally defined by statutory and judicial principals in Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 86-27, § 1, 9-2-86; Ord. No. 2002-07, § 1, 2-18-02) 
Sec. 12-32. - Occupants or owners to keep premises free of litter, debris junk materials, derelict vehicles and overgrowth. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the occupant of premises or the owner of premises to have or to place any of the following on said premises to the extent and in a manner that could threaten or endanger the public health, safety or welfare or could adversely affect and impair the economic value of adjacent property: 
(1)  Any accumulation of litter, debris, refuse, garbage or animal excrement on any front, side, or rear yard or on any porch, or underneath any building or in any accessory building. 
(2)  Any object or objects as defined, on the front yard or on a front porch of residential, commercial, or industrial property. 
(3)  Any object or objects, as defined, on the side or rear yards, or on side or rear porches or underneath any building or in any accessory building unless such objects are completely enclosed within a building or are enclosed with a solid fence of such height that the objects are completely screened from the view of persons on adjacent property and to passers-by on public rights-of-way. 
(4)  Any overgrown grass or weeds of a height of six (6) inches or more or any other unkempt vegetation, including but not limited to dead tree limbs or dead trees, in any yard, front, side or rear. 
(5)  Any storage building on the front yard or any dilapidated storage building on the side or rear yard. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to place, keep, store or allow to remain any derelict automotive vehicle, derelict boat or derelict trailer-type vehicle or parts thereof on an established driveway of a front yard, and it shall be unlawful to place, keep, store or allow to remain any derelict automotive vehicle, derelict boat or derelict trailer-type vehicle or parts thereof on the side or rear yards if visible from a street, lane, or adjoining property unless completely enclosed within an accessory building so as not to be visible from the street, lane, or adjoining property. In the case of a dispute as to the condition of a vehicle, the owner will cooperate with the city's inspection department and police department to verify the state of repair of the vehicle within five (5) days of notice. If the vehicle owner does not cooperate with the inspection department and police department, the vehicle shall be presumed to be in violation of this article. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to material which is being used in connection with a construction actively taking place on said premises provided the construction activity is being diligently pursued and complies with applicable ordinances and codes. 
(Ord. No. 86-27, § 1, 9-2-86; Ord. No. 88-22, §§ 2, 3, 8-15-88; Ord. No. 94-6, §§ 1, 2, 9-6-94; Ord. No. 95-01, §§ 1, 2, 1-3-95; Ord. No. 2002-38, § 1, 9-3-02; Ord. No. 2004-29, § 1, 9-20-04) 
Note- See editor's note, § 12-29.3. 
Sec. 12-32.1. - Outdoor storage of personal property. 
(a)  No person shall store, keep, maintain, or allow to be kept for sale on any property which is, zoned for commercial or industrial uses within the city (with the exception of the W-1 Warehouse District) any used, wrecked, dismantled or junk automobiles or vehicles, or any new or used appliances, antiques, furniture, lumber, machinery, equipment, building material, cordage, and similar items and material unless the same is housed in a building. However, property displayed for sale during normal business hours may be stored outside for a period not to exceed twelve (12) hours each business day. Seasonal sales products may be displayed outside during the appropriate season, but in no case shall remain stored outside no longer than thirty (30) days. Any person needing a period of time in excess of thirty (30) days for the outside display of seasonal sales products shall make a written application to the mayor and council for such approval. 
(b)  On property zoned W-1 Warehouse District, no materials, equipment, supplies or similar items shall be placed or maintained in the required front yard area of such property, as defined and required by the city zoning ordinance, for a period of time exceeding seventy-two (72) hours of its arrival on the premises. At locations on the property other than in the required front yard areas; materials, equipment, supplies and similar items may be placed and maintained in outdoor storage, provided that such storage areas are enclosed by a chainlink fence at least six (6) feet in height equipped with view-obscuring slats. 
(c)  Notwithstanding any other provision in this section, it shall be unlawful to store new or used motor vehicle tires unless the same is housed in a building or permanent enclosed structure. 
(Ord. No. 97-01, § 2, 2-3-97; Ord. No. 99-15, § 4, 9-7-99; Ord. No. 2014-16, § 1, 10-21-14) 
Sec. 12-33. - Fences. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to erect a fence constructed of materials not specifically designed for fence construction, such as tin roofing material, plastic roofing material, barbed wire, or doors. The restriction on the use of barbed wire shall not apply to its use atop a lawful fence which is constructed at a height of not less than six (6) feet. Electric fences are permitted subject to restrictions within Section [Article] XX of the city's zoning ordinances. 
(b)  It shall also be unlawful for any person to improperly construct or maintain in unsound condition any fence. Likewise, it shall be unlawful for any dilapidated or otherwise unsound or unsightly fence or portion of fence to exist on any property. 
(Ord. No. 86-27, § 1, 9-2-86; Ord. No. 93-1A, §§ 1, 2, 2-1-93; Ord. No. 2015-13, § 1, 8-17-15) 
Sec. 12-34. - Maintenance of commercial and industrial properties. 
    All owners and occupants of commercial and industrial properties within the city shall keep buildings and other structures on such property in a good state of repair and free from dilapidation. The following constitute an illustrative, but not exclusive, listing of dilapidated conditions, which constitute a violation of this code: 
(1)  Broken windows or broken glass in doors; 
(2)  Gutters which are bent, missing, or which have pulled loose from their secured installation; 
(3)  Awnings which are torn, bent, or which present a dilapidated appearance due to holes, missing edging, or discoloration; 
(4)  Roofing material, which is missing, broken or which has blown loose; 
(5)  Peeling or blistered paint; 
(6)  Mildewed exterior surfaces; 
(7)  Repairs utilizing mismatched or substandard materials; 
(8)  Wood which is splintered, rotting, or which has lost its structural integrity. 
(9)  Masonry which has missing pieces or severe cracking; 
(10)  Raw untreated wood exposed to the elements; 
(11)  Any condition which would constitute a violation of the Unsafe Building Abatement Code. 
(Ord. No. 99-15, § 2, 9-7-99) 
Sec. 12-35. - Closure of businesses. 
(a)  For all structures designed to be used for or occupied by commercial or industrial uses, but which are currently vacant or are scheduled to become vacant, the owner of the property shall secure such structures for the protection of the property against vandalism and for the aesthetic preservation of the neighborhood and shall maintain such security measures until the building is once again occupied. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, the building owner shall remove all signage which no longer refers to a commercial or industrial use of the property, shall cover all windows of the structure with plywood which shall be painted in a color complementary to the building, and shall likewise secure all glass doors with a painted plywood covering. 
(c)  The owner of the vacant commercial or industrial property shall be responsible for maintaining the exterior of the building in accordance with all city codes and ordinances, including this Property Maintenance Code, and shall further be responsible for cleaning the exterior of premises to keep the exterior free from litter and other debris. The owner of such property shall promptly remove any litter and debris left upon the exterior of the property. 
(d)  While an owner may require any of the actions required by this section to be performed by a tenant prior to vacating the premises, such delegation will not relieve the owner from full compliance with this section or negate the owner's liability to the city in any manner whatsoever. 
(Ord. No. 99-15, § 2, 9-7-99) 
Sec. 12-36. - Notification of owner and tenant. 
    Whenever any provision of this article is being violated, the city shall notify the owner and/or any tenant and/or any user in possession of the land on which the alleged violation exists to abate the alleged violation within five (5) days of the date of service of the notice. Notice shall be by personal service or certified mail addressed to the party in violation at the address where the party is determined to be located, or if not possible by such service, notice shall be by posing a notice on the subject property. 
(Ord. No. 86-27, § 1, 9-2-86; Ord. No. 99-15, § 1, 9-7-99; Ord. No. 2002-38, § 2, 9-3-02) 
Sec. 12-37. - Violations. 
(a)  The failure to abate the alleged violation as set forth in the written notice within five working (5) days of the notice shall be deemed a violation of this article and the building official shall take all such appropriate measures to insure enforcement of this article is carried out; up to and including causing the violation, with approval of the city manager, to be removed by the use of city equipment and employees. In the event the city does not have sufficient equipment and/or employees to perform the removal, the building official, with the approval of the city manager, may contract with outside forces for the removal of said violation. The total cost to the city for removing and violation shall be special lien against the property and shall be placed on the tax records of the city and the applicable county. 
(b)  If the violation set forth in the notice is the first of such offense during a period of twelve (12) consecutive months, the owner or occupant may file an appeal in writing to the construction board of adjustment and appeals. Should the owner or occupant give cause to receive notice for more than one (1) offense for the same violation during a period of twelve (12) consecutive months, the building official shall issue a citation to the owner or occupant to appear before the city court and there shall be no appeal for the second or subsequent offenses occurring during a period of twelve (12) consecutive months. The fine for such additional citations shall be not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for the second offense and not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) for the third offense, when the second and third offense occurs within such period of twelve (12) consecutive months. 
(Ord. No. 86-27, § 1, 9-2-86; Ord. No. 88-24, § 1, 9-6-88; Ord. No. 99-15, § 1, 9-7-99; Ord. No. 2002-38, § 3, 9-3-02) 
Secs. 12-38-12-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RESERVED. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 97-11, § 1, adopted April 21, 1997, repealed Art. III in its entirety. Said article pertained to registration, sale and disposition of certain firearms and derived from Ord. No. 92-2, § 1, adopted March 16, 1992. 
ARTICLE IV. - CURFEW FOR MINORS 

Sec. 12-60. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the Curfew for Minors Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 97-10, § 1, 4-21-97) 
Sec. 12-61. - Findings; purpose. 
    The mayor and council after having received and studied reports compiled by the police department are alarmed and concerned for the safety and well-being of juveniles within the city, as well as the high number of incidents of thefts, including, but not limited to burglary and motor vehicle thefts being perpetrated by juveniles within the city. With the interstate highways, rapid transit system, and Hartsfield International Airport bringing thousands of nonresident transient people into and through the city at all hours of the day and night, juveniles are found to be at a high risk. The national epidemic of drugs and crimes of violence are of such nature that all reasonable and constitutional efforts must be employed to insulate and protect our youthful citizens from the influence and dangers associated with such activities. It is the intent of this article to make the parents the primary agents of enforcement, and, in addition to promote family life by encouraging children to be at home. 
    Prevailing community standards of family responsibility, public good, safety and welfare have determined that there is a proper time for cessation of outdoor activities by minors. This standard takes into consideration the danger hours for nocturnal crime and for exposure of minors to potential risks incident to immaturity, along with exceptions and provisions so as to not prohibit or unnecessary infringe upon reasonable legitimate purposes of any person. 
    Parental responsibility for the whereabouts of children is the norm. Legal sanctions to enforce such responsibility have had a demonstrated effect and, as parental control increases, the likelihood of juvenile delinquency and danger to minors decreases. The cooperative enforcement of this curfew by the city, the parents, and the minor will provide for a more safe and healthy community environment and will achieve the purposes hereinbefore stated. 
(Ord. No. 97-10, § 1, 4-21-97) 
Sec. 12-62. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this article: 
(1)  City is the City of College Park, Fulton and Clayton Counties, Georgia. 
(2)  Minor is any person under the age of seventeen (17), or, in equivalent phrasing often herein employed, any person sixteen (16) or less years of age. 
(3)  Parent is any person having legal custody of a minor (i) as a natural or adoptive parent, (ii) as a legal guardian, (iii) as a person who stands in loco parentis or (iv) as a person to whom legal custody has been given by order of court. 
(4)  Remain means to stay behind, to tarry and to stay unnecessarily upon the streets, alone or with others, in such manner that any minor involved would not be using the streets for ordinary or serious purposes such as mere passage or going home. To implement that thought with additional precision and precaution, numerous exceptions are expressly defined in section 12-64 so that this is not a mere prohibitory or presence type curfew ordinance. More and more exceptions become available with increasing years and advancing maturity as appropriate in the interest of reasonable regulation which is intended for use of the meaningful phrase "be or remain." 
(5)  Street is a way or place, of whatsoever nature, open to the use of the public as a matter of right for purposes of vehicular travel, or in the case of a sidewalk, for pedestrian travel. The term "street" includes the legal right-of-way, including but not limited to the cartway or traffic lanes, the curb, the sidewalks, whether paved or unpaved, any grass plots or other grounds found within the legal right of way of a street. The term "street" applies irrespective of what is called or formally named, whether alley, avenue, court, road or otherwise. 
(6)  Time of night referred to herein is based upon the prevailing standard of time, whether Eastern Standard Time or Eastern Daylight Saving Time, generally observed at that hour by the public in the City of College Park, prima facie the time then observed in the College Park Administrative Office. 
(Ord. No. 97-10, § 1, 4-21-97) 
Sec. 12-63. - Curfew for minors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person sixteen (16) or less years of age (under seventeen (17)) to be or remain in or upon the streets within the City of College Park at night during the period ending at 6:00 a.m. and beginning: 
(1)  At 8:00 p.m. for minors thirteen (13) or less years of age; 
(2)  At 10:00 p.m. for minors fourteen (14), fifteen (15) or sixteen (16) years of age. 
(Ord. No. 97-10, § 1, 4-21-97; Ord. No. 2008-15, § 1, 11-3-08) 
Sec. 12-64. - Exception. 
(a)  In the following exceptional cases a minor on a College Park street during the nocturnal hours for which section 12-63 is intended to provide the maximum limits of regulation (and a clear general guide for minors, their parents and their fellow citizens) shall not, however, be considered in violation of the curfew ordinance. 
(1)  When accompanied by a parent of such minor. 
(2)  When accompanied by an adult authorized and approved by a parent of such minor to take said parent's place in accompanying said minor for a designated period of time and purpose within a specified area. 
(3)  When exercising First Amendment rights protected by the United States Constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech and the right of assembly, provided that the exercise of such right is clearly evidenced by the minor's conduct. 
(4)  When the minor is on the sidewalk of the place where such minor resides, or on the sidewalk of either next-door neighbor who has not communicated an object to the police officer. 
(5)  When returning home, by a direct route from (and with thirty (30) minutes of the termination of) a school activity of a religious or other parentally-approved association. 
(6)  When authorized, by action by the mayor and council or chief of police or his or her assistant, in cases or reasonable necessity. Normally such action by the mayor and council or chief of police permitting use of the streets should be issued sufficiently in advance to permit appropriate publicly through news media and through other agencies such as the schools and churches, and shall define the activity, the scope of the use of the streets permitted, the period of time involved, not to extend more than thirty (30) minutes beyond the time for termination of such activity, and the reason for finding that such regulation is reasonably necessary and is consistent with the public interest and the purposes of this curfew ordinance. 
(7)  When traveling from or to the minor's residence and a verifiable place of employment and within thirty (30) minutes of the minor's time of departure or arrival. 
(8)  When in a motor vehicle with parental consent and engaged in bona fide interstate movement through the city, particularly on normal routes such as U.S. Highway 29 and interstate highways I-85 and I-285. This also exempts interstate travel beginning or ending in the city. 
(b)  Each of the foregoing exceptions, and their several limitations, are severable, as hereinafter provided, but here reemphasized; and additional, also severable, other exceptions, broadening with the progress toward maturity of minors enrolled respectively in elementary, middle and high schools, will be considered by the mayor and council as warranted by future experience illuminated by the views of student government associations, school personnel, citizens, associations, ward, precinct and neighborhood spokesmen, parents, officers and persons in authority concerned positively with minors as well as with juvenile delinquency. 
(Ord. No. 97-10, § 1, 4-21-97) 
Sec. 12-65. - Parental responsibility. 
    It shall be unlawful for a parent having legal custody of a minor knowingly to permit or by inefficient control to allow, such minor to be or remain upon any city street under circumstances not constituting an exception to, or otherwise beyond the scope of, the curfew ordinance. The term "knowingly" includes knowledge which a parent should reasonably be expected to have concerning the whereabouts of a minor in that parent's legal custody. It is intended to continue to keep neglectful or careless parents up to a reasonable community standard of parental responsibility through an objective test. It shall be no defense that a parent was completely indifferent to the activities or conduct or whereabouts of such minor. 
(Ord. No. 97-10, § 1, 4-21-97) 
Sec. 12-66. - Police procedures. 
(a)  A police officer of the city, upon finding or having attention called to any minor on the streets in prima facie violation of the curfew ordinance, normally shall take the minor into custody. A parent shall immediately be notified to come for such minor, and upon arrival the parent shall be interrogated. This is intended to permit ascertainment, under constitutional safeguards, of relevant facts, and to centralize responsibility in the officer there and then on duty for accurate, effective, fair, impartial and uniform enforcement, and recording, thus making available experienced supervisory personnel, the best of facilities and access to information and records. In the absence of convincing evidence such as a birth certificate, a police officer on the street shall in the first instance use his best judgement in determining age. 
(b)  Police procedures shall constantly be refined in the light of experience and may provide that the police officer may deliver to a parent thereof a minor under appropriate circumstances, for example a minor of tender age near home whose identity and address may readily be ascertained or is known. 
(c)  In any event such police officer shall, within twenty-four (24) hours, file a written report with the department. 
(d)  When a parent, immediately called, has come to take charge of the minor, and the appropriate information has been recorded, the minor shall be released to the custody of such parent. If the parent cannot be located, or fails to take charge of the minor, then the minor shall be released to the juvenile authorities, except to the extent that in accordance with police regulations, approved in advance by juvenile authorities, the minor temporarily be entrusted to a relative, neighbor or other person who will on behalf of a parent assume the responsibility of caring for the minor pending the availability or arrival of a parent. 
(e)  In the case of a first violation by a minor, the city, at its discretion, may issue: (1) a warning citation to the minor's parent so as to apprise the parent that any subsequent violation will result in full enforcement of the curfew ordinance, including enforcement of the parental responsibility provisions in section 12-65 and the penalties in section 12-67; or (2) an actual citation to the minor's parent fully enforcing the curfew ordinance, including enforcement of the parental responsibility provisions in section 12-65 and the penalties in section 12-67. 
(Ord. No. 97-10, § 1, 4-21-97; Ord. No. 2015-18, § 1, 6-15-15) 
Sec. 12-67. - Penalties. 
    Prevailing community standards, as to when minors should be off the streets as reflected in this curfew ordinance, are the basis for the following legal sanctions. 
(1)  For the first violation by a parent of section 12-65, the parent shall be fined one hundred dollars ($100.00) and, for each subsequent violation of 12-65 by that parent, the fine shall be increased by an additional one hundred dollars ($100.00), i.e., two hundred dollars ($200.00) for the second offense, three hundred dollars ($300.00) for the third offense. For purposes of this section, a warning citation given to a parent pursuant to section 12-66(e)(1) shall not constitute the first violation by that parent. The city judge, upon finding a parent guilty, or upon acceptance of a plea of guilty or nolo contendere, shall sentence the parent to pay such fine and the costs of prosecution, and upon refusal to pay such fine and costs, the parent may be imprisoned for a period not exceeding ten (10) days. 
(2)  Any minor who shall violate any of the provisions of the curfew ordinance more than two (2) times shall be reported to the juvenile court in the county of his residence with an appropriate petition filed pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 15-11-1 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 97-10, § 1, 4-21-97; Ord. No. 2008-15, § 2, 11-3-08; Ord. No. 2015-18, § 2, 6-15-15) 
Secs. 12-68-12-79. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - TRUANCY 

Sec. 12-80. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the Truancy Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 97-05, § 1, 3-3-97) 
Sec. 12-81. - Findings; purpose. 
    The mayor and council after having received and studied reports compiled by the police department are alarmed and concerned for the safety and well-being of juveniles within the city, as well as with the high number of incidents of thefts, including but not limited to burglary and motor vehicle thefts being perpetrated by juveniles within the city. With the interstate highways, rapid transit system, and Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport bringing thousands of nonresident transient people into and through the city at all hours of the day and night, juveniles are found to be at a high risk. The national epidemic of drugs and crimes of violence are of such nature that all reasonable and constitutional efforts must be employed to insulate and protect our youthful citizens from the influence and dangers associated with such activities. It is the intent of this article to make the parents the primary agents of enforcement, and, in addition, to enforce the mandatory education requirements in the State of Georgia. 
    The Official Code of Georgia Annotated provides that any child between the ages of six (6) and sixteen (16) shall be enrolled in and attend a public school, private school, or a home study program. While this requirement supports the state's goal of providing an education to its residents, information has been provided to the mayor and council which indicates an extremely high truancy rate in the metropolitan Atlanta area. The goal of this article, therefore, is to support compulsory education and to reduce the truancy rate within the city. 
    Parental responsibility for enrolling children in school is required. Legal sanctions to enforce such responsibility have had a demonstrated effect and, as parental control increases, the likelihood of school absences, juvenile delinquency, and danger to minors decreases. The cooperative enforcement of this article by the city, the parents, and the minor will support the Mandatory Attendance Law, will provide for a more safe and healthy community environment, and will achieve the purposes hereinbefore stated. 
(Ord. No. 97-05, § 1, 3-3-97; Ord. No. 2016-16, § 1, 5-2-16) 
Sec. 12-82. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this article: 
(1)  City is the City of College Park, Fulton and Clayton Counties, Georgia. 
(2)  Minor is any person between their sixth and sixteenth birthdays, or, in equivalent phrasing often herein employed, between the ages of six (6) and sixteen (16) years of age. 
(3)  Parent is any person having legal custody of a minor (i) as a natural or adoptive parent, (ii) as a legal guardian, (iii) as a person who stands in loco parentis or (iv) as a person to whom legal custody has been given by order of court. 
(4)  Remain means to stay behind, to tarry and to stay unnecessarily upon the streets, alone or with others, in such manner that any minor involved would not be using the streets for ordinary or serious purposes such as mere passage or going home. To implement that thought with additional precision and precaution, numerous exceptions are expressly defined in section 12-84 so that is not a mere prohibitory or presence type truancy ordinance. More and more exceptions become available with increasing years and advancing maturity as appropriate in the interest of reasonable regulation which is intended by use of meaningful phrase "be or remain." 
(5)  School day is any day which the Clayton County or Fulton County Boards of Education have scheduled as a day when schools will be open and student attendance is required. 
(6)  Street is a way or place, of whatsoever nature, open to the use of the public as a matter of right for purposes of vehicular travel or in the case of a sidewalk thereof for pedestrian travel. The term "street" includes the legal right-of-way, including but not limited to the cartway or traffic lanes, the curb, the sidewalks, whether paved or unpaved, any grass plots or other grounds found within the legal right-of-way of a street. The term "street" applies irrespective of what is called or formally named, whether alley, avenue, court, or road or otherwise. 
(7)  Time of day referred to herein as based upon the prevailing standard of time, whether Eastern Standard Time or Daylight Saving Time, generally observed at that hour by the public in the City of College Park, prima facie the time then observed in the College Park Administrative Office. 
(Ord. No. 97-05, § 1, 3-3-97; Ord. No. 2016-16, § 2, 5-2-16) 
Sec. 12-83. - Truancy. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person between the ages of six (6) and sixteen (16) years of age to be or remain in or upon the streets within the City of College Park during the hours of 8:30 a.m. and 2:30 p.m. on any school day. 
(Ord. No. 97-05, § 1, 3-3-97; Ord. No. 2016-16, § 3, 5-2-16) 
Sec. 12-84. - Exceptions. 
(a)  In the following exceptional cases a minor on a College Park street during school hours for which section 12-83 is intended to provide the maximum limits of regulation (and a clear general guide for minors, their parents and their fellow-citizens) shall not, however, be considered in violation of the truancy ordinance: 
(1)  When the minor has a valid excuse from school attendance and is: 
a.  Accompanied by a parent of such minor; 
b.  Accompanied by an adult authorized and approved by a parent of such minor to take said parent's place in accompanying said minor for a designated period of time and purpose within a specified area; 
c.  On the sidewalk of the place where such minor resides; 
d.  Participating in an approved school or study activity which requires the minor to be off of school property, or returning to school or home, by a direct route from (and with thirty (30) minutes of the termination of) such activity; 
e.  Upon an emergency errand directed by his parent; 
f.  When the minor is enrolled in a valid home study program as authorized by O.C.G.A. § 20-2-690; 
(2)  When in a motor vehicle with parental consent and engaged bona fide interstate movement through the city, particularly on normal routes such as U.S. Highway 29 and interstate highways I-85 and I-285. This also exempts interstate travel beginning or ending in the city; 
(3)  When the minor has completed all course study requirements for high school graduation; 
(4)  When the minor is married in accordance with applicable law; 
(5)  When a parent has failed to enroll the minor in a public school, private school, or home study program; provided, however, that in such instance, the parent shall be issued a citation for violation of O.C.G.A. § 20-2-690.1. 
(b)  Each of the foregoing exceptions, and their several limitations, are severable, as hereinafter provided, but here reemphasized; and additional, also severable, other exceptions, broadening with the progress toward maturity of minors enrolled respectively in elementary, middle and high schools, will be considered by the mayor and council as warranted by future experience illuminated by the views of student government associations, school personnel, citizens, associations, ward, precinct and neighborhood spokesman, parents, officers and persons in authority concerned positively with minors as well as with juvenile delinquency. 
(Ord. No. 97-05, § 1, 3-3-97) 
Sec. 12-85. - Parental responsibility. 
    It shall be unlawful for a parent having legal custody of a minor knowingly to permit or by inefficient control to allow, such minor to be or remain upon any city street under circumstances not constituting an exception to, or otherwise beyond the scope of, the truancy ordinance. The term "knowingly" includes knowledge which a parent should reasonably be expected to have concerning the whereabouts of a minor in that parent's legal custody. It is intended to continue to keep neglectful or careless parents up to a reasonable community standard of parental responsibility through an objective test. It shall be no defense that a parent was completely indifferent to the activities or conduct or whereabouts of such minor. 
(Ord. No. 97-05, § 1, 3-3-97) 
Sec. 12-86. - Police procedures. 
(a)  A police officer of the city, upon finding or having attention called to any minor on the streets in prima facie violation of the truancy ordinance, normally shall take the minor into temporary custody and deliver the child to the school from which the child is absent, or to the juvenile authorities. A parent shall immediately be notified to come to the school or to the juvenile authorities, and upon arrival, the minor's parent shall be interrogated. This is intended to permit ascertainment, under constitutional safeguards, of relevant facts, and to centralize responsibility in the officer there and then on duty for accurate, effective, fair, impartial and uniform enforcement and recording, thus making available experienced supervisory personnel, the best of facilities and access to information and records. In the absence of convincing evidence such as a birth certificate, a police officer on the street shall in the first instance use his best judgment in determining age. 
(b)  Police procedures shall constantly be refined in the light of experience and may provide that the police officer may deliver to a parent thereof a minor under appropriate circumstances, for example a minor of tender age near home whose identity and address may readily be ascertained or is known. 
(c)  In any event such police officer shall, within twenty-four (24) hours, file a written report with the department. 
(d)  When a parent, immediately called, has come to take charge of the minor, and the appropriate information has been recorded, the minor shall be released to the custody of such parent. If the parent cannot be located, or fails to take charge of the minor, then the minor shall be released to the school from which the minor is absent, or to the juvenile authorities, except to the extent that in accordance with police regulations, approved in advance by juvenile authorities, the minor may temporarily be entrusted to a relative, neighbor or other person who will on behalf of a parent assume the responsibility of caring for the minor pending the availability or arrival of a parent. 
(e)  In the case of a first violation by a minor, the city, at its discretion, may issue: (1) a warning citation to the minor's parent so as to apprise the parent that any subsequent violation will result in full enforcement of the truancy ordinance, including enforcement of the parental responsibility provisions in section 12-85 and the penalties in section 12-87; or (2) an actual citation to the minor's parent fully enforcing the truancy ordinance, including enforcement of the parental responsibility provisions in section 12-85 and the penalties in section 12-87. Where the parent has failed to enroll the minor in a public school, a private school, or a home study program that meets the requirements for a public school, a private school, or a home study program in violation of O.C.G.A. § 20-2-690.1, the parent shall be issued a citation under that statute instead of this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 97-05, § 1, 3-3-97; Ord. No. 2015-17, § 1, 6-15-15) 
Sec. 12-87. - Penalties. 
    Prevailing community standards, as to when minors should be off the streets and in school as reflected in this truancy ordinance, are the basis for the following legal sanctions. 
(1)  For the first violation by a parent of section 12-85, the parent shall be fined one hundred dollars ($100.00) and, for each subsequent violation of 12-85 by that parent, the fine shall be increased by an additional one hundred dollars ($100.00), i.e., two hundred dollars ($200.00) for the second offense, three hundred dollars ($300.00) for the third offense. For purposes of this section, a warning citation given to a parent pursuant to section 12-86(e)(1) shall not constitute the first violation by that parent. The city judge, upon finding a parent guilty, or upon acceptance of a plea of guilty or nolo contendere, shall sentence the parent to pay such fine and the costs of prosecution, and upon refusal to pay such fine and costs, the parent may be imprisoned for a period not exceeding ten (10) days. 
(2)  Any minor who shall violate any of the provisions of the truancy ordinance more than two (2) times shall be reported to the juvenile court in the county of his residence with an appropriate petition filed pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 15-11-1 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 97-05, § 1, 3-3-97; Ord. No. 2015-17, § 2, 6-15-15) 
Secs. 12-88-12-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - DRUG-FREE COMMERCIAL ZONE 

Sec. 12-101. - Drug-free commercial zone. 
(a)  Statement of findings. 
(1)  The mayor and council of the city desire to combat drug related crime in and around the commercial areas of the city; to provide a safe environment for citizens and businesses alike, including residential properties within one-half (1/2) contiguous mile of this drug free zone; 
(2)  O.C.G.A. § 16-13-32.6 authorizes establishment of a "drug free commercial zone," allowing for enhanced penalties for conviction of drug offenses under this chapter; 
(3)  City law enforcement has documented, as reported in Exhibit "B", a high rate of criminal drug activity around the contiguous area described in detail in Exhibit "A" and, which law enforcement believes will be curtailed by the enhanced punishment provided by O.C.G.A. § 16-13-32.6 related to manufacturing, distributing, dispensing, or possessing with intent to distribute controlled substances or marijuana within a drug-free commercial zone; and 
(4)  The city now desires to enact said "drug free commercial zone" pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 16-13-32.6 within the boundaries set forth in Exhibit "A". 
(b)  Drug-free commercial zone established; criteria of state met. 
(1)  The city hereby creates, pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 16-13-32.6, a "drug free commercial zone" to be located within the city limits of the City of College Park, Fulton/Clayton County, Georgia, with said zone being fully described and shown in Exhibit "A", excluding all non-commercially zoned areas within said boundaries which are not residential in nature, and excluding all areas that are not within one-half (1/2) mile of commercially zoned areas. Exhibit "A" is hereby incorporated by reference as if fully set forth herein and includes all previously zoned commercial property with the marked boundaries and all residential property within the marked boundaries contiguous to such commercially zoned area and within one-half (1/2) mile from any portion of the commercially zoned areas; 
(2)  The city is hereby authorized to do everything necessary to ensure the posting of signage designating the area as a "drug free commercial zone" in prominent and conspicuous places on the boundaries of and throughout the established zone; and 
(3)  The city is hereby authorized to do everything necessary to file the required documentation of the "drug free commercial zone" with the Georgia Department of Community Affairs; to obtain the required adoption of the aforementioned zone by the Georgia General Assembly; to provide the department of community affairs with an copy of the ordinance from which this article derives, Exhibit "B" (Initial crime report), Exhibit "A" (map), and follow-up annual reports; to maintain said records in a permanent register; to publish the required three-weekly notices of designation in the legal organ of the city; and, to permit enforcement under O.C.G.A. § 16-13-32.6 commencing thirty (30) days after adoption by the Georgia General Assembly. 
(Ord. No. 2010-18, § 1, 11-15-10) 
Editor's note- The exhibits referred to in this section are not set out at length herein, but are on file in the offices of the city. 
Chapter 13 - PARKS AND RECREATION 

Sec. 13-1. - Advisory recreation board-Created. 
    There is hereby created for the city an advisory recreation board. 
(Code 1963, § 17-16) 
Sec. 13-2. - Members; appointment, term, filling of vacancies. 
(a)  The advisory recreation board shall be appointed by the mayor and shall consist of six (6) prominent citizens of the city. The term of office of each citizen member shall be five (5) years. 
(b)  Vacancies occurring other than by expiration of term shall be filled by another appointment. 
(c)  Absences of members shall be noted in the minutes of the appropriate meetings as being either excused or unexcused. All absences shall be considered unexcused unless the absent member, prior to the applicable meeting, notifies either the chairman of the board or the secretary of the city manager that he or shell will be unable to attend the meeting. In the event that a member accumulates three (3) unexcused absences from consecutive regularly scheduled meetings, the secretary of the board shall notify the city manager of such situation. Upon receipt of such notice, the city manager shall issue a letter to the member and to the mayor and council. Upon the city manager's issuance of such letter, the member shall be deemed to have resigned and vacated his or her position on the advisory recreation board. 
(Code 1963, § 17-17; Ord. No. 2002-14, § 1, 4-1-02) 
Sec. 13-3. - Same-Function; purchases. 
(a)  The advisory recreation board shall generally advise and recommend overall procedures and plans in the administration of the recreation program of the city in conformity with the laws and ordinances of the city, and said procedures and plans shall be followed by the recreation director unless otherwise directed by the governing body. 
(b)  Said board shall approve all purchases made by the recreation department; provided however, that one member of said board and the recreation director shall be privileged to make purchases not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) at any one time. 
(Code 1963, § 17-18) 
Sec. 13-4. - Same-Recreation budget, recommendation. 
    The advisory recreation board shall recommend the annual budget for the recreation department of the city. 
(Code 1963, § 17-19) 
Sec. 13-5. - Same-Reports; recommendations. 
    The advisory recreation board may from time to time make such recommendations as it may deem proper relative to recreation activities within the city to the governing body and shall make an annual report to the governing body, and such other reports as may be requested. 
(Code 1963, § 17-20) 
Sec. 13-6. - Use of parks. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to be in any public or public recreation grounds of the city between the hours of 10:30 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. unless such person is engaged in activities specifically authorized in writing by the recreation department or the mayor and council. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person who is not an employee, officer or agent of the city or a resident of the city to be in any public park or public recreation grounds of the city except under the following circumstances: 
(1)  Such person is engaged in activities specifically authorized in writing by the recreation department or the mayor and council. 
(2)  Such person is accompanied by at least one (1) employee or resident of the city, provided that no two (2) or more such persons may be accompanied by the same employee or resident. 
(3)  Where the general public is invite to an event through an advertisement placed by the city with a newspaper, magazine, radio station, or television station, or through signs erected by the city that do not state that the event is limited to city residents and/or employees; or 
(4)  Such person is attending n organized event previously approved in writing by the city department of recreation, in which case the requirement of subsection (2) above shall not apply. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to host or attend any organized event in any public park or public recreation grounds of the city without the prior written approval of the city department of recreation. Requests for organized events may only be made by city residents. The city department of recreation may refuse any request for such approval based on prior actions of the person or entity making the request, or for any other lawful reason. The mayor and council may by resolution from time to time set fees for organized events. For the purposes of this subsection, the term "organized event" shall mean any activity sponsored by any person or any formal or informal entity, other than the city department of recreation, where at least ten (10) persons are present, for a common purpose or event, at a public park or recreation grounds of the city. 
(d)  For the purposes of this section, "public park or recreation grounds of the city" shall mean: 
(1)  Barrett Park: Rugby Ave. and West Walker; 
(2)  Bill Badgett Stadium; 
(3)  Bill Evans Field: College Street; 
(4)  Brannon Memorial Park: Charlestown Drive; 
(5)  Richard D. Zupp Park: Temple and Hawthorne Ave; 
(6)  Jamestown Park: Riverdale Road. 
(Code 1963, § 17-3(c); Ord. No. 2002-39, § 1, 9-3-02) 
Sec. 13-7. - Use of motor vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in any public park or public recreation grounds of the city to park or drive a motor vehicle of any kind off the driveways or upon the grass of said parks or grounds. This shall not apply to any person who parks a motor vehicle in any area set aside for parking. 
(Code 1963, § 17-3(b)) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2006-28, § 3, adopted Sept. 18, 2006, repealed former § 13-7 in its entirety which pertained to littering, throwing missiles and damaging property in parks and derived from the Code of 1963. Said ordinance also consecutively renumbered the remaining sections of this chapter. 
Sec. 13-8. - Nonresident use of tennis courts. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any nonresident of the city to use the tennis courts within the city that are under the control and supervision of the recreation department of the city. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to a nonresident who has paid an approved nonresident recreation fee to the city and has evidence of the same on the person, nor shall this section apply to a nonresident who is playing as a guest of a citizen of the city who is present at the time. 
(Code 1963, § 16-21; Ord. No. 2006-28, § 3, 9-18-06) 
Editor's note- Formerly numbered as § 13-9. 
Sec. 13-9. - City auditorium; smoking prohibited, 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in smoking at any time in the city auditorium; provided no person shall be found guilty of a violation of this section without first having failed or refused to desist from smoking after being requested to do so by a police officer or some other official deputized by the governing body to enforce this section. 
(Code 1963, § 17-1; Ord. No. 2006-28, § 3, 9-18-06) 
Editor's note- Formerly numbered as § 13-10. 
Sec. 13-10. - City lake; regulations. 
(a)  Swimming, boating. It shall be unlawful for any person to swim or ride in any boat on the city lake on the city park property on the west side of the city. 
(b)  Fishing: It shall be unlawful for any person to fish in any manner in, or to take fish from, said city lake. 
(c)  Golf: It shall be unlawful for any person except the owner or the owner's agent, or a duly authorized employee of the city, to remove any golf balls from the city lake. 
(Code 1963, § 17-2; Ord. No. 2006-28, § 3, 9-18-06) 
Editor's note- Formerly numbered as § 13-11. 
Sec. 13-11. - Swimming pool-Regulations for use. 
(a)  Established. The following regulations are established for the operation and use of the city swimming pool and bathhouse. Violation of any of these regulations shall be unlawful: 
(1)  All persons using bathhouse and pool shall purchase tickets before entering same. 
(2)  No person shall be allowed to use the swimming pools without being clothed in a bathing suit. Bathers will be allowed to use any decent bathing suit. The manager shall at all times be the judge as to whether a bathing suit is decent and proper. 
(3)  No one shall enter the bathing pool except through the regular entrance provided for that purpose. 
(4)  Bathers shall use the shower bath. before entering the pool, and also the foot bath before entering and after departing from the pool. 
(5)  Persons showing the slightest evidence of being under the influence of intoxicants will not be permitted entrance to the bathhouse or pool. 
(6)  Eating or drinking shall not be permitted in the enclosure where the pool is located. 
(7)  Bottles, paper cups, drinking straws, cigarette butts or other foreign matter shall not be taken to or thrown into the pool. 
(8)  No profane language shall be permitted in the bathhouse or pools.
