Cross reference- Economic development incentive fee reductions, § 5-26. 

Sec. 15-21. - Old National Corridor enterprise zone. 
(a)  Statement of findings. The mayor and council of the city find that: 
(1)  The area surrounding Old National Highway (the Old National Corridor) in the southern portion of the city is suffering from severe decline, disinvestment and encroaching blight; 
(2)  Unemployment levels surrounding the Old National Corridor are significantly higher, by at least ten (10) percent, than the state average unemployment rate; 
(3)  A disproportionately higher rate of crime exists in the Old National Corridor or Zone 3 of the city as compared with the remainder of the corporate limits; 
(4)  A total of five hundred eighty-six thousand six hundred fifty-five (586,655) square feet of retail space has been abandoned from January 1, 1997 to the present time along the Old National Corridor; 
(5)  The area surrounding Old National Corridor has seen the issuance of only two (2) land disturbance permits between 2003 and 2007; and that 
(6)  Without significant governmental intervention by the city, deterioration of the Old National Corridor area will most likely continue, resulting in an ever destabilized tax base, increased blight and ever-increasing crime rate for that area. 
(b)  Enterprise zone established; criteria of state met. 
(1)  There is hereby created and established the Old National Corridor Enterprise Zone. The boundaries of such Enterprise Zone are delineated on Exhibits A and B to Ord. No. 2003-06 which are incorporated herein by reference as fully as though set out at length. The Enterprise Zone shall also include the following tax parcels as identified in the tax records of Fulton County, Georgia: 
a.  13-0067-LL-075-6, and 
b.  13-0067-LL-079-8. 
(2)  The Old National Corridor Enterprise Zone, as configured herein, meets the criteria for establishment of enterprise zones under O.C.G.A. § 36-88-6. 
(c)  Definitions. In the interpretation and application of the provisions of this section, those terms defined in O.C.G.A. § 36-88-3 are incorporated by reference into this section and made a part hereof. 
(d)  Entitlement to incentives; standards; applicability. 
(1)  In order for a business or service enterprise to qualify for the incentives outlined in subsection (g), such business or service enterprise must, as an initial threshold, increase employment in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 36-88-4(b) at a physical facility located within the enterprise zone, in such manner as to provide additional economic stimulus in the zone. Additionally, the business or service enterprise must engage in new construction; make additions to existing structures; engage in substantial renovation of existing structures; make a significant investment in equipment replacement or expansion; or otherwise alter the physical premises in which the business or service enterprise operates in a manner which adds substantial value to the structures. Cosmetic changes or remodeling to the appearance of a structure which does not increase the assessed valuation of the property by more than twenty-five (25) per cent does not meet the construction or renovation standards of this paragraph. 
(2)  The determination of the number of increased full-time job equivalents required to qualify and whether a business or service enterprise qualifies for the incentives of this section shall be made on a case-by-case basis by the mayor and council upon application of the criteria established in this section. In making such determination, the mayor and council may rely upon information provided by the applicant, staff reports, economic studies, or other information determined by the mayor and council to provide a reliable indicator of economic stimulus. The burden shall be on an applicant to establish that the applicant meets the criteria set out in this section. 
(e)  Maintenance and continuation of qualifying criteria. In order to maintain the incentives established by this section, a qualifying business or service enterprise shall maintain the new full-time job equivalents for an entire ten-year period. Every qualifying business or service enterprise shall provide to the city's director of development by December 31 of each year a written report on the full-time job equivalents for that calendar year. The director of development shall be responsible for monitoring compliance by every qualifying business or service enterprise with this section. Failure to maintain the incentive qualification shall result in revocation and recapture of all incentives granted prior to the expiration of the incentive term. The agreement between the city and the qualifying business entered into pursuant to subsection (g)(1) shall include a clause granting the city's director of development to enter into the qualifying business facility at any time to audit and/or monitor compliance with this section. 
(f)  Duration of enterprise zone. The Old National Corridor Enterprise Zone shall be established effective with the date of re-adoption of this section [August 17, 2009] and shall continue for a period of ten (10) years. Business and service enterprises nominated for incentives in the enterprise zone during that ten-year period will have ten (10) years from date of approval during which such incentives may be utilized, even though such ten-year period for the particular business or service enterprise may extend beyond the enterprise zone's duration. 
(g)  Incentives available to qualifying business. 
(1)  Upon qualifying therefore, and by agreement with the city, qualifying business and service enterprises may be exempt from municipal ad valorem taxation which would otherwise be levied under chapter 18, article I on that portion of the business or service enterprise meeting the qualifying criteria, but only as to that portion of said taxes resulting from increased property value due to improvements made to the property by the qualifying business or service enterprise subsequent to qualification. The agreement with the city shall include a schedule of exemptions not to exceed the amounts set forth in O.C.G.A. § 36-88-8(a)(1). 
(2)  The tax exemption shall be effective upon approval by the mayor and council of the business or service enterprise as qualifying and upon execution of a contract between the City of College Park and such qualifying business or service enterprise. The effective date of the tax abatement shall begin on January 1 of the year following the effective date of approval and such tax exemption shall continue for ten (10) years, even if the Old National Corridor Enterprise Zone designation has terminated. 
(3)  If the project consists of rehabilitation of an existing structure and the value of the improvement exceeds the value of the land by a ratio of five (5) to one (1), then the tax exemption schedule set out in subsection (g)(1) above shall apply whether or not the project is carried out by a qualifying business or service enterprise. 
(4)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, in the event that the value of the property tax exemptions granted to qualifying business and service enterprises within all enterprise zones created by the city constitute ten (10) per cent of the property tax digest of the city, no further exemptions shall be available to new businesses. 
(5)  The mayor and council reserve the right to amend this section at some future time to add additional development incentives as authorized by state law. Such additional incentives shall be applicable upon adoption of an amendment to this section and shall run coterminous with the existing tax incentives above described. 
(Ord. No. 98-09, §§ 1-7, 4-6-98; Ord. No. 2003-06, § 1, 2-3-03; Ord. No. 04-14, § 1, 6-7-04; Ord. No. 2009-18, §§ 1-5, 8-17-09; Ord. No. 2009-19, § 1, 9-21-09) 
Sec. 15-22. - Downtown Area enterprise zone. 
(a)  Statement of findings. The mayor and council of the City of College Park find that: 
(1)  The downtown area of the City of College Park, as described and defined in subsection (b) of this section (the "Downtown Area") is suffering from severe decline, disinvestment and encroaching blight; 
(2)  Unemployment levels surrounding the downtown area are significantly higher, by at least ten (10) per cent, than the state average unemployment rate; 
(3)  The downtown area has seen a seventy (70) per cent population decline, a sharp rise in dilapidated and/or abandoned structures and is generally in distress; 
(4)  The downtown area has pervasive poverty in that twenty-one (21) per cent of the population have incomes below the poverty index, and portions of the area show sixty (60) per cent of the population having income levels below the poverty index; 
(5)  The downtown area suffers from significant underdevelopment; 
(6)  Without significant governmental intervention by the city, deterioration of the downtown area will most likely continue, resulting in an ever destabilized tax base, increased blight and ever-increasing crime rate for that area. 
(b)  Enterprise zone established; criteria of state met. 
(1)  There is hereby created and established the Downtown Area Enterprise Zone. The boundaries of such Enterprise Zone are delineated on Exhibit A which is incorporated herein by reference as fully as though set out at length. 
(2)  The Downtown Area Enterprise Zone, as configured herein, meets the criteria for establishment of enterprise zones under O.C.G.A. § 36-88-6. 
(c)  Definitions. In the interpretation and application of the provisions of this section, those terms defined in O.C.G.A. § 36-88-3 are incorporated by reference into this section and made a part hereof. 
(d)  Entitlement to incentives; standards; applicability. 
(1)  In order for a business or service enterprise to qualify for the incentives outlined in subsection (g), such business or service enterprise must, as an initial threshold, increase employment in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 36-88-4(b) at a physical facility located within the enterprise zone, in such manner as to provide additional economic stimulus in the zone. Additionally, the business or service enterprise must engage in new construction; make additions to existing structures; engage in substantial renovation of existing structures; make a significant investment in equipment replacement or expansion; or otherwise alter the physical premises in which the business or service enterprise operates in a manner which adds substantial value to the structures. Cosmetic changes or remodeling to the appearance of a structure which does not increase the assessed valuation of the property by more than twenty-five (25) per cent does not meet the construction or renovation standards of this paragraph. 
(2)  The determination of the number of increased full-time job equivalents required to qualify and whether a business or service enterprise qualifies for the incentives of this section shall be made on a case-by-case basis by the mayor and council upon application of the criteria established in this section. In making such determination, the mayor and council may rely upon information provided by the applicant, staff reports, economic studies, or other information determined by the mayor and council to provide a reliable indicator of economic stimulus. The burden shall be on an applicant to establish that the applicant meets the criteria set out in this section. 
(e)  Maintenance and continuation of qualifying criteria. In order to maintain the incentives established by this section, a qualifying business or service enterprise shall maintain the new full-time job equivalents for an entire ten-year period. Every qualifying business or service enterprise shall provide to the city's director of Development by December 31 of each year a written report on the full-time job equivalents for that calendar year. The director of development shall be responsible for monitoring compliance by every qualifying business or service enterprise with this section. Failure to maintain the incentive qualification shall result in revocation and recapture of all incentives granted prior to the expiration of the incentive term. 
(f)  Duration of enterprise zone. The Downtown Area Enterprise Zone shall he established effective with the date of re-adoption of this section 15-22 and shall continue for a period of ten (10) years. Business and service enterprises nominated for incentives in the enterprise zone during that ten-year period will have ten (10) years from date of approval during which such incentives may be utilized, even though such ten-year period for the particular business or service enterprise may extend beyond the enterprise zone's duration. 
(g)  Incentives available to qualifying business. 
(1)  Upon qualifying therefore, and by agreement with the city, qualifying business and service enterprises may be exempt from municipal ad valorem taxation which would otherwise be levied under Chapter 18, Article I of the City Code on that portion of the business or service enterprise meeting the qualifying criteria, but only as to that portion of said taxes resulting from increased property value due to improvements made to the property by the qualifying business or service enterprise subsequent to qualification, in accordance with the following schedule: 
a.  One hundred (100) per cent of ad valorem taxes shall be exempt for the first five (5) years; 
b.  Eighty (80) per cent of the ad valorem taxes shall be exempt for the next two (2) years; 
c.  Sixty (60) per cent of the ad valorem taxes shall be exempt for the next year; 
d.  Forty (40) per cent of the ad valorem taxes shall be exempt for the next year; and 
e.  Twenty (20) per cent of the ad valorem taxes shall be exempt for the last year. 
(2)  The tax exemption shall be effective upon approval by the mayor and council of the business or service enterprise as qualifying and upon execution of a contract between the City of College Park and such qualifying business or service enterprise. The effective date of the tax abatement shall begin on January 1 of the year following the effective date of approval and such tax exemption shall continue for ten (10) years, even if the College Park Downtown Enterprise Zone designation has terminated. 
(3)  If the project consists of rehabilitation of an existing structure and the value of the improvement exceeds the value of the land by a ratio of five to one, then the tax exemption schedule set out in subsection (g)(1) above shall apply whether or not the project is carried out by a qualifying business or service enterprise. 
(4)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, in the event that the value of the property tax exemptions granted to qualifying business and service enterprises within all enterprise zones created by the city constitute ten (10) per cent of the property tax digest of the city, no further exemptions shall be available to new businesses thereafter. 
(5)  The mayor and council reserve the right to authorize additional development incentives to qualified businesses as authorized by state law. 
(Ord. No. 98-12, §§ 1-7, 7-20-98; Ord. No. 04-14, § 2, 6-7-04; Ord. No. 2011-02, §§ 1-5, 3-7-11) 
Sec. 15-23. - Millennium Area enterprise zone. 
(a)  Statement of findings. The mayor and city council of the City of College Park find that: 
(1)  The Millennium Area of the City of College Park, as described and defined in subsection (b) of this section (the "Millennium Area") is suffering from severe decline, disinvestments and encroaching blight; 
(2)  The average unemployment rate in the Millennium Area is significantly higher (more than ten (10) per cent higher) than the state average unemployment rate; 
(3)  The Millennium Area suffers from significant underdevelopment; 
(4)  The Millennium Area suffers from general distress in the area, including but not limited to substantial population decline; 
(5)  Without significant governmental intervention by the City of College Park, deterioration of the Millennium Area will most likely continue, resulting in an ever increasing destabilized tax base, increased blight and continued distress for that area. 
(b)  Enterprise zone established: criteria of state met. 
(1)  There is hereby created and established, the College Park Millennium Enterprise Zone. The boundaries of such Enterprise Zone are shown on Attachment I to Exhibit A, which is incorporated herein by reference below. 
(2)  The College Park Millennium Enterprise Zone, as configured as described herein, meets the criteria for establishment of enterprise zones under O.C.G.A. section 36-88-6 as supported by the enterprise zone report prepared by Bill Johnston, city planner, attached hereto and incorporated herein by reference as Exhibit A. The mayor and city council hereby adopt the conclusions and findings contained in Exhibit A as their own. 
(c)  Definitions. In the interpretation and application of the provisions of this section, those terms defined in O.C.G.A. section 36-88-3 are incorporated by reference into this section and made apart hereof. 
(d)  Entitlement to incentives: standards: applicability. 
(1)  In order for a business or service enterprise to qualify for the incentives outlined in subsection (g), such business or service enterprise must, as an initial threshold increase employment by five (5) or more full-time job equivalents at a physical facility located within the enterprise zone, in such manner as to provide additional economic stimulus in the zone. Additionally, the business or service enterprise must engage in new construction; make additions to existing structures; engage in substantial renovation of existing structures; make a significant investment in equipment replacement or expansion; or otherwise alter the physical premises in which the business or service enterprise operates in a manner which adds substantial value to the structures. Cosmetic changes or remodeling to the appearance of a structure which does not increase the assessed valuation of the property by more than twenty-five (25) per cent does not meet the construction or renovation standards of this section. 
(2)  The determination of whether a business or service enterprise qualifies for the incentives of this section shall be made on a case-by-case basis by the mayor and council upon application of the criteria established in this section. In making such determinations, the mayor and council may rely upon information provided by the applicant, staff reports, economic studies, or other information determined by the mayor and council to provide a reliable indicator of economic stimulus. The burden shall be on an applicant to establish that the applicant meets the criteria set out in this section. 
(e)  Maintenance and continuation of qualifying criteria. In order to maintain the incentives established by this section, a qualifying business or service enterprise shall maintain the new full-time job equivalents for an entire ten-year period. Every qualifying business or service enterprise shall provide to the city's director of development by December 31 of each year a written report on the full-time job equivalents for that calendar year. The director of development shall be responsible for monitoring compliance by every qualifying business or service enterprise with this section. Failure to maintain the incentive qualification shall result in revocation and recapture of all incentives granted prior to the expiration of the incentive term. 
(f)  Duration of enterprise zone. The College Park Millennium Enterprise Zone shall be established effective with the date of adoption of this section and shall continue for a period of ten (10) years. Business and service enterprises nominated for incentives in the enterprise zone during that ten-year period will have ten (10) years from date of approval during which such incentives may be utilized, even though such ten-year period for the particular business or service enterprise may extend beyond the enterprise zone's duration. 
(g)  Incentives, available to qualifying business. 
(1)  Upon qualifying therefore, and by agreement with the city, qualifying business and service enterprises may be exempt from municipal ad valorem taxation which would otherwise be levied under Chapter 18, Article I of the City Code on that portion of the business or service enterprise meeting the qualifying criteria, but only as to that portion of said taxes resulting from increased property value due to improvements made to the property by the qualifying business or service enterprise subsequent to qualification, in accordance with the following schedule: 
a.  One hundred (100) per cent of ad valorem taxes shall be exempt for the first five (5) years; 
b.  Eighty (80) per cent of the ad valorem taxes shall be exempt for the next two (2) years; 
c.  Sixty (60) per cent of the ad valorem taxes shall be exempt for the next year; 
d.  Forty (40) per cent of the ad valorem taxes shall be exempt for the next year; and 
e.  Twenty (20) per cent of the ad valorem taxes shall be exempt for the last year. 
(2)  The tax exemption shall be effective upon approval by the mayor and council of the business or service enterprise as qualifying and upon execution of a contract between the City of College Park and such qualifying business or service enterprise. The effective date of the tax abatement shall begin on January 1 of the year following the effective date of approval and such tax exemption shall continue for ten (10) years even if the College Park Millennium Enterprise zone designation has terminated. 
(3)  If the project consists, of rehabilitation of an existing structure and the value of the improvement exceeds the value of the land by a ratio of five to one, then the tax exemption schedule set out in subsection (g)(1) above shall apply whether or not the project is carried out by a qualifying business or service enterprise. 
(4)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, in the event that the value of the property tax exemptions granted to qualifying business and service enterprises within all enterprise zones created by the city constitutes ten (10) per cent of the property tax digest of the city, no further exemptions shall be available to new businesses thereafter. 
(5)  The mayor and council reserve the right to amend this section at some future time to add additional development incentives us authorized by state law. Such additional incentives shall be applicable upon adoption of an amendment to this section and shall run coterminous with the existing tax incentives above described. 
(Ord. No. 03-12, § 1, 3-17-03; Ord. No. 2005-24, § 1, 11-7-05) 
Chapter 16 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority as to public utilities and public service, including streets, sidewalks, curb and gutter improvements, Art. VI; street repaving, etc., Art. IX. 
Cross reference- Depositing injurious materials on streets, highways prohibited, § 19-10; littering streets, § 8-6; operating vehicle so as to damage street, § 19-33; selling on streets, § 12-6; vehicle access control, App. A, Art. XI-B. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Numbering system. 
(a)  All improved lots, buildings and structures in the city shall be numbered according to the present numbering system in effect in the city and by numbers assigned by the engineering department of the city. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the owners and occupants of every house, building and structure in the city to have placed thereon in a place visible from the street, or at the street, figures at least two and one-half (21/2) inches high showing the number of the house, building or structure. Any person failing to so number any house, building or structure owned or occupied by such person, after receiving notice from the city, shall be in violation of this section and subject to punishment as for a misdemeanor. It shall further be the duty of the owners and/or managers of multifamily residential complexes in the city to place on each separate building within the complex, in a place visible from the street, a figure at least eight (8) inches high showing the identifying number of the individual building. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any owner and/or manager of any multifamily residential complex within the city to change the official name of his development without first receiving the prior approval of the mayor and council of the City of College Park. 
(Code 1963, § 5-12; Ord. No. 86-32, §§ 1, 2, 10-20-86) 
Sec. 16-2. - Encroachments. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect any fence, railing, platform, steps, hedge, portico or other obstruction beyond the limits of such person's lot within the city, and thus encroach upon the street, alley, sidewalk or other public way of the city. 
(Code 1963, § 19-1) 
Sec. 16-3. - Obstructions; permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place or maintain, or cause to be placed or maintained, in any of the streets, alleys, sidewalks or other public ways of the city, any obstruction of any kind or character whatsoever which exceeds the limits of such person's lot, except by special written permit of the governing body. 
(Code 1963, § 19-2) 
Sec. 16-4. - Stands on streets. 
    No license shall be issued to any newsstand, popcorn stand, or other stand, where it is proposed that any such stand will be located on any street, sidewalk, alley or other public way of the city, unless written permission be granted by the governing body. 
(Code 1963, § 19-3) 
Sec. 16-5. - Washing of loose dirt onto streets and sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to allow loose dirt in quantities of the equivalent of one square foot or more to escape from private property, with water as the carrier, onto a sidewalk or street, within a single twenty-four (24) hour period. 
(Code 1963, § 19-5) 
Sec. 16-6. - Street, sidewalk improvements; approval required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make or cause to be made any improvements in or upon any public street, public alley, public sidewalk or other public place in the city, either by grading, paving, paving foundation, curbing or guttering or otherwise, without the consent of the city through its governing body, upon and after written application by and on the part of such person. 
(Code 1963, § 19-6) 
Charter reference- Municipal authority as to public service and improvements, including streets, sidewalks, curbs and gutters, Arts. VI, IX. 
Sec. 16-7. - Street work by power driven equipment; permit required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to perform or do any excavation, trenching, grading or other movement of soil, earth, concrete, asphalt or other types of surface coating by means of power driven equipment without first obtaining a permit from the city engineering department. 
(b)  The city engineering department shall not issue a permit as required in subsection (a) until the applicant has filed with such department a plat showing the location of all gas, water, electric, sewer, telephone or other utility lines located underground or below grade. Said plat shall show the location of the work to be performed. The department may require satisfactory proof of discontinuance of service by any utility which such official deems a hazard. 
(Code 1963, § 19-12) 
Sec. 16-8. - Excavations-Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person except the city to make any cut or excavation in any city street, sidewalk or other public way without first obtaining a permit therefor from the city engineering department. 
(Code 1963, § 19-7) 
Sec. 16-9. - Same-Application for permit. 
    Any person desiring to cut or make any excavation in any street, sidewalk or other public way in the city for the purpose of making connections with sewer, water pipes, gas pipes or for any other purpose, shall make application for a written permit from the city. The application for such permit shall state the name of the person who expects to cut the street, sidewalk or other public way or make the excavation therein, for whom, and for what reason, and where, and the number of days required to do the work. 
(Code 1963, § 19-8) 
Sec. 16-10. - Same-Indemnification. 
    Any person who shall obtain a permit required by section 16-8 shall thereby assume full responsibility for any loss or damage to the city or any person as a result of such excavation or acts of negligence, and shall indemnify the city against any loss resulting from any damage to either person or property of any person, and any such permit shall contain this provision. 
(Code 1963, § 19-9) 
Sec. 16-11. - Same-Refilling and repairing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, after having made an excavation in any street, sidewalk or other public way, to refill the same except under the immediate supervision and direction of the city engineer. The cost of restoring any such excavated street to its former condition shall be paid by the person making or causing such excavation. 
(Code 1963, § 19-10) 
Sec. 16-12. - Same-Safety precautions. 
    It shall be the duty of the person making any excavation in any public street, sidewalk or other public way to maintain a signal at the place of excavation by keeping a red light burning at same from sundown to sunrise and red flag during the day. 
(Code 1963, § 19-11) 
Secs. 16-13-16-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RIDE SHARE 
DIVISION 1. - BIKE SHARING INFRASTRUCTURE 

Sec. 16-25. - Purpose and intent. 
(a)  The public health, safety and welfare will be enhanced by the implementation of a self-service bicycle rental program. The program, which will establish bike sharing infrastructure, both in the public right-of-way and on private property in the City of College Park, and which will be fully paid for by one or more vendors ("providers") selected by the city, will accomplish the city's goals of establishing a positive and useful program for the general public while eliminating city costs and expenses if the city were to directly implement the program. 
(b)  The location of bike share infrastructure on public property is intended to increase utilization of other public transit modes by providing a first mile and last mile travel alternative that will increase the range of destinations served. 
(c)  The bike sharing experience of the general public will be enhanced by the ability of the city to contract with providers to install and manage bike share infrastructure on public property including the public right-of-way for the installation around the city of multiple rental stations ("stations" or "kiosks") that house rental bicycles. 
(d)  The system will allow the general public to rent bicycles from stations located around the city, use a bicycle for trips of varying times and durations and return the bicycle to a different station. Such programs provide a convenience for residents, workers and visitors because bicycles are available on an as-needed basis and are available for one-way trips. The program, made available by the city, can operate on a cooperative basis and link with other programs sponsored by other entities to grow the system quickly and expand the reach of the program beyond the city. 
(Ord. No. 2019-04, § 2, 3-18-19) 
Sec. 16-26. - Definitions. 
    The words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. The use of capitalized abbreviated reference terms for the definitions contained herein are intended to refer to the terms and phrases from which they were derived. 
    Bike sharing rental program means a system funded, managed and operated by one or more providers under contracts entered into with the city, which provide the public with opportunities to rent bicycles from stations at locations on both private and public property including the public right-of-way. 
    Kiosk means self-service bicycle rental station kiosk which is a structure containing the self-service payment device located at a station at which bicycles are rented. 
    Provider means a bicycle rental service provider which is a person or entity with a contract with the city to provide self-service bicycle rental services. 
    Rental bicycle or bicycle means a self-service rental bicycle that is rented from a station that is operated by a private self-service bicycle rental service. 
    Station means a public self-service bicycle rental station which is an automated facility constructed as a part of a bike sharing rental program where bicycles are made available for rental without the requirement that employees or attendants be present to accept rental payments from customers, rent bicycles to customers, or receive bicycles from customers when the bicycles are returned from rental. 
    Storage means self-service rental bicycle storage which is a part of a station that is utilized for the storage of rental bicycles available for rental or being returned after rental at any station, including stations maintained by a private self-service bicycle rental service; for the servicing of rental bicycles, or for the storage of any goods or materials, provided that no part of any station may be used for the storage of rental bicycles that are inoperable or which cannot be rented within twenty-four (24) hours after their return. 
(Ord. No. 2019-04, § 2, 3-18-19) 
Sec. 16-27. - Authorization to allow the use of public property and right-of-way for the program. 
    As directed by mayor and city council, the public works director is authorized to allow the installation of stations and kiosks on public property including the public right-of-way. Such stations shall only be installed by a provider that has a contract with the city to manage and provide services to the public under the program. In order for the provider to install required infrastructure for operations of the program in the public right-of-way, the provider must enter into an encroachment agreement with the city for the installation of each kiosk and station. In no instance shall the contract or the authorization granted by this section require the public works director to allow the installation of kiosks and stations in locations which the public works director deems unsuitable for the installation of such infrastructure. 
(Ord. No. 2019-04, § 2, 3-18-19) 
Sec. 16-28. - Criteria for the location of stations in the public right-of-way. 
(a)  No station shall interfere with the reasonable visibility needs of drivers on the street where the station is located or any connecting street. 
(b)  No station shall interfere with the flow of pedestrian traffic taking into consideration the queuing areas for adjacent businesses, the size of the station, and the width of the sidewalk. 
(c)  No station shall be located so as to unreasonably interfere with businesses located on the same block (block faces) as the proposed station location. A notice shall be posted by the provider at the site on the street frontage where the station is to be located which states that the provider has sought permission from the city to install a station at the location. The required encroachment agreement shall not be executed by the city until the provider submits an affidavit that the notice has been posted for ten (10) days. The public works director shall receive any comments from the public and consider those comments in making a decision as to whether to authorize the station installation. 
(Ord. No. 2019-04, § 2, 3-18-19) 
Sec. 16-29. - Installation of infrastructure on private property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to erect or maintain a station on private property except as permitted by the city planner through an approval of an administrative permit obtained from the building and inspections department by a provider and issued pursuant to the city's zoning ordinance. The approval of the city planner of such an administrative permit shall be the final approval required before a building permit may be sought to construct the station. 
(b)  All stations to be located on private property shall be erected, operated and maintained by the provider in conformity with the city's zoning ordinance, including without limitation, the requirements as to signage, station size and design, as evidenced by the approval of an administrative permit by the city planner. The permit and review of the criteria required in this section to obtain the approval of the administrative permit by the city planner shall be in addition to and shall in no way modify or replace the requirements set forth in the zoning ordinance and all permits required therein. 
(c)  Before a permit for a station to be located on private property can be approved, the applicant must submit design plans, to be accompanied by photographs and any other required supporting documents, to the building and inspections department for review by city staff. Submitted plans will either be: approved; denied; or recommended for resubmittal with modifications. The submitted design plans for stations located on private property must also comply with the same restrictions related to the location and placement of the stations installed in the public right-of-way as described immediately above in section 16-28. 
(Ord. No. 2019-04, § 2, 3-18-19) 
Sec. 16-30. - Provider assumes risk for installation and operation/management of the stations. 
    All stations located on public property are to be installed and managed by the provider who shall at all times assume all risks for the condition and management of the stations. The provider will obtain liability insurance in an amount approved by the city and under which the city shall be named as additional insured. Such insurance requirements shall be set out in the encroachment agreement that must be executed by the provider. 
(Ord. No. 2019-04, § 2, 3-18-19) 
Sec. 16-31. - Provider responsible for condition of public property. 
    All stations located on public property are installed at the risk of the provider who shall at all times have the obligation to return the public property on which the station is located back to the city in the same condition as when the encroachment agreement was entered into. In this regard, bond requirements as set out in the encroachment agreement must be complied with by the provider. 
(Ord. No. 2019-04, § 2, 3-18-19) 
Sec. 16-32. - City held harmless. 
    The provider shall hold the city harmless against all losses or damages resulting from or alleged to have resulted from the installation, and/or existence, and/or maintenance operation or any other aspect of the operation and use of the stations and the bicycles. Such hold harmless agreement as provided for in the encroachment agreement must be agreed to by the provider. 
(Ord. No. 2019-04, § 2, 3-18-19) 
Sec. 16-33. - Maintenance. 
    The provider shall be responsible for maintaining the stations in a safe and clean condition. The stations shall be kept in good order and repair at all times. 
(Ord. No. 2019-04, § 2, 3-18-19) 
Sec. 16-34. - Failure of compliance. 
    The provider shall be notified by code enforcement when a station is no longer in compliance with City Code requirements and/or the provisions of the encroachment agreement and the actions that must be taken to bring the station into compliance. In addition to any contractual remedies, the public works director may order removal of a station that cannot be brought into compliance by issuing a written order of removal to be sent by certified mail. Failure of the provider to remove the station within thirty (30) days of being issued a written order of removal by the public works director shall allow for the removal of the station at the cost of the provider. 
(Ord. No. 2019-04, § 2, 3-18-19) 
Secs. 16-35-16-44. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SHAREABLE DOCKLESS MOBILITY DEVICES 

Sec. 16-45. - Definitions. 
    As used in this division, unless specifically stated otherwise, the following terms shall mean and include: 
    Customer: Any person that uses, rents or rides a shareable dockless mobility device or is a customer of the operator. 
    Dockless mobility device: A non-motorized device that permits an individual to move or be moved freely, including, but not limited to, a bicycle, scooter or skateboard. 
    Dockless mobility device system operator ("operator"): A private entity that operates a shareable dockless mobility device system. The term includes any employee, agent or independent contractor hired by the operator. 
    Electric/motorized dockless mobility device: An electric or motorized device that permits an individual to move or be moved freely that does not require a driver's license, including, but not limited to, a bicycle, scooter or skateboard. This definition shall exclude any motor vehicle required to be registered with the state in accordance with state law, or the operation of which is otherwise governed by state law. 
    Fleet: Total amount of dockless mobility devices. 
    Shareable dockless mobility device permit ("dockless permit"): A permit required to operate a shareable dockless mobility device system within the City of College Park. 
    Shareable dockless mobility device systems: A system operated by private entities that provides the general public with mobility devices that can be rented on a short-term basis with no docking stations, for point to point trips, where the dockless shareable dockless mobility device is intended to remain in the public right-of-way, even when not being rented/used by a customer. 
    Shareable dockless mobility devices: Both dockless mobility devices and electric/motorized dockless mobility devices available for rent to the general public for short-term, one-way trips. 
(Ord. No. 2019-04, § 2, 3-18-19) 
Sec. 16-46. - Safety. 
(a)  All shareable dockless mobility devices must have minimum safety standards on board as follows: 
(1)  All bicycles shall meet the standards outlined in the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) under Title 16, Chapter II, Subchapter C, Part 1512- Requirements for Bicycles, as well as meeting the safety standards outlined in ISO 43.150-Cycles, Subsection 4210. 
(2)  All e-scooters shall meet equivalent safety standards as those outlined in CFR under Title 16, Chapter II, Subchapter C, Part 1512-Requirements for Bicycles. When powered solely by a motor, e-scooters shall be incapable of exceeding fifteen (15) mph. Additionally, the city may terminate any permit issued under this division if the battery or motor on an e-scooter is determined by an applicable regulatory agency in the State of Georgia to be unsafe for public use. 
(3)  Any permitted electric bicycles shall meet the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) definition of low-speed electric bicycles; and shall be subject to the same requirements as ordinary bicycles (described above). This means, among other requirements, that electric bicycles shall have fully operable pedals, an electric motor of less than seven hundred fifty (750) watts, and a top motor-powered speed of less than twenty (20) miles per hour, when operated by a rider weighing one hundred seventy (170) pounds. Additionally, the city may terminate any permit issued under this division if the battery or motor on an electric bicycle is determined by the appropriate regulatory agency in the State of Georgia to be unsafe for public use. 
(4)  All bicycles and e-scooters shall meet any State of Georgia requirement for lights during hours of darkness, including a rear red reflector and all other applicable requirements of state law. Additionally, all e-bicycles and e-scooters must always have front and back lights that are visible from a distance of at least three hundred (300) feet under normal atmospheric conditions at night. Front and rear lights must stay illuminated for at least ninety (90) seconds after the e-bike or e-scooter has stopped. 
(5)  Every bicycle and e-scooter shall have a unique identifier that is clearly displayed and visible to the user. 
(6)  Every bicycle and e-scooter shall have a customer service phone number that is in-service during all operating hours and clearly displayed and visible to the user. 
(b)  All operators shall provide in-app messaging, or visible language, that notifies their users of the following: 
(1)  People operating bicycles and e-scooters shall adhere to all applicable local, state, and federal laws regarding motorized and non-motorized vehicles. 
(2)  People operating bicycles and e-scooters shall yield to pedestrians. 
(3)  People shall operate bicycles and e-scooters safely and park responsibly. 
(4)  Helmet use is encouraged while riding a bicycle or scooter. 
(5)  The user shall not ride while under the influence of alcohol or drugs. 
(c)  Each shareable dockless mobility device must be equipped with a locking mechanism and/or smart technology equipment to prevent theft, as well as permanently affixed real-time GPS tracking device in order to track ridership data, owned and provided by the operator. 
(d)  All operators shall maintain liability insurance that names the City of College Park as additional insured with a minimum of a three million dollar ($3,000,000.00) aggregate limit. 
(e)  Shareable dockless mobility devices shall not be operated by more than one person at a time. 
(f)  While operating a shareable dockless mobility device, no individual shall physically hold a wireless telecommunications device, including cell phones. 
(g)  Shareable dockless mobility devices shall not be operated on sidewalks or any space exclusively for pedestrian use, state roads and federal highways. Devices may be otherwise operated in vehicle travel lanes, bike lanes, and along shared use paths throughout the city. Device riders must yield to pedestrians in all cases, including along shared use paths. 
(h)  All operators are required to educate users regarding laws applicable to riding and operating in the City of College Park. 
(Ord. No. 2019-04, § 2, 3-18-19) 
Sec. 16-47. - Parking. 
(a)  Shareable dockless mobility bicycle devices must have the ability to lock to a fixed object. 
(b)  Shareable dockless mobility devices cannot be parked in such a manner as to impede access to the public right-of-way. Any shareable dockless mobility devices that are reported or found to be in the public right-of-way in violation of this section are subject to removal by the city. Operator shall be responsible for reimbursing the city for all costs associated with removal. 
(c)  The city retains the right to create geo-fenced areas where shareable dockless mobility devices shall be parked. If the city elects to create geo-fenced parking areas, the city will issue written notification to all operators identifying the designated geo-fenced parking areas and all operators must comply within five (5) days of notification. 
(d)  All shareable dockless mobility devices shall have permanently affixed contact information for relocation requests. 
(e)  Shareable dockless mobility devices shall be parked upright at all times. 
(f)  No more than ten (10) shareable dockless mobility devices may be parked per block citywide, among all operators, and no more than one hundred (100) shareable dockless mobility devices may be parked per square mile citywide, among all operators. 
(g)  To maintain parking compliance, operators shall: 
(1)  Provide a single point-of-contact (phone number and e-mail) customer service line, available twenty-four (24) hours, for complaints regarding improper parking; 
(2)  List that contact clearly on each device along with a unique identifying number; 
(3)  Address those complaints within three (3) hours during typical work hours (Monday-Friday, 9:00 a.m.-6:00 p.m.) and twelve (12) hours on weekends, holidays, and between 6:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. on working days; 
(4)  Issue a "ticket number" for each issue to both the city and the person who reported the issue; 
(5)  Provide a response when a complaint is closed to the city and the person who reported the issue; and 
(6)  Provide sufficient operations and maintenance staff in the City of College Park to address issues and remove improperly parked devices. 
(h)  Shareable dockless mobility devices shall be parked closest to the curb on the sidewalk, but not hanging over the curb onto the public street, next to, or in, an existing bicycle rack or against a building, and in such a manner as to afford at least five (5) feet clearance for pedestrian traffic on the sidewalk. Operators shall inform customers on how to park properly. 
(i)  Shareable dockless mobility devices shall not be parked: 
(1)  In any vehicular travel lane or bicycle lane; 
(2)  At the corner curb sight radius area of sidewalks and shall not conflict with the required intersection sight triangle distance; 
(3)  On blocks without sidewalks; 
(4)  On vegetation; 
(5)  On any grate, manhole cover, or access lid; 
(6)  At or within five (5) feet of a bike share station as discussed in division 1 of this article; 
(7)  Where it obscures any fixed, regulatory, or informational signs or traffic control devices; 
(8)  Where it obstructs emergency service infrastructure including, but not limited to, fire hydrants, stand pipes, or automated external defibrillators; 
(9)  On any sidewalk adjacent to sidewalk dining, bus stops and/or shelters or passenger waiting areas, loading zones, street furniture that requires pedestrian access (such as benches, parking pay stations, bus shelters, transit information signs, newsracks, etc.), curb ramps and signal push buttons, within ten (10) feet of entryways and exits into a building and driveways, where they obstruct vehicle parking or pedestrian or wheelchair access to: 
a.  Private or public buildings and establishments; 
b.  Accessibility and safety features including curb ramps, wheelchair ramps, ramp landings, handrails, areas of refuge, and detectable warning strips. 
(j)  The city reserves the right to determine certain areas where device parking is prohibited, which shall be clearly marked by a sign installed by the city and shall be posted online. Operators shall communicate proper shareable dockless mobility devices parking requirements to all users. 
(k)  An operator shall remove any shareable dockless mobility device that is parked in one location for more than twenty-four (24) hours upon notice. If not properly removed after notice, the city may remove the device and take it to a city facility for storage at the expense of the operator. 
(l)  Upon evidence that an operator's shareable mobility devices are found to be consistently parked improperly, the city reserves the right to reduce the number of shared devices allowed under their permit or revoke it all together. 
(m)  The city reserves the right to impound, store and dispose of improperly parked devices at the operator's expense. 
(Ord. No. 2019-04, § 2, 3-18-19) 
Sec. 16-48. - Operations. 
(a)  All operators shall have a staffed operations center in the City of College Park and shall hire one (1) staff member for every one hundred (100) shareable dockless mobility devices in their fleet. 
(b)  All operators shall provide the city with a direct contact for local staff. 
(c)  All operators shall have no more than three hundred (300) and no less than fifty (50) shareable dockless mobility devices in their city fleet. 
(d)  Every shareable dockless mobility device shall have a city-issued identifier that is permanently affixed to the device and visible to the user. 
(e)  The operator shall be responsible for any costs for any damage to public property caused by the use of shareable dockless mobility devices. Upon receiving written notice of associated costs, the operator shall reimburse the city for costs within thirty (30) days of notice. 
(f)  Operators are required to provide the city's public works department with real-time data sharing and monthly reports showing bike usage and maintenance issues. 
(g)  Operators shall not use shareable dockless mobility devices for the sale or display of third-party advertising. Operators shall not publish or advertise the city's endorsement of their system in marketing or promotional materials. 
(h)  All operators shall have a performance bond of $80/device, with a cap of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). The form of the bond shall be approved by the city. These funds shall be accessible to the city for future public property repair and maintenance costs that may be incurred, removing and storing devices improperly parked, or if a company is not present to remove bicycles if its permit is terminated. If an operator increases the size of their fleet, the performance bond shall be adjusted appropriately before deploying additional devices. 
(Ord. No. 2019-04, § 2, 3-18-19) 
Sec. 16-49. - Permits required; applications. 
(a)  The primary authority and responsibility for the enforcement of the provisions of this division shall be vested in the code enforcement official. Upon a determination that a person is in violation of this division, the code enforcement official shall give notice or issue a citation that indicates the operator is in violation of a section of this division. Should the violation continue after receiving notice of violation, the public works director or designee may cite the violator to appear before the College Park Municipal Court to answer for the violation. Each day a violation continues shall be a separate offense. 
(b)  No operator may have a shareable dockless mobility device fleet in the City of College Park without a permit in accordance with this division. Any operator interested in applying for a shareable dockless mobility device permit shall submit an application to the building and inspections department or designee. The application shall be sworn by the applicant or agent thereof and shall include the following: 
(1)  Completed application form provided by the city; 
(2)  Valid College Park Occupational Tax Certificate; 
(3)  Insurance documentation and acknowledgment that the city is indemnified and held harmless for all liability related to the operation of the shareable dockless mobility device system; 
(4)  Images and description of the shareable dockless mobility device(s), including technical specifications, safety standard documentation, any signage or instructions permanently affixed to the device, and mobile application; 
(5)  Detailed shareable dockless mobility device maintenance policy and procedures; 
(6)  Address of the operations center location in the City of College Park; 
(7)  Names of all staff members employed at the operations center and the identification of any additional positions for staff that may be hired upon expansion of the fleet; 
(8)  Size of fleet and composition of shareable dockless mobility device at launch, including any planned fleet expansions; 
(9)  Service area at launch, including any planned expansions; 
(10)  Plan for educating users on proper parking and applicable City of College Park laws; 
(11)  Plan for encouraging helmet usage; 
(12)  Plan for sustainability measures when disposing of a broken shareable dockless mobility device; 
(13)  Description of pricing structure, rates, and methods of communication to the customer illustrating how the devices will be available at rates that are clearly and understandably communicated to the customer prior to device use; 
(14)  Documentation of how users with a smartphone can use the device share system; 
(15)  Documentation how users with a credit card can use the device share system; 
(16)  Documentation, if available, how users without a smartphone and/or credit card can use the device share system; 
(17)  Application fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(c)  The permit(s) under this division do not authorize use of the devices on private property and operator must have permission from any property owner whose property operator would like to utilize as part of its system. 
(d)  The annual dockless permit fee shall be $_____, plus $___ per shareable mobility device in the operator's fleet. 
(e)  The dockless permit shall be valid for twelve (12) months and shall be renewed each year. 
(f)  Any expansion of a shareable dockless mobility device fleet not specifically addressed in the most current dockless permit on file will require subsequent dockless permit application and fee. 
(g)  If an operator's permit is revoked, the operator may not reapply for a new permit for twelve (12) months after all of the operator's shareable dockless mobility devices are removed from the City of College Park. Operator must continue to provide access to real time data regarding device locations until all of operator's shareable dockless mobility devices are removed. Upon revocation of the dockless permit(s), the decommissioning of the fleet shall be completed within thirty (30) days from final revocation of the permit unless a different time period is determined by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2019-04, § 2, 3-18-19) 
Sec. 16-50. - Enforcement; permit suspension and revocation. 
(a)  The primary authority and responsibility for the enforcement of the provisions of this division shall be vested in the code enforcement official. Upon a determination that an operator is in violation of this division or any administrative regulations promulgated by the city pursuant to the provisions of this division, the person responsible for the operator's shareable dockless mobility device system in the city shall be cited for said violation. 
(b)  The fine for each violation shall not exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per day. 
(c)  An operator's dockless permit may be suspended or revoked by the city manager or designee upon a finding by the municipal court that the operator has violated any provision of this division or regulations promulgated therefrom. To initiate a suspension or revocation, the city manager shall send a notice to the operator at the address provided in the application, stating the reason for said suspension and revocation and allowing the operator an opportunity to appeal same. 
(d)  Within ten (10) days of the date of suspension or revocation, the operator shall have the right to appeal same to the mayor and city council, by providing a notice of appeal to the city manager. The city manager shall place the appeal on the next available city council agenda, but in no event later than thirty (30) days following the date of the notice of appeal. The city manager shall provide the city council with a recommendation at the hearing. 
(e)  At the hearing, the operator shall have the opportunity to present to the mayor and city council the reason for the appeal and to show the mayor and city council, by preponderance of the evidence, why the dockless permit should not be suspended or revoked. The mayor and city council shall, immediately after the hearing, make a determination as to whether to affirm the suspension or revocation, reverse the suspension or revocation, or modify same. Said decision, and reason for same, shall be noted in the official meetings minutes of the mayor and city council. 
(f)  During the pendency of the appeal process, operator shall have the right to continue operating under the dockless permit. However, any further violation during the pendency of the appeal process shall be treated as a public nuisance, which the city may abate by injunctive or other equitable relief and by such other means as are provided by law. This right shall be cumulative to the city's right to prosecute the violator(s) in addition to proceeding with suspension or revocation. 
(Ord. No. 2019-04, § 2, 3-18-19) 
Sec. 16-51. - Sharing of data. 
(a)  Permitted operators shall provide the city with real-time information on the entire College Park fleet through a documented application program interface (API). The operator is directly responsible for obtaining an API key from the city to which they will publish the data described herein. Operators are required to make the API endpoint available for public consumption. The data to be published to the city's API will include the following information in real time for every shareable dockless mobility device parked in the College Park operational area: 
(1)  Point location; 
(2)  Device identification number; 
(3)  Type of device; 
(4)  Fuel level (if electric). 
(b)  The City of College Park shall be authorized to display and publish real-time data provided via the API described herein. 
(c)  All permitted operators shall provide the following anonymized data for each trip record to inform and support safe and effective management of the shareable dockless mobility device system, and for transportation planning efforts. Data will be submitted to the city via the API: 
(1)  Company name; 
(2)  Type of device ("standard" or "electric"); 
(3)  Trip record number; 
(4)  Trip duration; 
(5)  Trip distance (in feet); 
(6)  Start date; 
(7)  Start time; 
(8)  End date; 
(9)  End time; 
(10)  Start and end location; and 
(11)  Device identification number. 
(d)  All permitted operators will provide the following device availability data for oversight of parking compliance and device distribution by minutes via the API: 
(1)  GPS coordinate; 
(2)  Availability duration (in minutes); 
(3)  Availability start date; and 
(4)  Availability start time. 
(e)  All permitted operators shall distribute a customer survey, to be provided by the city, prior to the end of their first permit year. 
(f)  All permitted operators shall keep a record of maintenance activities, including, but not limited to, device identification number and maintenance performed. These records shall be sent to the city's public works director weekly. 
(g)  All permitted operators will keep a record of reported collisions. These records will be sent to the city public works director weekly. 
(h)  All permitted operators will allow the city to temporarily install ten (10) mounted GPA trackers on a random sample of devices for research and trip analysis purposes. Trip data will be anonymous. 
(i)  All permitted operators shall report the aggregated breakdown of customers by gender and age monthly. Age will be reported into these age groups: under 5, 5-17, 18-24, 25-34, 35-44, 45-54, 55-64, 65 and over. 
(j)  All permitted operators agree to the city using a third-party researcher for evaluation of the shareable dockless mobility device program. Data will be shared with the third-party researcher only for the purposes of evaluation and/or enforcement of the requirements of the permit. 
(k)  Operators shall report the total number of complaint, total number of complaints resolved and number of complaints by type (i.e., blocking sidewalk, private property trespass, vandalism, inoperable device, etc.). Said report shall be submitted on a bi-weekly basis. 
(Ord. No. 2019-04, § 2, 3-18-19) 
Sec. 16-52. - Provision of accessibility to persons experiencing disabilities. 
(a)  Operators shall be required to include adaptive bicycles for users experiencing disabilities, including hand-cycles, tandems and trikes. The total percentage of adaptive E-bikes should be based on expected need, performance and usage. 
(b)  If operator is unable to deploy adaptive bicycles at the time of permit issuance, a plan must be submitted to the city within three (3) months, detailing a timeline for incorporation of shared adaptive bicycles into their fleet. This plan should detail the types and numbers of adaptive bikes that will be made available. 
(Ord. No. 2019-04, § 2, 3-18-19) 
Sec. 16-53. - Protect personal data and privacy. 
    Operators should clearly communicate to the public and to the city what personal information is being collected about users, how it is being used, and for how long. The shareable dockless mobility device permit shall include a standard reporting form for this information, and the responses should be available on the city's website. 
(Ord. No. 2019-04, § 2, 3-18-19) 
Sec. 16-54. - Establish a community engagement process. 
    The city manager or designee will establish requirements for a robust community engagement process, including public workshops where operators co-plan the system with the community and a public forum for operators to present their proposals directly to, and receive comments from, the city's residents. Public outreach plans shall be pre-approved by designated city staff, and should include a full list of presentations, activities and events. 
(Ord. No. 2019-04, § 2, 3-18-19) 
Sec. 16-55. - Equity. 
(a)  Operators shall have payment options which do not require the rider to have access to credit cards in order to access the shareable dockless mobility device. 
(b)  Operators shall provide an equity plan to the city as part of the permit application. The equity plan may include such elements as discounted price options, cash-based payment systems, and non-smartphone reservation systems. 
(Ord. No. 2019-04, § 2, 3-18-19) 
Chapter 17 - SUBDIVISIONS[1]

Cross reference- Organization of planning commission, § 15-1; zoning, App. A; payment of cost of water line extension, § 10-30. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 17-1. - Purpose and intent. 
    This chapter shall be known as the "Subdivision Ordinance" and serves the purpose of promoting the public health, safety, convenience and general welfare of the City of College Park by setting standards for the form and content of preliminary and final plats or plats; by setting standards to regulate the division of land; and by establishing procedures for the review of subdivision plats by the planning commission and mayor and council. This chapter further serves the following purposes: 
(1)  To encourage economically sound and stable development of the city; 
(2)  To assure the provision of required streets, utilities, and other facilities and services to new land developments; 
(3)  To assure the adequate provision of safe and convenient traffic access and circulation, both vehicular and pedestrian, to new land developments; 
(4)  To assure the provision of needed public open spaces and building sites in new land developments through the dedication or reservation of land for recreational, educational, and other public purposes; and 
(5)  To assure, in general, the wise development of new areas, in harmony with the master plan of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2007-20, § 1, 4-3-07) 
Sec. 17-2. - Definitions. 
    In addition to the definitions below, this chapter shall include all the definitions appearing in the city zoning ordinance [Appendix A], unless such definitions otherwise conflict with the definitions below: 
(1)  Alley: A secondary access road, typically to the rear of a building site. 
(2)  Arterial street: Arterial streets provide the principal network for traffic flow within the community. They connect areas of major activity within the urban area and function primarily as carriers of cross-town traffic. Arterial streets should be designed as four-lane facilities with maximum operating speeds as referenced in the thoroughfare plan. Maximum capacity would be approximately thirty thousand (30,000) vehicles per day. Arterial streets should have limited access to adjacent land uses with driveways that do not require a vehicle to back into the street. 
(3)  Block: A parcel of land entirely surrounded by public streets and other rights-of-way, other than alleys, or land which is designated as a block on any recorded subdivision map. In cases where the plotting is incomplete or disconnected, the subdivider may determine the outline of the block. 
(4)  Condominium: An estate in real property consisting of an undivided interest in common in a portion of a parcel in real property together with a separate interest in space in a residential, industrial or commercial building on such real property, such as an apartments office or store. A condominium may include, in addition, a separate interest in other portions of such real property. 
(5)  Design: Includes, but is not limited to, street alignments, grades and widths; the alignment and widths of easements and rights-of-way for drainage, sanitary sewers, water, utilities and other facilities for public use or benefit; the size, configuration, and location of park, open space, and recreation sites; and the lot area, width, depth, shape and pattern as may be required or otherwise provided for in this chapter, the City Code, any site plans, zoning plat or planned development plans, and the comprehensive plan and any of its elements. 
(6)  Easement: A grant by the property owner for the use by the public, a corporation or persons of a strip of land for specified purposes. 
(7)  Final plat: Refers to a plat showing a subdivision for which a preliminary and final plat is required by this chapter, prepared in accordance with the Georgia Plat Act and this chapter, which is designed to be recorded with the superior court clerk of Fulton or Clayton County. 
(8)  Georgia Plat Act: The Georgia Plat Act of the State of Georgia codified at Official Code of Georgia, Section 15-6-67. 
(9)  Improvement: Includes, but is not limited to streets, curbs, gutters, sidewalks, drainage facilities, sanitary sewer facilities, utilities, water facilities, street lights, landscaping, parks, or other improvements to be installed, or agreed to be installed by the subdivider on the land/or land appurtenant thereto, to be used for public streets, highways, ways, easements, park and recreation facilities or as otherwise may be necessary for the general use or benefit of the lot owners in the subdivision and the surrounding area as a condition precedent to approval and acceptance of the final plat. Improvement also refers to such specific improvements or types of improvements the installation of which, either by the subdivider, by public agencies, by private utilities, or by a combination thereof, are necessary or convenient to ensure conformity with or implementation of the comprehensive plan and any of its elements, this chapter, the City Code, or any specific plans or planned unit development plans. 
(10)  Local street: Provides direct access to abutting properties and allows for localized movement of traffic. Local streets are characterized by low daily volumes of less than two thousand (2,000) vehicles per day, and low operating speeds as indicated in the city thoroughfare plan. 
(11)  Lot of record: A lot which is part of a subdivision, the plat of which as been recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court of Fulton or Clayton Counties; or a parcel of land, the deed of which was recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court of Fulton or Clayton Counties. 
(12)  Lot or parcel: Lot or parcel shall mean a parcel of land established or to be established by procedures as provided for in this chapter. 
(13)  Lot depth: The horizontal distance from the midpoint of the front to the midpoint of the rear lot line. 
(14)  Lot depth-average: The sum of the length of the two (2) side lines of the lot divided by two (2). In the case of irregularly shaped lots having four (4) or more sides, "average lot depth" shall be the sum of the length of two (2) lines, drawn perpendicular to the front lot line at the widest and narrowest portions of the lot, divided by two (2). 
(15)  Lot line-front: In the case of an interior lot, the boundary of the lot along the public right-of-way; and in the case of a corner lot, a line separating the narrowest street frontage of the lot from the right-of-way, except in those cases where the latest recorded tract deed restrictions, approved as part of a subdivision approval, specify another line as the front lot line. 
(16)  Lot line-rear: A lot line which is not a front or side lot line as defined herein, which is parallel or approximately parallel to and opposite the front lot line. In the case of an irregularly-shaped lot, a line within the lot most nearly parallel to and at the farthest distance from the front lot line. 
(17)  Lot line-side: Any lot line not a front lot line or a rear lot line as defined herein. 
(18)  Lot width-average: The sum of the length of the front and rear lot line divided by two (2). In the case of irregularly-shaped lots having four (4) or more sides, "average lot width" shall be the sum of the length of two (2) lines, drawn perpendicular to one (1) side line at the widest and narrowest portions of the lot, divided by two (2). 
(19)  Owner: The individual(s), or entity(ies), having sufficient proprietary interest in the land sought to be subdivided, and to commence and maintain proceedings to subdivide the same under the law of the State of Georgia and this chapter. 
(20)  Pedestrian way: An easement exclusively for pedestrian use. 
(21)  Planting strip: The strip of land adjacent to the back of curb line or sidewalk line, which may be used for street trees, mailboxes, and traffic signs and may be reflected on the final plat. 
(22)  Preliminary plat: Any plat made for the purpose of showing the design and improvement of a proposed subdivision and the existing conditions in and around it, prepared in accordance with this chapter and the Georgia Plat Act. 
(23)  Reserve strip: A strip of land not less than ten (10) feet in width deeded or dedicated to the city for the purpose of regulating access to a partially improved or dedicated or dead-end, alley, street or highway, or to any arterial street. 
(24)  Subdivider: A person(s), or entity(ies), who causes land to be subdivided into any number of parcels. 
(25)  Subdivision: Any division or revision of a lot, tract or parcel of real property improved or unimproved, or portion thereof shown on the latest equalized county tax roll as a unit or as contiguous units, which is proposed to be divided by a subdivider, including the combination or recombination of previously platted lots into a larger parcel, either by platting or by metes and bounds, into two (2) or more lots, building sites, or other divisions, or the recombination of previously platted lots into a larger parcel, including all division or recombination of land involving the dedication, change, or abandonment of a street, site, easement or other right-of-way for any public use or facility for the purpose of sale, lease, or financing, whether immediate or future, by any subdivider within any period. When appropriate to the context, the term "subdivision" shall relate to the process of subdividing or to the land area subdivided. The following, however, are not subdivisions with the meaning of this chapter: 
a.  Financing or leasing of industrial buildings, stores, offices, apartments or similar space within a building or spaces within a trailer park; 
b.  Mineral, oil or gas leases; 
c.  Cemetery lot. 
(Ord. No. 2007-20, § 1, 4-3-07) 
Sec. 17-3. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the following: 
(1)  When any parcel of land within the city is to be divided into two (2) or more separate lots or parcels; or 
(2)  Where the lot lines between contiguous parcels are proposed to be adjusted; or 
(3)  Where two (2) or more parcels of land are proposed to be merged into lesser number of parcels. 
(Ord. No. 2007-20, § 1, 4-3-07) 
Sec. 17-4. - Administration. 
    These regulations shall be administered by the city planning commission. The planning commission shall have all the powers and duties with respect to preliminary and final plats and the related procedures, which are specified by law and by this chapter. The city planning commission shall review and recommend approval of any amendment to this chapter prior to adoption by the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 2007-20, § 1, 4-3-07) 
Sec. 17-5. - Approval required. 
    No land in the City of College Park shall hereafter be subdivided and sold or otherwise transferred in ownership by reference to, or exhibition of, or by any other use of a plat of a subdivision until such plat has received final approval by the planning commission, after which such plat shall be duly recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court of the county in which the subdivision is located. The description by metes and bounds in the document of sale or transfer shall not exempt the transaction from the regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2007-20, § 1, 4-3-07) 
Sec. 17-6. - Compliance with other laws. 
    Compliance with this chapter shall not substitute for compliance with federal and state laws nor for other City of College Park ordinances and resolutions. Whenever the following regulations conflict with federal, state or local law, the more stringent regulation shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 2007-20, § 1, 4-3-07) 
Sec. 17-7. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  Any person violating any of the provisions of these regulations shall be deemed guilty of an offense and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or imprisonment in the city jail for not more than ninety (90) days. Each day of continuance of a violation shall be considered a separate offense. The owner of any lands or parts thereof where anything in violation of these regulations shall be placed or shall exist, or any builder, contractor or agent of the owner who may have assisted in the commission of any such violation, shall be guilty of a separate offense. 
(b)  In any case in which any land is or is proposed to be used in violation of these regulations, the city attorney or any owner of real estate may, in addition to other remedies provided by law, institute injunction, abatement, or any appropriate action or proceeding to prevent, enjoin or abate such unlawful use. 
(Ord. No. 2007-20, § 1, 4-3-07) 
Secs. 17-8, 17-9. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PROCEDURE 
DIVISION 1. - PREREQUISITES AND OTHER REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 17-10. - Perequisites to grading and/or building permits. 
(a)  Any person proposing to subdivide land within the city shall conform to the comprehensive plan and its elements, the zoning ordinance of the City of College Park, any specific plans, and all policies of the city, or any part thereof, including but not limited to the type, density, and intensity of use established for the site, any phasing requirements, and reservations of utility and infrastructure service capacities. 
(b)  No subdivider shall proceed with any construction work on a proposed subdivision before obtaining approval from the planning commission. 
(Ord. No. 2007-20, § 1, 4-3-07) 
Sec. 17-11. - Commencement of construction work. 
    Subsequent to the approval of the civil plans, the developer may commence construction work in accordance with either of the following: 
(1)  The improvements may be installed per the approved plans and then the final plat may be recorded; or 
(2)  Prior to installation of the improvements, a bond or other suitable financial security sufficient to cover the cost of all improvements shall be submitted to the city engineer; the developer shall enter into a subdivision agreement to be approved and accepted by the mayor and council; and the final plat is recorded. 
(Ord. No. 2007-20, § 1, 4-3-07) 
Sec. 17-12-17-19. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PRELIMINARY PLATS 

Sec. 17-20. - Preliminary plats.
