ARTICLE I. - PROPERTY TAX 

Sec. 18-1. - Rate for ordinary expenses. 
    There is hereby assessed and levied upon all real and personal property in said city, for the fiscal year 2000, and for each year thereafter until changed, a tax which shall be determined annually by the city and adopted by resolution of the mayor and council. Said tax shall be for the purpose of providing revenue for the ordinary expenses of the municipal government of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2001-26, § 1, 11-1-01; Ord. No. 2002-37, 8-19-02; Ord. No. 2002-40, 9-16-02; Ord. No. 2002-44, § 1, 10-7-02) 
Sec. 18-2. - Levy for sinking fund. 
    There is hereby assessed and levied upon all real and personal property in the city, for each year until changed, a tax in such amount as prescribed by the governing body on and for each one hundred dollars ($100.00) of valuation of said property for the purpose of providing a sinking fund with which to discharge and pay off principal and interest on the bonded indebtedness of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2001-26, § 1, 11-1-01) 
Sec. 18-3. - Date liability accrues. 
    All property in the city, and the owners thereof, shall be liable for ad valorem taxes for the year in respect of all property owned and subject to taxation on January 1 of the year for which said taxes are assessed. 
(Ord. No. 2001-26, § 1, 11-1-01) 
Sec. 18-4. - Return and assessment of property. 
    Procedures for the return and assessment of all property subject to taxation under this chapter shall be as provided by state law and in accordance with procedures adopted by the county in which such property is located. 
(Ord. No. 2001-26, § 1, 11-1-01) 
Sec. 18-5. - Due date for payment; interest charge; penalty. 
(a)  Due date; interest on unpaid taxes. All ad valorem taxes due the city for the year shall mature and be due and payable on or before November 28, of the year for which taxes are assessed. Any ad valorem taxes and penalty due the city remaining unpaid on November 29, in each year shall bear interest at one (1) per cent per month from November 29. 
(b)  Penalty on willful failure to pay ad valorem tax. In any instance in which any person willfully fails to pay, on or before November 28 shall pay a penalty of ten (10) per cent of the amount of tax due and not paid, plus fi fa and recording fees. 
(Ord. No. 2001-26, § 1, 11-1-01) 
Sec. 18-6. - Homestead exemption. 
    The homestead of each resident of the City of College Park actually occupied by the owner as a residence and a homestead, but only so long as actually occupied by the owner primarily as such, is hereby exempted from city ad valorem taxes, except taxes levied by said city for the payment of interest on and retirement of bonded indebtedness, in the amount to be determined annually by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2001-26, § 1, 11-1-01) 
Secs. 18-7-18-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SPECIAL TAX DISTRICTS 

Sec. 18-11. - Administrative provisions. 
(a)  Due date; interest an unpaid taxes. All taxes due the city under this article for the year shall mature and be due and payable on or before November 28, of the year for which taxes are assessed. Any taxes and penalty due the city under this article which remain unpaid on November 29, in each year assessed shall bear interest at one (1) per cent per month from November 29, and each tax collector and tax commissioner shall collect the interest on unpaid taxes and account for such in his final settlement. 
(b)  Penalty on willful failure to pay special tax. In any instance in which, any person willfully fails to pay, on or before November 28, any special tax shall pay a penalty of ten (10) per cent of the amount of tax due and not paid plus fi fa and recording fees. 
(Ord. No. 2001-26, § 1, 11-1-01) 
Sec. 18-12. - Same-Exception as to tax. 
    Nothing contained herein shall be construed to impose an additional ad valorem taxation, under the provisions hereof, for any purpose against property used exclusively for residential purposes within any such tax district. For the purposes of this chapter, residential purposes shall not include hotels, motels, or any place of lodging. 
(Ord. No. 2001-26, § 1, 11-1-01) 
Sec. 18-13. - Hotel/motel special tax district. 
(a)  Renaming. There is currently existing within the city a special tax district, known as the "Development Authority Tax District," which was created by Ordinance 97-09, and authorized by Georgia Laws 1980, page 2071, et. seq. Said Development Authority Tax District shall be hereafter named the "Hotel/Motel Special Tax District" and said Hotel/Motel Special Tax District shall encompass all that area encompassed by the Development Authority Tax District which parcels are designated on the map entitled "Hotel/Motel Special Tax District Map." Said map is attached hereto and incorporated herein by express reference. A copy of the "Hotel/Motel Special Tax District Map" shall be maintained on file in the office of the city clerk where it shall be available for public inspection. 
(b)  Purpose. The hotel/motel special tax district was established for any purposes allowed under Georgia law. The tax is assessed against the owner of each parcel of property included within the tax district. 
(c)  Rate. There is hereby assessed and levied upon all real and personal property in this district for each year, until changed, a tax, the rate of which shall be determined annually by the city and adopted by resolution of the mayor and council. Said tax revenues shall be used for all purposes allowed by Georgia Laws 1980, page 2071 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 2001-26, § 1, 11-1-01; Ord. No. 2002-37, 8-19-02; Ord. No. 2002-40, 9-16-02; Ord. No. 2002-44, § 2, 10-7-02) 
Sec. 18-14. - Georgia International Convention Center Area Infrastructure Special Tax District. 
(a)  Establishment. There is hereby created and established for the City of College Park a special tax district pursuant to Georgia Laws 1980, page 2071, et seq., such district to be known as the "Georgia International Convention Center Area Infrastructure Special Tax District" and said Georgia International Convention Center Area Infrastructure Special Tax District shall encompass all that area upon the parcels designated on the map entitled "Georgia International Convention Center Area Infrastructure Special Tax District Map," which is attached hereto and incorporated herein by express reference as Exhibit A. A copy of the "Georgia International Convention Center Area Infrastructure Special Tax District Map" shall be maintained on file in the office of the city clerk where it shall be available for public inspection. 
(b)  Purpose. The Georgia International Convention Center Area Infrastructure Special Tax District is established for the purpose of installing all infrastructure, including roads and utilities, to serve the Georgia International Convention Center Area and for all purposes allowed by Georgia Laws 1980, page 2071, et seq. The tax is assessed against the owner of each parcel of property included within the tax district. 
(c)  Rate. There is hereby assessed and levied upon all real and personal property in this district for each year, until changed, a tax, the rate of which shall be determined annually by the city of adopted by resolution of the mayor and council. Said tax revenues shall be used for all purposes allowed by Georgia Laws 1980, page 2071 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 2001-26, § 1, 11-1-01; Ord. No. 2002-44, § 3, 10-7-02) 
Secs. 18-15-18-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BLIGHTED PROPERTY 

Sec. 18-21. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known as the "College Park Blighted Property Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 2012-10, § 1, 11-5-12) 
Sec. 18-22. - Purpose. 
    The existence of real property which is maintained in a blighted condition increases the burden of the state and local government by increasing the need for government services, including but not limited to social services, public safety services, and code enforcement services. Rehabilitation of blighted property decreases this need for such government services. 
    In furtherance of its objective to eradicate conditions of slum and blight within the city, the mayor and council, in exercise of the powers granted to municipal corporations at O.C.G.A., Tit. 36, Ch. 61, Urban Redevelopment, has designated those areas of the city where conditions of slum and blight are found or are likely to spread. 
    In recognition of the need for enhanced governmental services and in order to encourage private property owners to maintain their real property and the buildings, structures and improvement thereon in good condition and repair, and as an incentive to encourage community redevelopment, a community redevelopment tax incentive program is hereby established as authorized by Article IX, Section II, Paragraph VII(d) of the 1983 Constitution of the State of Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 2012-10, § 1, 11-5-12) 
Sec. 18-23. - Definitions. 
    Blighted property, blighted, or blight means any property which: 
(1)  Presents one (1) or more of the following conditions: 
a.  Uninhabitable, unsafe, or abandoned structure; 
b.  Inadequate provisions for ventilation, light, air, or sanitation; 
c.  An imminent harm to life or other property caused by fire, flood, hurricane, tornado, earthquake, storm, or other natural catastrophe respecting which the governor has declared a state of emergency under the state law or has certified the need for disaster assistance under federal law; provided, however, this division shall not apply to property unless the relevant public agency has given notice in writing to the property owner regarding specific harm caused by the property and the owner has failed to take reasonable measures to remedy the harm; 
d.  A site identified by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency as a superfund site pursuant to 42 U.S.C. Section 9601, et seq., or having environmental contamination to an extent that requires remedial actions; 
e.  Repeated illegal and criminal activity on the property of which the property owner knew or should have known; or 
f.  The maintenance of the property is below state, county, or municipal codes for at least three (3) months after written notice of the code violation to its owner; 
g.  Is conducive to ill health, transmission of disease, infant mortality, or crime in the immediate proximity of the property; 
h.  Property that is subject to frequent property maintenance or environmental code citations; and 
i.  Vacant property last occupied by a commercial or industrial use where no visible commercial or industrial activity has occurred in more than three (3) months. 
Property shall not be deemed blighted solely because of aesthetic conditions. 
    Building inspector means a certified inspector possessing the requisite qualifications to determine minimal code compliance. 
    Community redevelopment means any activity, project, or service necessary or incidental to achieving the redevelopment or revitalization of a redevelopment area or portion thereof designated for redevelopment through an urban redevelopment plan or through local ordinances relating to the repair, closing, and demolition of buildings and structures unfit for human habitation. 
    Governing authority means the mayor and council of the City of College Park, a Georgia municipal corporation. 
    Millage or millage rate means the levy, in mills, which is established by the governing authority for purposes of financing, in whole or in part, the levying jurisdiction's general fund expenses for the fiscal year. 
    Person means such individual(s), partnership, corporations, business entities and associations which return real property for ad valorem taxation or who are chargeable by law for the taxes on the property. 
    Public officer means the city manager or such officer or employee of the city as designated by the city manager to perform the duties and responsibilities hereafter set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2012-10, § 1, 11-5-12; Ord. No. 2017-09, § 1, 6-5-17) 
Sec. 18-24. - Ad valorem tax increase on blighted property. 
(a)  There is hereby levied on all real property within the city which has been officially identified as maintained in a blighted condition an increased ad valorem tax by applying a factor of seven (7.0) to the millage rate applied to the property, so that such property shall be taxed at a higher millage rate generally applied in the municipality, or otherwise provided by general law; provided, however, real property on which there is situated a dwelling house which is being occupied as the primary residence of one (1) or more persons shall not be subject to official identification as maintained in a blighted condition and shall not be subject to increased taxation. 
(b)  Such increased ad valorem tax shall be applied and reflected in the first tax bill rendered following official designation of a real property as blighted; provided however, if a property owner resolves the blighted condition of such owner's property to the city's satisfaction (in accordance with the provisions of section 18-26) at least sixty (60) days prior to the preparation of the first tax bill following such official designation of such real property as blighted, the property shall be eligible for the decrease of the tax rate as provided in section 18-27 in the first tax bill rendered following official designation of such real property as blighted. 
(c)  Revenues arising from the increased rate of ad valorem taxation shall, upon receipt, be segregated by the city manager and used only for community redevelopment purposes, as identified in an approved urban redevelopment program, including defraying the cost of the city's program to close, repair, or demolish unfit building and structures. 
(Ord. No. 2012-10, § 1, 11-5-12) 
Sec. 18-25. - Identification of blighted property. 
(a)  In order for a parcel of real property to be officially designated as maintained in a blighted condition and subject to increased taxation, the following steps must be completed: 
(1)  An inspection must be performed on the parcel of property. In order for an inspection to be performed, 
a.  A request may be made by the public officer or by at least five (5) residents (each living in a different household from the others) of the city for inspection of a parcel of property, said inspection to be based on the criteria as delineated in ordinance, or 
b.  The public officer may cause a survey of existing housing conditions to be performed, or may refer to any such survey conducted or finalized within the previous five (5) years, to locate or identify any parcels which may be in a blighted condition and for which a full inspection should be conducted to determine if that parcel of property meets the criteria set out in this article for designation as being maintained in a blighted condition. 
(2)  A written inspection report of the findings for any parcel of property inspected pursuant to subsection (1) above shall be prepared and submitted to the public officer. Where feasible, photographs of the conditions found to exist on the property on the date of inspection shall be made and supplement the inspection report. Where compliance with minimum construction, housing, occupancy, fire and life safety codes in effect within the city are in question, the inspection shall be conducted by a certified inspector possessing the requisite qualifications to determine minimal code compliance. 
(3)  Following completion of the inspection report, the public officer shall make a determination, in writing, that a property is maintained in a blighted condition, as defined by this article, and is subject to increased taxation. 
(4)  The public officer shall cause a written notice of his determination that the real property at issue is being maintained in a blighted condition to be served upon the person(s) shown on the most recent tax digest of Fulton or Clayton County as responsible for payment of ad valorem taxes assessed thereon; provided, however, where through the existence of reasonable diligence it becomes known to the public officer that real property has been sold or conveyed since publication of the most recent tax digest, written notice shall be given to the person(s) known or reasonably believed to then own the property or be chargeable with the payment of ad valorem taxes thereon, at the best address available. Service in the manner set forth at O.C.G.A. § 41-2-12 and a notice posted on the property shall constitute sufficient notice to the property's owner or person chargeable with the payment of ad valorem taxes for purpose of this section, except that posting of the notice on the property will not be required. 
(b)  The written notice given to the person(s) chargeable with the payment of ad valorem taxes shall notify such person of the public officer's determination the real property is being maintained in a blighted condition and shall advise such person of the hours and location at which the person may inspect and copy the public officer's determination and any supporting documentation. Persons notified that real property of which the person(s) is chargeable with the payment of ad valorem taxes shall have thirty (30) days from the receipt of notice in which to request a hearing before the city's municipal court. Written request for hearing shall be filed with the public officer and shall be date stamped upon receipt. Upon receipt of a request for hearing, the public officer shall notify the municipal court and the building inspector or person who performed the inspection and prepared the inspection report. 
(c)  Within thirty (30) days of the receipt of a request for hearing, the municipal court clerk shall set a date, time and location for the hearing and shall give at least ten (10) business days notice to the person(s) requesting the hearing, the public officer and the building inspector or person who performed the inspection and prepared the inspection report. Notice of scheduled hearings shall be published as a legal advertisement in the designated legal organ of the city, at least five (5) days prior to the hearing. Hearings may be continued by the municipal court judge upon request of any party, for good cause. 
(d)  At the hearing, the public officer shall have the burden of demonstrating by a preponderance of the evidence that the subject property is maintained in a blighted condition, as defined by this article. The municipal court judge shall cause a record of the evidence submitted at the hearing to be maintained. Upon hearing from the public officer and/or their witnesses and the person(s) requesting the hearing and/or their witnesses, the judge of municipal court shall make a determination either affirming or reversing the determination of the public officer. The determination shall be in writing and copies thereof shall be served on the parties by certified mail or statutory overnight delivery. The determination by the court shall be deemed final. A copy of such determination shall also be served upon the tax commissioner of Fulton or Clayton County, as applicable, who shall include the increased tax on the next regular tax bill rendered on behalf of the city. 
(e)  Persons aggrieved by the determination of the court affirming the determination of the public officer may petition the Superior Court of Fulton or Clayton County, as applicable, for a writ of certiorari within thirty (30) days of issuance of the court's written determination. 
(Ord. No. 2012-10, § 1, 11-5-12) 
Sec. 18-26. - Remediation or redevelopment. 
(a)  A property owner or person(s) who is chargeable with the payment of ad valorem taxes on real property which has been officially designated pursuant to this article as property maintained in a blighted condition may petition the public officer to lift the designation, upon proof of compliance with the following: 
(1)  Completion of work required under a plan of remedial action or redevelopment approved by the city's planning and development director which addresses the conditions of blight found to exist on or within the property, including compliance with all applicable minimum codes; or 
(2)  Completion of work required under a court order entered in a proceeding brought pursuant to College Park's nuisance ordinance. 
(b)  Before action on a petition to lift the designation, the public officer shall cause the property to be thoroughly inspected by a building inspector who, by written inspection report, shall certify that all requisite work has been performed to applicable code in a workmanlike manner, in accordance with the specifications of the plan of remedial action or redevelopment, or applicable court order. Upon finding required work to be satisfactorily performed, the public officer shall issue a written determination that the real property is no longer maintained in a blighted condition. Copies of this determination shall be served upon the person(s) chargeable with the payment of ad valorem taxes, and upon the tax commissioner of Fulton or Clayton County, as applicable. 
(c)  All plans for remedial action or redevelopment shall be in writing, signed by the person(s) chargeable with the payment of ad valorem taxes on the real property and the director of the city's planning and development department, and contain the following: 
(1)  The plan shall be consistent with the city's comprehensive plan and all laws and ordinances governing the subject property, and shall conform to any urban redevelopment plan adopted for the area within which the property lies; 
(2)  The plan shall set forth in reasonable detail the requirements for repair, closure, demolition, or restoration of existing structures, in accordance with minimal statewide codes; where structures are demolished, the plan shall include provisions for debris removal, stabilization and landscaping of the property; 
(3)  On parcels of five (5) acres or greater, the plan shall address the relationship to local objectives respecting land uses, improved traffic, public transportation, public utilities, recreational and community facilities, and other public improvements; 
(4)  The plan shall contain verifiable funding sources which will be used to complete its requirements and show the feasibility thereof; 
(5)  The plan shall contain a timetable for completion of required work; and 
(6)  Any outstanding ad valorem taxes (state, school, county and city, including the increased tax pursuant to this article) and governmental liens due and payable on the property must be satisfied in full. 
(Ord. No. 2012-10, § 1, 11-5-12) 
Sec. 18-27. - Decrease of tax rate. 
(a)  Real property which has had its designation as maintained in a blighted condition removed by the public officer, as provided in section 18-25, Identification of blighted property, of this article, shall be eligible for a decrease in the rate of city ad valorem taxation by applying a factor of 0.5 to the city millage rate applied to the property, so that such property shall be taxed at a lower millage rate than the millage rate generally applied in the municipality or otherwise provided by general law; such decreased rate of taxation shall be applied beginning with the next tax bill rendered following removal of official designation of a real property as blighted. The decreased rate of taxation may be given in successive years, depending on the amount of cost expended by the person(s) chargeable with payment of ad valorem taxes on the property to satisfy its remediation or redevelopment, with every twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) or portion thereof equaling one (1) year of tax reduction; provided, however, that no property shall be entitled to reduction in city ad valorem taxes for more than four (4) successive years. 
(b)  In order to claim entitlement for a decreased rate of taxation, the person(s) chargeable with payment of ad valorem taxes on the property shall submit a notarized affidavit to the public officer, supported by receipts or other evidence of payment, of the amount expended. 
(Ord. No. 2012-10, § 1, 11-5-12) 
Sec. 18-28. - Notice to tax commissioner. 
    It shall be the duty of the public officer to notify the tax commissioner of Fulton or Clayton County, as applicable, in writing as to designation or removal of designation of a specific property as maintained in a blighted condition. Such notice shall identify the specific property by street address and tax map, block and parcel number, as assigned by the tax commissioner of Fulton or Clayton County, as applicable. The public officer shall cooperate with the tax commissioner to assure accurate tax billing of those properties subject to increased or reduced ad valorem taxation under this article. 
(Ord. No. 2012-10, § 1, 11-5-12) 
Chapter 19 - TRAFFIC[1]

Cross reference- Streets to which moving of buildings restricted, § 5-164; establishment of routes for vehicles carrying explosives and blasting agents, etc., §§ 7-18, 7-19; storage of vehicles, § 7-9; establishment of fire lanes, § 7-20; use of motor vehicle horns, § 8-32; noise from vehicle repair, § 8-33; placing advertising matter in vehicles, § 12-7; motor vehicles in parts, § 13-8; vehicle access control, App. A, Art. XI-B.

State Law reference- Authority to adopt by reference state traffic regulations, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-372. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 19-1. - Uniform Rules of the road adopted; penalty for violation. 
(a)  Pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-372 through 40-6-376 there is hereby adopted O.C.G.A. Title 40, Chapter 6, known as the Uniform Rules of the Road for the traffic regulations upon the streets and thoroughfares of the city with like effect as if the same were recited herein in full. 
(b)  Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of violation of said Uniform Rules of the Road, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished as provided by section 1-8. 
(Code 1963, § 15-34) 
Sec. 19-2. - Financial responsibility and accident reparation; state law adopted. 
    The Georgia Motor Vehicle Safety Responsibility Act, O.C.G.A. Title 40, Chapter 9 as amended, and the Georgia Motor Vehicle Accident Reparations Act, O.C.G.A. Title 33, Chapter 34, as amended, are hereby adopted by reference and made a part of this Code as if set out in full. Therefore, it shall be unlawful to operate a motor vehicle within the city without compliance with said Acts. 
(Code 1963, § 15-72.2) 
Sec. 19-3. - Police; duties, authority in congested areas. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the police officers on traffic duty at intersections or heavily congested traffic zones to so direct traffic as to expedite the same, and to this end it shall be the duty of police officers, where it can be safely done, to direct traffic through intersections controlled by traffic signal lights without regard to the signal light, so that when a red traffic signal light is holding traffic at a street intersection the traffic shall be released and directed to move forward when there is little or no traffic at or approaching such intersection on a green light; and in extremely heavily congested areas such police officer shall have power and authority to direct traffic without regard to such automatic traffic signal light, even though there be substantial traffic on both or all of such intersecting streets at or near and approaching such intersection. 
(b)  The object and purpose of this section is to eliminate traffic bottlenecks caused by red lights facing heavy traffic while a green light on the intersecting street is of no benefit or of small benefit because of the light traffic on such intersecting street. 
(Code 1963, § 15-30) 
Sec. 19-4. - Obedience to police; temporary regulations. 
(a)  Required. No person shall wilfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of any officer invested by law with authority to direct, control or regulate traffic. 
(b)  Temporary regulations. The chief of police may establish temporary traffic regulations which the public must obey after being warned. Verbal warning by an authorized police officer of the city, or by printed signs erected in the area affected shall constitute sufficient notice to the public of said temporary traffic regulation or regulations. 
(Code 1963, § 15-31) 
Sec. 19-5. - Public officers, employees subject to traffic regulations. 
(a)  The provisions of this chapter applicable to the drivers of vehicles upon the streets and highways shall apply to the drivers of all vehicles owned or operated by the United States, this state, county or city, or any other political subdivision of the state, except as provided in this section and subject to such specific exceptions as are set forth in this chapter with reference to authorized emergency vehicles. 
(b)  Unless specifically made applicable, the provisions of this chapter shall not apply to persons, teams, motor vehicles and other equipment while at a place where work is in process on a highway or a bridge and while engaged in such work, but shall apply to such persons and vehicles when traveling to or from such places where work is in process. 
(Code 1963, § 15-32) 
State Law reference- Persons working on highway, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-5. 
Sec. 19-6. - Boarding, alighting from vehicle-Generally. 
    Persons entering or leaving a vehicle shall do so on the side nearest the curb. 
(Code 1963, § 15-2) 
Sec. 19-7. - Same-Vehicle for hire, discharging passengers. 
    Passenger vehicles consisting of automobiles, buses, trackless trolleys and any other sort of vehicles conveying passengers for compensation or otherwise shall, before discharging passengers, drive up as near to the curb of the street as possible to allow passengers to alight from such passenger vehicles at or as near the curb of the street as possible and in such area that it will be impossible for any meeting or following vehicles to pass between such passenger vehicle discharging passengers and the curb on the street. 
(Code 1963, § 15-3) 
Sec. 19-8. - Same-Vehicles in motion. 
    No person shall board or alight from any vehicle while such vehicle is in motion, except railway workers in the course of their employment in switching or otherwise operating or controlling cars on rails. 
(Code 1963, § 15-4) 
Sec. 19-9. - Riding on portions of vehicles not intended for passengers. 
    No person shall ride on any portion of any vehicle not designed or intended for the use of passengers. This prohibition shall not apply to an employee engaged in the necessary discharge of a duty, or to persons riding in truck bodies in space intended for merchandise. 
(Code 1963, § 15-6) 
Sec. 19-10. - Depositing harmful materials on streets. 
(a)  No person shall throw or deposit upon any street or highway any glass bottle, glass, nails, tacks, wire, cans, rubbish, garbage, trash or other dangerous or unsightly material which is likely to injure any person or animal or damage any vehicle upon such street or highway. 
(b)  Any person who drops or permits to be dropped or thrown upon any street or highway any destructive or harmful material shall immediately remove the same or cause it to be removed. 
(c)  Any person removing a wrecked or damaged vehicle from a street or highway shall remove any glass or other injurious substance dropped upon the street or highway from such vehicle. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or cause to be operated upon any public street in the city any truck, wagon, or other vehicle, in and upon which sand, dirt, rocks, cement, garbage, trash, waste materials, or other debris or other materials, is transported unless such vehicle shall be equipped with a cover or other device that will prevent such sand, dirt, rocks, cement, garbage, trash, waste materials, or other debris or other materials, from falling from the vehicle onto the streets of the city. 
(Code 1963, § 15-15) 
Cross reference- Littering, § 8-5 et seq. 
State Law reference- Removal after accident, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-277. 
Sec. 19-11. - Shrubbery, or other hazards at street corners; duty of property owner. 
    It shall be the duty of every property owner to keep weeds on his respective lot, as well as shrubbery thereon, in such condition so as not to create a traffic hazard at street corners. Shrubbery, vines, trees or other objects which would obstruct the view of a person passing a street corner or street intersection shall be kept in such condition as not to obstruct the view of motorists using the streets. 
(Ord. No. 94-15, § 1, 12-5-94) 
Secs. 19-12-19-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES 

Sec. 19-20. - Responsibility for operation of vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or any other person employing or otherwise directing the driver of any vehicle, to require or knowingly permit the operation of such vehicle upon a street or highway in any manner contrary to this chapter. 
(Code 1963, § 15-29) 
Sec. 19-21. - Towing another vehicle. 
    No vehicle shall pull more than one (1) other vehicle, and the connection between vehicles shall not exceed sixteen (16) feet. 
(Code 1963, § 15-92) 
Sec. 19-22. - Improperly loaded vehicles. 
    No driver shall operate a vehicle which is overloaded, or which is loaded in such manner that articles or freight thereon are likely to fall therefrom, or which is so loaded that the brakes of such vehicle will not stop same immediately when properly applied, upon any streets in the city. 
(Code 1963, § 15-7) 
Sec. 19-23. - Metal tires and cleats; permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle, the gross weight of which is in excess of one (1) ton, over or on any paved or hardsurfaced street or way within the city when such vehicle has iron or metal tire or cleats on the wheels thereof which come in contact with the surface of the street or way, unless the operator of such vehicle has obtained and has in such operator's possession and on such operator's person, a written permit from the chief of police. This section shall not apply in case such tires and cleats are covered with wood, rubber or similar substances, so that the tires and cleats do not come in contact with the surface of the streets or ways. Neither shall this section apply to snow chains used for safety purposes in the event of a snowfall or icing of roads. 
(Code 1963, § 15-180; Ord. No. 2005-12, § 1, 5-16-05) 
Sec. 19-24. - Truck routes-Compliance. 
    The driver of a motor truck of a tractor-trailer type or of a weight of two and one-half (21/2) tons or more shall not drive said vehicle on any of the streets in the city other than those streets designated in section 19-25 as truck routes; provided however, that this section shall not apply to transit trucks engaged in delivery of personal property to customers at specific locations within the city. 
(Code 1963, § 15-17) 
Cross reference- Parking of trucks, § 19-56 et seq. 
Sec. 19-25. - Designated truck routes. 
    The following streets in and through the city are designated as truck routes: 
(1)  Interstate 85: Beginning at the east city limits on Interstate 85 and continuing in a southwesterly direction to the west city limits. 
(2)  Interstate 285: Beginning at its intersection with the east city limits at State Route 139 (Riverdale Road) and continuing in a westerly direction to the west city limits on interstate 285. 
(3)  U.S. Highway 29: Beginning at the north city limits on U.S. Highway 29 and continuing on said highway to the southernmost city limits on U.S. Highway 29. 
(4)  State Route 139 (Riverdale Road): Beginning at the intersection of the eastern city limits and Riverdale Road and continuing north on Riverdale Road to its intersection with the Global Gateway Connector. 
(5)  State Route 279: Beginning at its intersection with U.S. Highway 29 and continuing south to Old Bill Cook Road. 
(6)  State Route 314 (West Fayetteville Road): Beginning at the intersection of Riverdale Road and West Fayetteville Road and continuing on West Fayetteville Road to the south city limits at Phoenix Parkway. 
(7)  Camp Creek Parkway: Beginning at the west city limits on Camp Creek Parkway and continuing on said street to its intersection with Interstate 85. 
(8)  Edison Drive: Beginning at the intersection of West Point and Edison Drive and continuing south on Edison Drive to Sullivan Road. 
(9)  Embassy Drive: Beginning at the intersection of Edison Drive and Embassy Drive and continuing on Embassy Drive to Riverdale Road. 
(10)  Howell Slade Circle: Beginning at the intersection of Virginia Avenue and Howell Slade Circle and continuing in a northeast direction to the intersection of Howell Slade Circle and Main Street. 
(11)  Massachusetts Boulevard: Beginning at the intersection of Sullivan Road and continuing on Massachusetts Boulevard to its terminus. 
(12)  Sullivan Road: Beginning at the east city limits on Sullivan Road and continuing west on Sullivan Road to west city limits at Rock Hill Road. 
(13)  Virginia Avenue: Beginning at the intersection of the east city limits and continuing on Virginia Avenue in a westerly direction to the intersection of Howell Slade Circle and Virginia Avenue. 
(14)  West Point Avenue: Beginning at Sullivan Road and continuing in a northeasterly direction to the intersection of Lesley Drive and West Point Avenue. 
(15)  Wickersham Drive: Beginning at the intersection of West Point Avenue and Wickersham Drive and continuing on Wickersham Drive to dead end. 
(16)  Best Road: Beginning at the intersection of Sullivan Road and Best Road and continuing north on Best Road to West Point Avenue. 
(17)  Godby Road: Beginning at the intersection of Godby Road and Charbett Drive and continuing east on Godby Road to West Fayetteville Road. 
(18)  Southampton Road: Beginning at the south city limits on Southampton Road and continuing east on Southampton Road to West Fayetteville Road. 
(19)  Global Gateway Connector: Beginning at the intersection of Global Gateway Connector and State Route 139 (Riverdale Road) and continuing north on Global Gateway Connector to its intersection with Camp Creek Parkway. 
(20)  Lesley Drive: Beginning at the intersection of Lesley Drive and West Point Avenue and continuing on Lesley Drive to its intersection with U.S. Highway 29. 
(21)  Georgia State Route Spur 14: Beginning at its junction with Interstate 285 continuing to the western city limits on Spur 14 to U.S. Highway 29. 
(22)  Buffington Road: Beginning at the intersection of Buffington Road and U.S. Highway 29 and continuing south on Buffington Road to the south city limits. 
(23)  Naturally Fresh Boulevard: Beginning at the intersection of Naturally Fresh Boulevard and Buffington Road and continuing on Naturally Fresh Boulevard to its terminus. 
(24)  Riverdale Road Connector: Beginning at its intersection with U.S. Highway 29 and continuing north on Riverdale Road Connector to Global Gateway Connector. 
(25)  T. Owen Smith Connector: Beginning at its intersection with Riverdale Road and continuing on T. Owen Smith Connector to Best Road. 
(26)  Herschel Road: Beginning at the intersection of Herschel Road at its intersection with U.S. Highway 29 and continuing north on Herschel Road to its intersection with Old National Highway. 
(Code 1963, § 15-18; Ord. No. 97-14, § 1, 5-5-97; Ord. No. 2005-12, § 2, 5-16-05; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 9-5-17) 
Sec. 19-25.1. - Commercial motor vehicles regulated on portions of Herschel Road and Riverdale Road. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful, except as otherwise provided in section 19-25, for any person to operate any commercial motor vehicle on the following portions of Herschel Road and Riverdale Road: 
(1)  Herschel Road: Beginning at the north city limits on Herschel Road and continuing south on Herschel Road to its intersection with Old National Highway. 
(2)  Riverdale Road: Beginning at Riverdale Road's intersection with Global Gateway Connector/Riverdale Road Connector and continuing west on Riverdale Road to its intersection with Herschel Road. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, the term "commercial motor vehicle" shall mean any vehicle that: 
(1)  Transports, for a fee or as part of the fee for some other service, people from one location to another; or 
(2)  Transports goods to a purchaser, lessee or distributor. 
(c)  Except as provided in subsections (d) and (e) below, and except for vehicles described in subsection (b) (1) that are capable of transporting more than eight (8) people, subsection (a) of this section shall not apply to the operation of commercial motor vehicles: 
(1)  Making deliveries of people or property to areas, homes, or businesses accessible only by routes including the roads described in subsection (a); or 
(2)  By the owner or operator of such vehicle while on his or her way to his or her residence, 
so long as such operation does not constitute a violation of any provision of Chapter 19, Article III of the City Code. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful to park or stand any commercial motor vehicle except authorized emergency vehicles and except as provided by subsection (c)(1) on any street or road described in subsection (a) for a period longer than one-half (1/2) hour. This subsection does not authorize parking of vehicles described in subsection (b)(1) that are capable of transporting more than eight (8) people. 
(e)  No commercial motor vehicle may be parked for overnight or weekend storage on any street or road described in subsection (a), except as provided by subsection (c)(1). The term "storage" shall not include short-term loading or unloading of such vehicles during daylight hours or otherwise in accordance with normally accepted commercial practices. Daylight hours shall mean the period between thirty (30) minutes after dawn and thirty (30) minutes after sunset. This subsection shall not apply to privately owned recreational vehicles which may be parked at a person's own residence. However, such vehicles must also comply with the other provisions of this Code as well as any neighborhood covenants and restrictions. Additionally, this subsection does not authorize parking of vehicles described in subsection (b)(1) that are capable of transporting more than eight (8) people. 
(Ord. No. 2000-38, § 1, 12-4-00; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 2, 9-5-17) 
Sec. 19-26. - Speed limits-City-wide. 
(a)  Thirty (30) miles per hour shall be the maximum speed limit throughout the city, except in the following instances when the maximum speed limits shall be as indicated: 
(1)  On streets, adjoining school property, and within the school block or zone, during school days, twenty-five (25) miles per hour. 
(2)  In parks and public playgrounds, fifteen (15) miles per hour. 
(b)  Zones for speeds in excess of, or less than, thirty (30) miles per hour, may be created by order of the proper authority, and shall be clearly marked with signs. 
(Code 1963, § 15-76; Ord. No. 94-3, § 1, 8-1-94) 
State Law reference- Maximum limits, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-181.

SIGNS TO BE ERECTED BY THE CITY OF COLLEGE PARK. 
(Ord. No. 90-24, 12-17-90; Ord. No. 94-3, § 1, 8-1-94; Ord. No. 97-24, § 2, 11-3-97; Ord. No. 98-01, § 2, 1-5-98; Ord. No. 2006-03, § 1, 2-6-06; Ord. No. 06-32, § 3, 10-2-06; Ord. No. 2007-08, § 1, 5-7-07; Ord. No. 2018-03, § 1, 6-4-18) 
Note- See editor's note to § 19-27. 
Sec. 19-28. - Same-Railroad trains. 
(a)  The following speed limit is hereby established for the operation of any locomotive or railroad train within the city: From the north city limits line to the south city limits line, the maximum speed limit shall be forty (40) miles per hour. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful and shall constitute an offense for any person to operate a railroad train or locomotive within the city at a speed greater than established in this section. 
(Code 1963, § 16-30.1) 
Sec. 19-29. - Bicycles; speed, passing pedestrian. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to ride a bicycle on any sidewalk in the city. 
(Code 1963, § 15-12) 
Cross reference- Parking bicycles, § 19-51. 
Sec. 19-30. - Driving through processions. 
    No driver of a vehicle, except an emergency vehicle in an emergency, shall drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral or other authorized procession. 
(Code 1963, § 15-90) 
Sec. 19-31. - Driving on areas not intended for vehicular traffic. 
    It shall be unlawful for any motor vehicle to be driven on any sidewalk, square or other public or private paved places other than roads, streets, alleys and drives constructed for the use of vehicular traffic. 
(Code 1963, § 15-91) 
State Law reference- Driving on sidewalk, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-241. 
Sec. 19-32. - One-way streets designated. 
    The following streets are hereby designated as one-way streets, with traffic to proceed only in the direction indicated, at all times: 
Adams Street from Cambridge Avenue to Hardin Avenue. 
Driveway in Richard D. Zupp Park, in a southerly direction. 
Parking lane behind City Hall, from the westerly access to the parking lane from Auditorium Way, in a southerly direction to Princeton Avenue. 
Parking lane in front of the library, from the northerly access to the parking lane from Auditorium Way, in a northerly direction to Auditorium Way. 
(Code 1963, § 15-93; Ord. No. 2005-07, § 2, 5-2-05; Ord. No. 2005-12, § 2, 5-16-05) 
Sec. 19-33. - Damaging streets. 
    No vehicle shall be operated in such a manner as to damage the streets. 
(Code 1963, § 15-104) 
Cross reference- Damaging street lights, § 12-20. 
Sec. 19-34. - Railroad grade crossings-Blocking by train. 
    It shall be unlawful for a railroad train, engine or car to be stopped so as to block a railroad crossing for more than five (5) minutes. 
(Code 1963, § 15-105) 
Sec. 19-35. - Vehicles discharging passengers. 
    When any passenger vehicle is discharging passengers, other vehicles following such passenger vehicles or meeting the same may pass such vehicles discharging passengers only on the left side of such passenger vehicle discharging passengers; and shall pass the passenger vehicle discharging passengers at such moderate and reasonable speed that the driver of such passenger vehicle may stop the same immediately in the event any passenger discharged from such passenger vehicle discharging passengers attempts to go around such passenger vehicle to the opposite side of the street by going around the front of such passenger vehicle discharging such passenger, or by going around behind such passenger vehicle in which such passenger has been riding, so that in no event will any person discharged from any passenger vehicle be negligently run down, run over or injured by any other vehicle passing, approaching or following the vehicle discharging such passengers. 
(Code 1963, § 15-118) 
Sec. 19-36. - Crossing "blind" intersections. 
    No driver shall attempt to cross any road, street or railroad crossing if there is no "stop" sign, traffic signal or police officer to regulate traffic at such location and if it is what is commonly called a "blind" intersection or crossing, without first ringing a bell, blowing a horn or giving some other signal or warning of such person's intention to cross such intersection. 
(Code 1963, § 15-129) 
Sec. 19-37. - "Stop" signs; erection, construction, location. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police to place and maintain a suitable stop sign or traffic signal at each street intersecting a through street, and at any street designated by ordinance as a vehicular stop, which sign or signal may be placed in or over the street or on a suitable post or support firmly fixed in the ground on the side of the street on which the vehicle required to stop is traveling. 
(Code 1963, § 15-55(a))

Sec. 19-40. - "No right turn on red" intersection designated. 
    The following intersections shall be designated as "no right turn on red" intersections, and vehicles thereon shall stop on the red signal and shall not make a right turn until such time as the traffic signal shall change to green or driver shall have been directed to turn by a law enforcement agent: 
Harvard Avenue at Main Street-Vehicles traveling West on Harvard wishing to turn north on Main. 
(Code 1963, § 15-132) 
Sec. 19-41. - "No left turn" intersection designated. 
    The following intersections shall be designated as no left turn intersections, and no vehicle may turn or attempt to turn left from the following intersections, unless the driver shall have been directed to turn by a law enforcement agent: 
School property and Jackson Street. Vehicles leaving the parking lot of the school property and wishing to turn south onto Jackson Street. 
Richway and Old National Highway. Vehicles leaving the business premises of Richway, Inc. wishing to turn north onto Old National Highway. 
(Code 1963, § 15-133; Ord. No. 2003-34, § 2, 10-20-03) 
Sec. 19-42. - Television in vehicle. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate a television set in a vehicle so that the picture is in the view of the driver while the vehicle is in motion. 
(Code 1963, § 15-9) 
Sec. 19-43. - Permit for vehicles with excess width or height-Required. 
    No vehicle shall travel over the streets or highways within the city transporting or towing a mobile home, modular home, sectional house, house, heavy equipment, or other load in excess of two hundred forty (240) inches in width or two hundred sixteen (216) inches in height or such width that said vehicle can not yield the right-of-way to all approaching vehicles so that one-half (1/2) of the street or highway shall be available to vehicles approaching and passing from the opposite direction, without first obtaining a permit from the city for the movement and escort of said vehicles within the city. 
(Code 1963, § 15-19; Ord. No. 85-9, 5-29-85) 
Sec. 19-44. - Same-Application. 
(a)  Each person desiring to move or transport any vehicle or load upon the streets or highways within the city in excess of the maximum width or height as set forth in section 19-43 shall make application with the city. The application shall provide the following: 
(1)  Full name and address of applicant. 
(2)  Name, address and title of person making application. 
(3)  Date and time move is to be made. 
(4)  Height of load. 
(5)  Width of load. 
(6)  Route of movement within city. 
(7)  Type and identification of moving vehicle. 
(8)  Support services provided by applicant. 
(9)  Copy of liability insurance policy. 
(10)  Copy of permit issued by the state department of transportation as required by Official Code of Georgia Annotated, section 32-6-28. 
(11)  Agreement to reimburse the city for any expense as set forth in section 19-45. 
(b)  For safety reasons the city may require a different time or route than submitted in the application. 
(Code 1963, § 15-20; Ord. No. 85-9, 5-29-85) 
Sec. 19-45. - Same-Fees. 
    A permit fee based upon the actual cost to the city for the use of city vehicles and equipment and personnel for escort of the overwidth or overheight vehicle within this city shall be as follows: 
(1)  Police escort; vehicles and officers as needed to protect motoring public, up to and including three (3) uniformed officers and police autos and motorcycles. 
(a)  Loaded vehicle moving through city from city limit to city limit ..... $280.00 
(b)  Vehicle loaded within city and moving from within city to city limit ..... $410.00 
(2)  Inspection department administrative cost to issue permit; coordinate escort with police department and with adjacent jurisdictions; inspections and reports of damage to public and private property, including secretarial and building inspector time with vehicle use. 
(a)  Loaded vehicle moving through city from city limit to city limit ..... $ 47.50 
(b)  Vehicle loaded within city and moving within city to city limit ..... $ 91.25 
(3)  Vehicles or loads in excess of two hundred forty (240) inches in width often exceed the passable area in a street requiring the displacement or removal of utility guy wires; street signs; street markers; traffic signs or other utility devices and in excess of the standard minimum height of electric wires and traffic signals requiring the removal; displacement; malalignment or other damage. Each mover shall reimburse the city any expense incurred as a result of moving the excess width or height load. Failure to pay for such expense shall be just cause to deny any future permit. 
(Code 1963, § 15-21; Ord. No. 85-9, 5-29-85) 
Sec. 19-46. - Same-Violation; penalty. 
    Any person moving or transporting any vehicle or load upon the streets or highway within the city in excess of the maximum width or height as set forth in section 19-43 without first obtaining a permit and payment of the expense to the city to provide protection to the motoring public shall be in violation of the ordinances of the city and may be fined or punished as the court deems proper. 
(Code 1963, § 15-22; Ord. No. 85-9, 5-29-85) 
Sec. 19-47. - Left turns to street parking prohibited. 
    No vehicle shall cause or attempt to cause any vehicle to turn left into street parking on Main Street between Hawthorne Avenue and Yale Avenue, unless so directed by a law enforcement agent. "Street parking" is defined as the public parking adjoining the roadway. 
(Ord. No. 95-5, § 1, 8-7-95; Ord. No. 2016-05, § 1, 2-15-16) 
Sec. 19-48. - "One-way" streets designated. 
    The following streets are hereby designated as one-way streets: 
Adams Street. One-way going south from Cambridge Avenue to Hardin Avenue. 
(Ord. No. 2003-34, § 3, 10-20-03) 
Sec. 19-49. - Right turns by certain large vehicles prohibited. 
    No vehicle in excess of one hundred twenty (120) inches in height shall turn or attempt to turn right onto Main Street, northbound, from Harvard Avenue without first obtaining a permit from the city for such movement and escort of said vehicle, unless the driver is directed to make such turn by a law enforcement agent. 
(Ord. No. 06-18, § 1, 4-3-06) 
ARTICLE III. - STANDING AND PARKING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Off-street parking requirements, App. A, Art. XI-C; taxicab parking permit, § 20-23. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to regulate parking, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371. 

Sec. 19-50. - Illegal parking; enforcement of regulations. 
(a)  Notification of owner or operator. When it is impossible or impracticable to serve the owner or operator or person in charge of any vehicle illegally parked within the city personally with a copy of charges, a notice shall be attached to the windshield, in such manner as is most likely to attract the attention of the operator or person in charge of such vehicle when such driver returns to such vehicle. 
(b)  Removal of notice. It shall be unlawful to remove any notice described in subsection (a) attached to any illegally parked vehicle unless and until the offender shall have reported to the police department in accordance with such notice. 
(c)  Removal of vehicle. It shall be unlawful for any person to remove any illegally parked vehicle from the place where the same was illegally parked, except to report to the police station in compliance with such notice. 
(d)  Impounding authorized. Whenever any vehicle shall be found parked in violation of this chapter or any city ordinance, it is subject to be impounded by the police department. 
(e)  Liability of owner. The owner shall be equally liable with the operator for parking violations. 
(Code 1963, § 15-136) 
Cross reference- Administration, enforcement of traffic regulations, § 19-3 et seq. 
State Law reference- Removal of illegally stopped vehicles regulated, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-206; uniform traffic citation forms, § 40-13-1. 
Sec. 19-51. - Parking bicycles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park a bicycle upon a street other than upon the roadway against the curb, or upon the sidewalk in a rack to support it, or against a building. 
(Code 1963, § 15-141) 
Sec. 19-52. - Parking for washing, repairing, advertising. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle upon any street for the purpose of washing, greasing or repairing the same or for the purpose of displaying advertising. 
(Code 1963, § 15-142) 
Sec. 19-53. - Vehicles parked at least five days; vehicles parked which pose a threat to public health or safety; impounding, redemption. 
(a)  Any vehicle parked for a period of at lease five (5) days on a public street, road, highway, right-of-way, or other public property shall be presumed to be abandoned and may be impounded by the police department. Any vehicle impounded by the police department by reason of a presumption of abandonment on account of parking such vehicle for a period of at least five (5) days may be redeemed by the owner or the owner's agent by paying towing and storing charges therefor. 
(b)  Any vehicle parked on a public street, road, highway, right-of-way, or other public property may be impounded immediately by the police department when such vehicle poses a threat to public health or safety, or to mitigate congestion. Any vehicle impounded by the police department by reason of a threat to public health or safety, or to mitigate congestion may be redeemed by the owner or the owner's agent by paying towing and storing charges therefor. 
(Code 1963, § 15-143; Ord. No. 96-06, § 1, 2-19-96) 
State Law reference- Abandoned vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-1 et seq. 
Sec. 19-54. - Locking parked vehicles. 
    No vehicle shall be parked on any street with the wheel thereof chained or locked, except by its brakes, or so fastened that the vehicle could not be easily moved in case of emergency; otherwise locking a vehicle intended as a safeguard against theft is permissible. 
(Code 1963, § 15-145) 
Sec. 19-55. - Limited or restricted parking areas. 
(a)  Signs required. When the governing body shall determine that parking in any area should be limited or restricted it shall by resolution direct the chief of police to have appropriate signs placed in or so near such area that any ordinarily observant person may readily see such signs, which signs shall clearly indicate the restriction imposed and the area affected by such restriction, but no one parking in such area shall be subject to prosecution until such signs shall have been so placed. Upon adoption of such resolution, it shall be the duty of the chief of police to promptly have such signs prepared and placed. 
(b)  Violation prohibited. It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle in a restricted or limited parking area in violation of parking restrictions or regulations established by resolution of the governing body when such area and the limitation of restriction is clearly indicated by appropriate signs or markings. 
(Code 1963, § 15-146) 
Sec. 19-56. - Parking of trucks-Generally. 
(a)  Regulated generally. No person shall stop, stand or park a truck except while actually engaged in loading or unloading of merchandise. 
(b)  At night. The parking of trucks having a capacity of more than one-half (1/2) ton on any street shall be prohibited for more than one (1) hour between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. at night, unless the truck is in charge of an attendant who is awake during all hours; and such parked truck shall be properly lighted. 
(c)  In the daytime. It shall be unlawful to park trucks in excess of one-half (1/2) ton for more than one (1) hour from 6:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. 
(d)  Residential areas at night. It shall be unlawful to park or stand any truck of a weight in excess of eight thousand (8,000) pounds gross weight or any other freight conveyance of a weight in excess of eight thousand (8,000) pounds gross weight except authorized emergency vehicles on any city street within the residential area of the city between the hours of 7:00 p.m. Eastern Standard Time and 7:00 a.m. Eastern Standard Time for a period longer than one-half (1/2) hour. 
(e)  No commercial vehicle, tractor, tractor-trailer, eighteen-wheeler or bus exceeding eight thousand (8,000) pounds gross weight may be parked for overnight or weekend storage visible to the general public on properties zoned residential or restricted commercial (R-1, R-2, R-3, R-4, R-5, R-A, MF, C-1, C-L, BP). The term "storage" shall not include short-term loading or unloading of such vehicles during daylight hours or otherwise in accordance with normally accepted commercial practices. Daylight hours shall mean the period between thirty (30) minutes after dawn and thirty (30) minutes after sunset. This section shall not apply to privately owned recreational vehicles which may be parked at a person's own residence. However, such vehicles must also comply with the other provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1963, § 15-148; Ord. No. 88-20, §§ 1, 2, 9-6-88; Ord. No. 94-5, § 1, 9-6-94) 
Sec. 19-57. - Same-Refrigerated transport trucks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park any refrigerated transport truck in a filling station, or on a railroad right-of-way, for a longer period than one (1) hour between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. Eastern Standard Time. 
(Code 1963, § 15-149) 
Sec. 19-58. - Parking trucks or buses of certain sizes; driver to be present. 
    It shall be unlawful to park a truck or bus with a body more than eight (8) feet wide or ten (10) feet high without the driver being actually present. 
(Code 1963, § 15-150) 
Sec. 19-59. - Parking trailers. 
    It shall be unlawful to keep or park any trailer, or any mobile home or other manufactured housing on any public street or other public place. 
(Code 1963, § 15-151) 
Cross reference- Parking on private property, § 9-1 et seq. 
Sec. 19-60. - Handicapped parking; enforcement by handicapped persons. 
(a)  The mayor and council may appoint not more than seven (7) persons to enforce the handicapped parking laws of the City of College Park. Each person so appointed shall be a citizen of the United States and of College Park, be of good moral character, and shall not have previously been convicted of a felony. In addition, each such person appointed shall be a handicapped person as defined in O.C.G.A. section 40-6-221(2). 
(b)  Each person appointed pursuant to this Code section shall submit an application to the city, and upon designation by the mayor and council, shall complete such training as directed by the chief of police and shall take and subscribe an oath of office as prescribed by the mayor and council. 
(c)  The application required by subsection (b) above shall include the name and address of the applicant; his citizenship; a statement of qualification as a handicapped person as that term is defined in O.C.G.A. section 40-6-221(2); and shall have attached to such application a two-inch by two-inch photograph of the applicant, together with a complete set of fingerprints. 
(d)  Upon receipt of the application, the chief of police or his designee shall cause a complete and thorough investigation to be made of the applicant's moral, physical and mental qualifications. 
(e)  Any person appointed and sworn as a handicapped parking enforcement officer shall have the power to serve citations for violations or failure to comply with handicapped parking laws of the City of College Park in the same manner as any law enforcement officer of the state or city, subject to the following limitations: 
(1)  No person so appointed shall be deemed a peace officer, nor shall such person be deemed an employee of the state, county or city, nor receive any compensation therefrom. 
(2)  No such appointed person shall be required to complete training as a peace officer. 
(3)  No such appointed person shall have the power or duty to enforce other traffic or criminal laws of the state or the city. 
(4)  No person so appointed shall possess or carry firearms or other weapons for the purpose of enforcing handicapped parking laws. 
(5)  No person so appointed shall be entitled to any indemnification from the state, county or city for any injury or property damage sustained as a result of his enforcement activities. Each such appointed person shall specifically acknowledge that he or she has no rights to any claim of injury or property damage resulting from handicapped enforcement activities. 
(6)  No government agency, department or officer of the state, county or city shall be liable or accountable for any act or omission of any person appointed to issue parking citations under this section. Each such appointed person shall specifically hold harmless the City of College Park, its employees or agents from liability for any such act or omission by such appointed person. 
(7)  No person so appointed shall issue citations involving any space which is not marked with posted signs as required by O.C.G.A. section 40-6-221(2)(A) or (B). 
(f)  No city vehicles shall be provided to or used by persons appointed under this section to enforcement handicapped parking laws. 
(Ord. No. 89-15, § 1, 4-17-89) 
Sec. 19-61. - Parking near sanitary dumpsters. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in front of or along side any sanitary dumpster unit in such a manner as to prevent access to that unit by collector trucks. A vehicle shall be considered parked in violation of this section, if such vehicle is parked in such a manner as to encroach upon painted pavement markings surrounding said dumpster, when "no parking" signs are erected on or adjacent to the dumpster or such words are painted directly on the pavement adjacent to or in front of the dumpster. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, § 1, 2-15-93) 
Sec. 19-62. - Parking across from College Park MARTA Station. 
(a)  No person shall stop or stand a vehicle on the east side of East Main Street across from the College Park MARTA Station unless such vehicle is positioned behind the barrier, such standing is for private noncommercial use, is limited to no more than five (5) minutes duration, and the driver of the vehicle remains in attendance with the vehicle. 
(b)  Taxicabs, limousines or other commercial vehicles shall not utilize the east side of East Main Street across from the College Park MARTA Station for stopping or standing, except within taxicab stands established by either the City of College Park or by MARTA for their use. 
(Ord. No. 93-4, § 1, 4-5-93) 
Sec. 19-63. - Parking or driving on private property after warning or notice not to; obstructing lane or drive through parking area on private property; penalties. 
(a)  No person shall, after having been requested not to do so by a law enforcement officer or an authorized agent of the owner, park or stand an occupied or unoccupied motor vehicle in or repeatedly drive a motor vehicle through or within a parking area located on privately owned property and provided by a merchant, group of merchants, or shopping center or other facility for customers if: 
(1)  The parking area is identified by at least one (1) sign as specified in this paragraph, and if the parking area contains more than one hundred fifty (150) parking spaces then by at least one (1) such sign at each entrance to the parking area, each such sign containing the following information in easy-to-read printing: 
a.  Notice of this code section; 
b.  Identification of the property which is reserved for customers' use only; 
c.  Identification of the merchant, group of merchants, or shopping center or other similar facility providing the parking area; and 
(2)  The motor vehicle is parked, is standing, or is being operated other than for the purpose of: 
a.  Transporting some person to or from the interior of the place of business of a merchant identified by the sign or signs in the parking area or to or from the interior of the shopping center or other facility so identified; 
b.  Making use of a telephone, vending machine, automatic teller machine, or similar facility located in the parking area; 
c.  Meeting the requirements of a situation in which it has unexpectedly become impossible or impractical for the motor vehicle to continue to travel on the public roads; or 
d.  Carrying out an activity for which express permission has been given by the owner of the parking area or an authorized representative of the owner. 
(b)  No person shall park or stand an occupied or unoccupied motor vehicle in a drive or lane which is within or leads to parking area located on private property and provided by a merchant, group of merchants, shopping center, commercial establishment, or other facility for customers where such motor vehicle creates or constitutes a traffic hazard, blocks the use of a fire hydrant, or obstructs or may obstruct the movement of any emergency vehicle. In addition to the penalties set forth in subsections (c) and (d) of this section, any vehicle which is parked in a drive or lane within or leading to a parking area on private property which creates or constitutes a traffic hazard, blocks the use of a fire hydrant, or obstructs or may obstruct the movement of any emergency vehicle may be impounded immediately by the police department. In the event that the vehicle is impounded, the vehicle may be redeemed by the owner or the owner's agent by paying towing and storing charges therefor. 
(c)  Any person who violates subsections (1) or (b) of this section shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine: 
(1)  Not to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first such offense; 
(2)  Not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the second such offense; and 
(3)  Not to exceed one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for the third or subsequent such offense. 
(Ord. No. 94-1, § 1, 7-18-94; Ord. No. 96-06, § 2, 2-19-96) 
Sec. 19-64. - Removal, relocation and storage of vehicles and other trespassing personal property from private real property. 
(a)  Only towing and storage firms issued permits by the Georgia Public Service Commission pursuant to Title 46 of the Official Code of Georgia, having a secure impoundment lot, and licensed by the mayor and city council for the City of College Park shall be permitted to remove vehicles and other trespassing personal property from private real property located within the boundaries of the city, and only in accordance with all applicable Georgia law. 
(b)  The maximum reasonable costs of removal, relocation, and storage of vehicles and other trespassing personal property from private real property located within the boundaries of the city shall be as follows: 
Service Provided       Maximum Allowable Fee Vehicle towing ..... $85.00 Towing of other trespassing personal property .....  85.00 Storage fee per day .....  10.00  
(Ord. No. 99-02, § 1, 1-4-99) 
Secs. 19-65-19-69. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PARADES AND PUBLIC ASSEMBLIES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Driving through procession, § 19-30; picketing, § 12-15; unlawful assembly, § 12-12. 
State Law reference- Operation of motor vehicles in parades, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-7. 

Sec. 19-70. - Permit-Required; definition of parade. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or organization to organize, participate in or conduct any parade, other than a funeral procession, or to cause a congregation of people, on the public streets, sidewalks or other public property or ways of the city unless an application for a permit has been previously filed and a permit therefor has been granted for such person or organization. However, under no circumstances shall more than one (1) permit be issued to the same person or organization in any twelve (12)-month period. "Parade" shall mean any march or procession consisting of people, animals or vehicles, or a combination thereof, except funeral processions, and hereinafter shall include any assemblage of persons, upon any public street, sidewalk or other public property or way which does not comply with normal and usual traffic regulations or controls. 
(Code 1963, §§ 16-5, 16-28(a)) 
Sec. 19-71. - Same-Application. 
    An application for a parade permit shall be filed with the city clerk. Such application shall be in writing, shall be filed at least seven (7) days prior to the proposed parade date and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The names, addresses and telephone numbers of all persons and organizations sponsoring, organizing or conducting the parade; 
(2)  The purpose of the parade; 
(3)  The date and time of the parade; 
(4)  The proposed route of the parade, including its beginning and terminating points, or the proposed fixed locations; 
(5)  The number and type of vehicles, animals, marching units, bands, and floats to be utilized in the parade including a description of any sound amplification equipment to be used; 
(6)  The estimated number of persons to participate in the parade; 
(7)  The maximum length of the parade; and 
(8)  A statement from the person or organization making the application that such person or organization anticipates no unusual problems concerning either police protection or traffic congestion to be experienced as a consequence of the parade, or if such statement cannot be made, the reasons therefor. 
(Code 1963, § 16-28(b)) 
Sec. 19-72. - Same-Investigation of, and report on, applicant. 
    The city clerk shall forward the application to the chief of police who shall investigate the application and make a report to the city manager. The report shall indicate whether the requirements of section 19-71 have been met and shall state the official position of the police department regarding the certification specified in section 19-71(8). If it is the opinion of the chief of police that the parade will require additional personnel above and beyond that number of police officers normally scheduled to be on duty on the date of the proposed parade, such information shall also be included in the report. 
(Code 1963, § 16-28(c)) 
Sec. 19-73. - Same-Issuance; denial. 
    The city manager shall review the report of the chief of police and if all of the requirements specified in this section have been satisfied by the applicant, the city manager shall issue a parade permit, unless such manager finds that: 
(1)  The parade will be of a size or nature that requires the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the city to properly police the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto that allowing the parade would deny reasonable police protection to the city; 
(2)  The parade will interfere with another parade for which a permit has been issued; 
(3)  The information contained in the application is found to be false in any material detail; 
(4)  The purpose of the parade is illegal or in any way prohibited by law; or 
(5)  The applicant refuses to agree to abide by and comply with the conditions of the permit. 
(Code 1963, § 16-28(d)) 
Sec. 19-74. - Same-Notice of denial; appeal. 
(a)  A decision to deny a permit shall be made in writing with all reasons for such denial enumerated and explained therein, and shall be issued to the applicant, at the supplied address, with all due promptness. 
(b)  Upon the denial of a parade permit, the applicant may appeal such decision to the governing body within five (5) days of the date of such decision. 
(c)  The governing body shall consider the appeal at its first regularly scheduled meeting which is at least three (3) days from the date of appeal. Upon such an appeal, the governing body may reverse, affirm or modify in any regard the decision to deny the permit. 
(Code 1963, § 16-28(f)) 
Sec. 19-75. - Same-Revocation. 
    Any permit for a parade issued pursuant to this article may be summarily revoked on the day of the parade by the chief of police when by reason of disaster, public calamity, riot or other emergency, the chief of police determines that the safety of the public or property requires such revocation. If a permit is so revoked, the permittee shall be allowed to reapply for a new parade permit. 
(Code 1963, § 16-28(g)) 
Sec. 19-76. - Bond of applicant. 
    If it is the official position of the chief of police that additional personnel shall be required for traffic and pedestrian control, the city manager shall require the applicant to post a bond in an amount deemed by the city manager sufficient for and conditioned on the payment by the applicant of the additional costs incurred by the city for such personnel. 
(Code 1963, § 16-28(e)(13)) 
Sec. 19-77. - Regulations. 
(a)  For the purpose of controlling traffic and pedestrian congestion and of providing for the public health, safety and general welfare, the following regulations shall pertain to all parades conducted within the city: 
(1)  Parades which include speeches, award presentations, or other activities involving the congregation of persons and/or vehicles in a stationary location shall be conducted along that portion of Main Street beginning at West Vesta Avenue and terminating at Princeton Avenue. The parade may be along all or a portion of this area, but, in any event shall terminate at Princeton Avenue. No such speeches, award presentations or other stationary activities shall be made or conducted until the conclusion of the moving portion of the parade, at which time participants, spectators and associated vehicles shall move off of the street and onto public property at the City Hall complex. All speeches, award presentations and other stationary activities shall be accomplished on city property completely off public rights-of-way at such location as designated in the permit. Parades associated with sports or recreation events shall be allowed to continue beyond Princeton Avenue to the recreation facilities at College Street and any such stationary activities shall be conducted on public property completely off the public right-of-way at the recreation center. 
(2)  Parades which do not include speeches, award presentations or other activities involving the congregation of persons and/or vehicles in a stationary location shall be conducted along that portion of Main Street beginning at West Vesta Avenue and terminating at West Yale Avenue. The parade may be along all or a part of this area, but, in any event, shall terminate at West Yale Avenue. 
(3)  Parades shall be conducted only on Saturdays or legal holidays and only between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 11:00 a.m. 
(4)  All parade participants shall assemble for the parade at one location to be designated by the chief of police. 
(5)  No parade participant shall carry arms or other weapons, nor bricks, bats, sticks, rocks, bottles or other items which may be used as weapons. 
(6)  The materials used in the construction of floats in the parade shall be of fire-retardant materials and shall be subject to such requirements concerning fire safety as may be determined by the fire chief. 
(7)  Once commenced, the parade shall not stop along the parade route, but shall continue to move at a fixed rate of speed, and any wilful delay or wilful stopping of said parade, except when reasonably required for the safe and orderly conduct of the parade, shall constitute a violation of the permit. 
(8)  The parade shall strictly follow the route designated in the permit application as submitted to the city. 
(9)  Literature, publications, leaflets or other written material shall not be distributed along the parade route. 
(10)  Speeches shall be allowed only at the conclusion of the parade and at a location designated by the chief of police.
