(11)  Speeches, rallies or other activity to be conducted at the conclusion of the parade shall be limited to a total time of thirty (30) minutes, after which the parade participants shall disperse. 
(12)  In no event shall speeches, rallies, etc., be conducted in the public streets, or along the sidewalks of the city. 
(13)  The permittee shall advise all participants in the parade, either orally or by written notice, of the terms and conditions of the permit, prior to the commencement of the parade, and shall sign an acknowledgment that the permittee has read, understands and will comply with the regulations specified in this article and the conditions of the permit and has advised all participants as so required in this subsection. 
(b)  Any other reasonable regulation or restriction deemed necessary by the city manager for the protection and safety of the parade participants, viewing public, or for the public health, safety and general welfare of the citizens of the city, may be imposed by the city manager. However, such additional regulations or restrictions shall be specified in writing to the applicant with all reasons therefor clearly enumerated. 
(Code 1963, § 16-28(e)(1)-(12), (14), (15); Ord. No. 89-23, § 1, 8-7-89) 
Secs. 19-78, 19-79. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RESIDENTIAL PERMIT PARKING 

Sec. 19-80. - Statement of findings. 
    The mayor and council finds that older residential areas of the city neighboring certain business, commercial, and educational uses have a shortage of parking as a result of minimal lot widths and high concentrations of visitors during certain hours. The result of such problems is that residents of the city have insufficient parking to accommodate their own vehicles. Additionally, in certain areas, as a result of parking congestion, there is insufficient space for movement of emergency vehicles to adequately respond in the event of emergency. The mayor and council find that such situations necessitate an innovative solution which will relieve parking congestion while supporting city neighborhoods. 
(Ord. No. 99-05, § 1, 5-3-99) 
Sec. 19-81. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except when the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Block face means that portion of one (1) side of a street located between an intersecting street and the next occurring side street or between the termination of a street and the first occurring side street. 
    Commuter vehicle means a motor vehicle, parked in a residential area, which is not registered to or operated by a resident of such area. 
    Curb parking space means a 24-foot long section of street, adjacent to the curb or edge of roadway, where a motor vehicle may lawfully park. 
    Residential area means a contiguous or nearly contiguous area containing public roadways which are primarily abutted by residential property and nonbusiness property, such as parks, churches, and schools. 
    Street address means the lot number assigned to a lot of record as shown on the official tax maps of the city. 
(Ord. No. 99-05, § 1, 5-3-99) 
Sec. 19-82. - Program established. 
(a)  There is established a residential permit parking program whereby motor vehicles bearing a special parking permit issued pursuant to this article may be parked in excess of the parking restrictions posted on streets within certain areas known as residential permit parking areas. Parking a motor vehicle on a street within a residential permit parking area shall be: 
(1)  Restricted to a consecutive two-hour period between 8:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. each day; or 
(2)  Prohibited entirely between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. of each day. 
(b)  For the purpose of this article, restrictions established in this article shall be effective seven (7) days per week, including Saturday, Sunday, and holidays, unless the motor vehicle displays a valid parking permit. 
(Ord. No. 99-05, § 1, 5-3-99) 
Sec. 19-83. - Procedure for initiating areas of residential permit parking. 
(a)  (1)  Residents of a residential area who desire to have such area designated as a residential permit parking area shall submit to the chief of police a petition requesting such designation. To warrant consideration, the request must be supported by the signature of one (1) adult resident from seventy (70) per cent or more of the residences within the area, provided only one (1) signature shall be allowed for each street address. Apartment buildings and other multiple family dwellings shall be considered as one (1) residence and shall be limited to one (1) signature, which shall be the signature of the property owner or the signature of a person who is legally authorized to sign on behalf of the owner. 
(2)  The petition shall clearly define the boundaries of the proposed residential permit parking area. 
(3)  The petition shall identify a resident petition coordinator and shall conform in form and content with requirements established by the chief of police. 
(4)  Upon receipt of a petition referred to in this section, the chief of police shall direct such evaluations and studies as needed to determine whether such residential area is eligible for designation as a residential permit parking area. 
(b)  As an alternative to petition request, the mayor and council may designate an area as a residential permit parking area where citizen complaints are of such magnitude and duration that the council determines a need for such an area to exist. Council determination of such a need shall be conclusive. 
(Ord. No. 99-05, § 1, 5-3-99) 
Sec. 19-84. - Eligibility of area for residential permit parking. 
(a)  In establishing the eligibility of a proposed residential permit parking area upon receipt of an application, the chief of police shall consider the following factors: 
(1)  The adequacy of the petition. 
(2)  The residential area proposed for designation as a residential permit parking area shall contain no less than twenty-five (25) single-family street addresses and shall contain no less than one thousand (1,000) linear feet of street frontage measured from the center of adjacent intersections. 
(3)  During the time period of the proposed restrictions, locations are identified where curb parking and space occupancy exceeds seventy-five (75) per cent and commuter vehicles represent at least thirty-three (33) per cent of the parked vehicles. 
(4)  If parking limitations as restrictive as or more restrictive than a two-hour parking limit exist and such limitations have been in place for more than six (6) months with the neighborhood continuing to experience parking shortages, the criteria in subsection (a)(3) of this section will be assumed satisfied. 
(5)  Designation of the area as a residential permit parking area will result in one or more of the following expectations for the area: 
a.  A reduction in commuter vehicles and the accompanying energy waste and air pollution. 
b.  A reduction in traffic congestion and illegal parking. 
c.  An improvement in vehicular and pedestrian safety. 
(b)  Having determined that the requirements for a residential permit parking area are met, the chief of police shall report to the city manager who shall review the chief's determination and place the proposed residential parking area on the agenda of the next council meeting. If approved by the mayor and council, the city manager shall assign an appropriate and unique identification letter to the area and shall notify the petition coordinator that the area has been approved as a residential permit parking area. 
(Ord. No. 99-05, § 1, 5-3-99) 
Sec. 19-85. - Application for permit. 
(a)  The application for a resident parking permit shall be made to the chief of police, or his designee, and shall provide the name of the owner or operator of the motor vehicle to be permitted; the residential address the operator's state driver's license number; the motor vehicle make, model, and license number; and other information requested on the application form. The applicant shall provide proof of residency as required by the city manager. 
(b)  Visitor permits shall require no written application except as provided in sections 19-86 and 19-87; however, the chief of police may require that previously issued and used permits be surrendered prior to replacement. 
(Ord. No. 99-05, § 1, 5-3-99) 
Sec. 19-86. - Issuance of permits. 
    Following approval of a residential permit parking area, the chief of police, or his designee, shall issue resident permits and visitor permits as follows: 
(1)  Each residential permit parking area shall have a unique number and permit expiration date, and permits shall be renewed every two (2) years. A permit shall be issued only to a motor vehicle owner or operator who resides on property fronting on a block face located within the residential permit parking area. Upon application and payment of the applicable fee, resident permits shall be issued in accordance with the following limitations: 
a.  Two (2) residential permits may be issued for each valid street address which consists of one (1) residential structure containing only one (1) dwelling unit. 
b.  One (1) resident permit may be issued for each legally constituted and existing dwelling unit in any two (2) family or multiple family dwelling facility at a valid street address within the residential permit parking area. This includes apartments, condominiums, attached dwellings, row houses, town houses, and the like. 
(2)  Upon request, two (2) visitor permits may be issued without charge to the recipient of a resident permit, and such visitor permits may be renewed or replaced in accordance with procedures established by the chief of police. 
(3)  A resident of a residential permit parking area which is eligible for a resident permit but does not apply for such permit may be issued two (2) visitor permits by making application as provided in subsection (1) of this section and omitting information which is not applicable. No fee shall be charged for such visitor permits. 
(Ord. No. 99-05, § 1, 5-3-99) 
Sec. 19-87. - Permit form and display. 
(a)  The resident parking permit shall be a decal and shall be affixed only to the motor vehicle for which it was issued. The decal shall be permanently attached to the inside lower corner of the rear window, driver's side, and must be clearly visible from outside the vehicle. Information shown on the permit decal shall include but not be limited to the residential permit parking area identification letter, the permit number and the expiration date. 
(b)  The visitor permit shall be a temporary permit designed for use by transient visitors and guests of residents of a residential permit parking area. Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, each visitor permit shall be valid for fifteen (15) days and shall provide all the rights and privileges of a resident permit. The visitor permit shall be of a form and shall be displayed as determined by the chief of police. 
(c)  The chief of police may issue a temporary permit, valid for not more than one (1) year, for a vehicle operated by a person who provides health care services or other essential services on a regular basis at an address within a residential permit parking area. Such temporary permit shall be a visitor permit bearing special validation and which is issued by the chief of police upon satisfactory proof of need presented by the resident at such address. A temporary permit shall not be issued for use by a person who provides services for a commercial activity conducted at a residence. 
(d)  A vehicle bearing a resident permit for one (1) residential permit parking area may display a visitor permit for a different residential permit parking area when the vehicle is in a valid visitor status within the area identified on the visitor permit. 
(Ord. No. 99-05, § 1, 5-3-99) 
Sec. 19-88. - Uniformity of parking regulations. 
    Within each discrete residential permit parking area there shall be uniform parking regulations governing permit parking. Upon approval of a residential permit parking area, the chief of police shall have parking regulation signs installed within the area indicating the time, location, and conditions under which parking in excess of restrictions shall be by permit only. 
(Ord. No. 99-05, § 1, 5-3-99) 
Sec. 19-89. - Adding or removing block faces. 
(a)  All block faces of a discrete residential permit parking area shall have identical parking regulations where parking is allowed, and such regulations shall not be removed or modified on individual interior block faces. 
(b)  The city manager may add or remove block faces along the boundaries of a residential permit parking area upon receipt of a petition in which more than fifty (50) per cent of the residences request such action. The petition shall conform to section 19-83. 
(c)  Eligibility for a block face to be added or removed from a residential permit parking area shall be determined by the city manager, who shall, to the extent possible, avoid approving changes which will create an isolated block face, which is considered as one which: 
(1)  Is not across the street from a residential permit parking area block face for its entire length; or 
(2)  Neither end of the block face is connected to an existing residential permit parking are block face by a continuous curb or edge of roadway. 
(d)  During the initial process of approving a residential permit parking area or as related to the addition or removal of block faces, the city manager may determine the appropriate status for any block face abutting a park or other property which has no street address or which has no resident qualified to sign a related petition. 
(Ord. No. 99-05, § 1, 5-3-99) 
Sec. 19-90. - Termination of parking area. 
    Upon receipt of an appropriate petition signed by a representative of fifty (50) per cent or more of the qualified street addresses, as identified in section 19-83, the city will terminate a residential permit parking area subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The parking regulations which will replace those installed as provided in § 19-88 must be determined on a block-by-block basis by consultations between the affected residents prior to the termination of the residential permit parking area. The final determination shall be made by the city manager. 
(2)  Any street section which has been part of a residential permit parking area and which is subsequently terminated under this section shall be ineligible for inclusion in a future residential permit parking area for a period of twenty-four (24) months after such termination. 
(Ord. No. 99-05, § 1, 5-3-99) 
Sec. 19-91. - Limitations on permit use. 
    A motor vehicle which displays a valid residential permit parking or visitor permit shall be allowed to stand or park in the residential permit parking area for which the permit has been issued without being limited by any restriction established in this article. Such permits shall not authorize a motor vehicle to stand or to park in any place where or during any time when the stopping, standing, or parking of a motor vehicle is prohibited or the area is designated for other uses. 
(Ord. No. 99-05, § 1, 5-3-99) 
Sec. 19-92. - Penalties for violations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for a person to furnish false information in an application for any permit authorized by this article or to represent falsely that such person is eligible for such permit. 
(b)  A person holding a valid parking permit issued pursuant to this article shall not allow the use or display of such permit on a vehicle other than that for which the permit was issued. Such conduct shall be unlawful and a violation of this article both by the person holding the valid permit and the person who so uses or displays the permit improperly. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for a person to produce or display a facsimile or counterfeit parking permit in order to evade parking restrictions in a residential permit parking area. 
(d)  Violation of any provision of this article shall constitute an offense and shall be punishable as provided under section 1-8. 
(Ord. No. 99-05, § 1, 5-3-99) 
ARTICLE VI. - STREET ACCESS CONTROL 

Sec. 19-93. - Scope, purpose of regulation. 
    In order to promote the safety of the motorist, cyclist and pedestrian, to minimize the traffic congestion and conflict by reducing the points of contact, and to promote the general welfare by preserving the traffic capacity of major streets and thoroughfares as designated on the College Park Thoroughfare Map the following regulations shall apply: 
(1)  All street access shall meet the following criteria: 
a.  No access to major streets from lots that abut secondary or minor streets shall be permitted. 
b.  Access shall be defined by paving, use of curbs or other means as approved by the city engineer. 
c.  No curb or right-of-way shall be cut, paved, established or otherwise altered until a scaled drawing, indicating the method of compliance with these "street access control" requirements, has been submitted to and approved by the city engineer; and further provided that no curb cut or driveway shall be established unless approval in writing for such curb cut or driveway has been obtained from the city engineer. 
(2)  All single family and two-family uses: 
a.  Access shall be limited to one (1) driveway for each lot; the city engineer may approve one (1) additional driveway upon a finding that such driveway will not cause a traffic hazard, that the design of such driveway complies with sound engineering practice and that surrounding properties will not be adversely impacted. Individual driveways shall not exceed ten (10) feet in width, measured at the right-of-way. 
b.  No driveway shall be established within ten (10) feet of the points of tangency of the curve connecting such driveway to a public street and any property line of adjacent private property. Measurements shall be made along the edge of pavement from the nearest point of tangency. 
c.  For corner lots, no driveway shall be established within ten (10) feet of the points of tangency of the curve connecting such driveway to a public street and any street which intersects the street which is being accessed. Measurements shall be made along the edge of pavement from the nearest point of tangency. 
(3)  All uses other than single family and two-family uses: 
a.  No access to major streets from lots that abut secondary or minor roads shall be permitted except as allowed by the city engineer in accordance with the further provisions of this article. 
b.  Access shall be limited to one (1) curb cut per street frontage on any lot containing less than one hundred forty (140) feet of frontage on the street being accessed, and no more than two (2) curb cuts per street frontage on any lot containing more than one hundred forty (140) feet and less than five hundred (500) feet of frontage on the street being accessed. Properties containing from five hundred (500) feet of street frontage to one thousand (1,000) feet of street frontage on any one street shall be permitted three (3) accesses and one (1) additional access for each additional five hundred (500) feet of frontage on that same street. 
c.  Such access way shall not exceed eighty (80) feet in width, measured at the edge of pavement. The established access width at the edge of pavement shall be gradually reduced (by equivalent radii or tapers) so as not to exceed thirty (30) feet at the right-of-way. This established thirty (30) feet or less access width shall be maintained for a distance of at least five (5) feet inside and parallel to the front (or side) property line. All such access should intersect the roadway at ninety (90) degrees. 
d.  However, whenever circumstances exist such that this is not practical or desirable, the city engineer may permit the intersection to occur at any angle of not less than forty-five (45) degrees, with compatible radii or tapers. 
e.  No curb cut shall be established within ten (10) feet of the intersection of a straight line projecting from any side (or rear) lot line and the right-of-way; and no two (2) curb cuts shall be established less than forty (40) feet apart. 
f.  Office uses shall have a minimum of two and nine-tenths (2.9) off street parking spaces per one thousand (1000) square feet of gross floor area. 
g.  Retail, hospitality, and hospitality malls uses shall have a minimum of four and five-tenths (4.5) off-street parking spaces per one thousand (1,000) square feet of gross floor area. 
h.  Off-site parking and or shared parking arrangements may be approved by the city provided such space is within four hundred (400) feet from the property line. Such off-site parking or shared parking will be measured along the nearest pedestrian walkway and must link directly to a sidewalk leading to the main entrances of all buildings on the site. Any space used to comply with this section may not include more than twenty-five (25) percent of the space used to comply with the minimum requirement for the lot from which the space is used. Any entity that utilizes parking spaces pursuant to this provision must provide a copy of such shared agreement to the city. 
i.  For any parking lot that exceeds fifty (50) spaces, at least thirty (30) percent shall be configured with the minimum dimensions authorized to allow compact cars. 
(Ord. No. 2001-36, § 2, 10-1-01; Ord. No. 2014-04, § 2, 2-3-14; Ord. No. 2015-03, § 2, 3-16-15) 
Sec. 19-94. - Major streets and thoroughfares. 
    Major streets and thoroughfares designated on the Thoroughfare Plan, City of College Park, 1996, dated December 16, 1996, and adopted by the mayor and council on the 16th day of December 1996, as now or hereafter amended. A copy of said plan shall be maintained on file in the office of the city clerk, where it shall be available for public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 2001-36, § 2, 10-1-01) 
Sec. 19-95. - Appeals. 
(a)  The city engineer is hereby designated as the enforcement authority for this section and is charged with making interpretations and decisions based upon those statutes within the jurisdiction of College Park. 
(b)  Appeals from any decision of the city engineer may be taken to the construction board of adjustment and appeals as are taken from other standard technical codes. 
(Ord. No. 2001-36, § 2, 10-1-01) 
Sec. 19-96-19-99. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - DOWNTOWN PARKING DISTRICT 

Sec. 19-100. - Establishment of Downtown Parking District and regulations. 
(a)  There is established a downtown parking permit program whereby motor vehicles bearing a special parking permit issued pursuant to this article may be parked in excess of the parking restrictions posted on parking lots within that certain area known as the Downtown Parking District, as defined in section 19-101 herein. 
(b)  Parking of motor vehicles not displaying the permit provided for in section 19-100(a) on parking lots within the Downtown Parking District shall be restricted to the posted time limits, which posted limits shall be established by a resolution of the city council. 
(c)  For the purpose of this article, restrictions established herein shall be effective Monday through Friday, unless the motor vehicle displays a valid parking permit. Restrictions established in this article shall not be effective on Saturday, Sunday or holidays. 
(Ord. No. 2007-32, § 1, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 19-101. - Definition of downtown parking district. 
(a)  For purposes of this article, the Downtown Parking District shall be that area bordered on the west by Conley Street (including Conley Street), bordered on the east by Main Street (including Main Street), bordered on the north by Vesta Avenue (including Vesta Avenue) and bordered on the south by Yale Avenue (including Yale Avenue). 
(Ord. No. 2007-32, § 1, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 19-102 - Downtown parking permits. 
(a)  Any licensed business operating or located within the Downtown Parking District shall be eligible for a number of parking permits equal to the number of employees reported in its yearly occupation tax return and oath. 
(b)  The city manager shall have the authority to issue parking permits to employees of the city as deemed necessary by the needs of the city. 
(c)  An application for a downtown parking permits shall be made to the city clerk, or their designee, and shall provide the name of the business; the number of requested permits; and other information requested on the application form. 
(d)  Each downtown parking permit shall have a unique number and permit expiration date, and permits shall be renewed annually by application. 
(e)  A copy of each approved application and records matching unique permit numbers with licensed business shall be provided to the chief of police for use in enforcing this section. 
(Ord. No. 2007-32, § 1, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 19-103. - Uniform load zones with in downtown parking district. 
(a)  No person shall stop, park or stand a truck or other motor vehicle for the purpose of unloading/loading merchandise on Main Street within the Downtown Parking District. 
(b)  The chief of police is authorized to place and maintain signs prohibiting the stopping, parking or standing of trucks within the Downtown Parking District, except for the northern side of the following streets within the Downtown Parking District: 
Harvard Avenue; 
Columbia Avenue; 
John Wesley Avenue; and 
Yale Avenue. 
(c)  In addition to the provisions of this section, all other general truck parking or loading restrictions in this Code shall remain applicable to any person loading or unloading a truck or other motor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2007-32, § 1, 12-17-07) 
Chapter 20 - TAXICAB SERVICES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2016-15, § 1(Exh. A), adopted May 2, 2016, repealed the former Ch. 20, §§ 201-20-18, and enacted a new Ch. 20 as set out herein. The former Ch. 20 pertained to vehicles for hire. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 

Sec. 20-1. - Definitions. 
    The followings words, terms and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this chapter, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Department means the College Park Police Department. 
(2)  Driver means the operator of a taxicab. 
(3)  Fare means that portion of the charge for the hire of a taxicab that is automatically calculated by a taximeter through the operation of the distance or time mechanism. Any fare shall be the maximum fare which may be charged, but which shall not prohibit lower amounts being charged. 
(4)  Open stand means a location designated by the department at which taxicabs may stop and wait for potential passengers in conformance with the provisions of section 20-10. 
(5)  Provider means any person or entity that is authorized, under this chapter, to provide taxicab services and uses a taximeter. 
(6)  Ride share driver means an individual who uses his or her personal passenger car, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1(41), to provide transportation for passengers arranged through a ride share network service. Should the definition of "Ride Share Driver" in this subsection differ from the definition in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-190, the definition in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-190 shall control. 
(7)  Ride share network service means any person or entity that uses a digital network or Internet network to connect passengers to ride share drivers for the purpose of prearranged transportation for hire or for donation. The term "Ride Share Network Service" shall not include any corporate sponsored vanpool or exempt rideshare as such terms are defined in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-100, provided that such corporate sponsored vanpool or exempt rideshare is not operated for the purpose of generating a profit. Should the definition of "Ride Share Network Service" in this subsection differ from the definition in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-190, the definition in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-190 controls. 
(8)  Taxicab means a motor vehicle or similar vehicle, device, machine or conveyance used to transport passengers, uses a taximeter, and is authorized to provide taxicab services pursuant to this chapter. 
(9)  Taxicab services means the act of picking up passengers in the incorporated limits of the city, excluding the limits of the Hartsfield Jackson Atlanta International Airport, and accepting or soliciting any consideration, charge or fee which is determined by agreement, by mileage, by the length of time the vehicle is used or by contract for the use of any taxicab. 
(10)  Taximeter means an instrument or device approved by the department attached to a vehicle and designed to measure mechanically or electronically the distance traveled by such vehicle, to record the times the vehicle travels or is in waiting and to indicate the fare to be charged. Should the definition in this subsection differ from the definition in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-190, the definition in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-190 controls. 
(Ord. No. 2016-15, § 1(Exh. A), 5-2-16) 
Sec. 20-2. - Doing business defined. 
    Any person or entity shall be deemed to be doing business in the city if such person or entity is providing taxicab services in the incorporated limits of the city, excluding the limits of the Hartsfield Jackson Atlanta International Airport. Any person or entity shall also be deemed to be doing business in the city if such person or entity has established a business relationship with independent contractors or provides taxicab services on such person's own behalf. 
(Ord. No. 2016-15, § 1(Exh. A), 5-2-16) 
Sec. 20-3. - Compliance. 
    No person shall conduct the business of providing taxicab services in the city without first meeting the requirements of this chapter and state law. 
(Ord. No. 2016-15, § 1(Exh. A), 5-2-16) 
Sec. 20-4. - Providers responsible for violations by drivers. 
    Providers doing business in the city are responsible for violations of this chapter by their drivers whether such operators are direct employees or independent contractors. 
(Ord. No. 2016-15, § 1(Exh. A), 5-2-16) 
Sec. 20-5 - Regulatory fee. 
    A regulatory fee, in an amount to be determined by the city council from time to time and by resolution, shall be imposed upon providers of taxicab services. 
(Ord. No. 2016-15, § 1(Exh. A), 5-2-16) 
Sec. 20-6. - Inspections of taximeters. 
(a)  The followings words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cleared (as applied to taximeters) means a taximeter is inoperative with respect to all fare indication, when no indication of fare or extras is shown and when all parts are in those positions in which they are designed to be when the vehicle on which the taximeter is installed is not engaged by a passenger. 
    Face (as applied to taximeters) means that side of a taximeter upon which passenger charges are indicated. 
    Multiple-tariff taximeter means a taximeter that may be set to calculate fares at any one of two (2) or more rates. 
    Road test means a distance test, over a measured course, of a complete taximeter assembly when installed on a vehicle, the mechanism being actuated as a result of vehicle travel. 
    Single-tariff taximeter means a taximeter that calculates fares at a single rate only. 
(b)  Effective July 1, 2016, all taxicabs, shall be operated with taximeters, and all such taximeters shall be utilized for every passenger trip. If and when so equipped, the taximeters shall be made available to the passengers thereof at all times, day and night. The taximeter shall conform to the requirements of this section. 
(c)  Taxicabs providing taxicab services shall be subject to two (2) random inspections of taximeters per calendar year. The following will be inspected: 
Taximeter inspection criteria. All taxicabs shall comply with the following at all times, and all random inspections shall be conducted by the department at a designated location and time and shall consist of the following inspection: 
a.  Design of indicating elements. 
i.  Generally. A taximeter shall be equipped with a primary indicating element. 
ii.  Advancement of indicating elements. Except when a taximeter is being cleared, the primary indicating elements shall be susceptible of advancement only by the rotation of the vehicle wheels or by the time mechanism. 
iii.  Visibility of indications. Except when a taximeter is being cleared, indications of fare and extras shall be clearly shown on its face at all times and at least ten (10) millimeter high for the fare and four (4) millimeter high for all other indications. 
iv.  Actuation of fare-indicating mechanism. When a taximeter designed to calculate fares upon the basis of a combination of distance traveled and time elapsed is operative with respect to fare indication, the fare-indicating mechanism shall be actuated by the distance mechanism whenever the vehicle is in motion at such a speed that the rate of distance revenue equals or exceeds the time rate and may be actuated by the time mechanism whenever the vehicle speed is less than this and when the vehicle is not in motion. Means shall be provided for the vehicle operator to render the time mechanism either operative or inoperative with respect to the fare-indicating mechanism. 
b.  Operating condition. 
i.  Generally. Whenever the indicating elements of a taximeter are set to indicate a charge for the hire of the vehicle, the character of the fare indication shall be clearly shown on the taximeter face. When a taximeter is cleared, the indication "not registering," "vacant" or an equivalent expression shall be shown. 
ii.  Single-tariff taximeter. Whenever a single-tariff taximeter is set so as to register charges, the indication "registering," "hired" or an equivalent expression shall be shown on the taximeter face. 
iii.  Multiple-tariff taximeter. Whenever a multiple-tariff taximeter is set so as to register charges, the basis for the particular tariff for which it is set shall be shown on the taximeter face. 
iv.  Extra charges. Extra charges shall be indicated as a separate item and shall not be included in the fare indication. They shall be identified by the term "extras" or by an equivalent expression. Values shall be defined by suitable words or monetary signs. 
v.  Protection of indications. Indications of fare and extras shall be displayed on the taximeter face through and entirely protected by glass or other suitable transparent material securely attached to the housing of the taximeter. 
vi.  Basis of fare calculations. A taximeter shall calculate fares only upon the basis of distance traveled, time elapsed or a combination of distance traveled and time elapsed. 
c.  Design of operating control. 
i.  Means of control. A control lever-arm knob, handle or other convenient and effective means shall be provided to set the taximeter mechanism for the desired operating condition and to clear the taximeter. 
ii.  Positions of control. The several positions of the control lever shall be mechanically defined, and displacement from any of these positions shall be sufficiently obstructed that the accidental or inadvertent changing of the operating condition of the taximeter is improbable. Possible movement of this control to an operating position immediately following its movement to the cleared position shall automatically be delayed enough to permit the taximeter mechanism to come to complete rest in the cleared condition. 
d.  Provision for security seals. Adequate provision shall be made for affixing lead-and-wire seals to a taximeter and to other parts required for service operation of a complete installation on a vehicle so that no adjustments, alterations or replacements affecting in any way the accuracy or indications of the device or the assembly can be made without mutilating the seals. The sealing means shall be such that it is not necessary to disassemble or remove any part of the device or of the vehicle to apply or inspect the seals. 
e.  Distance test methods. To determine compliance with distance tolerances, a distance test of a taximeter shall be conducted utilizing a road test. 
f.  Tolerance values. 
i.  Distance tests. Maintenance and acceptance tolerances for taximeters shall be as follows: 
A.  On overregistration, one percent of the interval under test. 
B.  On underregistration, four percent of the interval under test, with an added tolerance of one hundred (100) feet or thirty (30) miles whenever the initial interval is included in the interval under test. 
ii.  Time tests on individual time intervals. Maintenance and acceptance tolerances on individual time intervals shall be as follows: 
A.  On overregistration, three (3) seconds per minute (five (5) percent). 
B.  On underregistration, nine (9) seconds per minute (fifteen (15) percent) on the initial interval and six (6) seconds per minute (ten (10) percent) on subsequent intervals. 
g.  Time mechanism tests. The time mechanism shall be tested at least through the first five (5) time intervals. 
h.  User requirements. 
i.  Position and illumination of taximeter. When mounted upon a vehicle, a taximeter shall be so located that its face can be seen by a passenger from the rear compartment of the vehicle. Adequate lighting facilities shall be provided for so illuminating the face of the taximeter that the indications thereof may be conveniently read by the passenger, and the face of the taximeter shall be so illuminated whenever the taximeter is in operation and artificial illumination is necessary for the convenient reading of its indications. 
ii.  Statement of rates. The distance and time rates for which a taximeter is adjusted shall be given. 
(d)  The regulatory fee shall encompass the fee(s) for inspections performed under this chapter. 
(e)  Taxicabs will be identified by their vehicle identification numbers (VIN) for purposes of inspections. 
(f)  At least seventy-two (72) hours prior to the date of inspection, the provider will be contacted by the department by certified mail, return receipt requested, at its last known address, and informed that a certain taxicab's inspection is to be performed at a certain date, time and location. Notwithstanding subsection (d) of this section, should such taxicab fail to appear at the designated location at the designated date, time and location, the provider and/or the driver of such taxicab is subject to a no-show fee of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(g)  Should a taxicab fail any inspection, the taxicab shall be subject to random bi-weekly inspections until compliance is achieved. Notwithstanding subsection (d) of this section, the provider and/or driver of such taxicab shall pay a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per bi-weekly inspection under this subsection. 
(h)  Nothing in this article shall prohibit any inspections, in addition to those required under subsection (c) above, of a taxicab based upon the reasonable suspicion of violations under this section by a police officer of the department. Such inspections under this subsection are not subject to a fee. 
(Ord. No. 2016-15, § 1(Exh. A), 5-2-16) 
Sec. 20-7. - Insurance. 
    All providers and drivers shall maintain insurance in the types and amounts required by state law. 
(Ord. No. 2016-15, § 1(Exh. A), 5-2-16) 
Sec. 20-8. - Vehicle condition and equipment. 
    Providers and drivers are responsible for maintaining each taxicab in good working order and adjustment and in a mechanically safe condition, as required by state law. 
(Ord. No. 2016-15, § 1(Exh. A), 5-2-16) 
Sec. 20-9. - Identification of vehicles; display required. 
    Providers and drivers shall ensure that their taxicabs display decals, certificates, license plates, or other forms of identification in accordance with state law. 
(Ord. No. 2016-15, § 1(Exh. A), 5-2-16) 
Sec. 20-10. - Use of open stands. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for a driver to park or otherwise loiter or wait on any public street or right of way or any private property open to the general public for more than five (5) minutes, while said driver remains inside or within ten (10) feet of its taxicab, except at open stands. 
(b)  The department shall maintain a list of all open stands. Open stands shall be created by the department based on the criteria of traffic conditions, public necessity and convenience, and the effect on police functions. 
(c)  No taxicabs shall be placed upon or occupy any open stand except for the purpose of being held forth for hire. Taxicabs shall enter stands on a non-exclusive, first-come first-served basis, only from the rear and shall be moved forward and to the front of the stand immediately as space becomes available by the departure or movement of preceding taxicabs. When an open stand is occupied to its full capacity, no taxicab shall loiter or wait nearby in violation of any traffic laws of the city. A driver occupying an open stand shall not leave his or her taxicab unattended. 
(Ord. No. 2016-15, § 1(Exh. A), 5-2-16) 
Sec. 20-11. - Fare schedule. 
    The city shall set, from time to time and by resolution, maximum fares to be observed by all providers and drivers. However, a provider or driver may charge lower rates. 
(Ord. No. 2016-15, § 1(Exh. A), 5-2-16) 
Sec. 20-12. - Failure, refusal to pay charges. 
    No person shall use a taxicab and refuse to pay therefore the amount accrued on the taximeter. 
(Ord. No. 2016-15, § 1(Exh. A), 5-2-16) 
Sec. 20-13. - Ride share drivers exempt. 
    Ride share drivers are exempt from regulation under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2016-15, § 1(Exh. A), 5-2-16) 
Sec. 20-14. - Vehicle immobilization devices prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place upon any vehicle any vehicle immobilization device, except as specified in subsection (b). 
(b)  This section shall not apply to any person who places upon a vehicle a vehicle immobilization device where such vehicle is owned, leased by or in the lawful possession of that person. 
(c)  For the purposes of this section, the term "vehicle immobilization device" shall mean any mechanical device that is designed or adapted to be attached to a wheel, tire, or other part of a parked motor vehicle so as to prohibit the motor vehicle's usual manner of movement or operation. 
(Ord. No. 2016-15, § 1(Exh. A), 5-2-16) 
Chapter 21 - SECONDHAND GOODS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 21-1. - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known as the "College Park Secondhand Goods Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 2016-7, § 1(Exh. A), 2-15-16) 
Sec. 21-2. - Findings and intent. 
    This chapter is adopted to address the interests of public safety, health and welfare of the community and to aid and assist in the recovery of stolen property, and to aid and assist local law enforcement in fulfilling their public safety functions. 
(Ord. No. 2016-7, § 1(Exh. A), 2-15-16) 
Sec. 21-3. - General policies and purposes. 
(a)  Secondhand dealers, pawnbrokers, precious metals dealers, and secondary metal recyclers may operate only after the issuance of a license or permit for such operation by the city and only in the manner authorized by such license or permit. Transactions by these businesses may only occur through a license or permit holder who complies with the rules and regulations of this chapter and with the licensing, regulatory and revenue requirements of the state. 
(b)  All licenses, permits, and work permit identification cards issued under this chapter are a mere grant or privilege subject to all terms and conditions imposed by this chapter and state law and are subject to being revoked by the city. 
(c)  Each holder shall display the license or permit issued under this chapter prominently at all times at the outlet for which the license or permit is used. A separate license or permit must be issued for each outlet of sale and a separate application must be made for each outlet. 
(Ord. No. 2016-7, § 1(Exh. A), 2-15-16) 
Secs. 21-4-21-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SECONDHAND DEALERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 21-26. - Applicability of article. 
(a)  Secondhand dealer means any individual, corporation, business, partnership or entity who, exclusively or as incidental to or in connection with other business, purchases, sells or acquires in trade or consignment used or secondhand goods, as defined below: 
(1)  Secondhand goods shall include but not be limited to electronics of any kind or description, video games, jewelry of any kind or description, watches and clocks or articles of that kind or description made in whole or in part of gold, silver, platinum or other precious or semiprecious metals; diamonds, emeralds, rubies or other precious or semiprecious stones; pistols or guns; bicycles or bicycle accessories; tools; office equipment; military service medals; or sporting goods, equipment, or accessories, shall, for the purpose of this article, be a secondhand dealer. 
(b)  This article shall not apply to transactions of secondhand goods involving: 
(1)  An organization or entity registered with the state as a non-profit, religious or charitable organization, or any school sponsored association or organization. 
(2)  A trustee in bankruptcy, executor, administrator, or receiver who has presented proof of such status to the secondhand dealer. 
(3)  A sale on the execution, or by virtue of any process issued by a court, if proof thereof has been presented to the secondhand dealer. The secondhand dealer shall keep such proof for two (2) years. 
(4)  Any dealer who sells household personal property as an agent for the property owner or their representative pursuant to a written agreement at that person's residence. 
(5)  Bona fide consignment shops, antique dealers, boutiques dealing in vintage clothing and accessories. 
(6)  Estate sales, yard sales, garage sales, or similar events at which a person desires to sell or trade his or her own personal used goods on his or her premises, said premises not being a regular place of business for the purchase or sale of secondhand items, with not more than three (3) such sales being conducted by the same person or persons upon the same premises within the previous twelve (12) months and each such sale shall not exceed ten (10) consecutive days. 
(7)  Licensed junk dealers or pawnbrokers. 
(c)  Until such time as a multi-jurisdictional operation regulating and monitoring secondhand dealers, pawn brokers, precious metals dealers, secondary metal recyclers, and like dealers is in place, the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority shall be the chief of police or his or her designee. Once a multi-jurisdictional regulatory and monitoring operation is in place, the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority shall mean that multi-jurisdictional operation. 
(Ord. No. 2016-7, § 1(Exh. A), 2-15-16) 
Sec. 21-27. - Construction and interpretation of article. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall be construed as repealing or modifying any section of this Code or other ordinance regulating pawnbrokers and junk dealers. The sections of this article with reference to the acquisition of automobile, truck, motorcycle or other vehicular tires and tubes by purchase, exchange, gift or in any other manner shall apply not only to secondhand dealers as described in section 21-26 but to every person, unless the tires or tubes were acquired from a regularly licensed dealer therein. 
(Ord. No. 2016-7, § 1(Exh. A), 2-15-16) 
Sec. 21-28. - Records required. 
(a)  Engaging in the business of buying or accepting in barter or trade used or previously owned goods within the incorporated areas of College Park is hereby declared to affect the public interest due to the opportunity it affords for the disposal of stolen property. 
(b)  In the public interest and as set forth herein, all secondhand dealers shall maintain records in sequential order by transaction number documenting all secondhand transactions as set forth herein. 
(1)  All secondhand dealers shall document an accurate description of each article of property sold, bartered, or traded to the secondhand dealer. Such description shall include, to the extent possible, the manufacturer, model, serial number, style, material, kind, color, design, number of stones if jewelry, and all other identifying names, marks, and numbers. The secondhand dealer shall assign a sequential transaction number which shall follow the previous transaction number one by one with no numbers skipped or omitted, documenting each transaction, and ensure each item received is tagged with the transaction number. 
(2)  A well-focused, properly exposed, color digital photograph of each article sold, bartered or traded to the secondhand dealer shall be made at the time of acquisition of any article, and of each article's serial number if imprinted on the article, which number shall be clearly visible and readable in the images. If the article was never imprinted with any type of serial number, then the image shall show the entire article. All such digital images shall be labeled with the transaction number and stored in such a manner that they are safe from corruption, readily identifiable, and readily available for review. 
(3)  The tag bearing the transaction number must be created and remain attached to the item until the property is disposed of by sale, trade, or other lawful means. This subsection does not apply to the purchase of property from licensed wholesale or distributor businesses for the purpose of retail sales; however the secondhand dealer shall be required to maintain all purchasing records for property exempted from this subsection. 
(4)  All secondhand dealers shall require all persons selling, bartering, or trading property to show proper identification prior to conducting a secondhand dealer transaction. Proper identification is defined as a government issued photo identification card such as a driver's license, military identification card, state identification card, or passport. 
(5)  All secondhand dealers shall also document the name, address, telephone number, race, sex, height, weight, drivers' license or other government identification number, date of birth, and Social Security Number of the person selling, bartering, or trading the property, along with the date and time of the transaction. This documentation shall be made at the time of the transaction and labeled with the transaction number. 
(6)  All secondhand dealers shall take a well-focused, properly exposed, color digital photograph of the person selling, bartering, or trading the property. The photograph shall clearly show a frontal view of the subject's face along with the broker's ticket transaction number. Digital images shall be labeled with the transaction number and stored in such a manner that they are safe from corruption, readily identifiable, and readily available for review by law enforcement personnel. Such images shall be stored for a minimum period of four (4) years from the date of creation. 
(7)  All secondhand dealers shall obtain from each person selling, bartering, or trading any property, the fingerprint (using an electronic digital fingerprint scanner) of the right hand index finger, unless such finger is missing, in which event the print of the next finger in existence on the right hand shall be obtained with a notation as to the exact finger printed. The fingerprint shall be imprinted onto the transaction form in the designated area along with the signature of the person selling, bartering, or trading the property. The fingerprint must be clear and legible. In the event that more than one transaction form is required, a fingerprint and signature shall be obtained for each form. Fingerprints and the information required herein shall be obtained each time such person sells, barters, or trades any property. 
(8)  Items of property that appear to be new, unused, and in their original packaging cannot be accepted by the secondhand dealer unless the customer can supply a copy of the original sales receipt, or other proof of purchase from the place of purchase, to the secondhand dealer who shall retain the receipt or proof of purchase on file, labeled with the transaction number. 
(9)  All secondhand dealers shall store the above documentation, digital images, and digital fingerprints, which shall comprise the record of each transaction, together by the transaction number and shall maintain said records for a period of four (4) years and make them available to law enforcement personnel upon request. Both a hard copy and an electronic copy of these stored records shall be kept on-site, which must be kept safe from corruption, readily identifiable, and readily available for review, may, if otherwise permitted by law, serve as the permanent record of the secondhand dealer. 
(10)  All secondhand dealers shall enter the complete record of each transaction as it occurs into the electronic automated reporting system via the internet to the administrator of the electronic automated reporting system. The administrator of the electronic automated reporting system will electronically transmit all transactions to the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority. 
(Ord. No. 2016-7, § 1(Exh. A), 2-15-16) 
Sec. 21-29. - Acquiring articles with serial number mutilated or altered. 
    It shall be unlawful for any secondhand dealer to purchase or acquire in barter or trade any electronic device, watch, clock, pistol, gun, automobile tire or battery or any other article commonly branded with a serial number, upon which the number has been mutilated or altered. 
(Ord. No. 2016-7, § 1(Exh. A), 2-15-16) 
Sec. 21-30. - Daily reports to the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority. 
(a)  All secondary dealers shall make a daily report, in such form as may be prescribed by the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority, of all secondary dealer transactions that occurred during the previous twenty-four (24) hours ending at 7:00 p.m. on the date of the report. 
(b)  Daily reports shall include all information as required by section 21-28(b). 
(c)  All secondary dealers shall enter each transaction as it occurs into the designated electronic automated reporting system via the internet to the administrator of the electronic automated reporting system. The administrator of the electronic automated reporting system will electronically transmit all transactions to the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority. 
(d)  In the event that the electronic automated reporting system becomes temporarily or permanently disabled, secondary dealers will be notified as soon as possible. Secondary dealers that incur electronic system failures or other events that would cause partial or complete loss of electronic reporting should notify the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority forthwith with the reason of the failure. In this event, the secondary dealers will be required to make records of transactions on paper forms. A digital camera will be used to collect the required pictures, which are to be transferred to a CD for submittal. The paper forms must include all information as enumerated in section 21-28(b). Secondary dealers shall maintain a minimum three (3) day supply of these paper forms. On a daily basis, all transactions not reported in the electronic automated reporting system will be delivered to the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority by the secondary dealer within two (2) hours of the end of the business day for every day until the disability or event has been corrected. Once the disability or event has been corrected, the secondhand dealer shall input the complete record of all transactions taken on paper forms into the automated reporting system via the internet to the administrator of the electronic automated reporting system. 
(e)  The secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority shall designate the required automated reporting system. There will be a regulatory fee assessed to each secondary dealer for each transaction: said fee shall be an amount of four dollars ($4.00) per transaction. The secondary dealer shall deduct this fee from the amount otherwise due to the seller at the time of the transaction and shall hold this fee in reserve to be paid to the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority on a weekly basis at the close of each business week. The total amount of regulatory fees collected each week shall be paid by the secondhand dealer to the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority at the close of each business week and shall be transmitted electronically or by check as approved by the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority. 
(f)  The amounts paid to the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority as regulatory fees shall be expended first to cover the costs of the automated reporting system, including but not limited to its lease or purchase, installation, maintenance, and updates, then to cover or supplement the costs of regulating and monitoring secondhand dealers, pawn brokers, precious metals dealers, secondary metal recyclers, and like dealers, including but not limited to personnel and administrative costs, and for programs aimed at the reduction of burglary and theft related offenses. 
(Ord. No. 2016-7, § 1(Exh. A), 2-15-16) 
Sec. 21-31. - Examination and inspection of articles by the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority; segregation of suspicious articles. 
    All property purchased or acquired by a secondhand dealer shall at all times be subject to examination and inspection by law enforcement or regulatory inspectors. If, upon the inspection, an officer or inspector shall have reasonable cause to believe that any of the property is stolen, the officer or inspector shall segregate it. It shall thereafter be unlawful for the person in possession of the property to dispose of it or in any manner mutilate, melt or disfigure it, until thirty (30) days have elapsed from the date of the inspection. 
(Ord. No. 2016-7, § 1(Exh. A), 2-15-16) 
Sec. 21-32. - Time period for holding property. 
    All property purchased or acquired by a secondhand dealer shall be held for not less than thirty (30) days. 
(Ord. No. 2016-7, § 1(Exh. A), 2-15-16) 
Sec. 21-33. - Unlawful activities. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any secondhand dealer or any agent or employee of a secondhand dealer who makes acquisitions of secondhand goods to: 
(1)  Fail to make, transmit, and maintain entries in the permanent record as required by section 21-28(b); 
(2)  Make or transmit any false entries therein; 
(3)  Falsify, obliterate, destroy or remove from the place of business such permanent record; 
(4)  Fail to submit daily reports as required in section 21-30; 
(5)  Fail to collect, hold in reserve, and pay any per-transaction regulatory fee as required in section 21-30(e); 
(6)  Refuse to allow a duly authorized law enforcement officer or regulatory inspector to inspect such permanent record or any secondhand goods in such dealer's possession; or 
(7)  Receive secondhand goods of any character or description from any person under 18 years of age. 
(b)  Any person violating subsection (a) of this section, in addition to being subject to license revocation as set forth in section 21-37, shall be guilty of a City Ordinance violation and upon conviction thereof shall be subject to a fine of up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and six (6) months in jail. 
(Ord. No. 2016-7, § 1(Exh. A), 2-15-16) 
Sec. 21-34. - Purchase and sale of used tires or tubes and building glass or plumbing material. 
(a)  Tires or tubes. 
(1)  Report to secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority. All persons who shall acquire by purchase or otherwise any used vehicular tires or tubes from any source other than from a regular licensed dealer shall, within twenty-four (24) hours after the acquisition, make and deliver to the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority, upon a form to be prescribed and furnished by the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority, a report disclosing the name and make of each tire or tube; the size and serial number; and for tires the type or description of the tread or, if the tread is smooth, a statement to that effect. The report shall further contain and disclose the name, address and detailed physical description, together with a legible print of a flat impression of the prints of the four (4) fingers of the right hand of the person or the representative from whom each of the tires or tubes were acquired, stating the manner of acquisition thereof. 
(2)  Retention; segregation; inspection. All persons to whom subsection (a)(1) of this section applies shall not, for a period of fifteen (15) days after the delivery of the report required to be made to the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority covering the acquisition of the tires or tubes, sell or otherwise dispose of any of them except upon written permission from the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority and shall, during that fifteen (15) day period, make and keep accurate and detailed bookkeeping records as to the acquisition of each tire and tube, segregated and tagged so that they may be readily and easily identified from the information describing them upon the report and so that they may be readily and easily examined and inspected by the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority. 
(3)  Acquisition if serial number and/or maker's name is altered, mutilated or defaced. It shall be a violation of this section for any person to acquire, by purchase or otherwise, any used vehicular tire or tube commonly branded with the name of the maker or a serial number, upon which the name of the maker or the serial number has been altered, mutilated or defaced. 
(b)  Building glass or plumbing material. 
(1)  Generally. It shall be unlawful for secondhand dealers to purchase or advance money on glass taken from buildings, such as mantel mirrors, art glass and the like, or copper wire, copper lining of bathtubs, lead pipes or any kind of plumbing material sold as junk where offered for sale by others than persons of known good character. 
(2)  Duties of secondhand dealers. In all cases where these goods are purchased or money advanced, secondhand dealers shall keep a record of the purchases or advances, showing the names of the persons from whom received, their residence, the goods so taken and the amount of money paid or advanced, and this shall be at all times open for inspection to the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority. It shall also be unlawful for secondhand dealers to purchase these goods or to advance money thereon where their appearance indicates that they have been tampered with or there is an effort to conceal identity or if they are mutilated or otherwise show an effort to destroy evidence of the former location of the property. While the goods are being kept for thirty (30) days before being disposed of, they shall be so arranged that they can be inspected by the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority on demand. 
(Ord. No. 2016-7, § 1(Exh. A), 2-15-16) 
Sec. 21-35. - Dealers in secondhand automobiles. 
(a)  Daily report. Every dealer in secondhand automobiles shall furnish the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority each day a complete description in writing of all automobiles bought by the dealer during the preceding day or left or deposited with the dealer for the purpose of sale or exchange. The report shall state the make, year, model, type, motor and serial numbers of any secondhand automobile and also the date and hour of the sale to the dealer. 
(b)  Report by auctioneer. Any person acting as auctioneer of secondhand automobiles shall furnish a description with respect to any automobile offered by the auctioneer for sale at auction, whether the automobile is sold at auction or not. 
(Ord. No. 2016-7, § 1(Exh. A), 2-15-16) 
State Law reference- Records of purchasers of used motor vehicles O.C.G.A. §§ 40-4-5, 40-4-40. 
Sec. 21-36. - Dealers in secondhand watches. 
(a)  Definition. For the purpose of this section, a watch shall be deemed to be secondhand if: 
(1)  It, as a whole, or the case thereof or the movement thereof has been previously sold to or acquired by any person for such person's use or the use of another, but not for resale; provided, however, a watch that has been so sold or acquired and is thereafter returned either through exchange or for credit to the original vendor who sold or passed title to the watch shall not be deemed to be a secondhand watch for the purpose of this section, if the vendor shall keep a written or printed record setting forth the name of the purchaser thereof, the date of the sale or transfer thereof and the serial number, if any, on the case and movement and any other distinguishing number or identification mark, which record shall be kept five (5) years from the date of the sale or transfer and shall be open for inspection during all business hours by the law enforcement or regulatory inspectors; 
(2)  Its case or movement of serial numbers or other distinguishing numbers or identification marks shall be erased, defaced, removed, altered or covered; or 
(3)  Its movement is more than five (5) years old and has been repaired by any person, including the vendor, notwithstanding that it may have been returned either through exchange or for credit to the original vendor. Cleaning and oiling a watch movement or recasing the movement in a new case shall not be deemed a watch repair for the purpose of this subsection. 
(b)  Tagging. Any person engaged in the business of buying or selling watches, who may sell or exchange or offer for sale or exchange, expose for sale or exchange, possess with the intent to sell or exchange or display with the intent to sell or exchange any secondhand watch shall affix and keep affixed thereto a tag with the term "secondhand" clearly and legibly written or printed thereon, which shall be affixed or placed so that the term "secondhand" shall be plainly visible at all times. 
(c)  Contents of invoice; records. Any person who may sell a secondhand watch or in any other way pass title thereto shall deliver to the vendee a written invoice bearing the term "secondhand" in bold letters larger than any other written matter upon the invoice. The invoice shall further set forth the name and address of the vendor, the name and address of the vendee, the date of the sale, the name of the watch or its maker and the serial number, if any, and any other distinguishing numbers or identification marks upon its case and movement. If the serial number or other distinguishing numbers or identification marks shall have been erased, defaced, removed, altered or covered, the invoice shall so state. The vendor shall keep on file a duplicate of the invoice five (5) years from the sale thereof, which shall be open to inspection during all business hours by the law enforcement or regulatory inspectors. 
(d)  Advertising. Any person who may advertise or display in any manner a secondhand watch for sale or exchange shall state clearly in the advertisement or display that the watch is secondhand. 
(Ord. No. 2016-7, § 1(Exh. A), 2-15-16) 
State Law reference- Secondhand watches, O.C.G.A. § 43-49-1 et seq. 
Sec. 21-37. - Claiming interest in property. 
(a)  Property which is in the possession of secondhand dealers and which has all of the characteristics set forth in section 21-38, below, shall be disposed of pursuant to section 21-39. 
(b)  Any person claiming an interest in the property shall be known as a respondent. 
(c)  A respondent or any other person claiming any ownership interest of any kind, or possessory right to the property shall have the right to appear at a hearing as set forth in section 21-39(b) and to present any and all evidence in support of such person's claim to the property. 
(d)  Except as provided in section 21-39(b)(2)(B) of this article, the failure of any person to appear at such hearing shall constitute a waiver of any claim to the property by such person as against the city and shall authorize the hearing officer to enter a ruling consistent therewith. 
(Ord. No. 2016-7, § 1(Exh. A), 2-15-16) 
Sec. 21-38. - Property included. 
(a)  The city has reason to believe that the property was stolen. 
(b)  Law enforcement has possession of the property or has placed a hold on the property as set forth in this section below: 
(1)  Every secondhand dealer within the city shall keep a permanent record at their place of business, in which a complete record of all transactions required to be reported under this article shall be entered in the English language in a clear and legible manner and at the time when the transaction takes place. Such record shall contain all the information required to be reported to the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority under the provisions of sections 21-28 and 21-30 and shall be retained for no less than four (4) years from the date of the last entry. 
(2)  The record of transactions required by subsection (b)(1) and the secondhand dealer inventory shall be available for inspection by the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority or his or her designated representative during normal business hours. 
(3)  Whenever there exists probable cause to believe that property in the possession of a secondhand dealer is stolen, a police officer or person so designated by the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority may place a hold on the property for a period up to ninety (90) days. When a police officer or representative of the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority (hereinafter referred to as "representative") places a hold on the property, the police officer or representative shall initiate such hold by contacting the secondhand dealer in person or by telephone and informing the secondhand dealer of the hold and describing the item or items to be held. Within three (3) days of the initial contact, the police officer or representative shall deliver or mail to the secondhand dealer a written notice of the hold. The written notice shall include a description of the item or items to be held. 
(4)  Whenever property that is in the possession of a secondhand dealer is subject to a hold and the property is required by a police officer in a criminal investigation or for use as evidence in a criminal proceeding, the secondhand dealer, upon reasonable notice, shall deliver the property to any police officer. 
(5)  The secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority may extend a hold placed pursuant to this section for the purpose of criminal investigation or for use in any judicial proceeding, including that set forth in this article. Any extended hold shall be no longer than is reasonably necessary. 
(6)  Whenever property that is in the possession of a secondhand dealer person is subject to a hold and the property is no longer required for the purpose of criminal investigation or any criminal proceeding, and more than one person can reasonably be anticipated to make a claim for possession of the property, the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority may follow the procedures set forth in this article for disposition of the property within forty-five (45) days of the conclusion of the criminal investigation or criminal proceeding. 
(7)  Whenever property that is in the possession of the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority pursuant to the procedures set forth in this section is no longer required for the purpose of criminal investigation or for use as evidence in any criminal proceeding, the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority may follow the procedures set forth in this article for disposition of the property within forty-five (45) days of the conclusion of the criminal investigation or proceeding. 
(8)  If a dealer has good cause to believe that any property in his or her possession has been previously lost or stolen, the dealer shall promptly report his or her belief to the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority, together with the name of the owner, if known, and the transaction record associated with the dealer's receipt of the suspected lost or stolen item. 
(c)  There are no pending charges in State or Superior Court against a suspect alleged to have stolen the property at issue. 
(d)  Two (2) or more persons are known or believed to have made or can reasonably be anticipated to make a claim for possession of the property. 
(e)  The city makes no claim to possession of the property. 
(f)  The property will not be required to be retained for use as evidence in any legal proceeding other than the hearing under this article and law enforcement has no other lawful reason for holding the property. 
(Ord. No. 2016-7, § 1(Exh. A), 2-15-16) 
Sec. 21-39. - Determination of property rights. 
(a)  Initiation and service of the petition. 
(1)  The petitioner shall file a petition with the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority which shall appoint a hearing officer that shall determine ownership of the property within forty-five (45) days of the conclusion of the criminal investigation or criminal proceedings involving the property. Such petition shall set forth the following: 
a.  The facts establishing compliance with section 21-38; 
b.  The name and address of each person described in section 21-38(d); and 
c.  An accurate description of the property, any identifying marks or serial numbers, the police identification number(s), the location where the property is currently being held, and the person from whom seized, if the property was in fact seized. 
(2)  The petition shall be served by personal service or by first class mail, postage prepaid, return receipt requested, upon all persons known to have an interest in the property, each person described and named in section 21-38(d), in all cases, the person from whom the property was obtained or who currently possesses the property subject to the secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority hold. 
(3)  A copy of sections 21-37 through 21-40 of this article shall be served with each petition. 
(b)  Hearing. 
(1)  Notice. 
a.  There shall be served with the petition a notice of hearing setting forth the date, time and place for the conduct of the hearing to determine the right of possession to the property. The hearing date shall not be sooner than twenty-five (25), nor more than forty-five (45), calendar days after the date of service of the petition and notice. 
b.  Service shall be made to the last known address of all persons included in subsection (b) of this section. 
c.  Service shall be complete upon receipt. If service is made by certified mail, the return receipt shall be prima facie evidence of service. 
d.  Proof of service upon each potential claimant shall be delivered to the hearing officer. 
(2)  Hearing officers. 
a.  The secondhand goods regulatory and monitoring authority shall have the authority to appoint a hearing officer for the purpose of acting as a fact finder regarding disputes of ownership of property brought by a petitioner. The hearing officer shall be appointed for a two (2) year term and shall receive seventy-five dollars ($75.00) for each day or part thereof the hearing officer appears for such hearings. The hearing officer shall be a licensed attorney at law with at least three (3) years' experience in the practice of law. No person shall be appointed as a hearing officer who holds any interest in any licenses issued under the police powers of the city or who represents any interest which may be adverse to that of the city. 
(3)  Conduct. 
a.  The hearing shall be conducted informally by a hearing officer and the technical rules of evidence shall not apply, provided that the decision of the hearing officer shall in all cases be based upon substantial and reliable evidence. All parties shall have the right to be represented by counsel, to present evidence and testimony in support of their position, and to cross-examine adverse witnesses. All witnesses shall be placed under oath before testifying. 
b.  The burden of proof in determining property ownership shall be by a preponderance of the evidence, and shall at all times be upon the person or persons challenging the possession of the party from whom the property was taken by law enforcement, even if the party from whom the property was taken does not appear at the hearing. If the property was not seized by law enforcement, the burden of proof shall at all times be upon the person or persons challenging the party who currently possesses the property subject to the hold. 
c.  The hearing shall be recorded electronically or by other means. 
d.  The decision of the hearing officer shall be issued within ten (10) calendar days of the close of the record. The decision shall be in writing, and shall be mailed postage prepaid to each respondent or claimant appearing. A copy of the decision shall also be sent to the respective law enforcement agencies. 
e.  The decision of the hearing officer shall be final upon issuance. 
(Ord. No. 2016-7, § 1(Exh. A), 2-15-16) 
Sec. 21-40. - Post-hearing. 
(a)  Judicial review. 
(1)  Any respondent or other party participating in the hearing who is aggrieved by the decision of the hearing officer may seek judicial review by way of special action to the Superior Court. 
(2)  A complaint seeking special action review shall be filed within thirty (30) days of a final decision by the hearing officer. 
(b)  Release of property. 
(1)  Any person prevailing in a hearing or uncontested proceeding administered pursuant to this article shall be entitled to receive the property described in the petition after producing a copy of the decision in their favor and appropriate identification to the property's custodian. 
(2)  A receipt shall be signed evidencing delivery of the property to the person identified in subsection (b)(1) of the section. 
(3)  Any person with custody of the property described who is presented with a copy of the hearing officer's decision and appropriate identification shall release the property to the prevailing party. 
(c)  Nothing in this article shall prevent any person from filing an action in a court of appropriate jurisdiction to establish ownership to the property. 
(Ord. No. 2016-7, § 1(Exh. A), 2-15-16) 
Secs. 21-41-21-44. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSING 

Sec. 21-45. - Annual license. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to operate as a secondhand dealer, as defined in this article, in the city without a secondhand dealer license. A proper application for renewal with the time required must be submitted and such license shall not be under suspension or permanently or conditionally revoked. 
(b)  Every person, before operating as a secondhand dealer within the city, shall first file an application with the police department for a license to operate such a business. The application shall be made on an annual basis.
